webTitle: Corruption scandal forces Japan's top regulator to step down

fields.headline: Corruption scandal forces Japan's top regulator to step down
fields.trailText: Japan's jittery financial authorities were shaken yesterday by the resignation of the country's top regulator amid allegations that he accepted hundreds of millions of yen from a leading bank and construction company.
fields.body:
Japan's jittery financial authorities were shaken yesterday by the resignation of the country's top regulator amid allegations that he accepted hundreds of millions of yen from a leading bank and construction company.

Kimitaka Kuze is the second head of the financial reconstruction commission - which is supposed to promote a more modern and transparent banking system - to stand down this year.

His decision to quit less than a month after his appointment puts pressure on unpopular prime minister Yoshiro Mori. It casts fresh doubt on the government's ability to modernise a banking sector that remains mired in bad loans dating from the bubble era of the late 1980s.

Mr Kazu was left with little choice after revelations that he had accepted 230m yen (£1.4m) in consultant's fees and office rent from Mitsubishi Trust and Banking over a 13 year period to 1996.

On Saturday, it also emerged that Daikyo, a residential building company had given him 100m yen (£620,000) in 1991 to attract new members into the ruling Liberal Democratic Party.

Neither of these donations was made public. Although they were not illegal at the time, they run contrary to the spirit of openness and fairness that the FRC was created to promote. With a new session of parliament beginning today, Kuze said he stood down to minimise the political fallout from the scandal.

"I apologise for disturbing the public," Kuze said. "I decided to quit this job, although it reflects badly on my honour. I didn't do anything illegal, but I decided to withdraw to prevent political disruption."

The resignation is likely to raise fresh questions about the competence of prime minister Mori, who selected the FRC chairman while aware of the gifts from Mitsubishi.

Mr Kuze had also expressed his reluctance to take up the sensitive and difficult post, which he was poorly qualified to hold.

Hiromu Nonaka, secretary-general of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party, said Mr Mori - whose poll ratings are hovering around 20% - should not be considered responsible.

"We appointed Kuze after confirming that he hadn't done anything unlawful under the rules at that time," Nonaka said. "The appointment has led to grief, but I don't think the prime minister should be blamed for what happened."

The leader of the main opposition party, Yukio Hatoyama, rejected this view. "Of course Kuze should be fired, but that is not the end of the matter," he said. "The prime minister knew the situation when he made the apppointment and thought it was OK. Naturally, he has responsibility for the appointment and the responsibility to explain it."

Under Mr Kuze, the FRC had to abandon plans to rescue the Sogo department store, which collapsed earlier this month in the second biggest bankruptcy in Japanese corporate history.

Amid growing uncertainty about the government's ability to handle similar crises in the future, the Nikkei index of the Tokyo Stock Exchange hit an 18 month low on Friday.

The new head of the FRC, Hideyaki Aizawa has the background to restore confidence: he is a former finance ministry bureaucrat who has served as head of the economic planning agency. But at 81 years old, he can hardly claim to be the new broom that the FRC so desperately needs.

fields.headline: Dazzling puzzle
fields.standfirst:
Holloway's Symphony
Royal Albert Hall/Radio 3
***
fields.trailText:
Holloway's Symphony
Royal Albert Hall/Radio 3
***
fields.body:
Commissioned to write an orchestral work for the Proms that responded in some way to the 20th century, Robin Holloway produced a symphony. A big-boned work scored for a huge orchestra and playing for nearly an hour, its premiere, conducted by Donald Runnicles with the BBC Symphony Orchestra, took up the first half of Saturday's prom.

Holloway's perspective proves to be a musical time line carved into three movements - the breaks between, "black holes" he calls them, represent the two world wars, to which he felt no musical response was adequate.

So the first movement portrays life before 1914, elegant and relaxed to begin, but increasingly frenetic and unstable as it develops; the elaborate scherzo that follows is a depiction of the jazz age, ending, again, in manic disorder, while in the glacial third the nuclear stalemate of the cold war gives way to worries about ecological disasters.

But for all that detail, the course of the symphony is elaborately allusive. In the opening section, the composers who defined the course of 20th-century music are extensively quoted - tags from Mahler, Stravinsky and Strauss jostle with Skryabin, Holst and Ravel.

A symphony should be a composer's most personal statement in orchestral terms, but sometimes it seems as if Holloway is observing the course of the century through the eyes of others - for the opening of the "cold war" movement, for instance, he resorts to a theme from the end of Schubert's Die Winterreise - and what the welter of notes in this intricately constructed, and often dazzlingly scored, piece really adds up to is hard to pin down.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable
** Mediocre * Terrible

webTitle: QCs earn four times more than heads

fields.headline: QCs earn four times more than heads
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: QCs paid mainly from public funds earn twice as much as hospital consultants and four to five times as much as headteachers and university professors, according to a study carried out for the Lord Chancellor's Department.
fields.body:
QCs paid mainly from public funds earn twice as much as hospital consultants and four to five times as much as headteachers and university professors, according to a study carried out for the Lord Chancellor's Department.

The study, which has not been made public, is the first comprehensive comparison between the bar and other public sector professions requiring similar levels of training. The government has used it to support Lord Irvine's decision this month to cut rates of pay for criminal defence barristers by 10%.

Those doing divorce and family law work on legal aid face similar pay cuts, and the government is introducing restrictions on the use of QCs in cases funded by the taxpayer.

The bar has argued that comparisons are invalid because barristers, who are self-employed, have to fund their own pensions out of their earnings. But the study adjusts for employees' pension contributions and sick leave entitlement in working out the sums.

A typical QC from criminal chambers, paid largely from public funds, earns £191,323 after overheads and expenses, according to figures from a bar survey by management consultants BDO Stoy Hayward. Those in family chambers typically earn £134,085, and those in mixed crime and family chambers £160,518, averaging out at £180,412 for all.

QCs are the top 10% of barristers, commanding premium rates. The top 10% of hospital doctors - the most highly paid consultants - typically earn £81,700.

Only the most junior barristers earn less than hospital doctors at similar levels. Those with under five years' experience earn 26% less than junior doctors, but after five years barristers earn 18% more, and after 10 years 22% more.

The gap between QCs' earnings and those of headteachers is much bigger. Heads and deputy heads typically earn £38,553 after an adjustment for employers' pension contributions and sick pay. The mid-point for professors, who make up 15% of university lecturers, is £48,864. QCs earn more than even the judges they appear before. Of all the public sector professionals, only judges come anywhere near their earning power. After adjustments, high court judges earn £150,723 and law lords £171,411.

fields.headline: Action on bank review
fields.trailText: The Treasury is likely to announce this week that it is to act on some of the main recommendations of the Don Cruickshank review of the banking industry, including his suggestion for a new regulatory body, dubbed paycom, for the payments part of the system.
fields.body:
The Treasury is likely to announce this week that it is to act on some of the main recommendations of the Don Cruickshank review of the banking industry, including his suggestion for a new regulatory body, dubbed paycom, for the payments part of the system.

However, it is not clear whether the paycom that the Treasury will sanction will have the scope envisaged by Mr Cruickshank, who called for a regulator to cover every aspect of the payment system from cash machine networks to cheque clearing and small business banking.

The publication of the Treasury report comes at a crucial period for leading banks, which are in the midst of telling the City and investors about the level of profits. HSBC, Barclays and NatWest, now part of Royal Bank of Scotland, are all scheduled to publish their profits in the coming days while Lloyds TSB reported its results last week.

The banks are at loggerheads with the government over its plan to set up a universal bank in post offices.

It is the four clearing banks which the Cruickshank report focused on. They hold almost 70% of current accounts and most of the banking services provided to small businesses, making it difficult for new competitors to take any meaningful market share.

Part of paycom's potential scope is already being scrutinised by the competition commission which is investigating small business banking, another recommendation made by Cruickshank, who also highlighted excessive charging for cash machine withdrawals.

fields.headline: Movietone
fields.standfirst:
Brudenell Social Club, Leeds
**
fields.trailText:
Brudenell Social Club, Leeds
**
fields.body:
How do you know when a "pop" band is part of the underground? There are probably several definitions, but one of them must surely be whether the band eschew the stage completely (it remains covered by curtains) and set up their gear in the middle of the audience. This is the sort of gesture with which Movietone are familiar.

Part of the other Bristol scene that doesn't include Massive Attack or Tricky, they have been pursuing a determinedly low-key approach that has so far spawned three albums and a cult following, and show no signs yet of turning into U2. What their underground status also means is that they almost appear as their own support band - opening act Crescent boast a curiously similar line-up.

With a mixture of shouted vocals, plundered drums, sharp guitar lines, dub bass and eerie keyboards, Crescent are one of the oddest bands in the UK. Not only are they refreshingly taking on the undermined PiL/Can legacy, but they are possibly the only group in rock history influenced by the second album from obscure early-80s Blackpool experimentalists, Section 25. You want to applaud such crazy idiosyncrasy, but as their hypnotic, violent trance-scapes reach a stunning climax, there is plenty else to cheer.

It's a surprise, then, that when Crescent's female bass player becomes Movietone's lead singer, she sheds the turbulent spirit of her alter ego. Rooted - like the excellent Broadcast - in the hallucinatory 60s sound of Nico and the Doors, Movietone appear to be doing their utmost to make challenging music sound as mundane as possible. Singer Kate is more atonal than Nico ever was (a feat previously thought impossible) but Teutonic menace is replaced by what sounds like trouble with a cold. The introduction of a clarinet makes matters even less tuneful, and the whole performance has the air of a sixth-form school band playing at being psychedelic. Once or twice, they rise above the shambles and the crowd's murmuring to produce something that borders on the dreamlike, but a grim nadir is reached with their descent into Soft Machine jazz noodling. One song shrinks to near silence, with Kate intoning: "Sleep well." Far be it from me to turn down such excellent advice.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable
** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: Touching memorial
fields.standfirst:
Bach's B Minor Mass
Royal Albert Hall, London
***
fields.trailText:
Bach's B Minor Mass
Royal Albert Hall, London
***
fields.body:
"An amalgam of prayer and dance that creeps into your soul and just won't let you go," was how Roger Norrington described the B Minor Mass, the work chosen to commemorate the 250th anniversary of Bach's death on July 28 1750. The performance began at the actual hour of his passing, and was touchingly preceded by the Motet Lieber Herr Gott, Wecke Uns Auf, written by his second cousin Johann Christoph, and believed to have been sung at Bach's funeral.

A sense of deep devotional and memorial weight hung over the evening - but did Norrington, conducting the Choir and Orchestra of the Age of Enlightenment, do the B Minor justice? Sadly, not quite, in my opinion, though it should be added that no single interpretation can capture every facet of what many consider to be the greatest score by the greatest of all composers.

Norrington's approach is reverential. "Prayer" was much in evidence "Dance" less so, though there was a translucent buoyancy and the instrumental obbligati that seem to twine round the solo singers. What one missed was the majesty, the exultation.

The soloists were at times less than ideally matched. Dominique Labelle's flawless crystalline soprano didn't quite blend with the earthier mezzo of Annette Markert, though both voices are fabulous. The base line lies a fraction low for the usually excellent Alastair Miles. Mark Padmore, beautiful in Bach, phrased the tenor solos with exquisite finesse, while the starry, cult counter-tenor, David Daniels brought a whiff of unearthly, pagan sweetness to proceedings.

webTitle: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

fields.headline: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
fields.standfirst:
Barbican, London
***
fields.trailText:
Barbican, London
***
fields.body:
It's great to have Chicago's Steppenwolf Theatre, headed by Gary Sinise, back in town. I just wish the chosen vehicle were something more challenging than Dale Wasserman's version of Ken Kesey's hippy, trippy 60s novel. I applaud its anti-authoritarian stance but by demonising the opposition it scores too many easy victories.

Everyone by now knows the story: the way rebel-outcast Randle P McMurphy, who is locked up in a state mental hospital, takes on the ward tyrant, Nurse Ratched, in an attempt to liberate the browbeaten patients. As a metaphor for the individual defying the system that's fine; but the play, like the book and the film, is every bit as manipulative as Nurse Ratched. McMurphy is, in Pauline Kael's unbeatable phrase, a "jock Christ"; the Nurse, in contrast, is a starched sadist and punishment freak. We cheer the hero on at every turn; but real drama, as Shaw taught us, only occurs when you give weight to the party you like least.

I was also surprised at how sentimental the story now seems. In the 60s lines like "We're doomed to the terrible burden of sanity" may have had a fuzzy Laing-ian charm; now we know too much about the problems of care in the community to endorse the idea of privileged insanity. Wasserman's play, like Kesey's novel, is also stuffed with adolescent sexism: the women are either whores or bullies while the men are laddish gamblers and sports nuts. Even McMurphy's arrest for statutory rape is viewed as a harmless prank. If you want to see how much the play softens the issue of state intimidation, compare it with Pinter's The Hothouse, written in 1958: Pinter's point is not just that we classify nonconformity as madness but that the staff are as much victims as the patients.

Even if the work itself is jokey melodrama, it is ebulliently staged by Terry Kinney and beautifully acted by the Steppenwolf ensemble. Sinise's McMurphy is vastly superior to Jack Nicholson's self-regarding performance in the movie. What Sinise brings to the party is effortless charisma and infernal cheek: when he twits pedantic Nurse Ratched - who in a therapy session claims: "I know you but I don't recognise you" - he becomes the eternal piss-taker whose chosen mission in life is to expose the absurdity of authority.

Amy Morton gets round the hellish problem of playing Nurse Ratched by suggesting she is less a medical Mephistopheles than an inflexible rule-follower cursed by a lack of imagination. Tim Sampson endows Chief Bromden, whose native Indian father was naturally emasculated by his white bride, with massive dignity, while Eric Johner lends the stammering Billy Bibbit, whose mental problems are solved by a quick lay, a touching vulnerability. They show that Steppenwolf remains one of the world's top ensembles even when working on a soft-brained play.

 Till August 5. Box office: 020-7638 8891.

fields.headline: Rangers find relief
fields.trailText: St Johnstone may have left Ibrox dispirited by defeat, but they produced enough of a scare on day one of the Scottish Premier League to remind Rangers of the need to be alert to the dangers of sabotage from the unlikeliest of quarters.
fields.body:
St Johnstone may have left Ibrox dispirited by defeat, but they produced enough of a scare on day one of the Scottish Premier League to remind Rangers of the need to be alert to the dangers of sabotage from the unlikeliest of quarters.

Having played with sufficient style and guile during the first half to lead, the Perth side were ultimately undone by a performance from the home side which owed more to their crush-proof spirit than to an exhilarating parade of skills.

Billy Dodds was once again the retriever, scoring the two goals in a quick burst of second half deadliness which ensured that the Ibrox side would begin the defence of their title with victory.

On days like these, when high expectations are not immediately fulfilled, booing is the commonest and most sustained sound to be heard at Ibrox. It is, of course, a kind of inverted compliment to the team causing the distress.

As St Johnstone left the field at the interval, they merited all the derisive noise directed at Rangers, their compactness, commitment and conviction having made things extremely difficult for the champions, while allowing themselves opportunities to bother Stefan Klos.

They did this to greatest effect when they took the lead, an incident which demonstrated that even the most formidable side in the country are not exempt from the sluggishness which often settles on players in these opening stages of a new season.

Rangers' nonchalance on this occasion was, however, cerebral rather than physical, as their defenders appeared to miscalculate the flight and arrival point of a free kick from Paul Kane on the left side of midfield.

The Ibrox players clearly assumed that the ball would drop over the line for a goal kick, while Nick Dasovic had correctly reckoned that he could get a toe to it while it remained in play. This he did with some adroitness, hooking the ball back to Graeme Jones.

The striker, unmarked some 12 yards from goal, knocked it forward to the central defender, Alan Kernaghan, who had ventured into the forward area in anticipation of a header from the original free kick. Instead, he was able to send a volley from six yards shoulder-high past the astounded Klos.

There was a rehearsed look about St Johnstone during that first half which Rangers mostly did not match, their reliance on the individual skills of players such as Jorg Albertz, Giovanni van Bronckhorst and Andrei Kanchelskis giving them the look of a team still trying to attain coherence.

It was, for example, only a mistake by Gary Bollan which allowed the champions their first scoring effort after 20 minutes, Kanchelskis taking possession on the right, driving inside and sending a low shot off the legs of Alan Main. The goalkeeper showed his appreciation of the angles later when he made it impossible for Wallace - released on a van Bronckhorst pass - to do anything other than slide the ball wide.

More than anything, there was a composure about the visitors - personified by the Ivorean defender, Mohammed Sylla - that was unusual in those who arrive at what is perennially regarded as the most difficult venue in the country.

That was dispelled by Dodds who, curiously, had retreated into a deeper role to allow Neil McCann, replacing defender Tony Vidmar, to play in a three-man attack with Rod Wallace and Kanchelskis. The little striker took his first beautifully, controlling Ferguson's wonderful through pass before flicking the ball with the outside of his right foot past the advancing Main.

Rangers enjoyed a little break with their second, as Wallace was clearly offside when a chip from Albertz was played towards his vicinity. As Wallace moved out and Dodds moved in, the linesman kept his flag by his side, allowing Dodds to slip the ball wide of Main from eight yards.

Dodds, with a double in stoppage time, pulled Rangers out of an unacceptable result against Zalgiris Kaunas just three days earlier, underlining the notion that, when Dick Advocaat paid Dundee United £1.3m for him last year, he concluded what would prove to be the kind of bargain which presents itself perhaps once in a decade.

Rangers: Klos; Ricksen, Amoruso, Konterman, Vidmar (McCann 46); Kanchelskis (Reyna 63), Ferguson, van Bronckhorst, Albertz; Wallace (Miller 74), Dodds.

St Johnstone: Main; Sylla, Weir, Kernaghan, Bollan; Kane, Dasovic, McBride, Lovenkrands (Connolly 81); Jones, Parker (Russell 70).

Referee: D. McDonald.

fields.headline: Summer Tales from the Tabs
fields.trailText: GUNNERS GO COCU
fields.body:
GUNNERS GO COCU

Arsenal have lined-up a massive £30m spending spree in a bid to silence fans angry at the sale of Marc Overmars and Emmanuel Petit. Arsène Wenger has already inquired about £15m-rated Dutch star Philip Cocu and will go back for Bordeaux striker Sylvain Wiltord.

BECKS CAN GO

Barcelona have revealed that Alex Ferguson is ready to sell David Beckham after being quoted a £46m asking price. Ferguson rejected, though, a similar approach for Ryan Giggs: 'When I asked about Giggs,' says an official, 'I was told he was priceless.'

KOP'S £17M ZIEGE

Liverpool are ready to make Middlesbrough's Christian Ziege the highest paid player in their history with a £45,000-a-week contract - £9m over four years. The package will come on top of an £8m transfer fee. Bryan Robson wants Didier Domi to replace him.

Arsenal

Bordeaux star Sylvain Wiltord has issued the first 'Come and get me' plea of the new season - he's chasing a £15m move to Highbury: 'Sylvain has never hidden his desire to join Arsenal,' said agent Ghislaine Duguperoux last night. A deal for Brazilian midfielder Edu has also been revived, and Brian McGovern is off to Norwich.

Aston Villa

John Gregory has set David Ginola a seventh deadline to make a decision on a move to Villa Park. The latest cut-off point is today. 'We have to say enough is enough,' says Gregory. 'Either you want to come and play for us or you want to stay where you are.' Man City , meanwhile, are back in for Ugo Ehiogu.

Bradford

Chris Hutchings has drawn up a list of possible new wingers after a deal for Nicky Summerbee collapsed and Jamie Lawrence demanded a transfer. Liverpool's David Thompson and Tottenham's Ruel Fox are top targets.

Charlton

Alan Curbishley has dropped a deal for Bulgarian Radostin Kischischevis - offers for Bolton's Mark Fish and Leeds' Michael Duberry also fell through. 'We are trying to buy players but it's increasingly difficult,' says Curbishley. 'Basically there is a huge gap between what we can spend and what players demand.'

Chelsea

Deportivo La Coruna have made a massive £9m approach for Tore Andre Flo, with Brazilian midfielder star Djalminha offered in part exchange - Coventry though are lining up a rival bid.

Coventry

Bryan Richardson will hand Gordon Strachan a large chunk of the £13m received from Inter Milan for Robbie Keane. And Strachan's transfer fund could grow further after Middlesbrough bid £2m for Noel Whelan.

Derby

Jim Smith has taken Australian Con Blatis and Frenchman Youl Mawene on trial - while new signing Bjorn Otto Bragstad links up with the squad this week. 'It has always been my dream to play in the Premiership,' says Bragstad. 'I have thought about it for a long time and am still very happy to be here.'

Everton

Walter Smith has begun talks with Blackburn for reserve striker Nathan Blake. Smith wants cover for the injured Kevin Campbell, and lined up Blake after a deal for old-boy Duncan Ferguson was blocked.

Ipswich

Celtic have become the first club to make an official approach for Richard Wright. 'Martin O'Neill has been on about Richard,' says George Burley. 'As yet, they haven't made a bid. That may or may not come - I don't know.' Ipswich want £5m.

Leeds

David O'Leary says he isn't worried by the big signings made by Premiership rivals. ' Chelsea and Liverpool have spent serious money and they will be making a really strong challenge. But it doesn't mean they will be better than us. Of all the top sides, we have spent the least, but when the season starts I will be happy with my squad. You certainly can't buy the title.'

Leicester

Chairman John Elsom has promised to continue backing Peter Taylor's transfer spending. Neil Lennon, meanwhile, will decide on a move to Celtic this week: 'Leicester have made me a fantastic offer but I need to think things through. I would love to join Celtic and even if their offer was a little less, it's no longer about money.'

Liverpool

Gerard Houllier has told Blackburn and Fulham to forget about young French defender Djimi Traore. 'There is no way Djimi is for sale,' says Houllier. 'He would cost millions. He's improving all the time and will be even more involved in the first team this season.'

Man City

Joe Royle - having made a massive new offer for Ugo Ehiogu - now wants to land a striker. 'If the right one becomes available I will sign him,' says Royle. 'There are no loan deals allowed between clubs at this level. So we could be talking money - big money.'

Man Utd

Mark Bosnich is ready to sit out his lucrative contract at Old Trafford in the reserves. 'Throughout my career I have honoured my contracts and I am in no hurry to break this one.' Alex Ferguson, meanwhile, is still watching Inter's Laurent Blanc. 'We have made three bids for Laurent but he has turned them all down. Other than that, we have not bid for any other player.'

Middlesbrough

Bryan Robson could make a late bid to scupper Christian Ziege's move to Liverpool by using him in part-exchange for Barcelona's £12m-rated Dani. Robson is also still chasing Real Mallorca's £8m hit-man Diego Tristan, Lazio star Alen Boksic and Real Madrid's unsettled Steve McManaman.

Newcastle

Manchester City's chief operating officer Chris Bird has denied sanctioning a move for Duncan Ferguson. 'There's no truth in it whatsoever, it's pure speculation. Joe is just monitoring the situation.'

Southampton

Glenn Hoddle has reversed a decision to sell striker James Beattie after the youngster turned on the style in pre-season with three goals in three matches.

Sunderland

Peter Reid has sealed a cut-price £875,000 deal for Slovan Bratislava defender Stanislav Varga. 'I've had my eye on him for a while and I'm delighted that we've signed him,' says Reid. 'He's tall, strong and has a great football brain. He speaks broken English but we'll work on that.' 'I am happy and excited,' says Varga.

Tottenham

Espen Baardsen and Allan Nielsen are continuing talks with Watford after Graham Taylor agreed deals with George Graham - the moves should be confirmed in the next two days. Iranian midfielder Karim Bagheri, meanwhile, is set to join Spurs tomorrow.

West Ham

Harry Redknapp will complete the signing of Australian Hayden Foxe today after selling Neil Ruddock to Palace . 'He's been on trial with us and he's done well,' says Harry. 'We are looking to do something with the lad.'

webTitle: So, what is Mark Hateley doing these days?

fields.headline: So, what is Mark Hateley doing these days?
fields.trailText: Our headline is borrowed from our sister OSM magazine... Diego Maradona casually enquiring what had happened to big Mark. Many others wondered the same thing when he returned from Monaco a few years back to star for Rangers in the Scottish Premier League.
fields.body:
Our headline is borrowed from our sister OSM magazine... Diego Maradona casually enquiring what had happened to big Mark. Many others wondered the same thing when he returned from Monaco a few years back to star for Rangers in the Scottish Premier League.

Now it's a well-trodden path for English players to ply their trade in Scotland. It reversed the old trend when Scotland's best players were enticed to ply their skills in England, where wage packets were fatter and career opportunities were more appealing.

Even though Gazza may be long gone from Rangers, the flow of English players heading for the border and a fresh start continues. Rod Wallace can lay claim to have been the most successful of the more recent English imports into the Scottish game.

Since signing from Leeds two years ago, Wallace, aged 30, has collected League Championship, Scottish Cup and League Cup honours at the same time collecting an annual salary estimated to be in the region of £1 million once bonus payments are taken into account.

As he was signed under the Bosman ruling his skills have been bought relatively cheaply by present standards. Celtic lead the way in the Anglo stakes in both quantity and quality, boasting a quartet of Englishmen with a combined market value of at least £15m.

Chris Sutton, formerly of Norwich City, Blackburn and Chelsea, became the first of Martin O'Neill's major signings when he was bought for £6m last month. Sutton, impressed by the splendour of the new-look 61,000 capacity Parkhead, now shoulders a heavy responsibility given the weight of expectation of the Celtic fans who will demand an instant return.

England B international central defender Alan Stubbs has been a Celtic player since July 1996 when he was signed from Bolton in a deal estimated at £3.5m. Stubbs, now 28, has one more year of his contract to run and has indicated a desire to return south on several occasions in the past, due in the main to his wife, Mandy's, initial failure to settle in the west of Scotland.

Having now resolved these difficulties, Stubbs says: 'There are two very good reasons for wanting to play in Scotland - Old Firm games and the passion of the fans. There is intense rivalry between Old Firm fans, but when I had my cancer problem last year I was overwhelmed by the number of get-well cards and messages of good wishes I received from Rangers fans. I was so touched by their genuine concern that I presented one disabled Rangers fan with a bouquet of flowers before an Old Firm game to show my appreciation.'

Team-mate Jonathan Gould, son of the former Wales team manager Bobby, has kept goal for Scotland, but his accent is more Gloucester than Glasgow. Newcastle-born striker Tommy Johnson has not had his troubles to seek since his move from Aston Villa to Celtic in March 1997 shortly before Tommy Burns's departure as manager. Yet the signs are 29-year-old Johnson, who has had to his share of injuries, may yet figure in O'Neill's longer-term plans after being at the whim of no fewer than four managers in a little over three years.

Aberdeen's English contingent is down to one, goalkeeper David Preece, signed a year ago from Darlington, while Dundee have two - ex-Northampton defender Lee Maddison and striker Nicky Banger, sent off on his debut against Motherwell, who saw service with Southampton, Oldham and Oxford.

Talking of Motherwell, they employ the services of Merseysider Ged Brannan, once of Manchester City, and the far travelled Don Goodman who starred for Hiroshima before wending his way to Lanarkshire.

Another former City player strutting his stuff in Scotland is St Johnstone defender Alan Kernaghan, while Lee Makel, the ex-Huddersfield midfield player, is a member of the Hearts squad.

London-born Junior Albert Mendes, 23, once of Chelsea, controversially quit St Mirren after four years to sign for rivals Dunfermline. The striker was said by Hendrie to have pledged his future to St Mirren after the club won promotion to the Premier League in May.

There are, perhaps understandably, given the meagre attendances of most lower league clubs, few English-born players outside the top flight. But First Division Ayr United have a trio - Glynn Hurst and Mickey Reynolds, who came to prominence on the back of FA Cup giantkillers Emley's exploits a couple of years back, and Dave Rogers who joined Dundee from Southport three years ago.

And Mark Hateley? He played briefly for humble Ross County last year and is now, as they say, open to offers.

fields.headline: Quota u-turn stuns FA
fields.trailText: Football is on a collision course with the Government over Ministers' refusal to limit the number of overseas players coming into the British game. The football authorities claim the Government has backtracked on earlier pledges to consider restricting the number of players from outside Europe allowed to come here.
fields.body:
Football is on a collision course with the Government over Ministers' refusal to limit the number of overseas players coming into the British game. The football authorities claim the Government has backtracked on earlier pledges to consider restricting the number of players from outside Europe allowed to come here.

The FA is seeking an urgent meeting to press for strict quotas to be introduced governing non-European Union players wanting to join British clubs. The Premier League, Football League and Professional Footballers Association also agree that action is needed in order to stop homegrown youngsters being squeezed out.

The FA wants Premier League clubs to be allowed to sign a maximum of two non-EU players, with First Division outfits limited to one and Second and Third Division sides barred from hiring any non-Europeans at all in a concerted effort to safeguard British talent. FA top brass will urge the Government to legislate to cut the number of non-EU players clubs are allowed to have on their books from five to two. At the moment clubs can employ five of them but play only three in any match.

European law means tehe Government can do nothing to halt the influx of players from the European Economic Area... the 15 EU states plus Norway, Iceland and Lichtenstein - but they could limit those arriving from elsewhere in the world without falling foul of the EU.

However, football is facing a difficult task in persuading Ministers to act. The Government last week refused to countenance non-EU quotas, arguing that they would be 'extremely unpopular with fans and clubs', and instead suggested football agree voluntary quotas. One senior football source expressed dismay that the Government has 'inexplicably' reneged on earlier promises that it would consider placing restrictions on non-EU numbers.

Ministers will also come under pressure to tighten up the existing rules governing work permits for non-EU players. Critics believe the Government's insistence that only 'quality' players are admitted who will add to the British game is a nonsense.

Critics believe the Government's insistence that only 'quality' players are admitted who will add to the British game is a nonsense.

fields.headline: O'Neill poses question of desire
fields.trailText: Events of the past dozen years have led most observers of Scottish football to the belief that whoever enters Celtic Park as manager is walking through a door that opens on to a thousand-foot drop.
fields.body:
Events of the past dozen years have led most observers of Scottish football to the belief that whoever enters Celtic Park as manager is walking through a door that opens on to a thousand-foot drop.

Curiously, throughout these turbulent times, there has been no shortage of volunteers willing to confront what is arguably the most demanding and potentially the most career-threatening job in the British game. There is no great demand for failed messiahs.

Martin O'Neill, the eighth appointee since 1988, when the Parkhead club celebrated their centenary by landing the double of league championship and Scottish Cup, is much too astute to make extravagant claims about his own credentials as a redeemer, but he has already imparted the impression that he is properly equipped.

There is about the former Leicester City man a credibility and a persuasiveness that was rare among his predecessors (even if Wim Jansen did emerge as a hero with a league title and a League Cup triumph in the 97-98 season, his appointment and his inaugural address to the media were met with widespread scepticism).

Familiarity with O'Neill, through his exposure as an animated - and indisputably successful - manager at Filbert Street and as a garrulous commentator on television, will have heightened excitement and anticipation among Celtic supporters, who received news of his coming with virtually unanimous approval.

Even so, he has said and done enough since his arrival two months ago to confirm the view that he is likely to bring to the distressed club at least the one quality that has been most singularly lacking in the past two years.

Mental fortitude seems to be at the core of the ethos that governs O'Neill's work, an encouraging asset to bring to bear on a team whose endeavours since 1998 have been marked by an unmissable lack of character. Even Dick Advocaat, the Rangers manager, has said often enough - and meant it - that, in terms of individual natural talent, there is very little to choose between his team of multiple winners and the under-achievers at Celtic.

O'Neill betrayed his admiration for players with an immovable urge to succeed when he introduced his latest signing, the 24-year-old Belgium defender Joos Valgaeren from JC Roda in Holland on Friday.

'Wanting to win and having the deep desire to see that through are two different things,' he said. 'I've seen enough of Joos to know he has that deep desire. I think if you have a good, strong mentality, you're well on the way. I think it's in-bred in top-quality sportsmen and I think Valgaeren is one of them. I like the way he talks when he's asked about himself and his qualities.

'You heard him say frequently, "I'm a sportsman, I want to win", and that is how a top-quality player should talk. There are parallels to be drawn between him and Matty Elliott, who developed into a marvellous player in the Premiership with Leicester after being around smaller clubs for a few years.

'Matty has that same strength of spirit, the will to succeed and it has shown throughout his time with me. I know that last season was an exceptional one for Roy Keane at Manchester United, but I'm convinced that if Elliott had been at one of the top three clubs, giving the same performances he brought for Leicester, he would have been right in the running for player of the year.

'Now, the kind of attitude that Matty and Joos possess can be put into players and that's part of my job. And it's something I have to do here at Celtic. I'm trying to change the mentality of some of the players here, because they seem to have been affected by recent failures.

'I'm told by some who were here that games last season were lost that shouldn't have been, that it was only discouragement, that habit of losing, that caused it. Now, if you can change that... that's my job... you can make winning a habit.'

O'Neill's first competitive test arrives tonight, when Celtic open their campaign with a visit to Tannadice to face Dundee United, who have frequently been awkward opponents in recent times. With Valkgaeren and Chris Sutton his only two new recruits so far - and a decision will have to be made on whether the Belgian is ready for his debut, having arrived only on Thursday - there will be little change in the side that finished 21 points behind Rangers in the championship.

One in particular, however, could be of huge significance. It is the return of the Swede Henrik Larsson to attack, following a nine-month absence after breaking a leg last October. O'Neill could not disguise his excitement at the prospect of having him on his side.

'Henrik is simply top quality,' he said. 'A very clever player, very unselfish, who makes decisions based on what is most likely to help the team rather than himself. And I don't think anybody here should have any worries whatsoever about Chris Sutton. I certainly don't. If he remains free of injury, take my word for it, he'll do great here.

'What I don't want is Chris having the Chelsea experience again. I don't want him getting bogged down if he happens to make a sluggish start.

'At Chelsea, he missed some good chances early on and the expectations were so high, and he was involved in a rotation system of selection that didn't help him show his true form. We'll make sure that doesn't happen.'

No matter the changes in playing personnel that may be effected in the coming weeks or months, there seems little doubt that the most needed - and, therefore, the most beneficial - contribution is likely to come from Martin O'Neill himself.

webTitle: In a league of its own

fields.headline: In a league of its own
fields.standfirst: Mike Lee, departing Premiership spin guru, says England's top league does rank with the best
fields.trailText: Exclusive interview: Mike Lee, departing Premiership spin guru, tells Denis Campbell that England's top league does rank with the best
fields.body:
Despite exporting hooliganism, enduring years of increasing isolation and pursuing a disastrous 2006 World Cup bidding campaign, English football has a new man at the heart of the European game.

Uefa have recruited Mike Lee, the Premier League's spin doctor, to deploy his undoubted presentational talents in their own overdue and wide-ranging makeover. Football Association chairman Geoff Thompson has just been elected to Uefa's ruling executive committee, a welcome first step back into European football's corridors of power for the FA.

But it is Lee who will have direct influence in advising Uefa on their battles with the European Union, ongoing power struggle with Fifa and often fractious relations with the G14 group of leading European clubs who last year tried to set up their own breakaway pan-continental super league. Not bad going for a 42-year-old, Sunderland-supporting miner's son from a Wearside pit village.

Lee's six years as the Premier League's Svengali of spin has coincided with its transformation into a competition in which grounds are nearly always sold out, tickets cost a small fortune, strip changes arrive almost as quickly as foreign imports, players earn £500 million a year and one club is worth more than £1 billion.

In that time, too, English clubs have at last reasserted themselves in European competition, media companies have begun buying into Premiership clubs and, for good or ill, overseas players have - through their sheer numbers and obvious skills - come to dominate the domestic game. Football's growing wealth and unprecedented popularity has seen lawyers, competition authorities and politicians play increasingly important roles in football's present-day soap opera. It's been a hectic time for Lee, who starts his new job at Uefa's Swiss HQ next Monday. He is relishing the challenge, but has no doubts that the Premier League he leaves behind has been a good thing.

'It has delivered a healthy domestic league competition, successful clubs that are also doing well in Europe, that can compete financially with other global clubs, and stadia that are safe and where families can go,' he says. 'A lot of positive things have come out of the very dark days of the 1980s, and people often lose sight of that. They lose a bit of that historical context. People should take more pride in what English football has achieved.'

Famously plain-spoken, Lee dismisses 'unrepresentative so-called fans organisations who claim to represent millions and millions of fans' as professional malcontents, but acknowledges that the recurring complaint about high ticket prices - now the dearest in Europe - poses a real challenge for the Premier League's 20 clubs.

'Going to, say, the North Bank at Arsenal isn't cheap, but it does represent pretty good value. However, more needs to be done about explaining pricing policies and creating stretch pricing so you can have lower-priced tickets, albeit subsidised by [even] higher-priced tickets.'

He denies football today is becoming a rich man's sport. 'Ticket pricing has not disenfranchised huge numbers of fans. Football isn't just there for the corporate client, and I don't know one chairman who thinks it is.'

Clubs do genuinely recognise the wisdom of keeping live football accessible to people in every income bracket, he says, citing extra-cheap 'junior junior' tickets for under-10s.

I raise the case of a Chelsea fan who recently emailed me complaining that the club he has supported for 30 years has just pushed the price of the cheapest seat for category A games from £24 to £30. As a true Blue, boycotting Stamford Bridge in protest is not an option. So what can he do? Lee replies that the 'customer charters' that top-flight clubs are introducing this autumn will mean 'a lot more explanation and consultation, which will produce some pressures about how clubs go about their pricing policies. Maybe some clubs have got it more right than others.'

But these customer charters will not actually stop chairmen from introducing 25 per cent price rises if they wish. Irritation starting to show, Lee delivers the Premiership's bottom line on this sensitive issue: 'It's right that, as in any leisure marketplace, clubs have the freedom as individual businesses to make decisions based on their assessment of their needs as clubs. Most fans think the Premiership is good value for money. And football is a very, very expensive business these days.'

Which brings us to players' earnings - another 'challenge', as Lee puts it. 'The spiralling costs of football are mainly down to players' wages. There are pretty widespread concerns among Premier League chairmen about this. But finding a way of resolving it is difficult, particularly if you try to put on restraints, which could see a haemorrhaging of talent abroad.'

Under Uefa's barely noticed radical restructuring, Lee will have a crucial role as their first-ever director of communications and public affairs. His brief includes telling the world what Uefa do and why they matter. Research Uefa commissioned showed that people were 'pretty negative' about them.

'People only associate Uefa with the Champions League, Uefa Cup and European Championship. They don't know about their investment in youth, women's and five-a-side football, their funding programmes in eastern Europe and Africa or their land-mines campaign.'

So Uefa face their own challenges, to coin a favourite Lee cliche. Relations with Fifa are spiky, not least because Sepp Blatter beat Uefa president Lennart Johansson to the Fifa presidency in 1998, in what many interpreted as an historic shift of world football power away from Europe. Not so, counters Lee. He says Uefa's recent successful campaign against Fifa's plan to impose a standardised world football calendar shows their influence is still strong, as, crucially, does Germany's largely unexpected triumph over South Africa in the 2006 race.

He likens the relationship between Uefa and Fifa to that between the Premier League and FA. 'Some clashes occasionally are inevitable. But on all the major issues currently confronting European football, Uefa and Fifa are at one.' Such as on the campaign for a special EU protocol on sport that would allow them to limit the number of overseas players.

One key issue, though, is non-negotiable: no European breakaway will ever be allowed and the G14 group will never be recognised. 'That threat is still bubbling away in the background,' Lee confirms.

But he believes the decisive factor that will dissuade the G14 from setting up their own competition is that 'instinctively football wants its own future in its own hands; it doesn't want the EC or Media Partners determining its own future. You can't allow major decisions to be based in one particular media HQ.' Spoken like a man who has never heard of Sky TV.

webTitle: How Ron finally got his big pay-day

fields.headline: How Ron finally got his big pay-day
fields.standfirst: Will Buckley on the former Southend United player whose testimonial will at long last take place on Tuesday
fields.trailText: Ron Pountney, ex-Southend United, Gravesend and Basildon, never thought his name would appear in the same sentence as Luis Figo, ex-Barcelona and now Real Madrid. So that's that one sorted. In the week that Figo's move caused the Daily Express to ask '£40 million to sign one player. Has the Game Finally Gone Crazy?' it is right and proper that we should consider those less fortunate, if only to restore a sense of perspective.
fields.body:
Ron Pountney, ex-Southend United, Gravesend and Basildon, never thought his name would appear in the same sentence as Luis Figo, ex-Barcelona and now Real Madrid. So that's that one sorted. In the week that Figo's move caused the Daily Express to ask '£40 million to sign one player. Has the Game Finally Gone Crazy?' it is right and proper that we should consider those less fortunate, if only to restore a sense of perspective.

In 1985-86, Ron Pountney, three times Southend player of the year during a decade spent at Roots Hall, was given a free transfer by Bobby Moore. I thought I had a couple of years left in me, easy,' says Pountney. 'I was 30 then. But the manager didn't think so. So we parted company.'

His disappointment was slightly diminished by the prospect of a big pay-day from a testimonial match against West Ham. The brochures were printed, the tickets were printed and 'Then the Football League made West Ham play a re-arranged fixture at Anfield on the same night. I've still got all the tickets in a drawer somewhere here.'

Last year, he tried again. This time before the brochures could even be printed, let alone the tickets, the Intertoto Cup intervened and the plans were scuppered once again. 'We didn't have a definite date, but we had a definite "Yes",' says Ron. 'But after that, I thought, that's it. It's finished.'

Yet still people campaigned and when other players were offered testimonials there were letters to the Evening Echo pointing out that Pountney had still not been recognised.

It helped that he still lived in the area. 'I'd bought my house off Southend and I had to decorate it myself. So I gave it a whirl and I haven't been out of work since.'

Earlier this year, he was once again approached by loyal supporters and, despite initial reluctance, he was convinced by Hugh Cumberland and Paul Fitzgerald to give it one more go. This time, with Gary Nelson's assistance, they went for Charlton. They will be bringing their first-team squad for a full 90-minute game at 7.45pm on Tuesday at Roots Hall. Prior to that, at 6.30-ish, there will be a 30-minute kick-about as Ronnie and his mates take on a London All Stars team including Geoff Pike, Trevor Putney and Mickey Hazard. After the match, there will be a memorabilia auction in The Shrimpers, which will include a pair of Nigel Martyn gloves. Later in the week, a Stan Collymore signed shirt will be auctioned off on local radio.

If you can't make it, donations (made payable to 'Ron Pountney Testimonial Fund') can be sent to Hugh Cumberland, Kia Ora, Pudsey Hall, Canewdon, Essex SS4 3RY.

fields.headline: Gravesen out-Gazzas Gascoigne
fields.standfirst:
Blackburn Rovers 2 (Jansen 17, 46)
Everton 1 (Cadamarteri 59)
Attendance 5,566
fields.trailText: Paul Gascoigne continued his assimilation into a new, abbreviated football role as he strode confidently and competently enough through the first half of Everton's friendly defeat at First Division Blackburn yesterday.
fields.body:
Paul Gascoigne continued his assimilation into a new, abbreviated football role as he strode confidently and competently enough through the first half of Everton's friendly defeat at First Division Blackburn yesterday.

A decade ago, following his lachrymose heroics for England in the World Cup, the lovable rogue Geordie was considered the most dominant player on the planet, capable of transforming games and destinies with his sublime skills.

The intervening years have been well documented and unkind, the hurt and abuse inflicted both by himself and the game have taken their toll and this, at least if he sees out his two year contract at Everton, is the future for Gascoigne; flitting in and out of a mediocre Premiership team. Gazza even appears to have lost that once unfailing ability to hog the headlines.

Yesterday, his new midfield team-mate Thomas Gravesen stole Gazza's thunder with his combative style and 53rd minute sending off. The £2.5 million Danish international, bought this summer from Hamburg, bears an uncanny resemblance to Steve McMahon, both in physical appearance and a kick-first-ask-questions-later approach to the game.

A running battle with Rovers' Garry Flitcroft ended with Gravesen committing one foul too many, although he would have escaped with a booking had Nathan Blake not sparked a subsequent fist fight. Gravesen saw red, Blake should have, but escaped with yellow.

Gascoigne had pointed out after his first 45 minutes as an Everton player, in a 2-1 testimonial defeat at Dundee United in midweek, that now was not the time to judge him.

The question is whether Walter Smith and Everton will enjoy even that sporadic creatvity and productivity, which the 33-year-old Gascoigne should still be capable of, body and mind willing.

This is no sentimental reunion with his former Rangers manager. A 'zero tolerance' contract, which could see Gascoigne released without recompense for a variety of misdemeanors, suggests Smith is not unaware of what he is potentially letting himself in for. But, of course, he is also aware that he could have acquired for the club the sort of attacking midfield presence that was so obviously lacking from his team last season.

Smith has even talked of using Gascoigne predominantly off the bench, a sort of American football-type substitute brought on when the situation requires his offensive skills and when his shortcomings in defence and in the stamina department will not hurt the cause.

Yesterday, Gascoigne looked eager, showed a deft touch on occasion and, more importantly, appeared relatively fit. Just as important, there is a collective goodwill to still see him succeed, certainly from the Evertonians on hand and even among the home supporters. Those Blackburn fans, who have endured a miserable two-year decline, must have been cheered by the performance of Matt Jansen, who scored twice in the opening 47 minutes.

The first, after 16 minutes, came after he created space for himself at the edge of the Everton area and beat Paul Gerrard with a fantastic strike into the opposite corner of the goal.

Two minutes after the restart, and with Everton having made seven substitutions at the interval, there was predictable uncertainty in the visiting defence as Damien Johnson's cross was headed on by Martin Taylor for Jansen to flick into the goal with his head.

A £3.5 million buy from Crystal Palace, Jansen has suffered from the collective malaise that has hovered over Ewood for the past two years. fields.headline: Heads rule Hearts
fields.standfirst: Glenn Gibbons on the crisis behind the derby opener
fields.trailText: Glenn Gibbons on the crisis behind the derby opener
fields.body:
The original Edinburgh festival - the one that has enthralled the denizens of Scotland's capital city with drama and intrigue for 125 years - will be renewed this afternoon to what has become an accustomed backdrop: one of the protagonists is in financial crisis and beset by political in-fighting.

It is at Tynecastle Stadium that Hearts, founded in 1874, and Hibs, established one year later, will stage a production that is already suffused with as much theatricality as any patron of the arts is likely to witness during three weeks of show-crawling from the middle of next month.

Having spent most of the past decade worrying over the very existence of their club - under serious threat from poor management and rising debt - Hibs supporters will have spent the week leading up to this first derby of a brand new season gratified by the knowledge that it is now the turn of their great rivals to experience the misery.

What may occur on the field of play has been rendered secondary to the troubles that have befallen Hearts, with an abortive take-over attempt by a consortium led by a former chairman of the club once again thrusting Tynecastle's woes into the headlines.

The Hearts chief executive, Chris Robinson, has presided over a period of such financial uncertainty that the manager, Jim Jefferies, was instructed to make cuts to the playing staff and the wage bill.

Jefferies has insisted that nobody will leave unless he approves, a clear indication to Robinson that there is a demarcation principle; Jefferies is in charge of the football department and will brook no interference, while the chief executive has responsibility for the business.

The result is that, while other teams - notably Hibs - have been busy customers at the summer sales, Hearts have not made a single purchase. Robinson's detractors claim that he is incompetent and that the club cannot go forward until he is removed. One of the conditions of the Deans group's offer to take over the boardroom - the one point that they insisted was not negotiable - was that the chief executive should be dismissed. 'They neither trust him nor rate him,' was how it was couched by an associate of the consortium.

The offer to buy into the club by taking £2.25 million worth of new stock - with a half-promise of a similar amount being invested within 18 months - was rejected because the prospective purchasers offered only 95p per share and because they wanted to put all four of their members in the boardroom and remove one of the existing directors as well as Robinson.

None of this is likely to heighten optimism among Hearts fans, and Jefferies is without a clutch of first-team regulars because of injury and suspension. Last season's first-choice attack, Darren Jackson and the promising youngster Gary Wales, are both missing, as well as defender Gary Locke and midfielder Lee Makel.

'You can see from that alone why I can't trim my squad,' said Jefferies. 'The season hasn't even started and we are a bit thin. I'm going to have to put youth players on the bench.'

The Hibs manager, Alex McLeish, who led his newly-promoted team to an extraordinary 3-0 victory in the corresponding fixture last season, allowed seven of his squad to move out, but replaced them all - and more. If there is a generally unfamiliar look about the Easter Road side, they will still have their most gifted players, the midfield pair of Frank Sauzee and Russel Latapy, and they should be well enough equipped at least to avoid defeat.

fields.headline: Esson saves 10-man Aberdeen
fields.standfirst:
Dunfermline 0
Aberdeen 0
Attendance 7,563
fields.trailText: Scottish Premier League round-up
fields.byline: Patrick Scott at East End Park
fields.body:
Ten-man Aberdeen hung on courageously to claim an opening-day point at East End Park and deny Dunfermline a winning return to the Scottish Premier League.

The visitors' manager, Ebbe Skovdahl, had been hit by an injury crisis during the pre-season and, consequently, started with a side bearing little resemblance to the Aberdeen first team.

His young and inexperienced players were then put under extra pressure just before half-time when Derek Young was red-carded for kicking out at Dunfermline defender Jason Dair.

The home side - with new signings Marco Ruitenbeek, Andrius Skerla, Junior Mendes and Stephen Crawford all included - threw everyone forward. But their poor finishing combined with some stout defending from Aberdeen saw them forced to settle for a point.

Dunfermline spent most of the match spurning glorious chances to take the lead. Junior Mendes, Stewart Petrie and Crawford all missing fantastic opportunities.

Aberdeen then almost made a shock breakthrough in the 23rd minute when Young sliced open the home defence and played a dangerous ball into Arild Stavrum only for Michel Doesburg to make a saving tackle.

The second half followed the pattern of the first, with Young's sending-off ensuring that Aberdeen were forced to hold back and defend en masse. But Dunfermline's finishing once again let them down in the 61st minute when Mendes found Crawford unmarked in the area, but his header sailed into the arms of the grateful Ryan Esson.

A minute later Esson produced a great save to deny Dunfermline when he pushed Owen Coyle's fierce drive over his crossbar - and moments later he again saved bravely, this time at Crawford's feet.

In the day's other matches, Dundee's new player manager Ivano Bonetti had a dramatic introduction to Scottish football when he was sent off during his side's outstanding 2-0 win over Motherwell at Fir Park.

The Italian was dismissed early in the second half for his second bookable offence, a foul on Motherwell substitute Martin Wood. Bonetti then watched Javier Artero seal the victory with an 85th-minute goal that added to Patrizio Billio's ninth-minute opener.

Dundee had come under a great deal of criticism before the start of the game thanks to Bonetti's wholesale changes - they started the game with only three Scotsmen in the team and six players making their Scottish Premier League debuts.

But despite the number of newcomers to the team, Bonetti's side took control of the match from the start. And Motherwell were unable to get an attempt on goal until the half-hour mark when Ged Brannan's header from eight yards was easily saved by Rab Douglas.

Minutes later the home side were twice unlucky when defender Stephen McMillan first hit the post with a header and then saw Douglas make a great save from his 20-yard shot.

The second half started in controversy as Bonetti was sensationally sent off after receiving his second yellow card. Booked in the first half for a foul on Martyn Corrigan the Italian lunged in at substitute Martin Wood and left referee John Rowbotham with little option but to dismiss him.

It was a dramatic moment for Bonetti, who had played a major part in Dundee's excellent first-half performance. Not surprisingly the home side gained the ascendancy as Dundee were forced to defend deep in their own half. However Motherwell were struggling to create any clear-cut chances and the visitors soon regained their composure and made it 2-0 with a goal from the impressive Artero.

St Mirren, back in the top flight after an eight-year absence, came close to winning but were ultimately denied when a Gary Holt goal earned Kilmarnock the points.

St Mirren had started the stronger side but faded after Holt's second-half goal and, on this evidence, will struggle to survive in the Scottish Premier League.

Mark Yardley, last year's top scorer for the Saints, came closest for the home side when his shot in the ninth minute scraped over the crossbar.

fields.headline: Windies face void after Walsh
fields.standfirst: Visitors' lack of fast-bowling depth gives England new boy a chance as Test series resumes
fields.trailText: Courtney Walsh is 38 next birthday. He should be relaxing on a golf course or brushing up on his DIY skills instead of putting the fear of God into England. Yet, come Thursday at Old Trafford, that's just what he'll be attempting to do.
fields.body:
Courtney Walsh is 38 next birthday. He should be relaxing on a golf course or brushing up on his DIY skills instead of putting the fear of God into England. Yet, come Thursday at Old Trafford, that's just what he'll be attempting to do.

I was 34 when I stopped playing Test cricket for England back in 1965. I knew it was time to go. All fast bowlers know and I suspect Courtney knows it too as he has already announced that this is last hurrah as a tourist in England.

Walsh has nothing left to prove. Nor does his formidable new-ball partner, Curtly Ambrose, just one year younger. This year, Walsh surpassed Kapil Dev's world record haul of Test wickets - a mark that belonged to me back in the Sixties - and his record will always stand muster. But I suspect he has been prompted to carry on for so long by the lighter workload of today's strike bowlers and the lack of natural successors in the Caribbean.

Only Courtney himself truly knows if he is starting to slide from the high standard every truly world-class fast bowler sets himself. But I can tell you what the tell-tale signs are. How do I know - because they happen to all quick bowlers, myself included.

The most important sign is that the thin snicks that go to first slip or the wicketkeeper are fewer and farther between. Instead, the batsman gets more of a bat on your delivery and the edge, thicker now, starts going past gully; the decision you make to shake up the batsman after he's just hit one back over your head is met not with trepidation - but with calm and confidence. You don't frighten them any more.

Then when you wake you don't leap out of bed to face the task ahead. Instead you fall out. And, at the other end of the day, when play is over, you stay longer than ever before in a hot bath. Yes, it's time to go.

I stopped playing county cricket for Yorkshire at about the age Courtney is now. I could, possibly, have gone on for another year or two if they'd agreed to give me a second benefit. They saw fit not to and that brings me on to my point about workload.

Today's players would baulk at the load I faced against the West Indies in 1957 when we met at Trent Bridge. England went into the game with only four recognised bowlers - myself, Brian Statham, Trevor Bailey and Tony Lock. When Bailey was injured, it left three of us to do the donkey work after Tom Graveney's double-hundred inspired us to 619 for six declared. I took five for 65 in the first innings as the Windies were bowled out for 372. Skipper Peter May, despite our protests, enforced the follow-on and the hard work started all over again. This time the West Indies got 367 and the match ended in a draw but only after I'd bowled 65 overs (nine wickets) in the game and Statham got through 70 overs. It was murder.

So, by those standards, the players we'll see in Manchester on Thursday are cosseted. No wonder Walsh and Ambrose are still going strong, but I fancy the tourists are going to struggle once this twin-pronged assault team finally call it a day.

The other pacemen on the tour are Nixon McLean, Franklyn Rose and Reon King. None of them, in my judgment, looks capable of reaching the standards set by Walsh and Ambrose who both learned so much from coming through into their Test side while great performers such as the late Malcolm Marshall - remembered last week in a memorial game in London - and Michael Holding were still running in.

This is essentially a two-man attack and that should be some comfort to Marcus Trescothick of Somerset and Yorkshire's Michael Vaughan who will both want to impress. It's vital for both men, especially Trescothick on his debut, to really concentrate. It's the mental application that differs so drastically between the five-day game and the commercial one-day enterprise we have just been through.

Trescothick did magnificently in those games, but he knows that Old Trafford will be very different. Some of the West Indies players know it too - they did not even bother with the one-day stuff. Walsh and Ambrose gave it a wide berth, resting themselves for the rigours ahead in the remaining Tests while Sherwin Campbell left the country to be with his wife during the birth of their child. In truth, the West Indies treated the NatWest series with contempt.

So Trescothick and Vaughan can expect a refreshed Walsh and Ambrose on Thursday. But it would be terrific if England responded by winning at Old Trafford and then taking the series. It would give the game the most enormous boost in this country from the Test players to the grassroots.

It can be done. When I look at the opposition I can't help but compare them with the first West Indies side I faced in 1950. Their side included Allan Rae, a fine opening left-hand bat; Jeff Stollmeyer, the other opener who later skippered the side; Gerry Gomez, dependable in the middle order; Lance Pierre, a right-arm fast bowler; skipper John Goddard, another all-rounder; Prior Jones, who could move the ball either way off the seam; spinner Sonny Ramadhin and his left-arm partner Alf Valentine. Then there were the three Ws - Clyde Walcott, a terrific bat who also kept wicket, his good pal Frank Worrell, who was to have such a great 1950 series against England, and the stylish Everton Weekes.

So pardon me when I cast an eye over the present West Indies side and declare that I'm underwhelmed. Brian Lara, of course, is absolute class when he's in the mood. So are Walsh and Ambrose, but they are carrying the side. I'm afraid this is the worst Windies side I've seen in 50 years - and I've seen a few since that day at Bradford's Park Avenue all those years ago. The time is right for England to strike. Let's hope they can take their chance.

None of them, in my judgment, looks capable of reaching the standards set by Walsh and Ambrose who both learned so much from coming through into their Test side while great performers such as the late Malcolm Marshall - remembered last week in a memorial game in London - and Michael Holding were still running in. This is essentially a two-man attack and that should be some comfort to Marcus Trescothick of Somerset and Yorkshire's Michael Vaughan who will both want to impress. It's vital for both men, especially Trescothick on his debut, to really concentrate. It's the mental application that differs so drastically between the five-day game and the commercial one-day enterprise we have just been through. Trescothick did magnificently in those games, but he knows that Old Trafford will be very different. Some of the West Indies players know it too - they did not even bother with the one-day stuff. Walsh and Ambrose gave it a wide berth, resting themselves for the rigours ahead in the remaining Tests while Sherwin Campbell left the country to be with his wife during the birth of their child. In truth, the West Indies treated the NatWest series with contempt. So Trescothick and Vaughan can expect a refreshed Walsh and Ambrose on Thursday. But it would be terrific if England responded by winning at Old Trafford and then taking the series. It would give the game the most enormous boost in this country from the Test players to the grassroots. It can be done. When I look at the opposition I can't help but compare them with the first West Indies side I faced in 1950. Their side included Allan Rae, a fine opening left-hand bat; Jeff Stollmeyer, the other opener who later skippered the side; Gerry Gomez, dependable in the middle order; Lance Pierre, a right-arm fast bowler; skipper John Goddard, another all-rounder; Prior Jones, who could move the ball either way off the seam; spinner Sonny Ramadhin and his left-arm partner Alf Valentine. Then there were the three Ws - Clyde Walcott, a terrific bat who also kept wicket, his good pal Frank Worrell, who was to have such a great 1950 series against England, and the stylish Everton Weekes. So pardon me when I cast an eye over the present West Indies side and declare that I'm underwhelmed. Brian Lara, of course, is absolute class when he's in the mood. So are Walsh and Ambrose, but they are carrying the side. I'm afraid this is the worst Windies side I've seen in 50 years - and I've seen a few since that day at Bradford's Park Avenue all those years ago. The time is right for England to strike. Let's hope they can take their chance.

webTitle: The end of Usk's village affair?

fields.headline: The end of Usk's village affair?
fields.standfirst: Norman Harris's cricket round-up
fields.trailText: With a solicitor's letter on its way to the organisers, it may yet be that a judge has to decide on a legal nicety before this year's Village Cup can progress to its annual climax at Lord's. Usk's last-ball win last Sunday seemed to have put them into the semi-finals of the Wadworth 6X Championship, but the Welsh side have been disqualified because they are deemed to be a town.
fields.body:
With a solicitor's letter on its way to the organisers, it may yet be that a judge has to decide on a legal nicety before this year's Village Cup can progress to its annual climax at Lord's. Usk's last-ball win last Sunday seemed to have put them into the semi-finals of the Wadworth 6X Championship, but the Welsh side have been disqualified because they are deemed to be a town.

That decision was made by the competition's organisers at The Cricketer magazine - and follows a number of similar decisions over the years, with sides sometimes being thrown out simply because they were considered too good.

Although the 2,187 population of Usk is comfortably within the 3,000 limit set by the competition's rules, the organisers say that 'Usk presents itself to the world as a town' - principally, with signs that say 'Welcome to the historic market town of Usk', and also on a website.

Usk cricketers say that such terminology is down to marketing for tourism, and that because villages can vary enormously in size and character the only definition relevant to the Village Cup can be the criteria laid down by the organisers. That is, a rural community of under 3,000, surrounded by open countryside.

At the heart of the legal argument is a single line on the competition's entry form, which, after Usk filled in the figure, reads 'Size of village: 2,187'. The organisers say that states a claim to be a village. Lawyers among the Usk club say it is no more than a statement of population. So certain are they that they have secured the funding for an injunction - which will follow, Usk have informed the organisers, if they are not back in the competition by tomorrow night.

'We know it will be embarrassing if we succeed with the injunction and then lose on the field,' says a club spokesman. 'But we all feel very strongly.'

Whatever now happens, the episode is surely a warning to all competition organisers. Even for village green cricket, rules need to be written by lawyers.

IT IS RARE enough for a no-ball to bowl a batsman and deflect from the stumps for a run. But it happened from successive deliveries during Surrey's National League match last Sunday against Nottinghamshire. First, Paul Franks hit the stumps of Adam Hollioake, then did the same with the following 'free-hit' ball to Graham Thorpe, an extra run coming as a bye in both cases.

There is already a school of thought that says that a throw which hits the stumps is unfairly penalised when the ball deflects and extra runs are scored. Perhaps it would be fair for dead ball to apply 'whenever the ball breaks the wicket'?

LAPTOPS TEND TO represent little more than a commercial promotion for the modern sports team. Not so the New Zealand 'A' tourists, with the players being required to buy their own laptop 'as part of their professional equipment'.

On the restricted-access 'Black Caps' website they respond to a constant flow of data and comment - not just from the touring management but also from home-based specialists in areas such as diet, fitness and 'mental-management'.

Says coach David Trist: 'Messages will also be posted by senior Black Caps - for example, Roger Twose telling everyone about his rainbow-trout fishing or his achievements on the stock market. It's great for so many reasons. As coach you can coordinate all the disciplines. I find it invigorating.'

fields.headline: McGrath on the ball
fields.trailText: Just as Australian batsmen appear to be a class above the natives, so, in the form of Glenn McGrath, are the bowlers.
fields.body:
Just as Australian batsmen appear to be a class above the natives, so, in the form of Glenn McGrath, are the bowlers.

After contributing four to the tumble of wickets - 15 - on Thursday Worcestershire's new recruit helped them to an unlikely first-innings lead when Gloucestershire were bowled out for 87 in reply to 98 in the Second Division game.

While McGrath was taking seven for 29 from 16 overs, Amalgir Sheriyar could only manage one for 51 in 13.

It looked different day, same again, when Phil Weston was dismissed for a duck by Mike Smith and Graeme Hick following soon after for 10 but half-centuries from David Leatherdale and Steve Rhodes took the score to 218 for 9.

Despite the first instance of both teams failing to make 100 in their first innings in the 100-year history of this fixture the England and Wales Cricket Board pitch liaison officer Phil Sharpe has not recommended a points deduction.

An unbeaten 62 from Peter Bowler helped Somerset avoid the follow-on in their First Division game with Durham at Chester-le-Street. At 88 for six in reply to 292 they were in trouble but Bowler and Graham Rose stood firm to close on 144 for six.

Off-spinners Jason Brown and Graeme Swann raised Northamptonshire's hopes of only a third championship win of the season as they shared nine Warwickshire wickets at Edgbaston.

They exploited a dry pitch to dismiss Warwickshire for 236 to give Northamptonshire an first innings lead of 82. They added 44 to that for the loss of Adrian Rollins, lbw to Ashley Giles who took six wickets in the first innings, and nightwatchman Paul Taylor.
