fields.headline: News
fields.trailText: Join Ransome trail in Lakeland | Find the treasure | Card offers cut-price entry to attractions
fields.body:
Join Ransome trail in Lakeland
The Lake District is celebrating the seventieth anniversary of the publication of Arthur Ransome's Swallows and Amazons with a special Swallows and Amazons Forever! exhibition at the Museum of Lakeland Life in Abbot Hall, Kendal.

Other sites along the Ransome Trail, including the Windermere Steamboat Museum (01539 445565) and the Ruskin Museum on Coniston (01539 441164) have decided to join in.

Ransome fans can find out more about Kanchenjunga, Octopus Lagoon, Secret Harbour and Wild Cat island, all Lake District locations, at the Museum of Lakeland Life: exhibits include Ransome's sketch books. Swallows and Amazons Forever! reveals other parts of the author's life. Before he started writing his famous books he worked as a war correspondent in Russia, played chess with Lenin and married Tolstoy's secretary.

Abbot Hall Art Gallery is also hosting Ruskin and the Light of Nature featuring works by Turner and Rossetti as well as Ruskin, until 1 October. There are workshops for children at both venues throughout August; activities include print-making, T-shirt design, still life and pinhole photography. Pre-booking is recommended (£3 per place).

Abbot Hall is open daily from 10.30am-5pm. Tel: 01539 722464 for details about both exhibitions and the workshops.

Find the treasure
Young pirates, explorers and adventurers should make their way to more than 80 National Trust properties this summer if they want the chance of finding hidden treasure. There are prizes at the end of each outdoor clue-strewn trail, as well as extra activities such as 'pirate workshops', raft-building and face-painting.

Venues include Chedworth Roman Villa, near Cheltenham, on 6 August (01242 890 256); Tattershall Castle, Lincoln, on 13 August (01526 342 543); and Petworth House on 18 August (01798 342 207).

On 30 August children can follow in the footsteps of Swallows and Amazons characters at Calke Abbey, Derbyshire (01332 863822). A complete list of treasure hunts and a leaflet, Events for Children and Families, is available from the National Trust's information service (020 8315 1111 or www.trusty.org).

The treasure hunts are part of the charity's Neptune Coastline campaign, which aims to safeguard stretches of Britain's coastline.

Card offers cut-price entry to attractions
Good news: you can now enjoy cheap days out at family attractions around the country and benefit charity at the same time. The Powerpass card is an initiative from Yorkshire Tourist Board and Northern Electric & Gas which allows two-for-one entry at over 150 attractions, from Warkworth Castle in Northumbria to Adventure Island in Essex. The passes cost a minimum of £1, which Yorkshire Tourist Board will donate to Childline, but larger donations are welcomed. You can use the cards as much as you like for the rest of the year.

The passes are available from tourist information centres in Yorkshire, or send a cheque or postal order for £1, or preferably more, to Yorkshire Tourist Board, 312 Tadcaster Road, York YO24 1GS, and it will send you a discount card and a leaflet of participating attractions.

Abbot Hall is open daily from 10.30am-5pm. Tel: 01539 722464 for details about both exhibitions and the workshops. Find the treasure Young pirates, explorers and adventurers should make their way to more than 80 National Trust properties this summer if they want the chance of finding hidden treasure. There are prizes at the end of each outdoor clue-strewn trail, as well as extra activities such as 'pirate workshops', raft-building and face-painting. Venues include Chedworth Roman Villa, near Cheltenham, on 6 August (01242 890 256); Tattershall Castle, Lincoln, on 13 August (01526 342 543); and Petworth House on 18 August (01798 342 207). On 30 August children can follow in the footsteps of Swallows and Amazons characters at Calke Abbey, Derbyshire (01332 863822). A complete list of treasure hunts and a leaflet, Events for Children and Families, is available from the National Trust's information service (020 8315 1111 or www.trusty.org). The treasure hunts are part of the charity's Neptune Coastline campaign, which aims to safeguard stretches of Britain's coastline. Card offers cut-price entry to attractions Good news: you can now enjoy cheap days out at family attractions around the country and benefit charity at the same time. The Powerpass card is an initiative from Yorkshire Tourist Board and Northern Electric & Gas which allows two-for-one entry at over 150 attractions, from Warkworth Castle in Northumbria to Adventure Island in Essex. The passes cost a minimum of £1, which Yorkshire Tourist Board will donate to Childline, but larger donations are welcomed. You can use the cards as much as you like for the rest of the year. The passes are available from tourist information centres in Yorkshire, or send a cheque or postal order for £1, or preferably more, to Yorkshire Tourist Board, 312 Tadcaster Road, York YO24 1GS, and it will send you a discount card and a leaflet of participating attractions.

fields.headline: Planting in rich soil
fields.trailText: It remains to be seen whether Stephen King's example will encourage other big-name authors to leave their print publishers and head for the web, but if they do, it will probably do younger authors more harm than good...
fields.body:
This week's World of Books column will be taking advantage of the latest cutting-edge breakthrough in publishing technology.

Here's how it works. The column will be written in instalments. I, the author, will provide this week's episode completely free of charge. But!

I will leave it suspended on a seat-gripping cliffhanger, and if you want to read the second part next week, you, the reader, will have to send me 50p (cash or cheque), to the usual Observer address, please. If I can raise about £15 by next week, I'll provide the second part of this column. Can't say fairer than that - the revolution is upon us and the good news is that everyone can join in!

This, at least, is the theory of horror-meister Stephen King, who set out this week to become 'Big Publishing's worst nightmare' by making his new novel, The Plant, available in instalments on his website. He's done it, bless him, not to make crateloads of money, as he did with his last on-line book, but to blaze a trail for the little people, 'all the mid-list writers, literary writers and just plain marginalised writers who see a future outside the mainstream'.

Which is a nice thought, but a bit naive, Steve. It's long been suggested that the new technology has the potential to democratise the business of writing and break the hegemony of Premier League agents and publishing corporations, but it's difficult to imagine on-line publishing working quite so effectively for any authors unable to muster King's legion of fans (ie almost every other writer in the world). King's gimmick is a brilliant one, but it only works if you're Stephen King.

The problem for most midlist and literary writers is that they can only see a future outside the mainstream. It's easy to post your first novel on the net, but that doesn't make you a published writer, and aspiring novelists still need the validation that comes from making your way through the old-fashioned chain of agent, publisher, bookseller and press coverage, the latter often dependent on the marketing muscle of the bigger publishing houses.

It's only when you've made your name - and your fortune - shifting huge quantities of books under the aegis of a well-known imprint that you have a sufficient profile to stand up and denounce the archaic and corrupt ways of the monolithic multinationals.

A similar trick is being tried in the US by Dave Eggers, author of the best-selling A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius. Having achieved renown and some staggering royalties, Eggers plans to self-publish his next book, not on the net but in good, old book form, because he dislikes the way that mainstream publishers force authors into rigid schedules that often mean a book is published as much as a year after it is written.

Eggers plans to publish not for profit but to give the authors more control over their work; a noble undertaking, but only possible because his first book had the support of a commercial publisher. Coincidentally, his American publisher is Simon and Schuster, which also publishes Stephen King - or used to.

Not only has King deprived his publishers of his first new work since his near-fatal accident last year, but the story itself is a satirical swipe at the machinations of big publishers and the tricky business of getting your work noticed. The Plant is a series of letters to and from John Kenton, associate editor at Zenith House, a New York publisher which, in Kenton's own words, 'is hardly Alfred A.Knopf'.

Kenton, a frustrated literature graduate, spends his days sifting through the slush pile of manuscripts and lunching the authors of such seminal works as Rats From Hell and Gash Me, My Darling. In the course of perusing these submissions, Kenton uncovers a letter from one Carlos Detweiller offering his work, True Tales of Demon Infestations, stories he claims to have based on personal experience.

Detweiller is ungrammatical and almost certainly frothing mad, but Kenton, desperate to make his mark with a bestseller, invites him to submit some sample chapters ('Don't do it, you fool!' you'll find yourself screaming at the computer, one hand over your eyes). This is where the real nastiness begins, but I'm not going to tell you what it is because you haven't paid your dollar.

King's website update claims that 'the number of downloads seems to be staying hot', and the surprising news is that King's loyal fans are stumping up the dollar even after they've read the chapter. It remains to be seen whether King's example will encourage other big-name authors to leave their print publishers and head for the web, but if they do, it will probably do younger authors more harm than good. Publishers can afford to gamble on unknown writers because they make their money from heavy-hitters like Stephen King, and if there is a mass exodus by others of his stature, his dream of undermining the book trade might not be so far fetched.

Meanwhile, if you feel like playing for the other team, you could always get all your friends to download The Plant and not pay for it. One imagines the big publishers might have conspired to do so already.

fields.headline: The cost of...
fields.standfirst: ... a bicycle
fields.trailText: ... a bicycle
fields.body:
Despite perfecting the bicycle - by adding essentials such as chains, gears, brakes, etc to the original French vélocipede - we have never really taken to it in the same way they have (admittedly they patented the pedal, though Leonardo first sketched one in 1490). But as Lance Armstrong packs his bike away for at least a week's break before he begins training for next year's Tour de France, it seems timely to look at what it would cost to keep up with him.

The Tour remains the world's most gruelling sporting event, and it is no surprise that France hosts it - this is, after all, the country that came up with the word 'sadism'. So the most important factor is the extra weight you will have to pedal up and down the Pyrenees.

Armstrong's bike, a Trek 5500, weighs 17lb with its components, while the carbon fibre frame alone is just 2.5lb and costs £1,000. Complete, it is £2,700, while his signature version is an extra £1,000. Frame material is crucial - carbon fibre and titanium are the most expensive, but aluminium bicycles have fallen in price and are almost as light.

Spare wheels are more than £500 per pair, while the groupset (gears and brakes) is £1,000. Shoes and pedals that clip together cost £90. Other racing essentials include a helmet (from £20 to £100) and a puncture kit (£1.50, pump £10), and to avoid dehydration you'll also need a water bottle (£5). Professional cyclists are unabashedly devoted to Lycra (shorts, £20) and also shave their legs; it is assumed this enhances their aerodynamics (razor and blades £3).

Note that designers have omitted any pouches for packed lunches and the like. Indeed, if you are concerned about provisions, you may not be cut out for the Tour de France at all - remember that these athletes diet for most of the year and have the body-fat of whippets and legs by Rodin.

A traditional bicycle, of the sort usually found in British university towns with a wicker basket and buckled wheels, is probably more appropriate and can be picked up for £30 or less. However, mountain bikes are still the biggest sellers: the most popular costs about £350, while a full-suspension model is about £1,000.

Tour de France bicycle £2,700
Frame only £1,000
Spare wheels £500/pair
Shoes £90
Helmet up to £120
Puncture kit £1.50
Pump £10
Lycra shorts £20
Razor £3
Total £3,434.50

webTitle: Down and out in New York (part two)

fields.headline: Down and out in New York (part two)
fields.standfirst: The Hotel Providence offers shelter of a sort to the 224 men who live and die in its windowless cages. Guy Lawson spends three weeks with Sleepout Jackie, Methadone Stevie, Turk and Raul in a Bowery flophouse
fields.body:
Stevie had broken his back in a car accident, and he had broken his knees in a variety of falls over the years, and was subject to petite and grand mal seizures; he was also addicted to Klonapin, an anticonvulsant, which he said he took to stave off seizures. Stevie often borrowed from loan sharks in the hotel: 10 bucks doubled to 20 in a couple of days with some sharks; with others, the rates were lower and a loan of 50 became 75. Stevie's mother sent him cash by Priority Mail, and she had set up a private toll-free 800 number for him to phone home, to save the charges he had long run up by calling collect; he phoned his mother every day, sometimes dozens of times a day, from a pay phone at the corner of Grand Street and the Bowery. He said he wanted to move back home with his parents but they wouldn't let him until he entered a detox programme and got clean.

Stevie had cut a hole in the chicken wire in his room so his cat, Malaka, could come and go as he pleased, and the sheets on Stevie's bed were filthy and covered with cigarette burns, the remains of the times he had passed out while smoking. 'My mother has no idea how I'm living,' he said. 'What I'm going to do, I don't care if it costs me every cent I've got, I'm going to get a fucking camera, one of those disposable cameras, and I'm going to take pictures of the fucking hotel, and I'm going to send them to all my relatives.'

That afternoon, when we got back from the soup kitchen, a man was waiting for Stevie in the hallway outside his room. The man was mangy, with a three-day beard and pony-tail drawn back on his head, and he stood close in on Stevie; he was one of the men I had seen loitering in front of the Providence day and night. Stevie had borrowed $3 from the man the day before for a pack of smokes. The man asked Stevie if he had the five bucks he now owed, the extra $2 amounting to interest on a day-long loan. Stevie pulled four crumpled singles from his pocket. The man counted the money. 'That's not the deal,' he said to Stevie. 'I'll give you the rest tomorrow,' Stevie said. 'That's not the deal,' the man said angrily, and he stepped closer to him. I quickly reached into my pocket for a dollar, but in the moment of threat, in the time it takes menace to become fact, a door behind us opened and the man who lived across the hall from Stevie held out a dollar - Stevie and his neighbour watched out for each other, Stevie later told me. The loan shark took the man's dollar and he took my dollar, then he stared hard at Stevie and he told him he'd better not fuck with him again.

Monday night in the third week of October, the windows in the lobby had been cleaned for the first time ever, seemingly, and the light from the outside world was startlingly bright, the shining glass gleaming the reflection of the men back at themselves. There was a football game on TV but the room was mostly abandoned.

Upstairs, the renovations continued apace: the bathroom on the fourth floor had been demolished, and steel caging had been added to join the tops of the boxes with the ceiling; the workers were rapidly nearing the main floor. The new owners were offering some of the permanent residents a cash settlement to leave the hotel and relinquish their claim to a room. It was common for the permanent residents to fall behind in their rent, some by as much as 500 days, and it was expensive and difficult for the owners to get the men evicted. The payout was, relatively speaking, a cheap solution. The amounts varied, but the maximum was $500, and Turk and some others had accepted the sum.

By the end of the third week of October, there was no way to get into the lobby. The second floor of the Providence had been turned into a construction site and the ceiling echoed with carpenters banging nails and sawing wood. The piles of dry wall and lumber began to shrink as the lobby was changed from one room, with the television set in the corner and tables and chairs and cats arranged in no particular order. There were now to be two separate rooms. No one was quite sure what was going on. There were rumours that one room was going to be the lobby for men, the other for female residents; women, it was rumoured, were going to take over the main floor. The rates were going to go up, it was said - $12 a night, $15 dollars a night, no one was sure how much. The renovations were nearly complete, the new bathrooms and shower stalls put in place. Other hotels along the Bowery that had once been flophouses had been redone recently and the owners had started to rent by the night to tourists, some charging as much as $30 and $40.

Late in the week, a small article buried in the bottom corner of a page in the middle of the New York Post carried the headline 'Bowery man held in fatal stabbing'. It was reported that the man who had been resident on the fourth floor of the Providence had been arrested. He had killed one man and seriously wounded two others, it was said, and he had been subdued by a security guard and an auxiliary cop after he had attacked a Chinatown shoe-store owner with a knife in broad daylight. He 'stabbed people who rubbed him the wrong way,' the article said. The shoe-store owner had looked at him in a manner he found offensive. One of the other stabbings had been caused when he grew angered at a man who spat on the pavement.

The same day that the Post story ran, Stevie rose early and walked to his methadone clinic, then caught the train out to Long Island to visit his parents. He did his laundry, had a shower, and picked up a winter jacket and thermal underwear; his mother gave him boxes of cereal and a jar of peanut butter, and a few cans of soup; she slipped him $20. His mother was pushing the idea of him getting into a detox programme, Stevie said when he got back to the hotel that night. He said he was seriously considering the prospect of trying to quit methadone and the pharmacy-worth of pills he was hooked on. There was a place in the city called The Realization Center that he was thinking of trying.

The next day, Stevie asked me if I would buy him a cup of coffee. We went to a bakery on the Bowery and Stevie chain-smoked cigarettes, his fingers yellowed with nicotine stains. He ate lemon rolls. He said he had walked by an automotive repair shop just off the Bowery that specialised in imports and, for a moment, contemplated going inside and applying for a job, but the place was a dump, he said, and he didn't want to risk using his tools and getting them damaged or stolen. His tools were worth $10,000, he said, and he could sell them but he never would; that was like a writer giving up his pen, an artist giving up his brushes. Stevie said he hadn't shot heroin that day or on Sunday, when his cat had spilled his dose of methadone. He said he had changed his mind that Sunday once he got to his dealer's room on the fifth floor of the hotel, despite the aching pain of withdrawal.

Stevie rolled up the sleeve of his sweatshirt to prove that he hadn't shot heroin. His arms were ravaged with angry, open sores and needle marks. Seemingly unaware of the contradictions in his story, or what the scars on his emaciated arms told of his situation, he said he couldn't shoot heroin by himself. He had a lot of good veins left, he said, but he was afraid of getting an air bubble in the syringe that would go straight to his heart. He said he had to pay a friend - the junkie who lived across the hallway from him in the Providence - a couple of bucks to get him high. He walked out on to the Bowery, into the crisp autumn air, and he said he was depressed because he had gone to The Realization Center for an assessment that day and had been given the dual diagnoses of CD and MI - chemically dependent, mentally incompetent. He had been put in a holding room with people who couldn't even talk, with zombies. He feared he was going to be stuck in the Providence for the next 30 years. His biggest worry, the thing he cared about most in the world, was what to do with his cat if he entered a programme to try to get straight. 'If I could get my cat into my parents' house, I'd leave the Providence today,' he said.

I took the train to Stevie's home on Long Island where the autumn leaves on the trees were red and puce and gold. The town was, as Stevie said, affluent, with quiet, winding streets, massive estates hidden behind steel gates and a Norman Rockwellian red-brick high school where Stevie had once been a student. Stevie's parents lived in a modest two-storey house in a less-wealthy quarter of the town. The living room was decorated with throw rugs and stuffed dolls and portraits of their daughter's graduation and wedding. Stevie's mother wore a cardigan and jeans and a pair of half-moon reading glasses strung on a necklace. His father, a retired investigator for the federal government, was a thin, softly spoken man, and he sat at the dining table smoking a pipe. They had given Stevie $120 a month, for years, they said; Stevie knew when his mother's social security cheque arrived, and he always came out from the Providence to collect the money. Stevie's mother said she always dreaded his visits. She also lived in dread that Stevie wouldn't arrive and she wouldn't know if he was alive or dead.

Stevie had told me he was 37, but his parents said he was really 43. 'We're both about to turn 70,' his father said, 'and soon we'll be gone and Stevie is going to have to fend for himself.' Stevie's mother played a message from Stevie she had saved from their answering machine that morning. 'I'm taking $500 to leave my room,' he said on the recording. 'I'm going to leave the cat, because you promised me you would take the cat, but obviously you're not going to do that. It's obvious I'm going to die, so I might as well die on the streets. You know, $500 will be enough to give me a nice overdose.'

Stevie's parents said that his troubles had been going on for years, and it had become impossible to clearly distinguish one event from another. They had made mistakes as parents, they said. 'We've apologised many times,' his mother said. 'We're not perfect people, or perfect parents. We all make mistakes. He was the first born, so he got more than the others. We're sorry, drop it, let it go, get on with your life.' Stevie's mother said that they had moved from a working-class neighbourhood to their new affluent town when Stevie was in grade school and that he had never fitted in with the more well-to-do kids. Stevie's father said he had suffered a nervous breakdown when Stevie was a teenager, and Stevie had started to steal his quaaludes. The heavy drinking and marijuana and LSD and, eventually, heroin came later. They had bought Stevie BMWs over the years and paid for his training as a mechanic; he had wrecked the cars and lost a string of jobs. Stevie's father said that their other children, their daughters, had grown to hate the way Stevie's troubles affected the family. On their eldest daughter's wedding day, Stevie had turned up at the house high, and his mother refused to let him in. Stevie shot up on the front step; his mother watched from the kitchen window as he injected the needle and swore at them that he would be dead by the time they returned from the church.

Since Stevie had moved into the Providence, six and a half years earlier, he had continued to come out to his parents' house to sleep from time to time. His mother and father were terrified that he would fall asleep with a cigarette and burn the house down, though, and they had made him sleep in the basement, where the floor was concrete. Stevie hadn't been allowed to stay the night for the past few months; during his visits, his father, exhausted by the repeated accusations and demands, had begun to retreat to a room on the second floor and stayed until his son left. His mother said that tough love, which they tried to practise, following the advice of drug counsellors and others who had experience in such matters, was hard to live out. 'It's very difficult for a mother to hear that your child hasn't eaten anything,' she said. 'Intellectually, you understand what to do, but emotionally it's very difficult.'

Outside, Stevie's mother and father opened the garage door and showed me the tools Stevie had told me about. The red Craftmaster tools were locked, and there was an empty pill bottle on top. They had bought the set for him at Sears: the tools were worth $800, not $10,000. Stevie's mother said she wished he would get into a good rehab programme, one that lasted a full year. The problem, she said, was that they couldn't afford to pay for it, and Stevie wasn't covered by their medical insurance.

'If there was some place out there for him to go,' Stevie's mother said, her voice trailing away. 'I wish I'd win the Lotto. I would put him in some place. That's what I wish.'

The lobby in the Providence was closed off entirely by the end of October. There were now two security doors near the front desk: one for the residents staying on the main floor, in the new rooms next to what had once been the lobby; the other, a black, prison-like steel door that led to the stairway upstairs, for the men living in one of the three floors above. The renovation was complete. With no lobby, the men had to keep to their rooms to stay out of the cold.

The men I had met in the lobby of the Providence had scattered to the four winds. Turk, it was said, went on a drinking jag and blew in a matter of days the cash the owners had given him; the last report was that he was sleeping in the subway. Raul, no longer able to rely on the free meal provided nightly in the lobby, had found a job working the midnight shift in a bakery in lower Manhattan. He said things were going good, that he had some responsibility for money and was proud of that. He just hoped he could keep it together.

In early November, precisely 30 days after I had set out to report on a month in the lives of the men and hotel, Stevie disappeared from the Providence. Around midnight that night, for no reason other than a growing sense of unease, I checked my answering machine and there was a message from Stevie's mother. 'I have some sad news for you,' she said. 'Stevie was killed by an automobile walking from the railway station to our house this evening.' Late that afternoon, in the gathering dusk, Stevie's train had pulled into his home town on Long Island. He had called his mother from the station. He had said that he was on his way home. He had been walking off the footpath, on the edge of the road against the oncoming traffic, as he made his way along the main route. A van had rounded a bend and hit him head on. Stevie's mother had been waiting for him when she heard the town's emergency siren go off, the alarm screaming throughout the village.

Sleepout Jackie, who lived in the hallway next to Stevie's on the fourth floor and who had feuded with him over the years, said that none of the men in the hotel had mourned his passing. 'He was shooting his arm up every fucking day,' Sleepout said. 'He haunted people. Nobody misses him.'

The night Stevie was killed, the handful of flophouses on the Bowery was scarcely noticeable, as always sheltered in the shadows cast by the street lights. A lone man stumbled along the pavement, his thick glasses askew. The man was carrying a crumpled paper bag with a bottle of liquor in it, and every few paces he stopped and took a long drink. Upstairs in the Providence, the windows in the room that had once been the lobby were blackened. The men in the hotel had lost their only gathering place, the only place for them to sit out of the weather, eat, watch Wheel of Fortune. In Far Rockaway, on the farthest margins of the city, there were the beginnings of the next last resort. On the Bowery, the time when a man alone in the world had found refuge, of a kind, in the heart of the city was slipping deeper into the past.
fields.bodyText: Stevie had broken his back in a car accident, and he had broken his knees in a variety of falls over the years, and was subject to petite and grand mal seizures; he was also addicted to Klonapin, an anticonvulsant, which he said he took to stave off seizures. Stevie often borrowed from loan sharks in the hotel: 10 bucks doubled to 20 in a couple of days with some sharks; with others, the rates were lower and a loan of 50 became 75. Stevie's mother sent him cash by Priority Mail, and she had set up a private toll-free 800 number for him to phone home, to save the charges he had long run up by calling collect; he phoned his mother every day, sometimes dozens of times a day, from a pay phone at the corner of Grand Street and the Bowery. He said he wanted to move back home with his parents but they wouldn't let him until he entered a detox programme and got clean. Stevie had cut a hole in the chicken wire in his room so his cat, Malaka, could come and go as he pleased, and the sheets on Stevie's bed were filthy and covered with cigarette burns, the remains of the times he had passed out while smoking. 'My mother has no idea how I'm living,' he said. 'What I'm going to do, I don't care if it costs me every cent I've got, I'm going to get a fucking camera, one of those disposable cameras, and I'm going to take pictures of the fucking hotel, and I'm going to send them to all my relatives.' That afternoon, when we got back from the soup kitchen, a man was waiting for Stevie in the hallway outside his room. The man was mangy, with a three-day beard and pony-tail drawn back on his head, and he stood close in on Stevie; he was one of the men I had seen loitering in front of the Providence day and night. Stevie had borrowed $3 from the man the day before for a pack of smokes. The man asked Stevie if he had the five bucks he now owed, the extra $2 amounting to interest on a day-long loan. Stevie pulled four crumpled singles from his pocket. The man counted the money. 'That's not the deal,' he said to Stevie. 'I'll give you the rest tomorrow,' Stevie said. 'That's not the deal,' the man said angrily, and he stepped closer to him. I quickly reached into my pocket for a dollar, but in the moment of threat, in the time it takes menace to become fact, a door behind us opened and the man who lived across the hall from Stevie held out a dollar - Stevie and his neighbour watched out for each other, Stevie later told me. The loan shark took the man's dollar and he took my dollar, then he stared hard at Stevie and he told him he'd better not fuck with him again. Monday night in the third week of October, the windows in the lobby had been cleaned for the first time ever, seemingly, and the light from the outside world was startlingly bright, the shining glass gleaming the reflection of the men back at themselves. There was a football game on TV but the room was mostly abandoned. Upstairs, the renovations continued apace: the bathroom on the fourth floor had been demolished, and steel caging had been added to join the tops of the boxes with the ceiling; the workers were rapidly nearing the main floor. The new owners were offering some of the permanent residents a cash settlement to leave the hotel and relinquish their claim to a room. It was common for the permanent residents to fall behind in their rent, some by as much as 500 days, and it was expensive and difficult for the owners to get the men evicted. The payout was, relatively speaking, a cheap solution. The amounts varied, but the maximum was $500, and Turk and some others had accepted the sum. By the end of the third week of October, there was no way to get into the lobby. The second floor of the Providence had been turned into a construction site and the ceiling echoed with carpenters banging nails and sawing wood. The piles of dry wall and lumber began to shrink as the lobby was changed from one room, with the television set in the corner and tables and chairs and cats arranged in no particular order. There were now to be two separate rooms. No one was quite sure what was going on. There were rumours that one room was going to be the lobby for men, the other for female residents; women, it was rumoured, were going to take over the main floor. The rates were going to go up, it was said - $12 a night, $15 dollars a night, no one was sure how much. The renovations were nearly complete, the new bathrooms and shower stalls put in place. Other hotels along the Bowery that had once been flophouses had been redone recently and the owners had started to rent by the night to tourists, some charging as much as $30 and $40. Late in the week, a small article buried in the bottom corner of a page in the middle of the New York Post carried the headline 'Bowery man held in fatal stabbing'. It was reported that the man who had been resident on the fourth floor of the Providence had been arrested. He had killed one man and seriously wounded two others, it was said, and he had been subdued by a security guard and an auxiliary cop after he had attacked a Chinatown shoe-store owner with a knife in broad daylight. He 'stabbed people who rubbed him the wrong way,' the article said. The shoe-store owner had looked at him in a manner he found offensive. One of the other stabbings had been caused when he grew angered at a man who spat on the pavement. The same day that the Post story ran, Stevie rose early and walked to his methadone clinic, then caught the train out to Long Island to visit his parents. He did his laundry, had a shower, and picked up a winter jacket and thermal underwear; his mother gave him boxes of cereal and a jar of peanut butter, and a few cans of soup; she slipped him $20. His mother was pushing the idea of him getting into a detox programme, Stevie said when he got back to the hotel that night. He said he was seriously considering the prospect of trying to quit methadone and the pharmacy-worth of pills he was hooked on. There was a place in the city called The Realization Center that he was thinking of trying. The next day, Stevie asked me if I would buy him a cup of coffee. We went to a bakery on the Bowery and Stevie chain-smoked cigarettes, his fingers yellowed with nicotine stains. He ate lemon rolls. He said he had walked by an automotive repair shop just off the Bowery that specialised in imports and, for a moment, contemplated going inside and applying for a job, but the place was a dump, he said, and he didn't want to risk using his tools and getting them damaged or stolen. His tools were worth $10,000, he said, and he could sell them but he never would; that was like a writer giving up his pen, an artist giving up his brushes. Stevie said he hadn't shot heroin that day or on Sunday, when his cat had spilled his dose of methadone. He said he had changed his mind that Sunday once he got to his dealer's room on the fifth floor of the hotel, despite the aching pain of withdrawal. Stevie rolled up the sleeve of his sweatshirt to prove that he hadn't shot heroin. His arms were ravaged with angry, open sores and needle marks. Seemingly unaware of the contradictions in his story, or what the scars on his emaciated arms told of his situation, he said he couldn't shoot heroin by himself. He had a lot of good veins left, he said, but he was afraid of getting an air bubble in the syringe that would go straight to his heart. He said he had to pay a friend - the junkie who lived across the hallway from him in the Providence - a couple of bucks to get him high. He walked out on to the Bowery, into the crisp autumn air, and he said he was depressed because he had gone to The Realization Center for an assessment that day and had been given the dual diagnoses of CD and MI - chemically dependent, mentally incompetent. He had been put in a holding room with people who couldn't even talk, with zombies. He feared he was going to be stuck in the Providence for the next 30 years. His biggest worry, the thing he cared about most in the world, was what to do with his cat if he entered a programme to try to get straight. 'If I could get my cat into my parents' house, I'd leave the Providence today,' he said. I took the train to Stevie's home on Long Island where the autumn leaves on the trees were red and puce and gold. The town was, as Stevie said, affluent, with quiet, winding streets, massive estates hidden behind steel gates and a Norman Rockwellian red-brick high school where Stevie had once been a student. Stevie's parents lived in a modest two-storey house in a less-wealthy quarter of the town. The living room was decorated with throw rugs and stuffed dolls and portraits of their daughter's graduation and wedding. Stevie's mother wore a cardigan and jeans and a pair of half-moon reading glasses strung on a necklace. His father, a retired investigator for the federal government, was a thin, softly spoken man, and he sat at the dining table smoking a pipe. They had given Stevie $120 a month, for years, they said; Stevie knew when his mother's social security cheque arrived, and he always came out from the Providence to collect the money. Stevie's mother said she always dreaded his visits. She also lived in dread that Stevie wouldn't arrive and she wouldn't know if he was alive or dead. Stevie had told me he was 37, but his parents said he was really 43. 'We're both about to turn 70,' his father said, 'and soon we'll be gone and Stevie is going to have to fend for himself.' Stevie's mother played a message from Stevie she had saved from their answering machine that morning. 'I'm taking $500 to leave my room,' he said on the recording. 'I'm going to leave the cat, because you promised me you would take the cat, but obviously you're not going to do that. It's obvious I'm going to die, so I might as well die on the streets. You know, $500 will be enough to give me a nice overdose.' Stevie's parents said that his troubles had been going on for years, and it had become impossible to clearly distinguish one event from another. They had made mistakes as parents, they said. 'We've apologised many times,' his mother said. 'We're not perfect people, or perfect parents. We all make mistakes. He was the first born, so he got more than the others. We're sorry, drop it, let it go, get on with your life.' Stevie's mother said that they had moved from a working-class neighbourhood to their new affluent town when Stevie was in grade school and that he had never fitted in with the more well-to-do kids. Stevie's father said he had suffered a nervous breakdown when Stevie was a teenager, and Stevie had started to steal his quaaludes. The heavy drinking and marijuana and LSD and, eventually, heroin came later. They had bought Stevie BMWs over the years and paid for his training as a mechanic; he had wrecked the cars and lost a string of jobs. Stevie's father said that their other children, their daughters, had grown to hate the way Stevie's troubles affected the family. On their eldest daughter's wedding day, Stevie had turned up at the house high, and his mother refused to let him in. Stevie shot up on the front step; his mother watched from the kitchen window as he injected the needle and swore at them that he would be dead by the time they returned from the church. Since Stevie had moved into the Providence, six and a half years earlier, he had continued to come out to his parents' house to sleep from time to time. His mother and father were terrified that he would fall asleep with a cigarette and burn the house down, though, and they had made him sleep in the basement, where the floor was concrete. Stevie hadn't been allowed to stay the night for the past few months; during his visits, his father, exhausted by the repeated accusations and demands, had begun to retreat to a room on the second floor and stayed until his son left. His mother said that tough love, which they tried to practise, following the advice of drug counsellors and others who had experience in such matters, was hard to live out. 'It's very difficult for a mother to hear that your child hasn't eaten anything,' she said. 'Intellectually, you understand what to do, but emotionally it's very difficult.' Outside, Stevie's mother and father opened the garage door and showed me the tools Stevie had told me about. The red Craftmaster tools were locked, and there was an empty pill bottle on top. They had bought the set for him at Sears: the tools were worth $800, not $10,000. Stevie's mother said she wished he would get into a good rehab programme, one that lasted a full year. The problem, she said, was that they couldn't afford to pay for it, and Stevie wasn't covered by their medical insurance. 'If there was some place out there for him to go,' Stevie's mother said, her voice trailing away. 'I wish I'd win the Lotto. I would put him in some place. That's what I wish.' The lobby in the Providence was closed off entirely by the end of October. There were now two security doors near the front desk: one for the residents staying on the main floor, in the new rooms next to what had once been the lobby; the other, a black, prison-like steel door that led to the stairway upstairs, for the men living in one of the three floors above. The renovation was complete. With no lobby, the men had to keep to their rooms to stay out of the cold. The men I had met in the lobby of the Providence had scattered to the four winds. Turk, it was said, went on a drinking jag and blew in a matter of days the cash the owners had given him; the last report was that he was sleeping in the subway. Raul, no longer able to rely on the free meal provided nightly in the lobby, had found a job working the midnight shift in a bakery in lower Manhattan. He said things were going good, that he had some responsibility for money and was proud of that. He just hoped he could keep it together. In early November, precisely 30 days after I had set out to report on a month in the lives of the men and hotel, Stevie disappeared from the Providence. Around midnight that night, for no reason other than a growing sense of unease, I checked my answering machine and there was a message from Stevie's mother. 'I have some sad news for you,' she said. 'Stevie was killed by an automobile walking from the railway station to our house this evening.' Late that afternoon, in the gathering dusk, Stevie's train had pulled into his home town on Long Island. He had called his mother from the station. He had said that he was on his way home. He had been walking off the footpath, on the edge of the road against the oncoming traffic, as he made his way along the main route. A van had rounded a bend and hit him head on. Stevie's mother had been waiting for him when she heard the town's emergency siren go off, the alarm screaming throughout the village. Sleepout Jackie, who lived in the hallway next to Stevie's on the fourth floor and who had feuded with him over the years, said that none of the men in the hotel had mourned his passing. 'He was shooting his arm up every fucking day,' Sleepout said. 'He haunted people. Nobody misses him.' The night Stevie was killed, the handful of flophouses on the Bowery was scarcely noticeable, as always sheltered in the shadows cast by the street lights. A lone man stumbled along the pavement, his thick glasses askew. The man was carrying a crumpled paper bag with a bottle of liquor in it, and every few paces he stopped and took a long drink. Upstairs in the Providence, the windows in the room that had once been the lobby were blackened. The men in the hotel had lost their only gathering place, the only place for them to sit out of the weather, eat, watch Wheel of Fortune. In Far Rockaway, on the farthest margins of the city, there were the beginnings of the next last resort. On the Bowery, the time when a man alone in the world had found refuge, of a kind, in the heart of the city was slipping deeper into the past.

webTitle: Patrice Leconte: Happy not to be critics' choice

fields.headline: Happy not to be critics' choice
fields.standfirst: Patrice Leconte caused a storm last year when he attacked France's negative reviewers. Now, he has an acclaimed new film.  So why is he 'unable to take himself seriously'? Interview  by  Damon Wise
fields.trailText: Patrice Leconte caused a storm last year when he attacked France's negative reviewers. Now, he has an acclaimed new film. So why is he 'unable to take himself seriously'? Interview by Damon Wise.
fields.body:
In the last few weeks of the twentieth century Patrice Leconte was the most talked-about director in France. Every major newspaper ran articles and editorials devoted to him, praising him and deriding him. But the strange thing was, Leconte didn't have a film out at the time.

The entire debacle was a mistake. What actually happened on 13 October 1999 was that Leconte finally put down on paper some of the thoughts that had been vexing him over the past few years. The French media, Leconte felt, was not supportive enough of the indigenous film industry.

At the height of the New Wave French critics and film directors had been pretty much indistinguishable, most - like Francois Truffaut, Jean-Luc Godard and Claude Chabrol - swapping the typewriter for a movie camera after serving an apprenticeship on pioneering intellectual film magazine Cahiers Du Cinema.

Nowadays, thought Leconte, critics were simply acting as judge, jury and executioner, effectively killing French films before they could even reach their intended audience. In a private letter to the Society of Auteurs, Directors and Producers, Leconte said the issue was nearing crisis point and suggested a summit meeting. He also added a list of the publications whose reviews he felt were most damaging, but as a result of an administrative slip-up, his memo ended up being faxed to them as well. The next day, all hell broke loose.

Was it really an accident or was he being disingenuous? And if it was an accident, was he really so surprised by the reaction? Actually, yes. Leconte, 52, a modest, wiry and conservatively dressed man, recalls the affair with detachment and perhaps a little irritation. 'I was surprised,' he says quietly, 'because of the scale of the whole thing. It just became huge. It blew up so much. When the critics - and that's a very small portion of specific, targeted critics - started writing pages and pages and pages I was shocked, really. I felt like saying, "Do you realise what a state you're getting yourself into?" Because, initially, all I wanted to say was "Please, just be a tiny bit careful about what you write, and show your readers that you really love cinema." But it just blew up beyond belief. And it really annoyed me.'

Interestingly, Leconte's new film is also about unlikely heroes. Starring Juliette Binoche, Daniel Auteuil and moonlighting film director Emir Kusturica, La Veuve De Saint Pierre takes place in 1850 and tells the story of an alcoholic sailor, Neel, who stabs a man to death in a drunken argument. The cause of the crime is beyond comprehension - in court, Neel recalls only that he cut the man open to settle an argument as to whether he was 'big or fat' - and the jury on the French-Canadian island of Saint Pierre sentences him to death. The problem is, there is no guillotine on the island, and even when one arrives in eight months time, there will be no one to act as executioner.

As he awaits his appointment with the chopping block, Neel is placed in the care of the Captain (Auteuil), whose wife, Madame La (Binoche), pleads for special allowances for the condemned man. Over the next eight months Neel is totally rehabilitated; he renounces drinking, carries out odd jobs for local widows and risks his life to save the town café and its owner.

As the execution date looms, the islanders begin to realise that the man who will die is not the same man who committed the crime and so they strive to stop the killing. Based on a true story, La Veuve is a surprisingly emotional and moving film from a director who usually presents his sharp intelligence in much more guarded terms, as in his breakthrough film, the Hitchcockian thriller, Monsieur Hire, made in 1989.

'I totally agree,' he says. 'But I knew that I had this desire to shoot a big melodrama, a film that would be a really novelistic film. Tragic. But obviously on condition that it would be with dignity, that it would be a very beautiful story.

'So, paradoxically, I was actually waiting for that kind of project. It wasn't that I was simply indulging myself by doing something different yet again. I wasn't chasing around after that. But I knew that, within me, there was this taste for the beautiful, sad things.'

That said, there's an extraordinary sense of wit underlying this apparently dark, morbid story. The idea, for example, that a convicted killer can charm the whole neighbourhood to become something of a local hero. And there's also the idea that, for all her good intentions, the socially conscious Madame La is simply pushing matters towards their obvious conclusion, while actually making things worse for herself and her doting husband.

To call it a black comedy would be going too far, but there's certainly something at odds with the ravishing, dark mood. 'I'm not consciously doing that,' says Leconte 'but it could be a reflection of my second nature. It's not necessarily humour you're seeing, but there is a kind of irony that comes through. And it's simply because I am incapable - violently incapable - of taking myself seriously. But it's also because in making this film - which I deeply wanted to do, was passionate about and which really moved me - I didn't want to risk becoming too heavy.'

Likewise, the film doesn't seem so concerned with history itself. Like Leconte's 1995 film Ridicule - another period film, which concerned itself with the social intrigues of the court of Louis XVI - La Veuve seems less interested in history than the conventions within it. 'You could say that,' he shrugs, 'but what interests me more is the customs of the people. I'm more interested in people as human beings, so obviously their behaviour is more interesting to me. But it's true that I haven't really got the soul of a historian. I was a very bad student in history at school and I haven't really changed much on that score. And so when I make a film like La Veuve , I apply my own sensitivity as a man of today. I didn't make the film by projecting myself into the past.'

After the furore about French critics and French film, how was La Veuve treated in its homeland? 'Basically, they pissed me off by writing things that were nothing. The specific targeted papers just wrote stuff that was very tepid. Neither good nor bad. It was the worst attitude, actually. But at the same time, I don't regret having caused such a stink. It wasn't a bad thing because it had a positive outcome; on the first of January - the first day of the new century - I made a resolution. I swore to myself that never again would I read reviews, either of my films or of the others. And for a very simple reason: when you read a good review it makes you feel good for a little while, but when you read a bad review, the damage can be very harmful.'

So it's unlikely that Leconte will be reading any press on his new film, Felix And Lola, which he shot almost back-to-back with La Veuve - and with good reason.

'I often shoot films straight away because I like to be in the middle of a shoot while the previous film is coming out,' he says. 'I like to keep myself busy, otherwise if you're not, you're at home, waiting for the figures to come in.'

He sighs.

'It's just too stressful!'

Tales of obsession: three of Leconte's finest

Hairdresser's Husband (1990)
An entrancing and deeply erotic love story between an enigmatic hairdresser and a middle-aged man . The plot is negligible, revolving around their frenetic sex life and strange behaviour. But the pleasure is all in the details.

Le Parfum d'Yvonne (1994)
Set during a heady summer on Lake Geneva in the Fifties. A young writer seeks refuge from military service and the Algerian War, falling in love with a cool beauty and embarking on a sensual journey of self discovery.

Ridicule (1996)
Trenchant comedy set during the reign of Louis XVI. An idealistic baron goes to court to win funds for a drainage system to benefit his peasants. There he discovers a gift for courtly humour and fame which threatens to corrupt him.

 La Veuve De Saint Pierre opens 4 August

fields.headline: The Screws missile
fields.standfirst: Last week the youngest ever editor of the world's biggest-selling English language newspaper was roundly vilified for printing sex offenders' pictures. But the red-top's red-top is unmoved
fields.trailText: A 'nasty piece of work'. 'Nonce-finder general.' A 'crude newspaper thug'. Not the kind of names you expect to be called unless, that is, you are a tabloid editor. Editing a popular newspaper is a rough business. To do the job you need rhino-thick skin, heavyweight confidence and the kind of composure that makes the Dalai Lama look skittish. Tough it may be at the red-top but few editors have had to put up with the scorn heaped upon the 31-year-old shoulders of Rebekah Wade, editor of the News of the World.
fields.body:
A 'nasty piece of work'. 'Nonce-finder general.' A 'crude newspaper thug'. Not the kind of names you expect to be called unless, that is, you are a tabloid editor. Editing a popular newspaper is a rough business. To do the job you need rhino-thick skin, heavyweight confidence and the kind of composure that makes the Dalai Lama look skittish. Tough it may be at the red-top but few editors have had to put up with the scorn heaped upon the 31-year-old shoulders of Rebekah Wade, editor of the News of the World.

Wade's decision to publish the names and photographs of 50 of Britain's 110,000 convicted sex offenders is the most controversial tabloid 'stunt' since the Sun - deputy editor at the time Rebekah Wade - ran photographs of Sophie Rhys-Jones topless. Then the chorus of disapproval forced the Sun to admit it had 'gone too far' and apologise. Now in the editor's chair, Wade is standing firm.

The youngest editor in Fleet Street insists her 'For Sarah' campaign - which continues today with more photos of shifty-looking members of the dirty mac brigade and a call for a public register of sex offenders - is 'not for some cheap publicity' but an 'extremely well-thought out campaign'. Others tell a different story. They insist the paper had no 'splash' - front page lead - last week and in desperation sent a reporter to rummage through the Scout Association files.

Whatever the truth behind the headlines, one thing is certain: 'flame-haired' Rebekah Wade - the red-top's red-top - has arrived. Everyone is talking about her and her paper. She has made enemies - Paul Dacre, her idol and editor of the Daily Mail, has described her as a 'rabble rouser' - and some unusual new friends - Stephen Glover, the acerbic media columnist of the Spectator, has dismissed the furore surrounding her as 'hysteria'.

For her part, Wade is saying little. She has turned down all requests for interviews repeating the Murdoch mantra that the newspaper should do the talking, not the editor. Friends say she does not enjoy explaining herself in public. A quick trawl through the cuttings files confirms her reticence. She has never done an interview with a broadsheet.

So what do we know about Rebekah? Talk to anyone about Wade for more than 30 seconds and the same words crop up: psychotic drive and terrifying ambition. 'She is so focused it's scary,' one friend says. 'Her life is her work and her hobby. I have never seen her do anything else. She works all the hours God sends.' She started early. Wade, who comes from Daresbury in Cheshire, decided she wanted to be a journalist shortly after her fourteenth birthday. At secondary school she spent the weekends and holidays hanging around Eddie Shah's Messenger titles in Warrington, 'just making tea and helping out'.

After completing her A-levels at a grammar school in Cheshire, she spent a couple of years living in Paris - she speaks fluent French - contributing articles to the magazine, Architecture Aujourd'hui. In 1988 she returned to Britain to work for the Post, Shah's ill-fated quality national tabloid.

There she met old Fleet Street hand Charlie Rae who got her her first break in tabloid journalism by helping her to land a job on the News of the World's Sunday magazine when she was just 20. Over the next nine years she rose to become features editor on Sunday magazine, then assistant to the paper's then editor Phil Hall and finally his deputy.

When the number two job at the Sun came vacant and Hall was asked who should fill it, he replied 'Rebekah, of course'. Two years later in May this year she ousted her old boss to become the youngest ever editor of the world's biggest-selling English language newspaper.

Editing a red-top Sunday is a gruelling business but friends say she thrives on her schedule. Five days a week she gets up at 7am and goes to the Harbour Club near the Battersea home she shares with her partner - actor Ross 'Grant Mitchell' Kemp. She works out and reads all the papers. She makes phone calls as her driver takes her across town to Wapping, arriving at the office at 10.30am. She chairs meetings, talks to staff, lunches a contact or two, has more meetings and stays until around 9pm when she heads off to the Ivy for a working dinner with a politician, industrialist or celebrity where Kemp often joins her.

Wade may have the drive of a legendary tabloid editor like Kelvin Mackenzie of the Sun but there the similarities with the traditional tabloid boss stop. True, she chain-smokes, enjoys a drink and has a weakness for Gucci, but she rarely swears and does not administer the bollockings of tabloid folklore. Unlike many of the brassy, push-up bra brigade of tabloid hackettes, male colleagues praise her cool get-the-job-done professionalism that befit a founder member of the support network Women in Journalism who tried to persuade Rupert Murdoch to dump Page Three topless models. 'She is charming and she is a woman but I have never seen her flirt to try to get what she wants. She thinks she is a woman doing a big job and that's the end of it,' one male colleague says.

Another praises her 'listening skills' and charm - not qualities tabloid editors are renowned for. 'She is a brilliant fixer. She can persuade people who would usually run a mile from the tabloids to talk,' one colleague recalls. Unlike a lot of women in tabloid newspapers who have stuck to feature writing, former colleagues at the Sun praise her grasp of daily news from the front page to the back. 'She has a real knack of knowing things that you would not expect her to know. She is surprisingly knowledgeable about football and business,' one remembers. .

She may be good in the office - and spend a lot of time in it - but she has never lost sight of the secret of successful journalism - contacts. Wade has a little black - Gucci probably - address book to die for. She has carefully cultivated Cherie Blair - earning a very public seal-of-approval hug from the prime minister's wife at a Labour centenary gala dinner. Among her closest friends are Elisabeth Murdoch, her boss's daughter, Matthew Freud, Elisabeth's partner and PR-meister, and dozens of celebrities. 'She is frighteningly well-connected and right on top of the game,' one colleague says.

In fact, talking to red-top hacks it is hard to recognise the woman who has been vilified all week as the lynch mob queen. Finding someone with a bad word to say about her is near-impossible. The worst anyone can come up with is 'a question mark over how well she can play the big political game - calling general elections right, the stuff Rupert (Murdoch) really likes.'

Being a popular editor of a red-top paper at the age of 31 would be enough for most hacks, but not Wade. Her ultimate goal is to become the first female editor of the Sun. None of her female predecessors in the Sunday red-top market - Wendy Henry, Patsy Chapman or Bridget Rowe - have made the leap. Few doubt Wade has got the talent and age is on her side. The only possible snag lies at home. Kemp has said he wants children. Friends say Wade does too. But editing Britain's biggest daily with young children would almost certainly be too much for someone even with Wade's stamina.

But that's for another time. Today the News of the World's latest perverts' gallery will be condemned by the chattering classes and its editor will go on insisting that she, not they, are in tune with the public mood. She is probably right. What's more, it is a great tabloid attention-seeking story and she knows it. As Phil Hall, her former boss at the News of the World, puts it: 'The thing about Rebekah is that she is simply a great newspaperwoman. She gets terrific stories, promotes them brilliantly and is smart enough to let the rest take care of itself.' Rebekah Wade

fields.headline: Videos
fields.standfirst: American Beauty | The Last Contract | Chance or Coincidence | The League of Gentlemen
fields.trailText: American Beauty | The Last Contract | Chance or Coincidence | The League of Gentlemen
fields.body:
American Beauty (pictured) (1999, 18, Universal, VHS/ Rental)
Multiple Oscar-winning debut by British theatre-director Sam Mendes, a smooth satire on American suburban conformity, the Protestant work ethic and the illusionary national dream, starring Kevin Spacey as a 42-year-old drop-out with a teenage daughter and a frigid estate-agent wife (Annette Bening) who both hate him. Scripted by a writer-producer of TV's Cybill, it's sophisticated, superficial, well-acted and attention holding, but has few claims to originality.

The Last Contract (1997, 15, Eureka, VHS/ Retail, Rental)
Directed by Kjell Sundvall, this provocative co-production between Norway, Finland and Sweden, a Scandinavian Day of the Jackal, goes straight to video in Britain. A hired assassin (Michael Kitchen) has flats in Valletta and London and contacts the world over. His target is Sweden's left-wing Prime Minister Olof Palme, whose domestic policies and outspoken criticisms of other countries have made him enemies everywhere. We know that on 28 February 1986 Palme was murdered. But why, and by whom? This tense, gripping paranoid thriller (based on a novel by John W. Grow) suggests the CIA and the Swedish State Security Police, alarmed by Palme's attempt to make Scandinavia a nuclear-free zone, turned a blind eye to his would-be assassin. All that stands in the killer's way is a decent cop. Though not always plausible, it makes out as convincing a case as any for the death of Palme. Crisply shot in widescreen with subtitles and a lot of the dialogue in English.

Chance or Coincidence (1998, PG, Tartan, VHS, Rental/Retail)
For the fourth time Claude Lelouch directs his wife, Italian dancer Alessandra Martines. His swooningly romantic movie follows an Italian widow and a French history professor as their lives briefly bisect and then proceed on parallel lines as he becomes obsessed with meeting her. The philosophical ideas and reflections on art are ludicrous, but there's never a dull moment as the picture sweeps from Venice to Paris via Canada, Acapulco and Turkey, all magically recorded by one of France's best cinematographers, Pierre-William Glenn.

The League of Gentlemen (1960, PG, VCI, VHS/Rental)
One of the best British heist movies, this splendid comedy-thriller stars Jack Hawkins as a disgruntled ex-colonel who recruits a mess of disreputable cashiered officers to stage a military-style bank robbery. The witty script is co-authored by Bryan Forbes who also performs in an expert cast that includes Nigel Patrick, Richard Attenborough and Roger Livesey.

fields.headline: Trescothick facing his sternest Test
fields.trailText: One of the functions of the England selectors is to be vilified in the national press at regular intervals following a Test defeat. Just occasionally, though, they warrant a little pat on the back and in recent times, two of their less obvious choices show signs of bearing fruit.
fields.body:
One of the functions of the England selectors is to be vilified in the national press at regular intervals following a Test defeat. Just occasionally, though, they warrant a little pat on the back and in recent times, two of their less obvious choices show signs of bearing fruit.

There is Michael Vaughan. In the 1999 season he averaged a paltry 27 for Yorkshire yet was whisked off to South Africa and the signs are that they have unearthed a potential Test player for years to come (although he has only scored one half-century so far and that was in the 'dubious' Centurion Test match).

This summer they have plucked out Somerset's Marcus Trescothick (albeit after injuries to original one-day squad memebers) and they were rewarded by several sterling innings in the NatWest Series that suggest he is at home at this level. Trescothick, aged 24, a year younger than Vaughan, did not have a massive weight of runs to support his claims. And his career average at the start of this season - 29 - was modest by county, let alone international standards. Impressed by what they saw in those one dayers, Trescothick makes his Test debut at Old Trafford on Thursday.

Both Vaughan and Trescothick revealed their pedigree playing for England Under-19s. Six years ago the rectitude of Vaughan's technique stood out, while the easy power of Trescothick's strokeplay often took the breath away.

Trescothick, who played for the Under-19s for three years and scored more than a 1000 runs, a total exceeded only by John Crawley. It may be that he played too much Under-19 cricket. The debate over which should take priority - representing the Under-19s or playing cricket in the County Championship - still continues.

The English authorities think the representative match should hold sway, a different view to the Australians, who recently flew one of their Under-19 players back home from the World Cup in Sri Lanka to play a state match. The Aussies are wary of pampering their youngsters. Mind you, Trescothick has never been a swaggerer; he respects the game, loves it even, and his gentle humour and self-effacing manner have made him popular wherever he's played.

Until he was 19 Trescothick excelled at every level, despite always being a little podgy. His diet too often comprised of sausages and Mars bars, but it didn't seem to matter much because the runs kept flowing. Only recently has he recognised the need to be as fit and mobile as possible.

From the time he pottered along to the Bath cricket school of Peter Wight, the former Somerset player and umpire, for weekly sessions at the age of 11, his only obvious setback was that he was omitted from the West's Under-15s tour of the Caribbean on the grounds that he was not fit enough.

In 1994, at the age of 18, he played some blistering innings for Somerset as an opener before he was taken away by the Under-19s. Until last summer he was never as productive again. There would be the odd remarkable innings in between the failures (one of them was in the second team in 1997 when he made 322 in pursuit of 612 for victory - he was run out trying to retain the strike seven runs short of the target). Even in 1999, when he was made vice-captain of Somerset, he was inconsistent and the odd brilliant innings was interspersed with an infuriating failure often brought about by a wayward flirtation outside his off-stump.

Then on September 3 he played his best innings yet. It was against Glamorgan at Taunton on the fastest pitch seen in this country for years. In the second innings he cracked 167 while no other player surpassed 50 - ensuring an easy Somerset victory. Jacques Kallis, no slouch, was repeatedly pulled over the mid-wicket boundary. A bewildered Steve Watkin saw one of his deliveries dispatched back over his head into the graveyard. An awesome innings and a timely one as well. For sitting on the balcony was Duncan Fletcher, fulfiling his role as Glamorgan's coach before moving on to the England job. 'Who is this man?' he murmured.

On that innings alone Fletcher insisted that Trescothick should go on the A tour. He was not a spectacular success on the trip to Bangladesh and New Zealand but the whole experience must have toughened him up. For Trescothick relies on more than sheer natural talent now. He's fitter and more dedicated than he has ever been and they have noticed the gradual change at Somerset. He spent all winter in the indoor nets anxious to hone his game, which he did to good effect; the face of the bat is not so open now, which has led to much greater consistency this year.

At Southgate, where Somerset were bundled out for 58 in the NatWest, he was churning out shuttle runs post-dismissal. Last week he stayed behind in the nets with specific preparations for the Test to come, before packing his bags for Durham and a Championship match.

There have been well-wishers everywhere in the West country this week. They sent him off a little nervously though. They remember what happened to Mark Lathwell seven years ago, another special talent who joined the desperate and disparate side that faced the Australians.

At Keynsham in particular they will be anxiously monitoring his debut. Trescothick's parents are still stalwarts at Keynsham CC and Marcus has never forgotten his old club. Every year since he became a pro he has tried to play at least once for them. Although in light of Duncan Fletcher's intentions to withdraw contracted players from the Championship run-in in September, I'm none too sure when Somerset, let alone Keynsham, will see him again.

webTitle: Net firms set to flee RIP Bill

fields.headline: Net firms set to flee RIP Bill
fields.standfirst:
Top internet service provider ready to move systems abroad | Blue-chip clients express security fears
Special report: Privacy on the net
fields.trailText: Claranet, the UK's largest independent Internet Service Provider, is poised to move parts of its telecoms infrastructure abroad to protect the communications traffic of its blue chip clients from potential vetting by the security services.
fields.body:
Claranet, the UK's largest independent Internet Service Provider, is poised to move parts of its telecoms infrastructure abroad to protect the communications traffic of its blue chip clients from potential vetting by the security services.

The threat of vetting comes from the Government's Regulation of Investigatory Powers (RIP) Bill, which is expected to become law later this year after passing its House of Lords committee stage last week.

Claranet's decision is likely to set a precedent for other corporate-focused ISPs.

The Lords introduced a number of amendments to the Bill, but Steve Rawlinson, Claranet's systems manager, said these were insufficient to dispel the worries of some its larger clients that their communication systems might be compromised.

'A small but significant number of our largest customers, which include several financial institutions, have expressed concerns about the RIP Bill to us,' Rawlinson said. 'If it goes through in its current form, we will look to relocate some of our services overseas.

'We've already developed the technology to move them abroad very easily. We will offer our UK customers the opportunity to locate them [their data services] outside the UK.'

Claranet, which has more than 350,000 users in Britain, is the highest-profile ISP looking to make such a move. UUnet, Poptel, the Co-operative Internet Service Provider, and GreenNet are considering the idea, too. Others have indicated that they are sympathetic to those looking abroad.

Demon Internet, owned by Thus (formerly Scottish Telecom) recently stated: 'We've already seen betting organisations move their Web servers offshore to enjoy offering tax- free betting... How many reasons do we want to give our innovators and entrepreneurs to move out of the country?'

Similarly, PSINet, the Internet solutions company which claims to work with a quarter of the world's biggest firms, has said: 'If the Bill is passed, PSINet will have to seriously reconsider whether the UK is an appropriate place for electronic commerce at all.'

Alexander Hazell, the company's lawyer, said: 'There is secondary legislation to come in draft stages that we will need to see before making a decision. The devil is in the detail.'

Some commentators have suggested that the ISPs were simply trying to scare the Government into axing large chunks of the Bill. But Rawlinson insisted: 'People need to understand how easy it is to achieve. It's a very straightforward cost-free exercise.

As well as the perceived threat to the UK's burgeoning e-commerce sector - viewed by the Government as crucial to the country's future prosperity - ISPs are angry that they may have to pay some of the costs of implementing the law - which the British Chamber of Commerce fears could total £60 million a year.

Other industry observers fear even worse drawbacks. 'I think it will have a much bigger effect on those companies looking to set up European data centres,' said Tim Pearson, a member of the Internet Service Providers' Association council. 'This is a reason not to do it over here. You won't see these people packing their bags.'
