fields.headline: Gross profits
fields.standfirst: Bad taste comedies looked like a tired genre. But a new film,  Scary Movie, which boasts low-brow gags and spoofs horror movies, has beaten its blockbuster rivals at the US box-office. Report by  Mark Morris
fields.trailText: Bad taste comedies looked like a tired genre. But a new film, Scary Movie, which boasts low-brow gags and spoofs horror movies, has beaten its blockbuster rivals at the US box-office. Report by Mark Morris.
fields.body:
The weakest idea of the year? The most predictable? Or just the most redundant? On paper, Scary Movie is all these things. Considering that the whole point of the Scream trilogy was that it played on the absurdity of horror clichés, to attempt a parody seems surreally pointless.

US critics agree. 'Hasn't it all been done to death?' sighed a despairing New York Times . The only thing Scary Movie seemed to have going for it was that the cumbersome titles of the two scripts melded together to make the film - Last Summer I Screamed Because Friday the 13th Fell on Halloween and Scream if I Know What You Did Last Halloween - had been dumped in favour of what was Scream 's original name.

But none of that troubled the American public - or at least the teenagers - who rushed to see the film. Scary Movie had the second-best opening weekend of the summer after Mission: Impossible 2 . And since its budget was around a tenth of MI:2's - or slightly less than Tom Cruise's salary - it instantly went into profit.

So what's going on here? Not only has the Scream cycle long since worn out its novelty, but making jokes about those movies is hardly less stale, since it has already been done on a dozen TV shows. One of the other films Scary Movie sends up is the Blair Witch Project : when the film was being written that must have seemed like a topical reference; now, it's a sketch that Hale and Pace would reject as past its sell-by date.

The prime of the parody genre was even longer ago, before it was worn out by Leslie Neilsen's reluctance to turn down work after Airplane revived his career. And it turns out that the Scream If I Know What You Did Last Halloween script was the work of the men who wrote Spy Hard (1996), one of the later, lesser Neilsen movies.

Last Summer I Screamed Because Friday the 13th Fell on Halloween, meanwhile, was written by Shawn and Marlon Wayans, previously responsible for Don't Be a Menace to South Central While Drinking Your Juice in the Hood (1996), a spoof of the brief outbreak of ghetto reality movies.

When Miramax bought both scripts, it was the Wayans brothers along with their friends Buddy Johnson and Phil Beauman who were given the responsibility of turning them into something, if not coherent ('It's not like plot was the overriding thing,' says Miramax's Bob Weinstein), then at least packed with the requisite number of gags per minute.

If the writers had no great track record, neither did the stars. Not unless you count Shannon Elizabeth - she played the eastern European girl in American Pie - as famous. Or would pay money to see a couple of min utes work from former Baywatch girl/Dennis Rodman's ex-wife Carmen Electra, who does the Drew Barrymore/celebrity first victim role.

All of which explains why the pundits were so genuinely taken aback when Scary Movie accelerated past long anticipated, star-powered blockbusters like The Patriot . What was going on? You can find the answer in the New York Times , but not in the film review. Beneath it there is a brief explanation of why the film merits its 'R' certificate: 'It consists almost entirely of vulgar sexual references, gory violence, depictions of drug use and references to nasal, genital and lower-intestinal bodily functions.'

It's surprising the distributors didn't blow that up and stick it on the poster. In fact, there has been some bafflement about how the film managed to pick up an R, rather than the more commercially damaging NC-17. One answer seems to be that some of the male genitalia and pubic hair in the film are fake and therefore somehow acceptable. The other is that these days, you can get away with most things as long as the film is a comedy.

As far as anyone has been able to count, Scary Movie has set new records for the range of naked body parts on show in a mainstream movie. So forget about its in-jokes about Scream and The Sixth Sense: the reason Scary Movie has done so well is that it is this summer's big gross-out movie. After There's Something About Mary and American Pie, everyone was expecting that there would be at least one supremely tasteless hit over the holiday season. Most thought it would be Bobby and Peter Farrelly's Me, Myself & Irene, which had an obvious headstart with Jim Carrey in the lead role(s). And if not that, then possibly Road Trip, which features headline-grabbing MTV shock king Tom Green.

Instead, following the rule of brothers that has given us the Farrellys and the Weitzes (the writers of American Pie), it was the Wayans - who also star in the film - who came out on top. There is nothing complicated about what they have done: girls in bikinis, sperm, snot and old women getting run over by pianos - it's a simple formula for success. They've just done more of it, pushed the boundaries that little bit further.

Having a multi-racial cast (the Wayans are black), and some jokes aimed directly at a black audience probably didn't hurt either. What's interesting about Scary Movie is that it forgoes the romance and hints of decency and human warmth that Something About Mary and American Pie used to balance the vomit and sperm gags. Even South Park creators Trey Parker and Matt Stone have insisted there is an 'overlying sweetness' to their work.

But Scary Movie doesn't do that - it couldn't really, given the spoof genre. This has meant that a couple of US critics have put themselves in the absurd position of citing the Farrellys - last seen as evidence of Western civilisation on its very last legs - as representing a kinder, more decent age (last year, perhaps?).

The problem with the Wayans, Salon on-line magazine suggested, is that they don't come across like naughty schoolboys. Which has to be the first time this has been an insult. However, the effect of Scary Movie will be that the MPAA (the US ratings board) will have a tough time with next year's batch of comedies: somewhere out there a studio executive is surely screaming 'Old women's breasts are so over! Give me more testicles!'

The film is a vindication of sorts for the sprawling Wayans family. In 1990 Damon Wayans - not in this film - was sharing star billing with Bruce Willis in The Last Boy Scout . But since the heyday of influential sketch show In Living Color, the Wayans have been a touch left behind by ex-colleagues Jim Carrey and Jennifer Lopez. Recently, Shawn and Marlon's sitcom - the imaginatively titled Wayans Bros - was cancelled, a move the network might be regretting now. Scary Movie was directed by eldest brother Keenan Ivory, whose career started with the blaxploitation spoof I'm Going To Git You Sucka in 1988, but who has only directed one film since. Now he is responsible for what will be the most commercially successful movie yet made by a black American.

The other siblings who have come out looking clever are the Weinsteins. On the one hand, they soothe Hollywood's bourgeois conscience: sweeping through the Oscars every year, protecting the business from accusations of rampant philistinism with movies like Shakespeare In Love . On the other, their Dimension Pictures wing cranks out horror and teen hits at (comparatively) rock bottom prices.

Other moguls might have felt more protective about their cash cow series of films: Bob Weinstein decided that if someone was going to make money spoofing the Scream series, it might as well be Dimension. And thus it chalked up another huge hit, made for under $20 million.

The bad news? Since Scary Movie truly was the most predictable film of the year, it is no surprise that the competing I Know What You Screamed Last Semester , with the unlikely pairing of Tom Arnold and rapper Coolio, is already on the way. Not to mention Scary Movie 2. Resign yourselves: there is no end in sight...

Blazing a trail from risque to rude

Hard to imagine, but on-screen flatulence was a big deal 25 years ago. The infamous cowboys 'n' campfire scene in Blazing Saddles was as gross as it got. 'It was so outside the bounds of manners that no one had ever put it on screen before,' recalls co-writer Andrew Bergman. 'It was kind of historic.'

It was also very funny. Ditto Woody Allen dressing as a giant sperm in Everything You Always Wanted to Know About Sex But Were Afraid to Ask .

Arthouse provocateur John Waters claimed he was challenging complacent moviegoers when Divine snacked on real dog excrement in Pink Flamingos, but as the boundaries of taste were pushed back, the temptations of fraternity house humour proved too much. In the Eighties, the success of Animal House and Porky's relied on an unsophisticated mix of Carry On and Mad magazine antics, inspiring many imitators. Now, anything goes. Gross comedies want to show audiences those crude scenes they've never seen on film before. In recent years a raft of relatively low-budget, teen-friendly comedies have become hits on the back of revealing trailers promising shocking things about bodily functions.

The cinema is no place for coyness. Before they've paid for the popcorn, moviegoers know they're going to see something GROSS, involving: apple pie (American Pie), 'hair gel' (There's Something About Mary) or Winona Ryder (South Park: Bigger, Longer and Uncut).

And these films can look forward to a long and profitable life in video rental shops. With the aid of rewind you can savour those moments again and again...

 Scary Movie opens in Britain later this year

webTitle: Music meanies plug the hole - but the dam has already burst

fields.headline: Music meanies plug the hole - but the dam has already burst
fields.standfirst:
Net news
Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Last week a Californian judge granted the Blue Meanies of the Recording Industry Association of America an injunction shutting down the NapsterNapster> site for the time being.
fields.body:
Last week a Californian judge granted the Blue Meanies of the Recording Industry Association of America an injunction shutting down the Napster site for the time being. This decision will no doubt come as a great relief to the moguls running the organised racket known as the music industry. After months of defensive warfare they have plugged the hole in the dyke. Trebles all round?

Er, no. To see why, you have to understand the technology. Napster turns your computer into a specialised kind of server. If you had MP3 music files that you were willing to share, you registered them with Napster's database. Thousands of others have done the same with the result that if you wanted a particular track by, say, Elton John, the database would tell you which computers had it. If any of them happened to be connected to the net at the time, then your Napster program requested a copy and the holding machine dispatched it to you.

It's called 'peer-to-peer' networking and it has spread like wildfire, much to the fury of the record industry, which sued Napster on the grounds that most MP3 files are pirated and that the company encourages copyright violation by pointing to the locations of bootleg audio. Napster mounted a vigorous defence but has lost the first skirmish of the legal war.

Nobody knows how the case will pan out in the end but, in a sense, it doesn't matter because the peer- to-peer genie (like the MP3 genie) is out of the bottle. The Achilles' heel of Napster was that it needed a central database, which presented the RIAA with a fixed target at which to aim. But already there are other distributed storage systems like Gnutella and Freenet which file stuff all over the net and yet can still retrieve it at will. Not even the record companies are up to the challenge of these fiendish new schemes.

Peer-to-peer networking is significant for several reasons. The first is that the files that are being shared don't have to be bootleg audio recordings - or even MP3 files. They can be any kind of file - including ones that Jack Straw & Co don't want you to see.

Second, the precipitous spread of the technology refutes the general assumptions of the media industry about their customers - that they are essentially passive zombies who are only interested in consuming the pap that Time Warner & Co want to push at them. What Napster shows is that if you give people technology for sharing and communicating then they will use it.

But perhaps the most important aspect of the Napster phenomenon is what it reveals about the future of broadband technology. The film, television and music industries believe that the huge increases in bandwidth that are in the offing will mainly benefit content providers - by which they mean them. What, after all, would Joe Public want with a fat pipe to the net, other than to consume video on demand?

Actually, Joe Public quite fancies broadband technology because he is already generating quite a lot of content himself which he wishes to share but is prevented by the prohibitive upload times imposed by ye olde telephone line.

Where is this home-grown content coming from? The multimedia lip curls in contempt at the thought of ordinary people originating anything worth transmitting. The answer, however, lies in your local Dixons, Comet or John Lewis store, where people are buying digital still and video cameras and minidisc recorders in very large numbers. These devices produce huge files - a 2.4 mega pixel portrait of baby Johnny, say, or a 50 megabyte video of the kids inhaling jelly at the school fair - which, in an ideal world, one would like to send to Grandma as an email attachment. For ideal, read broadband.

webTitle: Unmasked net porn gang face arrest in Britain

fields.headline: Unmasked net porn gang face arrest in Britain
fields.trailText: A huge internet pornography empire set up by a group of Edinburgh University graduates who boasted of their ability to evade the law has been closed down by the authorities in Antigua.
fields.body:
A huge internet pornography empire set up by a group of Edinburgh University graduates who boasted of their ability to evade the law has been closed down by the authorities in Antigua.

A week after The Observer revealed how they were exploiting Antigua's offshore banking regime to rake in a fortune from a stable of slickly produced hardcore sex sites, the founders of the Rhino Corporation have been deported as undesirables by the Caribbean island's government, which is now moving to forfeit the company's considerable, ill-gotten assets.

For almost three years, the three men and one woman behind Rhino stayed one step ahead of the law as they steadily grew to become major players in the overcrowded world of internet pornography.

With all their profits being paid into Rhino's offshore bank accounts in Antigua, the group carried out all their day-to-day financial transactions using company credit cards in an attempt to keep police off their scent. They had also changed their names, operating under the assumed identities of Amber, Jason and Mark Rhino, and DragonKing.

The Observer can now reveal their real identities. Amber is Rebecca Thomas from Henley-on-Thames; Jason Rhino is Jason Freeman, from Amersham; and Mark Rhino is Mark Corti, from London.

The three met at Edinburgh and, after graduating, set up Rhino in 1998 along with the fourth member, DragonKing, an American national called Vincent Head. He has now been returned to the United States where he faces prosecution for criminal offences carried out in New York. In the wake of The Observer's disclosures last week, it emerged that he was wanted by the US authorities on felony charges and was the subject of an extradition warrant.

The three Britons will not face further prosecution in Antigua after being deported, but police in this country may be keen to talk to them. When Rhino went into business in Edinburgh, it tried to get round Britain's strict obscenity laws by using webspace rented from US hosting companies specialising in porn sites.

The operation came to the attention of police, however, and the group was put under surveillance. Detectives believed they were posting pornographic material on to their sites from this country, which would have come under the criminal offence of handling and distributing obscene materials. But the group ducked out of sight and shifted their operation to Antigua just before Edinburgh officers moved in. In a move which infuriated police, the four placed a picture of themselves lounging on a white Caribbean beach, beers in hand, on one of their promotional sites.

As a result, the sudden and spectacular demise of Rhino has delighted British officers. 'This is a spectacular result,' one senior source told The Observer. 'They thought they could make us look like monkeys and they thought they had made themselves invincible and now they are finding out how wrong they were.'

The Antiguan authorities are now in the process of closing down Rhino's stable of 10 hardcore sites, whose titles ranged from 'Wives Exposed' to 'Dirty Teens', a site run by Thomas that specialised in material involving young girls. The company also made a fortune, under the name Flash Cash, by sponsoring smaller porn operations to get their users to subscribe to Rhino's sites.

It claimed that the island's regulatory regime was so lax that owners of offshore companies could mask their identities, move assets around under the noses of the tax authorities and render themselves virtually immune from prosecution. It also claimed that the island did not have stringent obscenity laws. But the misleading and inaccurate claims incensed Antigua's government, and ultimately led to the Rhino empire's downfall. Investigators from the Financial Intelligence Unit, set up to prevent offshore companies being used for international moneylaundering, placed Rhino under surveillance before raiding its base in the capital St John's early last Tuesday.

'Successful prosecutions have been carried out on several offshore corporations that have been involved in fraud and there has been full co-operation with the UK, the USA, Belgium, Switzerland and Canada in bringing criminals to justice.'

He added: 'While Rhino also claimed that we do not have stringent obscenity laws, they are now painfully aware of the inaccuracy of their information... Effectively, Rhino Corporation's websites are no longer operational and their business licence will be revoked under our laws pending further legal action.'

Trueheart Smith, the island's police commissioner, said: 'We are very, very glad to see the back of these people. They are not the type of people we want on the island and we hope the British authorities will consider taking action against them.'

fields.headline: Web watch
fields.trailText: Checkyourbank.com | First-e.com
fields.body:
If you think your bank charges are steep but have no idea how to work out whether you are being overcharged, a new website is offering to help.

The service, www.checkyourbank.com, has been set up by a Manchester accountant, Saeid Mokhtassi, who says he was inspired to do it after being overcharged £700 by his own bank. Users can obtain an assessment for free after feeding in a series of facts about their accounts. There is a charge of £12.50 if you want a report to help you argue your case.

The system will probably appeal mainly to small or medium-sized businesses, but many personal customers whose banks operate more complex charging systems may benefit. Check-yourbank says it is dealing with a case for a small business that believes it has been overcharged by £90,000 over the past six years.

Internet banks may have the edge over their old-technology rivals when it comes to charges and rates, but they're not immune from complaints. Internet bank www.first-e.com has been featured on the BBC consumer programme Watchdog over allegations that customers have been unable to find anyone at the organisation to resolve complaints.

First-e is Spanish-owned, and is not eligible for membership of the UK's Banking Ombudsman scheme. It has set up its own complaints-handling service, where complaints will be dealt with through a firm of solicitors, Lawrence Graham. There will also be an independent arbitrator, Tony Willis, a fellow of the Chartered Institute of Arbitrators.

webTitle: Tim Atkin on the Great Cork Debate

fields.headline: What a corker
fields.standfirst: Winemakers may lose 300 million bottles a year to an organic compound found in corks, but even that's not enough to tempt purists to go plastic. Will the Great Cork Debate never end?
fields.trailText: Winemakers may lose 300 million bottles a year to an organic compound found in corks, but even that's not enough to tempt purists to go plastic. Will the Great Cork Debate never end?
fields.body:
After a period of relative quiet, when producers of natural corks and 'alternative closures' agreed to co-operate and stop hurling propaganda at one another, the Great Cork Debate (GCD) has turned nasty again. The latest round of animosity was sparked by reports in the press (including this newspaper) that two British supermarkets had sent letters to customers accusing the cork industry of greed and of damaging the environment.

The charges were given extensive coverage in the Portuguese media. With one eye on the rural electorate, national politicians lined up to dismiss the smears as a 'campaign based on falsehoods' and as the work of US multinationals. (Bill Gates is an investor in Supremecorq, the world's largest plastic-stopper manufacturer.) The natural cork industry was not above a few barbs of its own, pointing to the incidence of 'plastic taint' and other problems associated with its competitors' products.

Call me a cynical hack, but I couldn't help noticing that the reports coincided with the annual cork harvest in Portugal, as well as with a nice photo opportunity. The 217-year-old Whistler Tree, the oldest source of natural corks in the world, was harvested for the first time in nine years in 2000. Cue ready-made articles about the environment, Portuguese peasants and an endangered rural tradition.

I'm frustrated by this fracas. While the two sides of the GCD swap insults, the problem of corked wines, caused primarily by a volatile organic compound called 2,4,6 trichloranisol (TCA), refuses to go away. According to the most conservative estimate, 2 per cent of the world's vino is affected by a mouldy, musty character reminiscent of wet undergrowth or old mops. That's around 300 million bottles of faulty wine a year worldwide.

No one knows the true extent of the problem. Is it 8 per cent, as some wineries claim? Or is it inconsequential? My own less than scientific evidence, gleaned from tasting around 10,000 wines a year, points to a rate of 3 per cent, which is a lot better than it was two years ago. (I was amused to see a letter from an English winemaker in The Guardian asserting that he'd had less than a dozen corked wines in his life. Either the man has a palate of lead or he doesn't know what TCA smells and tastes like.)

Recent innovations in the treatment of corks (microwaves, ozone, the elimination of chlorine) may have reduced the incidence of faulty wines, but they haven't done away with it. Despite spending millions on research and instituting a Code of Good Cork Practice, the cork industry still doesn't fully understand TCA. One thing is for certain: Portuguese and Spanish cork forests are not about to disappear. Plastic stoppers are used in less than 2 per cent of the world's wine, and most high-end producers prefer to use cork, despite the inherent commercial risks. (Vega Sicilia, Spain's most famous winery, recently had to withdraw its 1994 Valbuena Reserva at a cost of £2m.) It's even possible that cork producers will be unable to satisfy demand if worldwide wine consumption continues to increase.

My own position is that I care about the environment, rural communities and the Whistler Tree. But I also want to drink a reliable bottle of wine. Not 97 per cent of the time, but every time. Until the cork industry can guarantee such a success rate, I don't blame wine drinkers for buying bottles with plastic stoppers. Ultimately, the choice is up to you.

fields.headline: Currant affairs
fields.standfirst: Summery fruit salads of bejewelled berries and currants as perfect on the eye as on the tongue
fields.trailText: Summery fruit salads of bejewelled berries and currants as perfect on the eye as on the tongue.
fields.body:
Karl Fabergé himself could not have designed anything so exquisite as the punnets of pale pink currants I found in one of the larger supermarkets last summer. Slightly tart on the tongue, the flawless, transparent bubbles hung from thin stems like costume jewellery at a ball. I have never seen such delicate beauty in anything edible. Since late June, I have lain in wait for their short season, roaming the aisles for a sight of these precious fruits, but this year they are gone. (There is a stalking currants joke in there somewhere, but I will spare you.) Perhaps they were considered too beautiful to eat.

I had hoped to re-create a fruit salad that was as perfect to look at as it had been to eat - an understated jumble of blackberries and pink currants that followed a cold salmon lunch. It was cheap, too, with the berries coming from the brambles that found their way into my garden from next door. But second best was also good - a bowl of blackberries and white currants that I scattered around a tiny mound of soft, white fromage frais. A perfect plate to cheer up this mean little summer.

The midnight-coloured fruits - blackberries, plump dessert blackcurrants and Dorset blueberries - make a mysterious and sumptuous salad. Drop some claret-coloured loganberries or overripe raspberries in there as well, and you have an impossibly luxurious dessert. It would be a crime to smother it with cream, and sacrilege even to pass the sugar shaker, but doubtless there are those who would. Those who share a fondness for clean, bright tastes may like to scatter their salad with redcurrants, too.

A decade or more ago, I ate a bowl of fruit that was to change the way I thought about summer puddings. Until then it had been a case of the more the merrier, and cut up into a million small pieces. A fruit salad wasn't worth eating unless it looked like a Jackson Pollock. We had driven down to Shipdham Place, a country house hotel near Dereham in Norfolk, where Vanessa Lam (now cooking at Ransome's Dock in south-west London) produced vast white porcelain bowls of perfectly ripe, pale green melon and wild blackberries - it remains one of the most memorable desserts I have ever eaten. The simplicity and perfection of the pale green melon dripping with sweet juice and cut into large chunks and the sharpness of the local berries threw a whole new light on to the genre. It is worth remembering that I was brought up on tinned fruit cocktail and Carnation milk.

The idea that two or three fruits will, if chosen with a little thought and cut not too small, make a more interesting end to a meal than one where you throw in everything in season has remained with me. I get a real buzz from getting such marriages right. You don't necessarily need something sweet with something sharp; you could choose two sweet fruits - mango and pawpaw, say - and spike them with a sharp juice, such as lime. Alternatively, two piercing fruits such as grapefruit and redcurrants can be softened by the addition of something sweet like an amber-fleshed melon. OK, so even David Beckham could work that one out, but then look how often a fruit salad is put together with no thought for anything other than what just happens to be in the fruit bowl at the time.

Ripeness is all, and it is worth spending time bringing peaches and apricots along the road to perfection ourselves. A warm windowsill and a daily sniff will do. You will smell them when they are ripe. Berries, though, do not ripen once they are picked, so we must be fussy in the shops. Generally, the darker the berry the deeper its flavour will be, yet to confuse the issue I bought some golden-pink raspberries the other day that at first looked like something to avoid, yet when I picked them up and sniffed them I got a promising scent of roses. They turned out to be superb, like berries you might pick from your own garden.

Apple does not belong in a mixture of summer fruit. The crunch seems inappropriate amongst sumptuous redcurrants and ripe berries. Wait till autumn and then toss them with fresh walnuts and lemon juice. Instead, go for the deep scarlet soft fruit whose season is all too short. Last night I had watermelon, raspberries and pink grapefruit - it looked sensational in its shades of ruby, and I will have it again tonight to finish the vast lump of melon left in the fridge.

But what about the fruit that looked good in the greengrocers but fails to live up to its promise? I have two suggestions and an emergency measure to pass on here. Passion fruit juice squeezed over the fruit will tease out its flavour, as will a few drops of balsamic vinegar. If these fail, you could always try a thin syrup made from twice as much water as sugar, boiled till the sugar dissolves, then allowed to cool thoroughly before you add the fruit. A little lemon juice or some chopped mint can turn even the saddest little strawberry into something worth getting a spoon out for.

Strawberry, passion fruit and mint

You will need a couple of passion fruit for each portion of strawberries. Check that the passion fruit is ripe, by which I mean heavily wrinkled. Hull the strawberries and cut them in half or even quarters, depending on their size. Halve the passion fruit and squeeze the juice and seeds into a bowl. Chop a couple of mint leaves per person very finely and stir them into the passion fruit, then add the strawberries and gently toss them about a bit. Cover with a small plate and leave for at least 20 minutes, an hour if you can. Serve lightly chilled.

Blackberry, blueberry and raspberry salad

A heady salad of the richest imaginable colour. Check over all the fruit, then mix it in roughly equal quantities. The textures are as interesting as the flavour here. Drizzle the berries with a little crème de cassis and serve at room temperature.

Warm raspberry salad

Tip the raspberries into an ovenproof dish. Sprinkle over a little caster sugar and leave them in a very low oven, 150 C/gas mark 2 for 25 minutes or so. Despite the fact that they have fallen and lost their shape, they will have produced copious red juice. Add just a touch - and I do mean a touch - of framboise or cassis. The rich, wine-red juices are the point of it all. Serve in pretty glasses, with elegant biscuits from a posh packet.

Salad of watermelon, blackberries and pink grapefruit

Cut the melon into wedges, then slice the soft flesh from the rind. Using the point of a knife, pick out all the seeds, then cut the flesh into fat chunks and drop into a bowl with as much of the juice as you can save. Pick over the blackberries - you want them to be juicy but sound - and toss them with the watermelon. Slice the peel from the grapefruit. Cut into segments, losing as much of the white skin as you can and catching the juice in the bowl. Toss gently then leave to chill. This is one salad that is best served very cold.

Syrup for a fruit salad

Sometimes a syrup will bring to life fruit that is not quite up to scratch. It works particularly well with peaches that prove disappointing. Try to let the sliced fruit stay in the syrup for at least an hour before serving.

600ml water
250g caster sugar
1 vanilla pod
the peel of a small lemon

Put the water and sugar in a stainless-steel pan and bring to the boil. When the sugar has dissolved, add the vanilla pod and the lemon rind and continue boiling for five minutes, then turn off the heat, but leave the vanilla and lemon in place.

When the syrup is cool, remove the seasonings and chill it thoroughly. Taste the cold syrup and add a little rose or orange flowerwater to taste - start with no more than a teaspoonful. The syrup is now ready to use.

Banana, peach and raspberry brlée

For those who just cannot take their fruit without cream. Serves 4.

175g caster sugar
700g mixed bananas (peeled weight), peaches and raspberries
350ml chilled double cream

Put the sugar in a heavy pan and pour in enough water to cover. Set over a medium to high flame to boil while you prepare the fruit. Slice the bananas, stone and slice the peaches, and remove any stems from the raspberries. Put all the fruit in a heat-proof serving bowl.

Whip the cream until it forms gentle peaks. Take care not to overwhip it. Spoon in high waves over the fruit. The sugar in the pan will start to turn a pale, golden caramel after 10 minutes or less - watch it carefully, as it is prone to burning.

The caramel is ready when it turns a rich, golden brown. Pour the caramel over the cream and fruit immediately - taking care not to splash or burn yourself. It will at once set to a crisp and shiny coat. Eat within 30 minutes.

Some good fruit salads

Blueberries, white currants and loganberries

Blackberries and watermelon

Raspberries, honeydew or ogen melon and orange

Raspberries and eau de vie de framboise

Dessert gooseberries, raspberries and apricots

Blackberries, raspberries and blueberries

Honeydew melon and blackberries.

Drizzle the berries with a little crème de cassis and serve at room temperature. Warm raspberry salad Tip the raspberries into an ovenproof dish. Sprinkle over a little caster sugar and leave them in a very low oven, 150 C/gas mark 2 for 25 minutes or so. Despite the fact that they have fallen and lost their shape, they will have produced copious red juice. Add just a touch - and I do mean a touch - of framboise or cassis. The rich, wine-red juices are the point of it all. Serve in pretty glasses, with elegant biscuits from a posh packet. Using the point of a knife, pick out all the seeds, then cut the flesh into fat chunks and drop into a bowl with as much of the juice as you can save. Pick over the blackberries - you want them to be juicy but sound - and toss them with the watermelon. Slice the peel from the grapefruit. Cut into segments, losing as much of the white skin as you can and catching the juice in the bowl. Toss gently then leave to chill. This is one salad that is best served very cold. Try to let the sliced fruit stay in the syrup for at least an hour before serving. 600ml water 250g caster sugar 1 vanilla pod the peel of a small lemon Put the water and sugar in a stainless-steel pan and bring to the boil. When the sugar has dissolved, add the vanilla pod and the lemon rind and continue boiling for five minutes, then turn off the heat, but leave the vanilla and lemon in place. When the syrup is cool, remove the seasonings and chill it thoroughly. Taste the cold syrup and add a little rose or orange flowerwater to taste - start with no more than a teaspoonful. Set over a medium to high flame to boil while you prepare the fruit. Slice the bananas, stone and slice the peaches, and remove any stems from the raspberries. Put all the fruit in a heat-proof serving bowl. Whip the cream until it forms gentle peaks. Take care not to overwhip it. Spoon in high waves over the fruit. Pour the caramel over the cream and fruit immediately - taking care not to splash or burn yourself. It will at once set to a crisp and shiny coat. Eat within 30 minutes. fields.headline: Hard act to follow
fields.standfirst: After an appetiser of blood and guts on the big screen, you'll need a place to unwind. Jay Rayner takes refuge at the Hanover
fields.trailText: After an appetiser of blood and guts on the big screen, you'll need a place to unwind. Jay Rayner takes refuge at the Hanover.
fields.body:
There are some films that make for perfect pre-eating-out entertainment and some that do not. Tampopo, that hymn to the art of the noodle, is a great dinner-date movie. The Silence of the Lambs is not. To the list of those films that come under the heading, 'I'm not really very hungry any more, funnily enough,' can now be added Dead Babies, a vivid adaptation of a Martin Amis novel about the lost weekend from hell, featuring many fine shots of blood, guts and other bodily fluids which, under health and safety regulations, can not be repeated so close to the mention of foodstuffs.

Needless to say, it was an advance screening of Dead Babies (due for release in October) that I saw before eating dinner at the Hanover Wine Bar and Grill. My companion was the actor Andy Nyman, whose character, Keith Whitehead, suffers extreme indignities for almost the entire 99 minutes of the film. There's something curious about breaking bread with a chap you've just seen being roundly violated by two large men before being tied naked to a tree and then hosed down at dead of night.

The Hanover Wine Bar and Grill was a rather good choice of post- Dead Babies destination, for being nothing like it. All they shared was a certain vintage. Amis's novel was published in the 1970s and there is more than a whiff of that decade about the Hanover: paper tablecloths, posters of Paris, bare floorboards and Georgie Fame on the stereo. Think Robin's Nest without the one-armed Irishman and you're pretty much there, save for one detail: the wine list.

The Hanover is part of the tiny empirette belonging to Don Hewitson. The wines are listed in a laminated booklet that sits on every table. The entries come complete with Don's tasting notes: what direction the wind was blowing when the grapes were picked, how he met the people who made the wine, whether he is godparent to any of their children. That sort of thing. Or at least that's what it feels like.

In the triumvirate of wine, atmosphere and food, the food comes third at the Hanover; yet it is not so bad as to be a reason for avoiding the place. It is, most simply put, bistro fare that occasionally promises a little more than it delivers. At present they are running a 'grape dinner' menu which, if you are a complete alcoholic, could prove a steal. For £20 you get a choice of three courses plus an unlimited supply of one of three wines. Even though I knew I could not do it justice, I gave it a try.

For my unending wine, I chose the Domaine de Jarras Rosé 'Gris de Gris'. Light and fresh, it was all but overwhelmed by my starter, a terrine of wild boar and wild mushrooms. The terrine was a hulking affair, solid and meaty without any social graces, but it did the job. Andy had tomato and mozzarella salad, then set about proving he really had been only acting in the film. He used both a knife and fork to eat it with, rather than his hands, as Keith Whitehead might have done. It was, he declared, fine.

My main course, which came with a naughty supplement of £2, was described as an open Australian sirloin sandwich. It was a pretty straight-up piece of beef, accompanied by more than passable chips and a light herb butter. Andy's Indian spiced fish and chips was one of those dishes of unrealised promise. A little cumin and garam masala had been chucked into the batter; otherwise it was bog-standard fish and chips. To finish, we shared a chocolate and rum truffle cake - the kind of thing they would have served at Robin's Nest.

All of this may sound a bit gloomy, but it shouldn't. The Hanover is a gentle place, with a cracking wine list, where I suspect you'll rarely have trouble finding a table. Just don't expect fireworks from the kitchen.

 The Hanover Wine Bar and Grill, 25 Hanover Square, London W1 (020 7408 0935). Grape dinner, including service and unlimited wine, £44 for two.

fields.headline: Making scents
fields.standfirst: Surround yourself with summer's sweetest smells by planting tobacco, honeysuckle and lilies
fields.trailText: Surround yourself with summer's sweetest smells by planting tobacco, honeysuckle and lilies
fields.body:
It may have been a god-awful start to the summer (although maybe not - I seem to have found it better than everyone else I talk to. Better for gardeners, perhaps), but there was still the odd evening when one could sit outside, full enough, tired enough, drunk enough to just let the night crawl in quietly like the tide submerging day.

There are never enough of those evenings and never as many as we think we remember, but the few there are remain in the memory, rich with scent. To properly relish the gloaming, it has to smell.

Thinking along these lines, I planted out the tobacco plants a fortnight ago. The tobacco plants? Is that inevitable? Are they obligatory? Well, yes, they do seem to be. At least the marvellous Nicotiana sylvestris are. Summer is not right without the 6ft flower spikes with the white tubes of flower falling off them like floral dreadlocks, the whole thing rising up from their fleshy, sticky leaves.

The warm flush of tobacco-plant scent just as the sun is slipping below the tree line is as much a measure of summer as sweet peas, dry grass and tomatoes. The season could exist without these things, but it wouldn't exist enough.

So every spring, greedy for my summer, I buy about four packets of N sylvestris, because I know I want masses, open the first packet, am reminded for the 20th year in succession how tiny the seeds are, sow one packet which, if sown reasonably thinly, will fill four seed trays, sow another packet because I've got it, a bit thicker this time because I don't have the space for eight trays of tobacco seedlings and about three weeks later prick out a quarter of them and chuck the rest away.

I'm left with the contents of perhaps half a packet of seed and about 100 healthy plants. It is important not to plant them out until every hint of frost has passed - which for most of us is June - and because we use them to fill gaps as part of a succession following on from white foxgloves or poppies or the earlier flowers, they have a tendency to sit around for a few weeks longer than they should. This doesn't seem to matter if they are in a large enough pot, but can seriously stunt their later development if they are in plugs.

Like all tobacco plants, they should go on flowering right up until the first frosts. If it is a mild winter, some plants will survive until next year and you will often find seedlings cropping up, even if the parent plant did not make it through the frosts.

For a plant I so completely associate with my own private English summer, they are, thinking about it, pretty exotic, almost tropical-looking. That's for the eye. But they don't just look the part. They know how to smell as muskily seductive as any plant in the book.

The flowers will shrink and close in bright sunshine and then open in the evening, releasing scent as they do. The hotter the daytime sun, the stronger the fragrance will be in the evening. In fact they are best planted in a sheltered, slightly shaded position rather than in full sun, both for the health of the plant and for the quality of the scent.

I used to regularly grow N alata (or N affinis - I don't know which is right and am always bemused by the change of names of plants as botanists redefine family groups. I wish that we used more vernacular names and kept classification to the specialists. I am repeatedly told that there is no aspect of gardening that is so off-putting to the enthusiastic but daunted amateur), but have not done so for a few years, because they are getting harder to find without being mixed up in a muddle of colour.

I don't like mixed seeds as a rule. They are not as dramatic - reaching only 3ft and are less trumpet-like, but smell wonderful and are easier for a container. None of the other available 'tobacco' plants seem to me to be worth growing, as they don't have any scent to speak of, although there is a certain magenta that always crops up in a mixed bag of tobacco plants which I like very much. I don't include N langsdorfii in this censure, and think it lovely, but then that is not grown for its scent.

If you make an area designed primarily for sitting in in the evening, it is important that it should be sheltered and preferably with a stone or paved surface with at least one brick or stone wall. This is because these surfaces hold the heat as the air cools, intensifying the scents, as well as making it comfortable to sit out there for longer.

For evening fragrance, you must have some honeysuckle working these heat-retentive walls. Lonicera periclymenum 'Belgica' is as lovely as it is ubiquitous. The hedges around here are full of L periclymenum in flower, and as you duck into the shade of a tree the scent adds another dimension to the moment.

Unlike the tobacco plants or resiny herbs, such as lavender, rosemary or basil, it does not need the heat of the day to cook its oils, but likes the cool of morning or evening for the scent to be at its best. L x americana has the scent of cloves, and L japonica 'Halliana' is especially good for a shady wall.

Cestrum is a climber I had not encountered until this summer when I visited Liz Collonette's garden in Guernsey while filming Real Gardens. It has flame-coloured flowers which emit scent as the daytime temperature drops.

According to Stephen Lacey, in his book Scent in Your Garden (£19.95, Francis Lincoln), C parqui releases a potent fragrance from it tiny flowers at night, but during the day 'the scent is unpleasantly meaty'. Night-scented stock (Matthiola bicornis) has no such complexities. It is stock that is scented at night. That scent is sweet and honeyed and is really the only justification for the plant.

Evening Primrose (Oenothera biennis) is a plant which it seems inconceivable to have to sow as once you have it in the garden it springs up everywhere unbidden. But for adding a touch of sweet lemon fragrance to the scented medley of an evening, it is worth its place in the sinking sun.

Flowers that loosen their scent at night do so to attract moths and night-flying insects. They all tend to be white or pale coloured which increases their visibility. This reduces the competition to find a pollinator as well as increasing the chances of the pollinating insect moving on to another plant from the same family.

Finally, I have grown to love lilies over the past few years. Like everything in my self-referential horticultural life, this is because we have been growing a fair selection here. But of all the lilies, I still think the best are the best known, L regale and L candidum, the madonna lily. Both are powerful without being overpowering, both have white flowers that gently glow in the dusk and both grow well in pots that can be moved to prime positions on a paved area and then tucked away when their time is done. Indispensable.

fields.headline: Joyce bans Molly's musical climax
fields.trailText: Molly Bloom, the promiscuous literary heroine who has caused more scandal than any other character in fiction, is in trouble again. A musical version of her sexually explicit monologue at the close of James Joyce's 1922 novel, Ulysses, has been banned by Joyce's grandson.
fields.body:
Molly Bloom, the promiscuous literary heroine who has caused more scandal than any other character in fiction, is in trouble again. A musical version of her sexually explicit monologue at the close of James Joyce's 1922 novel, Ulysses, has been banned by Joyce's grandson.

Molly Bloom: A Musical Dream is due to open next week on the Edinburgh Fringe but a letter from Stephen James Joyce to festival director Paul Gudgin has demanded that the cabaret show be pulled. The reclusive grandson, who lives in Paris and jealously guards the family literary estate, claims the show turns the 'masterful' words of the book into a 'circus act'.

Writing initially to Anna Zapparoli, the Italian actress and singer who is to play Molly, he argued that 'The listener/viewer should not have their attention distracted by music, Molly lying on a piano...'

The first edition of Ulysses was published in Paris and denounced by the church for its sexual content. It was banned in Britain and the US. Zapparoli and her husband, composer Mario Borciani, have developed the show in Milan and plan to portray Bloom reclining on a grand piano rather than on the bed in which she conventionally delivers the bawdy monologue.

The crude language used in the show is also likely to attract controversy if the curtain goes up this Wednesday. One number is called 'Song of the Big Hole', and the lyric to another tune is equally graphic:

'`Standing there in front of me a crowbar sticking out at me he filled me with his cock so big and boisterous yet he must have eaten oysters and you feel so nice all over you there's nothing like a kiss a kiss gets into you inside you long and hot deep in your soul.'

Stephen Joyce has no objection to the explicit language, but contends that the monologue should never be used out of context and just for its sensational value. 'This last chapter/episode was not written for the stage, or to be performed, but as the concluding part of a novel. I do not know who first authorised extracts from what has become known as the Molly Bloom monologue/soliloquy to be performed in theatres, even the radio, but looking back it was opening a Pandora's box.'

But the letters from the Joyce estate have not so far swayed the Fringe organisers. A spokesman told The Observer: 'The show will go on. We understand that in this case, because of the copyright rules, the permission of the estate is not needed.' Zapparoli, 40, first wrote to Stephen Joyce at the end of last year asking for approval for the project. Describing herself as a Molly Bloom-physical type, she offered to sing the piece for Joyce in his Paris home.

'After I wrote to Mr Joyce,' she said this week, 'we discovered we were legally in the clear if we went ahead with the production. Then this week the whole thing exploded around us. Of course, we would much prefer it if Stephen Joyce came along and watched the show without any scorn and made up his own mind to either like it or loathe it. Mario and I worship James Joyce as an author.'

Stephen Joyce, who in 1997 attempted to sue the publishers Picador over an amended edition of Ulysses, is not convinced. He replied to Zapparoli: `We have read your submission carefully and have come to the conclusion that you propose to treat the Molly Bloom Monologue as if it were a circus act or a jazz element in a jam session. This was clearly not the intention of the author. Therefore we must refuse you permission.'

fields.headline: Plastic protection from online demons
fields.standfirst: Dotcom crashes make virtual shopping risky, but credit cards may be your best defence, says  Maria Scott
fields.trailText: Dotcom crashes make virtual shopping risky, but credit cards may be your best defence, says Maria Scott
fields.body:
Internet shopping may become an increasingly risky proposition as the shake-out in internet businesses gets under way.

Online shoppers need to be aware of the risk that they could buy products from companies that go out of business before the items are delivered.

There have already been collapses, the most prominent being that of Boo.com. Established internet operations which fail to make profits are likely to be taken over - perhaps even by off-line competitors - rather than go bust. But smaller operations that cannot secure financing are likely to go to the wall.

Concerns over the security of credit-card transactions deter many people from purchasing on the internet. But according to Ajay Patel, prin ciple lawyer for the Consumers' Association, if you are using the net to shop, the best protection against losing out to a collapsing business is to buy with a credit card. Under the Consumer Credit Act, that card operator is liable if the goods you order are not delivered.

Accountant KPMG, which handled the liquidation of Boo.com, says any customers owed money - most creditors were businesses - were directed towards their card companies.

Patel stresses the importance of using a credit card, rather than debit card, as the latter are not covered by the legislation. Despite the generous protection offered by credit cards, however, there have been disputes over refunds, particularly regarding purchases overseas. Card companies generally pay up and Barclaycard, the largest operator, says it views internet purchases as 'business as usual'. But Patel says there may be disagreements. Since internet shoppers can buy from anywhere with relative ease, it may be unwise to be too complacent about assuming a card will protect you regardless of where, and from whom, you're buying. Net shoppers should also note that the protection applies only to purchases of £100 or more and Patel says it is a matter of dispute whether this limit applies to individual items or to several simultaneous transactions with one organisation together worth £100 or more.

A second step towards protecting yourself is to check whether the company you are buying from has a policy of not debiting your account until after the goods have been dispatched. Robert Coles, head of information security at accountant KPMG, recommends deal ing with well-known, established names, which include the online operations of high street retailers.

Patel points out, however, that if you are a creditor of a collapsed online company your rights, while the same as if dealing with a collapsed offline organisation, are minimal.

'They are pretty poor when it comes to getting your hands on some cash, he says. 'As an unsecured creditor, you have to stand in line after creditors such as the Inland Revenue and the banks. If there is anything left after that, you get your share from the person dealing with the insolvency.'

Another line of defence is to look for membership of a recognised trade organisa tion that operates a compensation scheme, or accreditation by a consumer protection organisation. None are are likely to give a guarantee of solvency, however.

Webtrust, run by the Institute of Chartered Accountants, involves an audit by a firm of accountants, aimed at assessing the strength and reputability of an organisation.

The Consumers' Association also operates an accreditation scheme, called Which? Web Trader. And yet another scheme, Trust UK, has been set up, with DTI backing, to vet the various codes.

If this sounds all too complicated, you could of course just do your shopping on the high street.

webTitle: Radio: Stuff the search engine, I'm off to the library

fields.headline: Stuff the search engine, I'm off to the library
fields.trailText: The Illusion of Information | Internet Dreamers | The David Jacobs Collection | The Torch Singers
fields.body:
The Illusion of Information R4
Internet Dreamers R4
The David Jacobs Collection R2
The Torch Singers R2

Do you ever feel trapped in a loop of disinformation? Yes, every time I telephone train timetable inquiries - but that isn't what documentary film-maker Roger Graef was referring to in The Illusion of Information.

What happens, asks Graef, when our experiences are refracted through the lens of globalised media?

Back in the Sixties, Marshall McLuhan prophesied that modern communications would turn the world into a global village. Think global, act local is the ideal but all too often it's the other way round.

Manchester United have 10,000 supporters in Thailand, few of whom bother to watch their local team. As a self-confessed internet klutz, I cherish Graef's pessimism; if he continues in this vein, by the end of programme three we'll be ready to ditch our search engines in favour of Whitaker's Almanack or even the local library.

So where did it all go wrong? Whether by design or accident, we had a chance to find out a couple of days before Graef's series in Internet Dreamers, when Tim Marlow went to Silicon Valley to talk to some of the people responsible for its conception. No single person invented the net. In 1964, Professor J.C.R. Licklieder at MIT (Massachusetts Institute of Technology) published a seminal paper, 'Man-Computer Symbiosis', which started the ball rolling.

In 1965, Bob Taylor, a computer scientist from Texas, ran with it at the request of Arpa (Advanced Research Projects Agency), an arm of the Pentagon which wanted a computer to spy on the Russians and then relay the information to MIT, Santa Monica and Berkeley.

Taylor got fed up with running between different computers on different desks. Please, sir, may we have one interactive network system that does the whole lot? he asked his boss. In 1974, four geeks formed the Home Brew Computer Club, one of whom went on to co-found Apple Mac.

Most agree with Graef's reservations - too much commercialism, advertising and junk - but despite that, the dream, the ideal, still holds good.

Besides, the net is still in its infancy; it's where the telephone was back in 1920, complete with wind-up handle. Well, at least you can download Radio 4 on the internet and get some sense.

Whose turn was it to wind up David Jacobs last week, or has his handle finally dropped off? You can slip a lot past Radio 2 listeners while they are looking for their teeth or counting out their pills but the sheer banality of the Andy Williams story he's presenting, which, God help us, still has five weeks to run, is in a league of its own.

Williams is a nice guy with a nice voice. End of story. By all means, fill up an hour with his Sixties hits but spare us the padding and the puffs from a presenter who sounded as if he'd not only lost his teeth but lost the plot.

I'm not being ageist. Eartha Kitt, who must be older than Jacobs, is doing a great job presenting The Torch Singers. At least when she miaows, she doesn't spit.

fields.headline: And then there were two
fields.standfirst: The sale of United's ITV licences to Granada Media leaves only a couple of major ITV players.  Emily Bell  on the unpicking of a British quilt
fields.trailText: The sale of United's ITV licences to Granada Media leaves only a couple of major ITV players. Emily Bell on the unpicking of a British quilt
fields.body:
ITV as a patchwork network reached the beginning of the end last week. Clive Hollick, Labour peer and erstwhile media baron, sold his television assets - or at least the greater part of them - to Granada Media. Hollick's United News and Media will hang on to its market information and internet businesses and, it says, Express Newspapers.

The £1.75 billion purchase by Granada of all three of United's ITV licences - HTV, Meridian and Anglia - will be followed by the swift selling on of HTV to Carlton Communications for regulatory reasons. This leaves Carlton and Granada as the two companies owning the vast majority of an ITV quilt once owned by 16 different companies. Outside the two big players only Scottish Media Group now holds a significant licence.

Hollick is expected to sell his remaining TV interest, a small stake in Channel 5, to RTL Group, which owns the other 64 per cent of the channel. The rest of the national press has focused on what may happen to the Express titles - the daily and Sunday newspapers - which Granada said from the outset it would not be interested in buying.

Hollick is adamant that he doesn't wish to sell the papers, but they sit even less easily with the strategy of United now that the TV assets have gone. There are no synergies between the Express and market information businesses, and synergies with the online businesses are relatively minor.

Buyers will not be hard to find - the rumoured interest of the Barclay brothers would certainly be real at the right price; US publisher Gannett would be able to take out the titles without missing a beat; and Trinity Mirror may well be tempted to apply its undoubted skill in the centre-left tabloid market to the Express .

Hollick is clear that he would never rule out an advantageous deal that benefited his shareholders, but adds: 'We've stabilised the Express: it is a content offline business that can be leveraged into online revenues and that is a business we are very interested in sticking with.'

He is ever the pragmatic businessman about the company's exit from television. Referring to the unrealistic conditions the DTI imposed on a Carlton/United merger, he says: 'We had a bum decision from Stephen Byers, and have sold our assets at a good price, but we're very proud of what we have achieved in the past nine years, from a television franchise bid which grew out of the Campaign for Quality Television.'

Does he think that this broadcasting record will be safe in the hands of Granada Media chairman Charles Allen? 'I think he runs a very fine business and the move towards consolidating ITV is one which we started and is undoubtedly the right one,' says Hollick.

As well as the ITV assets, United must now decide what to do with its 20 per cent holding in ITN, its 33 per cent share of digital terrestrial broadcaster SDN and a 20 per cent stake in SIS, the horse- racing satellite system installed in many betting shops. It seems unlikely that any of these assets will remain in the company for long.

From Allen's perspective the deal is also a good one. He managed to extract the juice from United without having to buy the whole orange. The City, which so recently sneered at Granada's demerger plans and gave Allen a tough time, responded by sending the share price back up in typically fickle style.

Allen has broken his 'holiday every 13 weeks' rule to crunch the demerger and acquisitions through, and now says his focus will shift to the future of the businesses he runs.

'We will have the practical boring bit of assimilating Meridian and Anglia, but our attention really then will be on both driving and develop ing ITV as a business in partnership with Carlton and looking for partnerships in Europe.'

The United buy-up - which makes Allen the key shareholder in ITV with Carlton for the time being playing a supporting role - will herald a number of changes to the UK's largest commercial broadcaster.

'It is important that we develop ITV as a multi-channel business, using that brand as the core,' says Allen.

This raises the question of whether ITV will now be more or less likely to offer its channel to Sky Television for its digital service. 'I think we would offer it to Sky, but only if we had a number of channels so ITV is not swamped in their digital offering.'

A further matter of some urgency is appointing a chief executive to ITV. Again, Allen says this will now be sooner rather than later. 'It was difficult to make an appointment until the shareholdings were sorted out, but now they are we can crack on with it.'

As a lead shareholder in ITV, another aim of Granada Media will be to 'strengthen the regions', which sounds suspiciously like a sop to the political rumblings that have accompanied the merger mania. A raft of backbench MPs have voiced their displeasure at the denuding of regional services caused by the centralisation of the big ITV operators. But this is something Allen says he is keen to reverse.

A further intriguing facet of the newly formulated ITV will be the chess game between Granada and Carlton. They will for the time being work as the closest partners in ITV, but are highly likely to find themselves playing cat and mouse when regulations relax in the next couple of years.

Allen dodges the sugges tion that he may soon be embroiled in a hostile takeover bid for Carlton, preferring to focus on the 'cooperation we can achieve in all areas while still being competitive in advertising and programming'.

The big 'what next?' for Granada cannot be answered until the publication of the communications White Paper this autumn. It would be remarkable if the recommendations did not allow the step from three ITV companies to two to become the step from two to one.

It would be equally remarkable if Allen were not in charge of that move, but as the past three weeks have proved, where media, the markets and the Government intersect there is no such thing as a certainty.

webTitle: Scores of paedophiles forced into hiding

fields.headline: Scores of paedophiles forced into hiding
fields.trailText: Scores of Britain's most dangerous sex offenders have slipped police surveillance and gone underground through fear of vigilante attacks following a newspaper campaign to 'out' paedophiles, The Observer can reveal.
fields.body:
Scores of Britain's most dangerous sex offenders have slipped police surveillance and gone underground through fear of vigilante attacks following a newspaper campaign to 'out' paedophiles, The Observer can reveal.

The Observer has obtained a dossier detailing evidence of the dramatic effect of the publication of the names and the photographs of dozens of sex offenders in last Sunday's News of the World.

The dossier, compiled by the Association of Chief Officers of Probation over the past week, contains reports of attacks on convicted paedophiles as well as dozens of examples of people who have contacted their probation officers to say they have no choice but to move. Children's charities ChildLine and the NSPCC have joined probation officers in calling on the newspaper to stop its campaign immediately, in the interests of public safety. But executives at the newspaper said that it would name another 50 paedophiles in today's edition.

Senior police officers are concerned that this American-style 'naming-and-shaming' tactic will add to the 500 paedophiles and rapists who live itinerant lifestyles to avoid signing the sex offenders' register.

In one case reported to the probation service, the police smashed down the door of a paedophile under supervision in the south-east of England to find that he had absconded. A copy of the News of the World was on his kitchen table. Another man in London, convicted of a series of assaults on children, said if he was named he would attack journalists at the News of the World and then go underground. He is described by police as 'highly dangerous'.

Gill Mackenzie, chair of the chief probation officers' association, said: 'The evidence within just a week is grave, but no one should be surprised. If probation monitoring and police surveillance are fractured, communities are at far greater risk.' Richard Garside, of the National Association for the Care and Resettlement of Offenders, said: 'This evidence shows what organisations like Nacro have been saying all along. This is bad for offenders, who are forced underground and off treatment programmes. But it is also bad for victims. Because, if offenders are more at risk of offending, you are simply creating more victims.'

The dossier has been passed to News of the World editor Rebekah Wade, who has agreed to meet representatives of the probation service, children's charities and offenders' groups on Tuesday. Wade has said she is determined to press on with her campaign, despite condemnation from the police and government Ministers. The parents of murdered eight-year-old Sarah Payne, who back the News of the World campaign, yesterday signed a petition to change the law to allow convicted paedophiles to be publicly identified.

This would be based on the so-called Megan's Law, introduced by President Clinton two years ago. It is named after Megan Kanka, who was murdered by a known paedophile in 1994.

The issue had caused deep divisions within the Home Office, with Charles Clarke, who has responsibility for Criminal Justice described as 'incandescent with rage' about what the News of the World has done. But Home Secretary Jack Straw and Prisons and Probation Minister Paul Boateng have resisted pressure to issue a direct condemnation of the News of the World because they realise it has the support of large sections of the public.

'No one here believes that it was a good idea on the part of the News of the World,' said one Home Office source, 'but some Ministers have reacted more angrily than others.'

News of the World managing editor Stuart Kuttner said he did not think his paper should feel defensive: 'We are galvanising public opinion and hoping to develop an important debate.

'The reaction from our readers indicates the enormous concern people have about their inability to know if there is a convicted child molester living within the community and the length of sentences for serious child sex offenders.'

fields.headline: No sheep-stunners here
fields.standfirst: Edinburgh film festival preview
fields.trailText: Lizzie Francke, the director of the Edinburgh International Film Festival, is taking no chances by book-ending the fifty-fourth event with proven successes from Cannes.
fields.body:
Lizzie Francke, the director of the Edinburgh International Film Festival, is taking no chances by book-ending the fifty-fourth event with proven successes from Cannes. The movie chosen for the opening on Sunday, 13 August at the ABC Lothian Road is Lars von Trier's dramatic musical, Dancer in the Dark, which won the Palme d'Or, brought Björk the best actress award and attracted widespread plaudits, though not from me.

The festival concludes on Sunday, 27 August with Wong Kar-Wai's enchanting In the Mood for Love, a romantic Hong Kong love story, for which handsome Tony Cheung was named Cannes's best actor and the cinematographer Christopher Doyle received the Grand Prix Technique.

In between these gala events are several hundred movies from 50-odd countries, ranging in time from Victor Sjöström's silent classic The Scarlet Letter, starring Lillian Gish (20 August) to newly minted movies by unknowns getting their premieres at Edinburgh. All are described in the festival programme as 'magical', 'superb', 'eccentric, surreal, liberated', 'this subtle masterpiece', 'a visual treat' and so on, the organisers having no truck with dour Caledonian modesty.

There are sections devoted to established directors and first-time offenders, the latter being unknown quantities, the former including two outstanding pictures from Cannes - Liv Ullmann's Faithless (21 August) from a script by Bergman, and Michael Haneke's first film outside Austria, Code Unknown (19, 20 August), starring Juliette Binoche.

Of particular interest are movies by two directors whose careers received a major boost from the favourable critical attention their early work attracted at Edinburgh. Terence Davies showed his semi-autobiographical trilogy at the 1983 festival in Edinburgh to great acclaim and is now back with his version of Edith Wharton's The House of Mirth (19, 24 August), set in New York, filmed in Scotland, and thought by many to have been unfairly rejected by Cannes.

The other director is Bernard Rudden whose impressive 50-minute The Hunger Artist, a transposition of Kafka's tale from Prague to Glasgow, was the major discovery of the 1995 festival. He's back this year with his first feature, Daybreak (22, 24, 26 August), set in the world of Edinburgh clubbers and low-lifes.

The festival began in 1947 and to honour Scotland's greatest cineaste, John Grierson, the man who coined the term 'documentary', it was initially devoted to non-fiction films. fields.headline: The price of fish...
fields.standfirst: It's hard enough earning a living at sea. Add a hurricane or two and things get really difficult
fields.trailText: Philip French: The storm is a stunning, gut-wrenching piece of film-making that leaves the spectator shattered
fields.body:
Wolfgang Peterson's vivid account of life aboard a German submarine in the Second World War, Das Boot, is one of the great movies about seafaring. His new film, The Perfect Storm, though not quite in the same class, is, nevertheless, fit to be moored alongside it.

The film is adapted by Bill Wittliff from Sebastian Junger's riveting documentary book about 'the storm of the century' that occurred around Hallowe'en 1991, when a hurricane moving north from Bermuda collided off the north-west coast of America with an Arctic blast moving south and an unusual cold front coming across Canada from the Great Lakes. In this context 'perfect' is an ironic meteorological term meaning 'the worst imaginable'.

At the centre of the book and the film is a swordfishing boat, the Andrea Gail, working the Grand Banks from the port of Gloucester, Massachusetts, where the walls of the old town hall, seen in the opening sequence, record the names of the 10,000 fishermen lost at sea since 1623. We're introduced to the ship's captain, Billy Tyne (George Clooney), and his crew as they return with a catch much inferior to that of a friendly rival, the Hannah Boden, skippered by Linda Greenlaw (Mary Elizabeth Mastrantonio).

Is Tyne's luck running out? Is the Grand Banks fishing ground becoming depleted? The crew are disappointed with their rewards, the owner of the Andrea Gail (unsympathetic Michael Ironside) sneers at the captain he employs. In consequence, Tyne decides to put to sea again two days later in a last attempt to retrieve a bad season.

The Perfect Storm is much influenced by Howard Hawks. It's the story of dedicated professionals who work together at dangerous jobs, respecting each other's skills. Fishing is what they do - because they love it or because it promised to pay well or because it's all they know. The women stoically stand by or they act like the men (Mastrantonio is an archetypal Hawksian woman) or they go away.

Most of the men are either anguished divorcés, dedicated loners or on the point of giving up the sea for a woman. In a traditional scene at their gathering place, the Crow's Nest Tavern, their characters are established ready for the central business of the film - the effects of the storm. Like miners, they belong to a close community that practises a physically demanding trade living with memories of tragedies and knowing that disaster might strike any time.

Eventually, the Andrea Gail puts out to sea, John Seale's photography giving the movie a crisp, clear, bracing feel, James Horner's emphatic score underlining the heroic aspect of the adventure. At first, the fish are brought in steadily on the 40 mile-long nets. But there's conflict between the unhappy Murph (John C. Reilly) and the difficult newcomer Sully (William Fichtner), which is broken up by the reliable Bugsy (John Hawkes) and the happy-go-lucky Jamaican, Alfred Pierre (Allen Payne).

Then a shark they accidentally land injures the first mate, Bobby (Mark Wahlberg) and Murph is dragged overboard and nearly killed. When the catch drastically falls off, Tyne persuades them to go further out to a better fishing ground. Meanwhile, the meteorologist at a Boston TV station starts noticing the freak weather pattern.

This is a story of man against an implacable, remorseless nature, not a factitious tale of confronting sea monsters or waterborne terrorists. But at its centre are the effects of economic imperatives. The boat is out because the crew need the money, and at a crucial juncture the ice-making machinery breaks down because of the owner's cost-cutting, so no more fish can be taken.

A choice arises between heading home through the storm with their catch or evading the storm by going further out and thus having to ditch a catch they can't preserve. The voyage begins with them thinking of their living; it ends with them fighting for their lives.

The storm is a stunning, gut-wrenching piece of film-making that leaves the spectator shattered. Petersen cuts between the community's agonies on land in Gloucester and the events at sea. In addition to the Andrea Gail, there's a foundering yacht to be helped, a rescue helicopter in desperate need of aerial re-fuelling, a merchant ship whose containers are being swept away like so many Lego bricks, and the Hannah Boden from which Greenlaw is relaying messages to the increasingly isolated Andrea Gail. The special effects are astonishing, but they never detract from the human story, which is old-fashioned in the finest sense.

The cast look like real working men who've lived hard, open-air lives. Their dialogue is laconic and given our postmodern times and the fact that even at sea they watch a lot of action videos, they are perhaps aware of the roles they act out. After one fisherman is thanked by a hostile colleague whose life he's helped save, he remarks: 'You'd have done the same for me - isn't that what I'm supposed to say?'

I was caught up in this movie far more than I was in Jaws and there's a memorial service in the Gloucester church that is every bit as moving as the funeral of Spencer Tracy in Captains Courageous, a picture that inevitably comes to mind. The first chapter of Junger's book has an unforgettable epigraph from Walter Scott's novel, The Antiquary: 'It's no fish ye're buying, it's men's lives.' I wish they'd quoted this in the film.
