webTitle: Observer review: The Coen Brothers by Ronald Bergen

fields.headline: Coen, Coen, gone
fields.standfirst: The Coen brothers prove a little too elusive for Ronald Bergen's biography
fields.trailText: The Coen brothers prove a little too elusive for Ronald Bergen's biography
fields.body:
The Coen Brothers
Ronald Bergen
Orion £18.99, pp256
Buy it at BOL

How do you write a biography of the Coen Brothers? With difficulty, it seems. The leading postmodernists of US independent cinema like to keep an enigmatic profile. They give interviews but rarely give anything away. Their allusive movies such as Raising Arizona and Fargo are offbeat paeans to Americana, which subvert genres and borrow liberally from literature and other films. A Coen brothers film is worth seeing more than once - to catch the joke in the corner of the frame, recognise that sly reference or simply to get to grips with the plot.

It's hard to know where Joel (the eldest and taller) starts and Ethan ends. On paper, Joel directs and co-writes and Ethan produces and co-writes. In practice, it's an equal partnership. 'At times, it was like being directed in stereo,' recalls one actor. Ronald Bergan makes little attempt to distinguish between the pair who, although now in their forties, still look like anaemic postgraduate students.

Born in cold, dreary Minnesota to intellectual Jewish parents, they describe themselves as Jew-ish. Unlike Woody Allen, their ethnic background is not an obvious inspiration. Barton Fink is the only film featuring a Jewish protagonist.

Apart from different spouses and the revelation that Joel is more 'visual' and Ethan more 'literature', we learn little. Bergan's subjects declined extensive interviews but allowed some access; he visits the set of their film O Brother, Where Art Thou, a Depression-era convict comedy starring George Clooney.

'You can print whatever you want,' Ethan tells him. 'You don't have to confirm anything.' What emerges is too much prosaic testimony from colleagues about a couple of eccentric yet dedicated guys who really know their stuff.

But should you take them seriously? Are they genuine auteurs or overgrown college pranksters? Undoubtedly, they are major figures in American film, consistently challenging and beguiling audiences. Their dialogue revels in high and low vernacular, while their camerawork is breathlessly inventive on a low budget. Sadly, this book fails to do them justice. As a critical biographer, Bergan seems unsure if there is much to analyse. So, in the chapters about their seven films to date, he is good on technical aspects. He also meticulously details those references, including nods to Dashiell Hammett (Miller's Crossing), Clifford Odets (Barton Fink) and Truffaut's Shoot the Pianist (Fargo).

But he fails in critical evaluation. Bergan is a fan but offers little hard evidence. He doesn't even rate the films according to personal preference. Instead, you discover that, like Hitchcock, their films are completely storyboarded prior to filming.

Ironically, the brothers probably aren't as smart as their fans might believe. They claim they are often credited with creating homages and pastiches to works they're unfamiliar with. 'When we read the books we were supposed to have read,' says Joel, 'we came up with new ideas for movies.' This could be another joke, but Bergan supplies a personal anecdote when they were offered an introduction to the great Polish director Krzysztof Kieslowski at Cannes. 'Who's Kieslowski?' one of them asked.

Despite only two real box-office successes to date - Raising Arizona and Fargo (arguably their most conventional and linear film) - they retain their creative autonomy. They always get the final cut even though their budgets have risen steadily in recent years.

To the White Sea, their next film after O Brother, is a $60 million Second World War epic starring Brad Pitt. They're not outsiders anymore. Like Allen, stars want to work with them for a pittance. But are they in danger of losing the edgy sensibility that makes them unique? After all, Brad Pitt? And a blockbuster budget? Whatever will the folks say back in Minnesota.

webTitle: After the perfect storm, the big fire

fields.headline: After the perfect storm, the big fire
fields.trailText: The search for the perfect successor to The Perfect Storm is over. After a wave of hopeful manuscripts and screenplays about natural disasters at sea - all designed to capitalise on the popularity of Sebastian Junger's bestselling book and the commercial impact of the hit film - a genuine candidate has emerged.
fields.body:
The search for the perfect successor to The Perfect Storm is over. After a wave of hopeful manuscripts and screenplays about natural disasters at sea - all designed to capitalise on the popularity of Sebastian Junger's bestselling book and the commercial impact of the hit film - a genuine candidate has emerged.

This time the working title for the project is The Perfect Fire and the real-life disaster is a fatal blaze, not a shipwreck. Once again, the story is set in New England and once again publishers and film-makers are competing ferociously to bring the details to the public.

The blaze in question is known as the Worcester Cold Storage Warehouse Fire and it took the lives of six firefighters in December 1999. The rights to a book on the blaze by journalist Sean Flynn have been sold for a reputed six-figure advance to Warner Books on the strength of an article in this month's Esquire magazine, although the book has not yet been written. The sale of the film rights is already being handled in Hollywood.

The warehouse fire can be regarded as 'perfect' in the same sense that Junger's killer storm was perfect, because the windowless building in Worcester, Massachusetts, had all the worst features imaginable, including a chimney that pumped oxygen to the seat of the blaze. Unfounded reports that homeless people were inside the warehouse encouraged the firefighters to go towards the fire's centre, where temperatures reached 3,000F (1,540C).

Rick Horgan at Warner Books is confident the book will be a success because it has all the elements of a natural disaster adventure but has got away from the maritime location that has dogged publishers in the three years since The Perfect Storm was published.

Junger's book told the story of the sinking of the Andrea Gail in conditions metereologically ideal for creating a violent storm. The film of the book, starring George Clooney, is released in Britain this week and is already a box-office smash in the US.

The success of the bestseller was quickly followed by a fleet of nautical nailbiters including In the Heart of the Sea by Nathaniel Philbrick, which tells the true story of the wreck of the whaleship Essex in 1820 - said to be the inspiration for the climax of Herman Melville's novel Moby-Dick. The 240-ton Essex set sail from Nantucket on a routine voyage and 15 months later, in the South Pacific, it was rammed by a bull-sperm whale.

The bestselling author Gary Kinder followed suit with Ship of Gold in the Deep Blue Sea, an account of the SS Central America which sank in a hurricane off the Carolina coast in 1857.

Most recently Linda Greenlaw, the female captain of the Hannah Boden, sister ship of the ill-fated Andrea Gail, brought out her own account of a successful but perilous trip across the ocean.

The tidal wave of publishing interest in seafaring tales of derring-do has reached British shores too, but had reached saturation point. 'I receive at least one manuscript like this a week,' said Roland White, a commissioning editor at Penguin.

'It seems that these stories have to have either sea, or snow or mountains. They do tend to be American, though. I think it is part of every American's view of their inalienable right to go out into the wilderness and be killed by it.'

The mountaineering story Into Thin Air is another publishing phenomenon, and in response White has brought out a reprint of the Shackleton story South, currently being made into a film starring Kenneth Branagh.

'The detail in these books is the key thing,' said White. 'People want to know exactly what happens when your fingers fall off.'

Macmillan will also be publishing a new true story adventure in this genre next month. Dark Wind is survivor Gordon Chaplin's story of a trip on the seas that ended in tragedy, and there are already hopes of a film deal for the story.

The wake of The Perfect Storm may be the longest stretch of big- budget adventure films seen since the heydays of the 1970s,when The Poseidon Adventure, Earthquake, The Towering Inferno, and the Airport series hit cinema screens.

fields.headline: Children's choice
fields.trailText: Jonathan Bouquet is innumerate, but grateful
fields.body:
The Midnight Folk
John Masefield
Mammoth £4.99, pp282
Buy it at BOL

I would like to pay a very belated thanks to Mr Legrice, the headmaster of my first prep school. When he wasn't being headmasterly or sawing through his fingers with a circular saw while teaching us carpentry, he also took maths lessons. Clearly, this subject bored him as much as his small charges and rather than indoctrinate in us the questionable joys of long division and multiplication, he would instead read to us from The Midnight Folk.

Aided by a good cat (Nibbins) and hindered by the distinctly dubious felines, Blackmalkin and Greymalkin, and abetted by a splendid fox, Rollicum Bitem Lightfoot, the tale also involves witchcraft, piracy and highwaymen.

fields.headline: Paperback of the week
fields.trailText: Marcus Chown weaves astrophysics and anecdote into the story of the atom
fields.body:
The Magic Furnace
Marcus Chown
Vintage £7.99, pp232
Buy it at BOL

Richard Feynman, the US physicist, posed this question: if all knowledge was to be destroyed and only one sentence passed to future generations, what would provide most information in fewest words? His answer: 'Everything is made of atoms.'

You can see his point. Once atomic theory was unravelled, it triggered a tsunami of breakthroughs, including quantum mechanics and nuclear power. Even more remarkable, however, was the discovery of the origins of these atoms, the tiny units of carbon, oxygen and iron that make up our bodies and world. These were forged, we now know, in distant stars and supernovae, out of primordial hydrogen created at the Big Bang, and then spewed across space in stellar explosions before condensing into planets and humans.

In short, we are made of stardust, as Joni Mitchell sang; or as Marcus Chown puts it, we are cosmic nuclear waste. This wondrous creation continues in our own sun, which turns 400 million tonnes of hydrogen into heavier atoms every second, releasing energy that keeps us alive. Stellar nuclear fusion has therefore given us atoms for our bodies and warmth in which to evolve. Magic is not the word.

To his credit, Chown has done this story great service, melding astrophysics with deftly worded pen portraits of the protagonists, from the cripplingly shy astronomer Arthur Eddington who worked the principles of stellar mechanics, to the wine-swigging, womanising Ukrainian George Gamov who first astonished the world with the idea of the Big Bang.

The end result is a graceful, witty biography of the universe's most important entity: the atom.

fields.headline: Paperbacks
fields.trailText: A sensuously charged novel that echoes Hardy, plus The Requiem Shark, Lovers for a Day, The Singing Line and Sacred Roads
fields.body:
The Harvest
Christopher Hart
Faber £6.99, pp235
Buy it at BOL

Lewis Pike, aged 17, wants nothing more than to hunt in the countryside around his home village near Salisbury and flirt with the wife of the local poet. But it's increasingly difficult to ignore the changes going on both inside and around him. The Job Centre wants to find him work, Yuppified newcomers want to reinvent 'quaint' pagan traditions, while local woods are set to become an Olde Tyme Farm theme park. And the voices in his head are getting louder.

Hart's sensuously charged first novel echoes Thomas Hardy in its chronicling of rural England and doomed inevitability. Lewis's tragedy is that he is essentially a throwback to a simpler way of life that is no longer possible. But while the tone is elegiac, there's a pulse of blood and violence beating just below the surface; the climax is dark and brutal, yet strangely satisfying.

The Requiem Shark
Nicholas Griffen
Abacus £6.99, pp359
Buy it at BOL

Griffen's debut, a crackling tale of eighteenth-century piracy, plants him squarely in the top rank of historical adventure novelists. Fiddler, scholar and reluctant sailor William Williams is commissioned by the notorious pirate captain Bartholomew Roberts to immortalise his deeds in ink after being taken from a captured slaver.

Rum, cutlasses and cannonades ensue as the crew are caught up in Roberts's Ahab-like obsession with a fabulously rich treasure ship. Based (however loosely) on actual characters, Griffen's loose-teeth-and-all depiction steers admirably clear of cliché by telling it how it was, showing the pirates' amorality and atrocities along with all the yo-ho-hoing. Vivid, exciting and with an ending that's got more twists than a furled mainbrace, this is so authentic you could catch scurvy just from reading it.

Lovers for a Day
Ivan Klima
Granta £6.99, pp229
Buy it at BOL

This collection of short stories from Klima, a Czech whose writings were banned in his own country until recently, spans his career from the early Sixties to the 1990s. Set in Prague, they deal with the passion, bitterness and frustrations of love against the backdrop of the Communist regime.

While the tone of the later stories reflects a freer social climate, the early stories in particular have an almost mechanistic oppression about them. In 'Execution of a Horse', a girl's bright and hopeful morning leads to an abattoir and submission to an indifferent lover, while the young man in 'The Assembly Line' tries to escape the tedium of his life in daydreams and loveless sex. But the keynote of these sensitive and perceptive studies is still one of hope - love is seen as a source of freedom, even when it disappoints.

The Singing Line
Alice Thomson
Vintage £7.99, pp292
Buy it at BOL

Those of us whose relatives are notable mainly for embarrassing themselves at family gatherings have to envy Thomson her altogether more singular ancestors. In 1870, her great-great-grandfather Charles Todd began what would be a two-year struggle to string the first telegraph wire across the then unexplored centre of Australia, from Adelaide to Darwin. In doing so, he made communication to Britain possible within hours instead of months, had a town - Alice Springs - named after his long-suffering wife and changed the face of Australia for ever.

A hundred and odd years later, his great-great-granddaughter set off along the same route to see how much of Grandfather Todd's work remained. The pioneers had floods, starvation and occasionally hostile Aborigines to contend with; Thomson and her husband faced fried Mars Bars and nylon bedspreads. Both ordeals are related with verve and humour.

Sacred Roads: Adventures from the Pilgramage Trail
Nicholas Shrady
Penguin £7.99, pp205
Buy it at BOL

Anyone might be forgiven for thinking that a book about pilgrimages has only a niche appeal, but there is nothing remotely dull or Sunday schoolish about Nicholas Shrady's account of his journeys on the world's six great pilgrimage routes. Whether he's helping a Spanish shepherd build a chimney in a blizzard, getting beaten up by soldiers in Bethlehem, escaping Indian bandits by pretending to be a doctor, or being kicked out of a Bosnian Nativity crib by a priest on Christmas morning, Shrady relates his adventures with a narrative skill that makes this more compelling than most novels. While his personal quest for spiritual enlightenment is genuine, his style is so anecdotal and his approach so sceptical that you don't have to be religious to enjoy it. Funny, informative and quietly uplifting.

webTitle: Observer review: Marijuana Time by Ken Lukowiak

fields.headline: You don't have to be stoned...
fields.standfirst: In Marijuana Time Ken Lukowiak follows up his memoir of the Falklands War with an account of killing time, army style
fields.trailText: In Marijuana Time Ken Lukowiak follows up his memoir of the Falklands War with an account of killing time, army style
fields.body:
Marijuana Time
Ken Lukowiak
Orion £9.99, pp344

Sometime in early 1974, Fred packed his surfboard and the rest of his belongings, including beach bunny DeAnne, perfect in every detail bar the void between her ears, into an ageing Chevvy schoolbus and headed south. California under Ronnie Reagan's governorship, said Fred, was just too damn pinko. So he put his foot down and didn't stop until he hit the Mexican free-port and border post of Chetumal.

Hours later, after many cross words and more crossed palms, DeAnne and Fred headed over the River Hondo into Belize. A few years on and Fred had slotted neatly into life in this Central American celebration of anarchy; mostly stuff was bartered - dope, of course; and wood and nails for the never-to-be-finished hotel he was building on St George's Cay just down from the British forces' R&R station.

A few years on, my then wife and I stumbled into Fred and, in return for food and shelter, agreed to help him with his hotel. Which meant in effect spending months on his blessed cay too stoned to do anything except eat fish or blag compo rations from bemused squaddies and chopper pilots, whose mates would buzz the island at 500ft in their Harrier. Strange, strange world; long gone until now when, for me at least, brilliantly recalled by former para Ken Lukowiak in Marijuana Time, his follow-up to the acclaimed account of his experience during the Falklands War, A Soldier's Song.

If you never inhaled, you might amble pleasurably enough through these pages, marvelling at the way Lukowiak evokes the pointlessness of an army with sod all to do, based in a place with sod all to offer bar a bit of whoring, and boozing, but most of all skinning up. If you did inhale, maybe you still do, you will love this book. Marijuana Time confirms Lukowiak as a writer able to do light as well as heavy and to do it with wit and honest verve.

webTitle: Observer review: Demolition Angel by Robert Crais

fields.headline: Audio
fields.trailText: Robert Crais is already big in America. With Demolition Angel, he is poised for take-off in Britain.
fields.body:
Demolition Angel
Robert Crais
Read by Lorelei King
Abridged 6hrs
Orion Audiobooks £12.99

Robert Crais is the scriptwriter for LA Law and Hill Street Blues, author of nine novels, including LA Requiem, and is already big in America. With Demolition Angel, he is poised for take-off in Britain.

Carol Starkey was caught in the blast when a bomb she was investigating in Los Angeles with her colleague and lover, Sugar, exploded. He shielded her from the worst and she survived but he was killed. Three years on, she is an LAPD detective living on alcohol, nicotine and tablets; the scars are not just the ugly physical ones which no man has yet come close enough to see. At work, she's on the case of another LA bomb disposal expert who has been blown up on site. Carol thinks she has identified the man she's after - Mr Red - and Mr Red's next target, she soon realises, is her.

One of Crais's skills is to draw us inside the minds - minds as complex and delicate as detonating devices - of these two driven, obsessive individuals. Mr Red is determined to kill again; Carol is equally determined to stop him. In fearlessly dismantling bombs, she unpacks the puzzle of the bomber's mind and, distracted only briefly by a copycat killing and police corruption, pursues him through chat rooms on illicit internet sites.

Lorelei King's narration delivers the immediacy of the writing: it is vigorous, hard LA but with tremendous range - covering the action, the pistol-shot dialogue and the moments of Carol's skinned-bare reflection. The taut terror of the ending is pure audio-cinema. Don't miss it.

webTitle: Observer review: Portrait of the Artist... by Joseph Heller

fields.headline: What's the catch?
fields.standfirst: Joseph Heller's last novel, Portrait of the Artist..., is a wry look at failure. Which makes its success all the harder to judge
fields.trailText: Joseph Heller's last novel, Portrait of the Artist..., is a wry look at failure. Which makes its success all the harder to judge
fields.body:
Portrait of the Artist, as an Old Man
Joseph Heller
Scribner £12.99, pp234
Buy it at BOL

Joseph Heller once observed that success and failure were equally difficult to endure. 'Along with success,' he noted, 'come drugs, divorce, fornication, bullying, travel, meditation, medication, depression, neurosis and suicide. With failure,' he went on, 'comes failure.' His writing life was always lived somewhere between these poles, and, at its end, it seems, he was still wryly in thrall to recollections of the aftermath of his great early triumphs, and troubled by the perceived dip in literary fortunes that followed.

It is the novelist's job to astonish, Heller knew that as well as anyone, but he was also more aware than most that 'after all, a new talent can be discovered only once. And astonish hardly more often than that.' His fate, like that of all extraordinary literary debutants, was to become 'acknowledged, accepted, assimilated and... familiar .' His valedictory response to that fate, what he calls a couple of times here his own 'Catch-22', was to attempt to write a clever book about failure.

It is a moderate success. The book is cast in the voice of one Eugene Pota, indistinguishable in all but name from the author, who sits at his desk day after day, towards the end of his life, trying to conceive of a fitting closure to his career. You know the kind of thing: 'What I really want to do, I guess, is write another really good novel that will be a big bestseller and a natural for the movies.'

Heller's book is made up of Pota's blanks and misfirings in pursuit of this quarry: the openings to books that are told by Tom Sawyer, grown up and on Wall Street; books written from the point of view of a famous work of fiction that begin 'I was conceived in the brain of Dostoyevsky or Kafka or Melville'; novels that are no more than one-liners, or odd lists, or novelties.

His thoughts are often deadpan metaphysical. He conceives of a story told by Isaac, being led up the mountain by Abraham ('Where is the lamb?'), and satirical gospels which begin: 'The kid, they say, was born in a manger, but frankly I have my doubts...'. Though he fears the research it might entail, worries if he'll be around to finish it, he imagines a series of epic books that relocate Mount Olympus somewhere in the vicinity of Manhattan, tales which tend to begin with Hera cracking wise: 'My husband is my brother. Among us gods that's not unusual. But still doesn't excuse him from the way he acts...'

Pota has great titles (A Sexual Biography of my Wife is a favourite, and a project, too, that Heller was fond of referring to as a work in progress in his last interviews) but he lacks any conception of the words and sentences and chapters that might attach themselves to such promising monikers.

Epigraphs float to the surface of his mind in place of outlines or themes or characters or dialogue: he knows, for example, that he would like the Duchess of Marlborough's line 'Last night my Lord returned from the wars and pleasured me twice with his boots on' on a frontispiece, but he has no idea of its book-length addendum.

In desperation he lunches his editors who, of course, provide nothing but discouragement. Pota's waning literary possibilities are matched by his increasing physical frailty - 'How many naps,' he calculates at one point, 'can a reasonable person take a day... before he fairly judges himself stagnant, moribund?' - and more particularly undermined by anxieties over the twilight of his virility.

He is possessed by the fact that he still loves women, all women, 'the way they dressed and looked, the smell and sound and shape of them', and is bothered less than ever by ties of fidelity to his wife, but still unable quite to summon performance. He has a couple of Viagra tablets stashed, but more out of bravado than intent. He is instead killing time between desire and fulfilment.

As you read this book, you might imagine Heller laughing his way hugely through it, imagining posterity and, like Pota, creating long lists of writers whose lives have ended in despair: Scott Fitzgerald, Henry James, Dickens, Eliot, Conrad, Jack London, Eugene O'Neill, James Joyce, Sinclair Lewis, stopping only when he realises the condition applies to all the writers he can think of.

He ends up offering Yossarian-like advice to parents whose child expresses the wish to write a story: 'You must spring right into action to save that child. Stop it - if you can. Nip that ambition in the bud. Guide that child instead into beating drums, or a career as a juggler.' He half means it, of course, and in some ways this book is a sardonic little abdication address, a posthumous piece of caustic self-parody. But it is also, more exactly, one last muted hurrah from a writer who knows his place in the authorial Hall of Fame was never really in doubt.

The Republic of Britain: 1760-2000
Frank Prochaska
Allen Lane £20, pp320
Buy it at BOL

At the death of Oliver Cromwell, his memorial procession included the figures of John Milton, Andrew Marvell and John Dryden, a more splendid and noble attendance than has occurred at the funeral of any monarch. You would not know this 'republican' fact from the work of Frank Prochaska; for one thing his book begins at the arbitrary date of 1760 and for another he seems hopelessly unaware of the deep roots upon which the English anti-monarchical tradition can draw.

Prochaska's book is misleadingly entitled, as if to suggest it's a history of republican thought. It turns out to be a tepidly written apologia for monarchy, based on the somewhat casuistical assumption that we already live in a republic and have done so, without quite realising it, for some considerable time.

Now it is true, as he never wearies of saying, that the Latin words res publica only mean what they say - 'a thing of the public' - and do not necessarily connote an absence of kingship. Even Tom Paine, who is quoted too much and to too little effect in these pages, said that any form of democratic rule could be described as republican. But a moment's reflection disposes of this pedantry.

Does Prochaska think it would have made no difference if George Washington, Paine's commander-in-chief, had accepted the title of monarch instead of rejecting it? To the American project, whether Democratic or Republican, it would obviously have made an immense difference. (If his opening chapters induce anybody to read Paine in the original, they will partly redeem their nullity.)

Prochaska, who never misses a chance to condescend to the 'marginal' nature of republican agitation, never asks himself why it has kept on reviving and recombining. As I say, he starts in the wrong place. But he is intellectually at a loss to understand why the thread remains continuous, probably from 1389, if not earlier, and all the way through the Civil War, to the supporters of Paine and Wilkes, through Bentham, the Chartists, Bradlaugh and Dilke, the early Labour movement and - via innumerable filiations - to its strong revival today. Tennyson and H.G. Wells may both have popularised the oxymoron 'crowned republic', but the expression has not been bled of its absurdity.

He shows his hand, and his style, very early on: 'The greatest threat to the monarchy in modern history has come not from domestic enemies, but from external ones. Had Britain been defeated by Napoleon or lost wars in 1918 or 1945, the case against the Crown might have seemed more cogent. But in a nation that has not been invaded, nor had a revolution since the seventeenth century, in which the sovereign's power has dwindled to influence, it is perhaps not surprising that the monarchy has been retained. "Why keep it?" ask the enemies of the Crown. "Why all the fuss?" reply the general public, who refuse to be reasoned out of monarchy.'

Such a mass of confusion in such a few ill-chosen words! Prochaska's own subsequent evidence is enough to confirm that it was external menaces, from France and Germany and Russia, that served to confirm monarchy as a symbol of nationalism, and to mute domestic criticism. While, if the First World War had gone the other way, the victors or conquerors would have been a German branch of the newly-titled House of Windsor. (If the same had happened in 1940, which is the date I presume Prochaska intends, we know that Hitler planned to install the Nazified branch of that very family.) So it's hard to see where 'cases' or 'cogency' come in to it.

Finally, it is the enemies of the Crown who ask 'Why all the fuss?' at each successive display of ostentation and vulgarity, while to identify 'the general public' with the monarchist cause is to disqualify oneself as a historian.

The principal interest of this book lies exactly in the monarchy's realisation that it has not always been popular or secure. During the Regency, the reign of George IV and of William IV, republican feeling was evident and extreme police measures had to be employed to keep it in check. Late Victorian spin doctors fretted about the contempt in which the throne was held. At the time of the Abdication, there were Establishment figures who thought the game might be up. During the wedding hysteria of Prince Charles and Princess Diana, which even Robert Runcie, the late Archbishop of Canterbury, knew to be a frigid and empty fraud, who would have guessed how compromised the royal family would look two decades later?

Prochaska scores a few points on the inessential details. He is right in saying that the expense of the Civil List has generally been exaggerated. He is correct in pointing out that the Palace has always sought to use charity, and its patronage of same, as a tactic (to replace its lost ability to cure scrofula).

He leaves out, however, entire segments of relevant history, such as the royal family's support for appeasement. And he cannot set himself to answer the question why, if the monarchy is such a constitutional irrelevance, it is defended by the conservative interest with such irrational tenacity. Arguing against himself, in any case, he cites numerous examples of flagrant and unconstitutional meddling by the Crown, such as the private police-intelligence system directed at the Labour movement and maintained by George V.

All in all, it's a sorry mixture of a book, unable even to make its own contradictions interesting. A favourite and repeated jeer of the author's is that republicans look down on the masses they purport to represent. William Cobbett had an answer to that when he despaired of a public opinion that accepted 'the national debt and the Royal Mint'.

But those doing the looking down are still stationed on Buckingham Palace's balcony, where they find no shortage of court historians to join them. Give this man an OBE.

 Christopher Hitchens is a columnist for Vanity Fair. His latest book, No One Left to Lie To: the Values of the Worst Family, has just been published in paperback.

webTitle: Observer review: The Two Hearts of Kwasi Boachi by Arthur Japin

fields.headline: Bad blood brothers
fields.standfirst: Arthur Japin journeys to the dark heart of the 19th-century slave trade in The Two Hearts of Kwasi Boachi
fields.trailText: Arthur Japin journeys to the dark heart of the 19th-century slave trade in The Two Hearts of Kwasi Boachi
fields.body:
The Two Hearts of Kwasi Boachi
Arthur Japin
Chatto and Windus £12, pp342
Buy it at BOL

One of the most intricate difficulties of the writer's 'art' is to represent the crab-wise motions of thought and memory. In his first novel, Dutch writer Arthur Japin sets himself the task of creating a speaking head for Kwasi Boachi, a real-life African prince from the Ashanti tribe, who was sent in 1837 with his brother Kwame to the court of Willem I in the Netherlands.

Japin adds to the ambitiousness of his enterprise by crafting the tale as a memoir, written by Kwasi Boachi in a confused old age on a tea plantation in Java. Not only is this a tale of a youthful mind in violent transition - from the Ashanti world to the mannered court - but a tale told by a mind putting up for the night, fading fast.

As an enthusiastic youth, experiencing the glittering European court, Kwasi never knew that he had been sent over to cement a slavery deal. The deal allowed the Dutch to take Ashanti slaves, side-stepping anti-slavery edicts with a semantic sleight of hand.

Eager to placate and ingratiate, Kwasi evolved in early adulthood into a public speaker of some note, presenting himself to Dutch audiences as a reformed barbarian, denouncing Ashanti rites. In contrast to Kwasi's immersion, his brother Kwame refused to trust his hosts and turned his thoughts at all times to Africa. Their vastly different responses separated them - Kwame returned to the Ashanti tribe and Kwasi fell into years of ungainly striving to live the life of a European man of letters, to keep his memories of Africa submerged.

Japin's novel dwells mournfully on the ensuing aimlessness of the lives of Kwasi and Kwame. When Kwame returns to Africa, he can no longer track an animal, nor can he understand the Ashanti dialect. Heir to the Ashanti throne, he can neither communicate with his subjects, nor survive by the ways they survive.

In the case of Kwasi Boachi, the experiment to educate him as a European prince leaves him a wandering Caliban, left with an immaculate Dutch diction in which he can merely curse his teachers, educated to disdain his tribe but barred by his blackness from the 'civilised'. Japin has fashioned an intelligent contribution to the 'dark heart of Victoriana' genre, telling a far from antiquarian tale of the exploitation of the developing world by the shady legalese of richer countries.

webTitle: Observer review: A Blood-Dimmed Tide by Amos Elon

fields.headline: Digging for victory
fields.standfirst: Amos Elon's collection of penetrative essays, A Blood-Dimmed Tide, offers the sharpest analysis of the Arab-Israeli conflict
fields.trailText: Amos Elon's collection of penetrative essays, A Blood-Dimmed Tide, offers the sharpest analysis of the Arab-Israeli conflict
fields.body:
A Blood-Dimmed Tide: Dispatches from the Middle East
Amos Elon
Allen Lane £20, pp340
Buy it at BOL

In 1975, the British publisher George Weidenfeld contacted the former Israeli general Moshe Dayan with an idea for a book. At the time, it seemed like an odd idea. Dayan had been in the political wilderness for two years after resigning as Defence Minister over his handling of the Yom Kippur War.

Dayan had written a dull autobiography based on official briefings and some second-rate poetry, but no one saw him as a great literary talent. Nevertheless, Weidenfeld offered him a six-figure advance to write about the one real passion of his life apart from soldiering: archaeology. The result, Living with the Bible, is recognised as a classic of amateur research and was a great commercial success.

For Amos Elon, it is made all the more engaging - or offensive, depending on your perspective - by Dayan's deeply held conviction that the modern state of Israel was legitimised by the work of archaeologists. In one interview quoted in A Blood-Dimmed Tide, Dayan said: 'Everything that ancient Israel was. Those who lived here then... I sometimes feel I can literally enter their presence.'

Dayan, with his trademark eye patch and straight-backed military bearing, was an icon of the Israeli state, the very image of the tough 'new Jew', or Sabra, who had helped build the most powerful army in the Middle East within 30 years of the Holocaust. Archaeology may seem like a peculiar private passion for a man who was ridiculed as a brute by more obviously intellectual Israeli politicians - Golda Meir described him as 'that Arab' as a mark of her disdain. Elon explains, however, that archaeology was etched into the very soul of the new Israel. 'Dayan's fame,' he says, 'contributed to the popular appeal of archaeology as a bloodless field sport.'

The Arab-Israeli conflict has been dug over, sifted, noted, labelled and analysed more intensely than any other since the Second World War. The Israeli writer Elon has done more digging than most, and this collection of essays, written between 1967 and 1997, is truly great journalistic archaeology. First published three years ago, the collection has been fully revised in the light of recent developments and a new introduction was written after Ehud Barak's landslide election victory last year. It is worth reading for this introduction alone, a remarkable crystallisation of three decades of Israeli politics in 20 pages.

Elon's patriotism is honestly declared and only occasionally obtrusive. In his first-hand description of the Six Day War of 1967, he wears his pride in Israel's achievements on his sleeve, but this does cauterise him against his shock at the scale of the Israeli victory.

In scenes remarkably close to those witnessed in the allied defeat of Saddam Hussein's army in 1991, Elon recounts the complete humiliation of the Egyptian forces with genuine humanity, describing how many of the retreating soldiers threw off their uniforms in the hope of passing themselves off as civilians: 'Shoes - tens, hundreds of shoes, cast off when their owners, broken as soldiers, had turned into frightened men and tried to escape into the dry hills - barefoot in their underwear, bareheaded and without water.'

Meanwhile, Elon reports, Radio Cairo was broadcasting in Hebrew that victory was still possible: 'We have lured you into the desert so we can destroy your hinterland at our ease... we still haven't used our secret missiles... O foolish Israeli soldiers we'll catch your one-eyed General Dayan and take out his other eye.' There were no secret missiles and defeat was total.

Dayan is clearly Elon's favourite subject and there are two essays devoted entirely to the deeds of the general. But the essay on archaeology and politics is the real jewel of the collection. Written in 1995, it looks forward to a time when the Israeli people have escaped from a neurotic obsession with their past. The fact that the collapse of negotiations last week coincided with yet another demonstration of fundamentalist Jews at the Dome of the Rock suggests there is still a long way to go.

The title comes from Yeats: 'The blood-dimmed tide is loosed, and everywhere/ The ceremony of innocence is drowned.' These deeply pessimistic lines hang over the events of the book like a curse and act as a check on Elon's natural optimism. He will not have been surprised by the collapse of the peace talks at Camp David, although A Blood-Dimmed Tide concludes that the conditions have never been better for an agreement between sides for whom there really is no other option.

Like the true Mediterranean intellectual he is, Elon quotes at every opportunity. He ends his chapter on the link between archaeology and bloodshed in Israel with an extract from Auden, who visited Jerusalem shortly before his death:

From Archaeology

one moral, at least, may be drawn

to wit, that all

our school text books lie.

What they call History

is nothing to vaunt of,

being made, as it is

by the criminal in us:

goodness is timeless.

Archaeology and history remain the life-blood of this conflict.

fields.headline: Letters to the Editor
fields.trailText: German invasion was all talk
fields.body:
German invasion was all talk

P.E. Perry (Letters, last week) is wrong to claim that it was the lack of 'substantial control of the air' that stopped the German army from invading Britain in 1940. If we compare the lengthy training and enormous logistic support behind the D-Day landings to what was available to the Germans in the summer of 1940 it is obvious that any talk of invasion was only ever that, talk. Emotive as it is, given the anniversaries involved, mythologising our past neither serves the interests of those that lived it and or those that need to learn from it.
Chris McColl
Bournemouth

Maggots of 42

Maggots (News, last week) were in use for healing wounds as late as 1942. During the 'gentlemanly' war in North Africa, many of those PoWs with broken and shattered bones were treated by German medical staff who mended and plastered their wounds. After plastering, orderlies would push in bits of meat which quickly became maggoty. When the plaster was removed (usually in prison camps) the wounds were clean and healed. The process was itchy and stray maggots were hastily dispatched but the efficacy of the treatment was undoubted.
David Smith
Boston, Lincs

Princess is fine

It is not true to suggest that Princess Alice is some kind of prisoner in Kensington Palace (News, last week). She lives with her son, daughter-in-law and three grandchildren, who recreated her rooms from Barnwell there to make her feel at home. She still receives representatives of certain charities, and in both 1998 and 1999 enjoyed a winter holiday in Africa. She worked very hard until into her nineties and now, aged 98, and frailer than her sister-in-law, she has retired.
Hugo Vickers
Ramsdell, Hants

BBC turn-off

Where has Mr. Egglestone been (Letters last week)? The one good reason for watching the BBC has now disappeared with the advent of those awful strident previews/adverts of coming programmes. Am I alone in finding them distasteful and a real deterrent to watching the programmes they seek to promote?
John Davies
Reading

Calibre counts not gende

Ms Harriet Harman is campaigning for more women in Parliament (News, last week), but why? It is calibre not gender that counts. Most of the current women in Parliament voted for cuts in single parent benefit. Most of the current women in Parliament voted for cuts in disability benefit. There used to be an illusion that more women in politics would result in a more compassionate and fairer society - an illusion that can no longer be cherished by anyone.
S. Hamilton
London SW17

Grotesque morals

Is Nick Cohen less than gracious in his review of the Foreign Office third report (Comment, last week)? Only recently, Peter Hain was saying that we were 'flying the flag' of human rights throughout the world, keeping sanctions against Iraq and Serbia, though rejecting sanctions on Zimbabwe, because its people had suffered enough under Mugabe. Quite an achievement - to sound high-minded while remaining morally grotesque.
Adrian Kozlowski
Birmingham

I cut up my card

Hope rose in my heart when Andrew Rawnsley (Comment, last week) suggested New Labour is on the verge of self-destruct. I was appalled when I received my Labour Party card this year to read the declaration which used to say: 'The Labour Party is a socialist democratic party' but now reads 'New Labour is...' Labour Party rules say I cannot belong to any other political party so I cut up my card and returned it to the cuckoos of Millbank Tower.
Martin Lewis
Ipswich

Is this the right way to grieve?

Am I alone in being made uncomfortable at yet another scene of massed ranks of flowers and people hugging and weeping before the cameras for a person they had never heard of? The abduction and murder of a child is cruel, and echoes the fears that parents have of seeing their most precious children stolen from them. For Sarah Payne's parents there is hopefully something to be gained from the obvious sympathy that many feel.
So why am I discomfited? What is shown oversteps the mark between sympathy and voyeurism. It is not the much reviled `media' making news that is bothering me. It's the suspicion that for some people the difference between reality and soap opera is so blurred that these unfortunate events are being used as dramatic entertainment N. Humphrey
Frome, Somerset

It's a strange day when I agree with something the News Of The World does (News, last week). I fully agree with naming paedophiles, both so the general public know how to avoid them and so they can't hide under a cloak of anonymity.
I'm shocked at the number of registered paedophiles though, 110,000! As for the National Association for the Care and Resettlement of Offenders, maybe a little more thought should go into care for victims. I feel that if someone abuses another person's Human Rights, they should lose some of their own Human Rights.
It is a well known fact that children who are abused are much more likely to become abusers as adults. If we care for abused children better, and remove abusers from society more effectively, perhaps we can end this cycle of abuse.
Alan Gregson
Rochdale, Gtr Manchester

Open secrets

At the tailend of his article following the Court of Appeal's ruling on disclosure of information by The Observer/Guardian/himself (Focus, last week), Martin Bright says that `the case also raises issues around the so-called Defence Advisory or `D-Notice Committee'. It is hard to see why.
Lord Justice Judge did not refer to the D-Notice Committee in his comments on the evidence at the hearing nor in his conclusions, unsurprisingly, because the committee was not involved at all in this particular case, nor does it ever have any role in extracting information or documents from unwilling journalists, nor in any other legal matters concerning them or their sources. It is an independent and media-dominated committee, which produces advice to editors, broadcasters and publishers on matters of national security, so that they themselves can consider whether any detail in what they wish to disseminate would in fact cause damage, for example to present or future operation or to the operators. It is not concerned with suppressing other aspects of the story, however embarrassing to government and officials. And use of the system and of the advice is voluntary (see www.dnotice.org.uk).
As to Stephen Dorril's known personal antipathy to the D-Notice system, it is hard to understand how the availability of something which includes an informal mediation capability, is quite limited and specific in what it covers, and is optional, can be, as he describes it, 'corrosive'. The label also carries an implied poor opinion of the intelligence and independence of investigative journalists and of his fellow-authors, which I do not share.
Rear Admiral Nick Wilkinson
Defence, Press and Broadcasting Advisory Committee, Ministry of Defence, London SW1

Public menace

The truth about the beach parties mentioned in Teenage Kicks (Comment, last week) is also covered by the local newspaper, the Cornish Guardian, which speaks of 'drunken behaviour, noise and damage to property' perpetrated by the public-school pupils who have terrorised the local law-abiding community, as well as the ordinary families who have traditionally spent their holidays in this beautiful part of North Cornwall. What an insult it is to dismiss the local residents as 'real surfers'.
Endellion Sharpe
London SW4

US Embassy, London W1
fields.bodyText: German invasion was all talk P.E. Perry (Letters, last week) is wrong to claim that it was the lack of 'substantial control of the air' that stopped the German army from invading Britain in 1940. If we compare the lengthy training and enormous logistic support behind the D-Day landings to what was available to the Germans in the summer of 1940 it is obvious that any talk of invasion was only ever that, talk. Emotive as it is, given the anniversaries involved, mythologising our past neither serves the interests of those that lived it and or those that need to learn from it. Chris McColl Bournemouth Maggots of 42 Maggots (News, last week) were in use for healing wounds as late as 1942. During the 'gentlemanly' war in North Africa, many of those PoWs with broken and shattered bones were treated by German medical staff who mended and plastered their wounds. After plastering, orderlies would push in bits of meat which quickly became maggoty. When the plaster was removed (usually in prison camps) the wounds were clean and healed. The process was itchy and stray maggots were hastily dispatched but the efficacy of the treatment was undoubted. David Smith Boston, Lincs Princess is fine It is not true to suggest that Princess Alice is some kind of prisoner in Kensington Palace (News, last week). She lives with her son, daughter-in-law and three grandchildren, who recreated her rooms from Barnwell there to make her feel at home. She still receives representatives of certain charities, and in both 1998 and 1999 enjoyed a winter holiday in Africa. She worked very hard until into her nineties and now, aged 98, and frailer than her sister-in-law, she has retired. Hugo Vickers Ramsdell, Hants BBC turn-off Where has Mr. Egglestone been (Letters last week)? The one good reason for watching the BBC has now disappeared with the advent of those awful strident previews/adverts of coming programmes. Am I alone in finding them distasteful and a real deterrent to watching the programmes they seek to promote? John Davies Reading Calibre counts not gende Ms Harriet Harman is campaigning for more women in Parliament (News, last week), but why? It is calibre not gender that counts. Most of the current women in Parliament voted for cuts in single parent benefit. Most of the current women in Parliament voted for cuts in disability benefit. There used to be an illusion that more women in politics would result in a more compassionate and fairer society - an illusion that can no longer be cherished by anyone. S. Hamilton London SW17 Grotesque morals Is Nick Cohen less than gracious in his review of the Foreign Office third report (Comment, last week)? Only recently, Peter Hain was saying that we were 'flying the flag' of human rights throughout the world, keeping sanctions against Iraq and Serbia, though rejecting sanctions on Zimbabwe, because its people had suffered enough under Mugabe. Quite an achievement - to sound high-minded while remaining morally grotesque. Adrian Kozlowski Birmingham I cut up my card Hope rose in my heart when Andrew Rawnsley (Comment, last week) suggested New Labour is on the verge of self-destruct. I was appalled when I received my Labour Party card this year to read the declaration which used to say: 'The Labour Party is a socialist democratic party' but now reads 'New Labour is...' Labour Party rules say I cannot belong to any other political party so I cut up my card and returned it to the cuckoos of Millbank Tower. Martin Lewis Ipswich Is this the right way to grieve? Am I alone in being made uncomfortable at yet another scene of massed ranks of flowers and people hugging and weeping before the cameras for a person they had never heard of? The abduction and murder of a child is cruel, and echoes the fears that parents have of seeing their most precious children stolen from them. For Sarah Payne's parents there is hopefully something to be gained from the obvious sympathy that many feel. So why am I discomfited? What is shown oversteps the mark between sympathy and voyeurism. It is not the much reviled `media' making news that is bothering me. It's the suspicion that for some people the difference between reality and soap opera is so blurred that these unfortunate events are being used as dramatic entertainment N. Humphrey Frome, Somerset It's a strange day when I agree with something the News Of The World does (News, last week). I fully agree with naming paedophiles, both so the general public know how to avoid them and so they can't hide under a cloak of anonymity. I'm shocked at the number of registered paedophiles though, 110,000! As for the National Association for the Care and Resettlement of Offenders, maybe a little more thought should go into care for victims. I feel that if someone abuses another person's Human Rights, they should lose some of their own Human Rights. It is a well known fact that children who are abused are much more likely to become abusers as adults. If we care for abused children better, and remove abusers from society more effectively, perhaps we can end this cycle of abuse. Alan Gregson Rochdale, Gtr Manchester Open secrets At the tailend of his article following the Court of Appeal's ruling on disclosure of information by The Observer/Guardian/himself (Focus, last week), Martin Bright says that `the case also raises issues around the so-called Defence Advisory or `D-Notice Committee'. It is hard to see why. Lord Justice Judge did not refer to the D-Notice Committee in his comments on the evidence at the hearing nor in his conclusions, unsurprisingly, because the committee was not involved at all in this particular case, nor does it ever have any role in extracting information or documents from unwilling journalists, nor in any other legal matters concerning them or their sources. It is an independent and media-dominated committee, which produces advice to editors, broadcasters and publishers on matters of national security, so that they themselves can consider whether any detail in what they wish to disseminate would in fact cause damage, for example to present or future operation or to the operators. It is not concerned with suppressing other aspects of the story, however embarrassing to government and officials. And use of the system and of the advice is voluntary (see www.dnotice.org.uk). As to Stephen Dorril's known personal antipathy to the D-Notice system, it is hard to understand how the availability of something which includes an informal mediation capability, is quite limited and specific in what it covers, and is optional, can be, as he describes it, 'corrosive'. The label also carries an implied poor opinion of the intelligence and independence of investigative journalists and of his fellow-authors, which I do not share. webTitle: There's nothing like a good disaster

fields.headline: There's nothing like a good disaster
fields.standfirst: Why is it only at times like the Concorde crash that we feel united? What happened to everyday public spirit and common purpose?
fields.trailText: We British are changing. Plane crashes aren't new but the reaction to Concorde is becoming part of a pattern. Diana. The Paddington train crash. Even, in a way, Sarah Payne. The interest in the the emotional and the intimate has been steadily rising for years, and a disaster meets this mood as almost the perfect public event. It legitimises our individualistic society's need to feel, and to do so, however shallowly, together.
fields.body:
We British are changing. Plane crashes aren't new but the reaction to Concorde is becoming part of a pattern. Diana. The Paddington train crash. Even, in a way, Sarah Payne. The interest in the the emotional and the intimate has been steadily rising for years, and a disaster meets this mood as almost the perfect public event. It legitimises our individualistic society's need to feel, and to do so, however shallowly, together.

Of course, a plane crash is a more complete disaster than almost any other. Nobody settling into the cocoon of a plane journey does so without for an instant thinking about a crash. The passengers of Concorde last Wednesday will have had similar thoughts, but two minutes into the flight those shadowy, fleeting fears became reality. They will have known that they had seconds left to live. Just to imagine the sensation is to be engulfed in horror.

But this was always true. What is different today is that our powers of empathy, and thus our capacity to be hurt, seem to be much more inflated. Part of the story is the media. Those pictures of the flames behind the doomed plane have been replayed a thousand times, refracting the reality back to us and making it larger than life. Yet for all the gigantic journalistic investment, the yield in extra knowledge has not been great. But not one editor dared declare independence from the stampede.

For these disasters are no longer solely news events. They have become hours when an individualistic society pursuing all kinds of disparate ends pulls together for a moment. The British are now the most secular Western society, at least judging by the declining proportion saying they have formal religious belief. But a disaster allows the triggering of a substitute for collective religious worship. It draws us together in awe, appealing to our deepest instincts to hold something sacred in common - and that something is life.

There is a street corner in Islington, north London, where a young man was recently mugged to death. There has been little national media coverage but almost spontaneously the pavement was covered with flowers. It is a shallow, almost narcissistic impulse; most people hardly knew the man, but still they feel the almost Catholic need to participate in making the place he died a shrine. It is a quasi-religious act springing from an individual need to share grief and emotion publicly; I can't imagine it taking place even 10 years ago. In this sense, the media is only reflecting an impulse that is already out there.

These disasters have all the more power because we live in times in which we have lost the sense of our past. No longer, as Christopher Lasch famously argued in The Culture of Narcissism, do we see ourselves as another generation connected to previous generations. We feel ourselves to stand alone, to have shrugged off the old bonds of religion, family, community ties and lifelong employment with one company. We are navigating alone in new territory, in which the experiences of the past have declining use for us. Thus we have little sense of memory in which to place a catastrophe in some relative context.

This sense of being estranged from old structures is not just a feeling about what it means to be modern; it reflects a social truth. Last week, for example, my own organisation, the Industrial Society, published its first essay on the changing face of work. In `Most wanted - the quiet birth of the free worker', John Knell details how a growing number of people are choosing to work as self-employed independents, using the internet to sell their services, exploiting the way companies are becoming more porous and ready to buy in contracted work rather than offer careers.

These `free workers', who in London now represent one in 10 of the workforce, are shifting from an organisational to what Knell calls a `protean' career. Typically, they have some knowledge or skill that gives them market power, they are self-confident and, as importantly, so desirous of controlling their own lives that they want to work freely. They dress as they choose, work where and when they want and move on from project to project in search of excitement. As this culture grows, so companies are having to imitate these conditions internally if they want to hold on to talented workers who have the option of declaring independence.

If we are becoming more detached from organisations, it is not only because they are less loyal to us; we are less loyal to them. To be a free worker is a positive step; it allows a declaration of independence from the ordinary that we all want to make. It is part of a culture in which more of us exercise alone rather than in teams; in which we are increasingly concerned about how to live well; in which we want to hold those who make mistakes in any sphere - from the NHS to national cricket selectors - to individual account.

This new individualism means that we look inside ourselves, to our own relationships and career to provide excitement and reward rather than acting together in a public or political context. Hence the increase in political apathy and distrust of politicians. But it was not just politics that used to express public purpose. Concorde was born in a world in which technology was as much a Promethean public adventure as politics. It was another triumph of human ingenuity over nature. There would soon be manned space stations. And while scientists and technologists opened up new frontiers, there was a parallel clash of political ideologies. The future might be capitalist, it might be socialist, but either vision was realisable and worth fighting for. We changed the world by acting on it.

Concorde was a symbol of all that and for 25 years it succeeded. But now it, too, has crashed, making us even less confident that we can look to the public domain for excitement and enduring transformations. Our scepticism about public possibility is once more reduced, confirming that what counts is our inner journey over which we have some degree of control. But the paradox is that we still need to find some way of acting together, hence our reaction to the disaster. But shared emotion is a poor substitute for reasoned public purpose; it is quixotic, erratic, even dangerous - the midwife of tabloid vigilante justice and xenophobia alike. Modern times, certainly, but the need to find some way of reinventing the legitimacy of public purpose has never seemed more urgent.

webTitle: The day mere girls subdued Baden-Powell

fields.headline: The day mere girls subdued Baden-Powell
fields.standfirst: Six teenagers stole into a Scout jamboree in 1909 - and paved the way for the Guides
fields.trailText: Their identities have never been revealed before. But now pictures discovered in the London archives of the Guide Association introduce us to the girls who forced Robert Baden-Powell to establish the Girl Guides. The young women shown here were part of a group who turned up and demanded entry to Britain's first Scout jamboree in September 1909.
fields.body:
Their identities have never been revealed before. But now pictures discovered in the London archives of the Guide Association introduce us to the girls who forced Robert Baden-Powell to establish the Girl Guides. The young women shown here were part of a group who turned up and demanded entry to Britain's first Scout jamboree in September 1909.

Forbidden to join their brothers, they donned scout uniforms and crept into the grounds of Crystal Palace before confronting scouting's founding father Baden-Powell. The Guide Association was eventually set up by Baden-Powell to see off the monstrous regiment of interlopers.

'In the summer we heard about the rally at Crystal Palace through the local boy scouts,' wrote Sybil Canadine in notes sent to the Guide Association. She was 13 in 1909 and living in Camberwell, south London.

'We hadn't got authority for the adventure but we got ourselves into some sort of scout uniform with Boy Scout shirts and hats which we had borrowed from Scouts not going to the rally.'

'4 September 1909 was a rather cold and misty day. We walked the six miles to Crystal Palace because between us we only had enough money to get home by bus and not to take a bus there.'

Baden-Powell had called together 11,000 Boy Scouts from around the country, two years after his first experiment with young boys on Brownsea Island in Poole Harbour. The legendary hero of the 1900 relief of Mafeking had acknowledged in his recently published Scouting for Boys: 'There have been women scouts of the nation too, such as Grace Darling, who risked her life to save a shipwrecked crew, Miss Kingsley the African explorer, Lady Lugard in Africa and Alaska, and many devoted lady missionaries and nurses in all parts of our Empire.' But he did not envisage them joining his boys.

Nesta Maude, from Sussex, recalled: 'We marched up to the entrance but were told quite firmly by a steward that we could not join the rally. We didn't argue, but when the next troop of boys appeared and marched through the gate, they had two camp followers on the gate marshal's blind side. Once inside, no power on earth would have got us out.'

The girls sat on the edge of the arena where a series of displays and march-pasts took place. 'One of the ones I remember most,' said Canadine, 'was the use of two bicycles to bring in casualties on home-made stretchers made up of poles and coats.'

Seventy years later she still had perfect recollection of what happened next: 'Quite suddenly from the other side of the arena a figure started to come, in fact strode, over towards us. We realised that it was Baden-Powell himself.

'We scrambled down the bank where we were sitting... and he came towards us demanding: 'What the dickens are you doing here?'

'Our `patrol leader' said: 'We want to do the same thing as the boys. We want to be girl scouts.' Baden-Powell said: 'That's impossible, this is only for the boys.'

'We thought he was going to send us away but in the end he said: 'I'll think about it.' We went into the arena when it began to rain and then joined the march-past. We were put at the back with some other girls.

'We were laughed at, we were whistled at, there were catcalls, but we didn't mind. We were there and we were part of the show and when the speeches were over and the telegram from the King was read we raised our hats and our poles and cheered the King and we did the same and cheered Baden-Powell.'

Two months later an embarrassed Baden-Powell published a pamphlet proposing scout training for girls. They were to be called Guides after some - male - trackers Baden-Powell recalled operating on the north-west frontier of India when he had served in the 13th Hussars.

With his sister Agnes, who became first President of the Guide Association, Baden-Powell wrote the first handbook for his Guides, How Girls Can Help Build Up the Empire. In February 1910 the Guide Association was incorporated, a triumph for the young women who had invaded Crystal Palace five months earlier. Soon after, Baden-Powell's new wife Olave became the association's first chief guide.

The mobilisation of Guides to service the 1914-18 war effort helped dispel prejudice against them. They were awarded a War Service badge after working for 21 days in a hospital or if they knitted at least 15 articles, including socks and a bed jacket, for war heroes.

In the intervening century, legions of feisty young women - including Clare Short, Julie Burchill, Mo Mowlam and Glenda Jackson - have passed through their ranks. The movement for young women now has 650,000 members, substantially more than the now-mixed Scouts who spurned them under the damp skies of south London in September 1909.

www.guides.org.uk ben.summerskill@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Japan's greedy grooms choose rich life with mother-in-law

fields.headline: Japan's greedy grooms choose rich life with mother-in-law
fields.trailText: When a serious courtship began nine years ago with the man who was to become her husband, Yukari Takada grew tense with apprehension over an ancient predicament in Japan that has only grown more urgent in an increasingly childless age.
fields.byline: by Howard W. French Amato, Japan
fields.body:
When a serious courtship began nine years ago with the man who was to become her husband, Yukari Takada grew tense with apprehension over an ancient predicament in Japan that has only grown more urgent in an increasingly childless age.

As the second daughter in a family of two children, Takada was feeling strong pressure from her parents to preserve their family name. Furthermore, since her older sister's husband was a firstborn son who would have to care for his parents, she expected that the burden of nursing her own parents in their old age would fall upon her shoulders.

So when Makoto Taki mura, a reporter with the local newspaper, finally overcame his shyness and proposed, Takada accepted, but with the request that he come to live with her in her parents' house and adopt her family name. This would reverse the longstanding practice in Japan of a woman joining her husband's family, taking his name and caring for his parents.

`My mother really wanted him to become an adopted groom,' said the 34-year-old woman, who teaches classical Japanese music. Adopted grooms are men who take their wives' names, an age-old but fading custom.

fields.headline: BA urged to ground Concorde
fields.trailText: British Airways was coming under new pressure from within the airline industry last night to ground its Concorde fleet, after it emerged that last week's Paris disaster was almost certainly caused by design weaknesses identified as potentially catastrophic more than 20 years ago.
fields.byline: by Jason Burke and Arnold Kemp (Paris) and Joanna Walters
fields.body:
British Airways was coming under new pressure from within the airline industry last night to ground its Concorde fleet, after it emerged that last week's Paris disaster was almost certainly caused by design weaknesses identified as potentially catastrophic more than 20 years ago.

A series of reports in recent years has warned both BA and Air France of Concorde's vulnerability to both tyre failure and fire - the causes of last week's tragedy. French investigators yesterday confirmed that tyre failure set off the chain of events that destroyed the plane and, for the first time, gave a definitive account of the disaster in which 114 people died.

Sources close to the inquiry said that seconds before the plane took off one or two tyres exploded, sending rubber and metal debris showering on to the plane's left wing and its two port engines. One fragment punctured a fuel tank, sending a stream of fuel into the plane's afterburners which had been ignited to provide extra thrust for take-off. Debris was also sucked into the jets.

As the pilot lifted the plane's nose, one of the four engines failed completely and a second lost power. Unable to maintain height and speed the plane sank to the left and crashed in a fireball.

BA insisted yesterday that all its seven Concordes were safe to continue flying. Jean-Claude Gayssot, the French Minister of Transport, said efforts were continuing to find new control systems to allow Air France to resume its Concorde flights, which are grounded indefinitely.

He will want to know why Air France has had more incidents of burst Concorde tyres than BA. The French use American Goodyear tyres. BA uses British Dunlops.

The disaster involved one of at least seven serious tyre failures on Air France Concordes that have damaged the aircraft or engines in the last 25 years. BA has had only two, both of them being less harmful.

John Hutchinson, an ex- BA Concorde captain, said: 'It is odd that Air France has had an inordinate number of tyre failures.'

The Observer has established that the tyre failure alarm fitted to all Concordes failed to prevent the tragedy of Flight AF4590. It should stop planes attempting to take off with tyres susceptible to blow-outs. The pilot, Captain Christian Marty, received no warning. When he made his split-second decision to continue the take-off rather than abort it, Marty believed he was dealing with a simple engine failure.

Concorde's delta shape and long fuselage would have made a visual check on the tyres impossible. As he took off, he merely told the control tower that one engine was out and even attempted to raise the crippled undercarriage, contrary to procedure in the event of a burst tyre.

Senior Air France crew endorsed the suspension of its Concorde flights. Francois Pradon said: 'I don't want to pilot Concorde again until I know what's happened.' The investigators are looking closely at a blow-out in 1979 on a French Concorde taking off from Washington, when debris punctured its fuel tanks. Luckily a fire was avoided then.

The Bureau Enquetes-Accidents is painstakingly reconstructing the crashed plane from the wreckage at a secret location.

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: Prisoner found hanged in Birmingham cell
fields.body:
Prisoner found hanged in Birmingham cell

Convicted burglar Michael Phelan was found hanging in his cell at Birmingham prison yesterday. Phelan, 23, was already dead when two guards found him hanging from bedsheets tied to his cell window at 1.51am.

Boy, 10, is beach rescue hero

A 10-year-old boy saved a family of three from the sea using his father's jetski. off Aberarch Beach near Pwlheli, north-west Wales after they fell from their inflatable boat. Matthew Dyson made two journeys to rescue the father, mother and daughter.

Neighbour on suicide charge

Anthony Bowler, 66, has been charged with assisting in the suicide of a neighbour. He was granted bail at a court in Carmarthen, South Wales. The body of a 63-year-old woman was found on Thursday at her home near Newcastle Emlyn.

Roddy Doyle

In the Review's special summer reading issue of 2 July we wrongly ascribed a reading list to Roddy Doyle, the celebrated Irish author. Unfortunately, owing to a misunderstanding the 'Roddy Doyle' we spoke to, and who gave us a very interesting selection of summer reading, was a computer engineer from north London.

Artists grin and bear it

Performance artists Cai and Xi walked naked across Westminster Bridge in London yesterday. They scrawled slogans on their bodies promoting artistic freedom and they held a Panda bear. The artists said its name was Tony Bear because the Chinese cannot pronounce the 'l' in Blair. Last year the pair staged a pillow fight on Tracey Emin's bed installation in the Tate.

BBC castaways' family reunion

The volunteers living on the remote Scottish island of Taransay as part of the BBC's Castaway 2000 TV show, had emotional reunions yesterday with their friends and family. It was the first time the 34 castaways had seen their loved ones in seven months.

999 ambulance kills woman

Police are investigating the death of an 86-year-old woman hit by a Kent NHS Trust paramedic ambulance answering an emergency call. The pensioner died at Maidstone General Hospital.

DNA hunt for serial sex pest

Police hunting a serial sex attacker nicknamed the Thursday Rapist have begun taking DNA mouth swabs from 100 men. The rapist is blamed for at least 13 sex attacks and one rape over the past four years in West Sussex, including an attack on a 12-year-old girl.

Major minor is a Harrison

James Major and his wife Emma Noble have named their new-born son Harrison John Major. The 8lb 13oz baby, who is the grandson of former Conservative Prime Minister John Major, was born on Friday at 4.58pm.

webTitle: If you're addicted to beetroot, blame your mother...

fields.headline: If you're addicted to beetroot, blame your mother...
fields.trailText: Want to make sure your children eat their broccoli? Then all you have to do, mothers, is eat platefuls yourselves.
fields.body:
Want to make sure your children eat their broccoli? Then all you have to do, mothers, is eat platefuls yourselves.

Scientists in the US have found that foods eaten late in pregnancy, or during breastfeeding, tend to be favoured by their children as they grow up. Parents' dearest wish - of finding a way to get their kids to eat what they are given - could soon be realised.

The discovery, made by scientists at the Monell Chemical Senses Centre, Philadelphia, is the latest and most striking study to demonstrate that experiences in the womb have a strong influence on subsequent lives. Old wives' tales about frights and foods affecting unborn babies have more than a grain of truth, it seems.

'We now know that what goes on in the womb can have a profound effect on a person for the rest of their lives, even into their sixties and seventies,' said Dr Keith Godfrey, of the Medical Research Council environmental epidemiology unit, Southampton.

The latest research, outlined at the American Psychological Society in Miami and reported in Science last week, involved pregnant women divided into three groups. Some were given carrot juice in the third trimester of pregnancy, others during the time that they breastfed their babies. A third group drank only water at these times.

The researchers, led by Julie Mennella, then waited until the women's children were more than six months old before giving them cereal that was either prepared with carrot juice or water. The team's results were clear, states Science: 'The babies exposed to carrot flavour either prenatally or in breast milk were much more enthusiastic about the carrot porridge than the plain mix; the other infants did not show a preference.'

The researchers say the discovery is the first experimental demonstration that exposure in the womb affects taste preferences in later life, and also suggests that breastfeeding is superior to feeding children with pre-prepared formula foods because the former will make them more accepting of new tastes. In addition, researchers speculate that dietary imprinting may have evolved because it helps new-born mammals learn more quickly what foods are safe or dangerous, while other scientists point out that in many countries women deliberately eat strongly spiced foods that are typical of their culture to ensure their rapid acclimatisation to such meals.

If the researchers are right, the offspring of Catherine Zeta-Jones and Madonna - who are both about to give birth - are likely to have decidedly odd eating habits. The former admits to being a beetroot addict, and the other has taken to wallowing in mud.
