webTitle: Brussels 'fat cats' to lose their cream

fields.headline: Brussels 'fat cats' to lose their cream
fields.standfirst: Closure for elite's cut-rate food shop targeted by tabloids
fields.trailText: Brussels will never be the same again. A controversial supermarket which has supplied Eurocrats with cheap booze and food since the Sixties is to close within the year after scathing attacks in the British tabloids.
fields.body:
Brussels will never be the same again. A controversial supermarket which has supplied Eurocrats with cheap booze and food since the Sixties is to close within the year after scathing attacks in the British tabloids.

Described as `one of the EU's most damning secrets' and `the most exclusive shop in the world', the Economat is stocked with delicacies from the EU's 15 member states which officials can buy at highly competitive prices. The much maligned shop has long since passed into Brussels folklore and was clearly becoming an embarrassment which did not sit well with the Commission's publicly stated aim of cleaning up its tarnished image.

Tucked away in the basement of a nondescript commission building on Rue de la Science, the shop is not signposted and its doors are shut to the general public. Entry is by EU identity pass only. Often compared to the former special shops for the Soviet elite, its shelves are laden with virgin olive oil for the Italians, breakfast tea for the Brits and a legendary selection of wine and spirits. It also stocks cut-price bottles of champagne whose labels bear the EU's stars emblem.

Its raison d'etre when it was first set up was to allow homesick Eurocrats to enjoy their favourite food and drink, then not readily available in Brussels.

But controversially, staff salaries and running costs are effectively paid by EU taxpayers, a fact which has made it an easy target for some of the UK's more Euro-sceptical tabloids. It is often claimed that the food and booze is tax-free, but in fact it is simply cheaper because the shop is run on a non-profit basis.

Its days are now numbered and a decision has been taken to shut it down as part of a review carried out to determine what the European Commission's priority tasks should be.

The issue has proved so emotive in the past, however, that the Commission is noticeably reluctant to publicise what some consider to be a rather humiliating climb-down and others believe to be a dose of common sense.

News of its closure is buried in a document detailing which activities the Commission is set to phase out, but no mention is made of its name and its demise is disguised as job losses in `techni cal service'. Neil Kinnock, who is charged with reforming the Commission, did admit last week, however, that its existence can no longer be justified.

`I couldn't justify the continued maintenance of shopkeeping as one of the roles of the European Commission,' he said. `It's been very clear to me that the Economat had its place at the beginning of the Commission, but as the decades have passed and it became evident that you can get the same foods in the local supermarkets the justification for retaining it has diminished.'

The store is not, he was at pains to stress, a perk for `fatcat Eurocrats'. But the British tabloids beg to differ and `exposed' the Economat's existence last year with fierce indignation.

`A carefully guarded shop where the bloated EU porkers can dip their trotters into piles of cut-price caviar and reservoirs of champagne,' was how the Sun described it, while the Mail on Sunday dubbed it a `Eurocratic Harrods'.

EU officials vehemently deny that the decision to close it down was prompted by media criticism and many continue to argue that there is nothing unsavoury or untoward about its existence.

But at a time when public support for Britain's membership of the European Union, let alone the single currency, has plunged to its lowest level in 20 years, EU spin-doctors are acutely aware that the Economat has had its day.

webTitle: Fury as Japan unleashes its harpoons

fields.headline: Fury as Japan unleashes its harpoons
fields.standfirst: Officially it's called research - but in Tokyo a slice of sperm whale sells for £20
fields.trailText: The four boats that slipped out of the Japanese ports of Shimonoseki, Inonshina and Shiyogawa yesterday provoked no interest, no crowds, and no announcement of their destination. They looked for all the world like boats heading for local fishing grounds.  But these ships were on a mission that is very far from being innocent. Over the next 24 hours they will rendezvous at sea and proceed on a task that will engulf their country in criticism and bitter disapproval: the resumption of the hunting of some of the world's largest and most endangered whales.
fields.body:
The four boats that slipped out of the Japanese ports of Shimonoseki, Inonshina and Shiyogawa yesterday provoked no interest, no crowds, and no announcement of their destination. They looked for all the world like boats heading for local fishing grounds. But these ships were on a mission that is very far from being innocent. Over the next 24 hours they will rendezvous at sea and proceed on a task that will engulf their country in criticism and bitter disapproval: the resumption of the hunting of some of the world's largest and most endangered whales.

Despite last-minute personal pleas from Tony Blair and Bill Clinton to the Japanese Prime Minister, the vessels are scheduled to kill a total of 100 minke, 50 Brydes (pronounced brooder) and 10 sperm whales in the North Pacific in the next few days. It is the biggest catch attempted since a world ban on whaling was introduced two decades ago. According to Japan's Fisheries Agency, the aim is merely to study the eating and migratory behaviour of the animals. The fact that their meat will then be sold to local markets in Japan is merely a by-product, it claims.

Yesterday most world leaders and environmentalists lined up to denounce this claim. 'The bottom line is that there is no convincing scientific reason for the Japanese to kill any whales at all,' said Helen Clark, the New Zealand Prime Minister. 'It is well known that meat from the whales killed during these 'scientific' expeditions finishes up at Japanese dinner tables. That's what appals people.'

Sperm whales - the giant toothed whales immortalised by Herman Melville in Moby Dick - have the largest brains of any mammal, and also the most valuable flesh. The Japanese eat it raw - for £20 a slice in Tokyo restaurants. The fact that Japan has decided to kill Brydes and sperm - which are much larger than the minkes that they have already hunted 'scientifically' over the past few years - has provoked particular fury. These animals require processing in large factory ships that are currently banned under International Whaling Commission rules.

'This raises the spectre of a return to the sort of big-time whaling that drove many species of whales to the brink of extinction over the past century,' said Richard Mott, vice-president of the World Wildlife Fund.

Three high-powered catcher boats will form the first wave of attack against the whales. As they approach one of the giant animals, a harpoon with an explosive head will be fired at its head, shattering its cerebral cortex. The carcass will then be pulled back to the catcher boat, before being brought to the foruth boat, the factory ship. Then the whale will be dragged up its main ramp and butchered. By the time the fleet returns to Japan in a few weeks, all whale meat will have been boxed ready for selling.

The prospect of this butchery has enraged Western leaders and officials. Last week Tony Blair and President Clinton both spoke person ally to Japan's Prime Minister and pressed him to reconsider his country's decision - to no avail.

'This decision is a slap in the face of President Clinton, Prime Minister Blair and many others around the world who have been working to persuade Japan to cancel its plans,' said Fred O'Regan, president of the International Fund for Animal Welfare. This view was shared by Richard Page, whale campaigner for Greenpeace. 'Japan clearly has no interest in the future of whale populations or world opinion,' he said. Japan's proposal to increase the intensity of its whaling missions was opposed bitterly at the last meeting of the International Whaling Commision which passed a resolution condemning the plan. For its part, Japan has rejected the motion.

'This is really an aggressive move by Japan,' said Rolland Schmitten, US Deputy Assistant Secretary of Commerce. 'These whales do not have to be killed for science.' This view was backed by a UK Ministry of Agriculture official. 'We are completely opposed to this. It flies in the face of world opinion,' he said.

The widening rift between Western nations and Japan shows that the latter's small but powerful whaling lobby now threatens to isolate the nation utterly. Japanese politicians believe that their relatively small scientific whaling missions are actually helping to pave the way for a return to full commercial whaling in the near future. Japan even pressed the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species (Cites) in April to remove many whales species from its 'Appendix One' category so that limited hunting of these animals, and trading in their products, could be resumed. However, the bid was squashed by a huge majority of countries, suggesting that, far from paving the way for the resumption of commercial whaling, Japan's antics are hardening the rest of the world to its stance.

At this month's whaling commission annual meeting in Adelaide, an attempt to create a whale sanctuary in the South Pacific was narrowly defeated - largely thanks to Japan's open offers of aid to countries in Africa and the Caribbean in return for their votes at the conference.

However, observers believe that at next year's meeting, in London, even this tactic will fail.

The hunted

Northern right whale: up to 59ft long and 80 tonnes in weight.

Status: it is heavily hunted and numbers may be as low as 350.

Minke whale: up to 33ft long and 10 tonnes in weight.

Status: insufficient data, but it is the only whale which is hunted commercially.

Sperm whale: up to 60ft long and 50 tonnes. Numbers have dropped to a sixth of the million which existed at the turn of the century.

Status: vulnerable.

Blue whale: up to 88ft long and 120 tonnes. Only 460 left from the turn of the century population of a quarter of a million.

Status: endangered.

Bryde's whale: up to 72ft long and 80 tonnes in weight. There used to be 78,000, but no one knows its status now.

webTitle: Maze prisoners find freedom has its price

fields.headline: Maze prisoners find freedom has its price
fields.standfirst: The ex-terrorists see their offences as political but outside jail they're treated as common criminals. John O'Farrell reports
fields.trailText: The ex-terrorists see their offences as political but outside jail they're treated as common criminals. John O'Farrell reports
fields.body:
The 78 paramilitary prisoners who left the Maze prison last Friday may be celebrating freedom, but their re-entry into civil society will be as hard as that of any released convict.

Despite their `political' status in jail, in the outside world the freed prisoners will be seen as ordinary ex-criminals by government agencies and financial institutions. The Children's Order prohibits anyone convicted of a sexual offence or violent crime from adopting or fostering children, and the former prisoners' partners will not be allowed to become registered childminders. There is no discretion made for the `political' nature of the offences.

Likewise, the Department of the Environment routinely refuses Public Service Vehicle licences to ex-prisoners.

They face further problems from financial institutions, who also make no distinction between criminal and political convictions. A former IRA prisoner filled out her home insurance form and replied `no' to the question `do you have any criminal convictions?' When her house in north Belfast was damaged by an accidental fire, her claim was refused by the insurance company. She was held to have lied on her insurance form.

The insurance companies, banks and government agencies claim this is `standard pro cedure'. But according to Mike Richie, a member of a support group for former IRA prisoners, `there are double standards at work' because the Government treats politically motivated acts differently from criminal offences in compensation claims for injuries and damages.

Richie cites the case of Paddy O'Hagan, a former IRA prisoner whose pregnant wife Kathleen was shot dead by the UVF in 1994. O'Hagan was refused compensation, despite being left with four young children to support. Even minor offences remain unforgiven by the Compensation Agency Ð as in the case of a west Belfast man who was given a six-month suspended sentence in 1974, when he was 16, for membership of Na Fianna Eireann, the youth wing of the republican movement. `He was caught training with a hurley stick.' Although avoiding any `involvement' since, he was refused compensation after being beaten by loyalists 21 years later in a random sectarian attack.

`He almost lost his sight and will never work again to support his family,' says Richie. `He has received no compensation.'

The reason given by the Compensation Agency is that past membership of a paramilitary organisation counts as `contributory negligence'. In September 1992, a 2,000lb IRA bomb wrecked the forensic science laboratories and damaged 700 homes in the loyalist Belvoir estate in south Belfast. Nearly all householders were compensated for both the physical and psychological collateral damage, apart from one former UVF inmate. He received nothing, according to Martin Snoddon, member of a support group for loyalist ex-prisoners.

A released prisoner was running a successful small shop in Portadown, until the Continuity IRA devastated the centre of the town in February 1998. Other business owners received criminal damage compensation but the ex-prisoner was refused on the grounds of `contributory negligence'.

In terms of jobs, there are still areas which will remain off-limits for `political' offenders, including, Richie says, `an automatic bar on civil service jobs'. Both Chris Patten and Peter Mandelson have said that a bar will operate in the new Police Service.

Richie believes the only solution is to call a blanket amnesty for all offences committed before the Belfast Agreement.

Prisoners' groups cite a precedent in UK legislation. At the time of Zimbabwean independence in 1980, a Bill was passed which had the effect of cancelling out all atrocities committed by both the white-minority illegal government of Ian Smith and the guerrilla Patriotic Front. It was the last significant part Westminster played in what was still officially the colony of Southern Rhodesia.

They also point to the South African Truth and Re-conciliation Commission, which was given the power to grant amnesties in exchange for honest testimony. Such a move would assist republicans `in exile' south of the border or abroad, who could face charges if they return north.

The release of prisoners has also raised the thorny issue of the return of exiles, those targeted by paramilitary groups and forced abroad. Up to 7,000 could be affected, according to groups in Britain who helped resettle the exiles. Government figures, which include only those who asked the police for help, claim that 335 were exiled in 1998 and 256 in 1999.

One Dungannon man who returned last year to see his children was brutally beaten by an IRA `punishment squad', within feet of his screaming baby in her cot. Soon afterwards he was killed in a car crash.

The Northern Ireland Select Committee is currently investigating the issue of returnees and seeks submissions from anyone with an interest, particularly exiles. One Select Committee member, Labour MP Harry Barnes, told The Observer that releases `must be a two-way process. If people have to accept the release of such prisoners, isn't it high time that their paramilitary organisations released their own prisoners too?

`The people they have forced out of their homes, or even out of the country altogether, aren't physically in prisons, but they are under sentence.'

One man unlikely to be given a warm welcome, or even forgiven by republicans, is Sean O'Callaghan, the one-time second-ranking member of the IRA's `Southern Command' who told all to the Garda.

Despite risking his life as the most senior informer ever within the Provisionals, and then voluntarily surrendering to the police and admitting his part in two murders in the mid-1970s, for which he served over a decade in prison, Sean O'Callaghan, too, in the eyes of government agencies and financial institutions, is on a legal par with any convicted killer.

He believes that, despite the pain caused to victims of paramilitary violence, ex-prisoners cannot be allowed to rot in a legal purdah. `There are over 15,000 ex-prisoners as a result of the conflict,' he says. `They need a relative stake in any new society being built in the North of Ireland.'

webTitle: Meddling Jewish mama meets her match on the net

fields.headline: Meddling Jewish mama meets her match on the net
fields.trailText: You can almost hear the cries of 'Enough already!' in the mating fields of north London. The legendary Jewish mother, who handpicks girlfriends for her sons, is out of a job.
fields.body:
You can almost hear the cries of 'Enough already!' in the mating fields of north London. The legendary Jewish mother, who handpicks girlfriends for her sons, is out of a job.

Kosher Casanovas are swapping bagel bars for internet cafes to date online. A match-making service, which boasts the largest directory of Jewish singles, video-dating, chat-up rooms, and daily sex positions from the 'Kosher Sutra', is threatening an institution as Jewish as chicken soup.

Jewish matriarchs, rabbis and community leaders who fear the online service will encourage casual sex have condemned it as anti-Jewish. The Jewish Telegraph has refused to publish advertisements that feature half-naked dolls with the slogan 'Your Mother wouldn't like it .... but you will.'

Totally Jewish Dating is an online service for Britain's 300,000-strong Jewish community. Its editor, David Garfinkel, says Jewish match-making is as old as the bible and the service simply brings it up to date - bypassing over-protective mums.

'The Jewish mother is legendary. She clucks over her sons and makes sure prospective partners can cook kneidlach in precisely the same way as her. But now Jewish men and women are using new ways to find partners for themselves.'

So many twenty-to-thirty somethings and divorcés tried to register when the site opened last week that the email system crashed. Daniel Solomons, a 27-year-old media planner from London, who sent in his photograph, said: 'My mum and auntie have tried setting me up in the past but none of the dates worked out. So I decided to check out the website. I've already got an email from a girl who is interested in meeting.'

David Israel from Leeds added: 'Young people hate their mothers setting them up on a blind date. Let's face it, we're living in the twenty-first century, not a remake of Fiddler on the Roof.'

But rabbis and community leaders have accused the site's operators, who run a regular 'get flirty with our PlayDate of the week in our totally Jewish jacuzzi' slot, of undermining traditional Jewish values. Jonny Waters, a Jewish youth leader and religious teacher, said: 'From a religious perspective, it oversteps the mark.'

But what do Jewish mothers think? Is computer dating kosher? Susan, a mother-of-two from north London, said: 'The only microchip a Jewish man needs is the one in his mother's head which sniffs out the nearest single Jewish woman and says to her son 'Just go for a coffee. What do you have to lose?' Jewish parents want their children married but not this way.'

fields.headline: Tusa attacks `glib' museums boss
fields.trailText: A war of words has broken out between two of Britain's leading cultural figures.
fields.body:
A war of words has broken out between two of Britain's leading cultural figures.

John Tusa, managing director of the Barbican Arts Centre and former controller of the BBC's World Service, has attacked Lord Evans, the museum supremo, for his `glib', `New Labour' attitude to cultural policy and for undermining standards of excellence. Since April, Evans has headed a commission watching over museums, galleries and libraries under the name Resource.

In an updated paperback edition of his book Art Matters, Tusa argues that Matthew Evans, Labour peer and chairman of the publishers Faber & Faber, typifies the fashionable, yet damaging attitude to the arts.

In a new chapter about the Government, called `Why I'm still Worried about TonyÉ', Tusa writes that Evans's inaugural speech as head of Resource, `had the instant recognisability of New Labour no-nonsense speak'.

Evans had suggested that galleries and museums should put some of their exhibits inside pubs rather than keeping them in storage. He also called for a shake-up of traditional curatorial values.

Tusa alleges that since Evans delivered his speech, `the museum and gallery world has put him right on almost everything he said in public and in private'.

He also denounces what he describes as Evans's modish emphasis on improving access rather than preserving artefacts: `He cannot have failed to notice that without collections there is nothing to which anyone would want access.'

Evans told The Observer that, far from being corrected by the museum industry, his words had been the catalyst for the kind of debate he wanted to see: `Although I am now in the House of Lords, I am not part of the New Labour operation,' he said, `and I know my speech was welcomed by many curators and actually reflected much of what they already felt.

`Since then, the National Gallery has decided to take some of its works to the Bluewater shopping mall in Kent and the Maritime Museum in Greenwich is taking a selection of its exhibits on a tour of the regions.'

vanessa.thorpe@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Woodward was sacked for fraud
fields.standfirst: Revealed: Au pair's mother cleared at trial lost her cashier job over dishonesty claims
fields.trailText: Revealed: Au pair's mother cleared at trial lost her cashier job over dishonesty claims
fields.body:
The mother of former au pair Louise Woodward, last week cleared of defrauding her daughter's trust fund, was once dismissed from her job as head cashier with a supermarket chain on suspicion of embezzlement, The Observer can reveal.

Susan Woodward, who along with her estranged husband Gary walked free from Chester Crown Court last week, had worked at Safeway in Upton near Chester for nearly three years when, in June 1991, she was accused of dishonesty. She was in charge of the cash office and responsible for all the money, coupons and vouchers which flowed through the store's 16 tills.

After a series of cash shortfalls, an investigation was launched and a colleague of Woodward's admitted her involvement in overstating the number of vouchers received and substituting them for cash. Further dis crepancies then came to light which implicated Woodward in a similar course of action. She was suspended after being interviewed by the store's security officer.

A series of disciplinary hearings were arranged but Woodward failed to appear at any of them. On 8 July, she was formally dismissed for dishonesty. No criminal proceedings were instigated.

Woodward claimed she had been sacked unfairly and took Safeway to an Industrial Tribunal. The tribunal found unanimously in favour of the supermarket.

The amounts involved were relatively small but the investigation suggested the activity could have been going on for some time and that the total amounts involved could have been more substantial.

The revelation follows last week's court case during which the Woodwards were cleared of defrauding the £250,000 appeal fund set up after their daughter was convicted of killing eight-month- old Matthew Eappen by shaking him to death while working as a nanny in Boston in 1997.

The couple, both 44, were jointly charged with using a bogus invoice to defraud £9,113 from the Louise Woodward and Family Trust.

They were also accused of furnishing false information that they had been charged rent at the home of Elaine Whitfield Sharp and paid the bill from Gary Woodward's personal bank account. They were acquitted of the charges after the jury was ordered to return not guilty verdicts by trial judge John Rogers QC.

The court heard that most of the couple's claims to the trust fund had been paid `on the nod' and the Woodwards believed this would also be the case with the rent invoice. Because of this, they did not prepare it as carefully as they could. It also emerged that for the whole of October, and part of November, the defendants were not actually living with the Sharps but in a flat provided by the British Charitable Society.

And the amount claimed of around £1,500-a-month, supposedly for the use of a spare bedroom, was five times what the Sharps would have charged for the rent of a two-bedroom self-contained flat in their home. A wealth of documentary and other evidence seen by The Observer confirms that the Sharps allowed the Woodwards to stay in their home for free.

The false invoice came to light after a newspaper article reported that the Sharps had housed the Woodwards for free. A member of the trust fund in the UK had received the invoice and set out to prove that the Woodwards had in fact been charged $2,200 per month while staying at the Sharps' home.

The false invoice was not the only financial irregularity that was exposed during the trial.

The court further heard the Woodwards claim that their finances had been `wiped out' as a result of the time they spent in America with their savings falling from £10,000 to just£2,000.

In fact, their assets had increased to around £37,000 and they had banked a further£50,000 from a newspaper after agreeing to sell their story.

Yesterday a Safeway spokesperson confirmed that Susan Woodward had been employed between June 1988 and July 1991 but would not discuss the circumstances under which she left.

Woodward was not available for comment.

The couple, both 44, were jointly charged with using a bogus invoice to defraud £9,113 from the Louise Woodward and Family Trust. They were also accused of furnishing false information that they had been charged rent at the home of Elaine Whitfield Sharp and paid the bill from Gary Woodward's personal bank account. They were acquitted of the charges after the jury was ordered to return not guilty verdicts by trial judge John Rogers QC. The court heard that most of the couple's claims to the trust fund had been paid `on the nod' and the Woodwards believed this would also be the case with the rent invoice. Because of this, they did not prepare it as carefully as they could. It also emerged that for the whole of October, and part of November, the defendants were not actually living with the Sharps but in a flat provided by the British Charitable Society. And the amount claimed of around £1,500-a-month, supposedly for the use of a spare bedroom, was five times what the Sharps would have charged for the rent of a two-bedroom self-contained flat in their home. A wealth of documentary and other evidence seen by The Observer confirms that the Sharps allowed the Woodwards to stay in their home for free. The false invoice came to light after a newspaper article reported that the Sharps had housed the Woodwards for free. A member of the trust fund in the UK had received the invoice and set out to prove that the Woodwards had in fact been charged $2,200 per month while staying at the Sharps' home. The false invoice was not the only financial irregularity that was exposed during the trial. The court further heard the Woodwards claim that their finances had been `wiped out' as a result of the time they spent in America with their savings falling from £10,000 to just£2,000. In fact, their assets had increased to around £37,000 and they had banked a further£50,000 from a newspaper after agreeing to sell their story. Yesterday a Safeway spokesperson confirmed that Susan Woodward had been employed between June 1988 and July 1991 but would not discuss the circumstances under which she left. Woodward was not available for comment. tony.thompson@observer.co.uk

webTitle: TV soaps at risk as directors make drama out of pay row

fields.headline: TV soaps at risk as directors make drama out of pay row
fields.trailText: More than 600 British television directors have been blacklisted by the major broadcasters in a row which threatens to take the country's most popular soaps off the air.
fields.body:
More than 600 British television directors have been blacklisted by the major broadcasters in a row which threatens to take the country's most popular soaps off the air.

The freelance directors are all supporters of a campaign which demands a better deal for their profession. They are refusing to sign away their creative rights when they accept a contract and, as a result, independent television companies and the BBC have imposed an effective boycott on their work.

The action has already disrupted the production of the BBC's EastEnders and Yorkshire TV's Emmerdale.

Last week television producers were searching for replacement directors.

'It looks as though I may not work in television any more,' said one young director. 'My career looks as if it is over just as it was starting. They told me I wasn't needed for the children's series I was supposed to be making.' The dispute centres on demands that directors should have the same pay arrangements as writers and actors.

Historically, directors working in Britain have not been paid additional fees when a programme is repeated.

'For three years we have been trying to exert some sort of pressure on the broadcasters to show how unfair it is,' said Herbie Wise, chairman of the Directors Guild and the director of I, Claudius and Breaking the Code.

'Pay for directors has gone down, not up, and that is not just in real terms.

'No other civilised European television producing company has this system. This action has been individually taken by each director. It is not just that they are all obeying a union instruction.'

The campaign is being co-ordinated by the Directors and Producers Rights Society and participating directors have assigned their rights to this new professional body as a way of forcing the broadcasters to negotiate.

Wise, along with other highly regarded British television directors, has gone on the record about the issue for the first time this weekend. Jack Gold, who directed John Hurt in the Naked Civil Servant, and Pennant Roberts, who directed Dr Who and Tenko, are also both prepared to jeopardise their chances of future work in order to draw attention to the pay anomaly.

While television companies argue that they pay extra fees up-front to compensate for the possible loss of income from repeats, Roberts, who is chairman of DPRS, argues that lowly-paid directors have been effectively subsidising the British television industry.

Wise adds: 'There is no way the television companies can know what the exploitative value of a programme is in advance. Of course an upfront 'buy-out' of our rights is not the same thing.

'The soaps are the most likely to be badly affected because they rely on directors, who, while not necessarily big names, are experienced and professional. The soaps need to bring episodes in quickly and under budget.'

A BBC spokeswoman said: 'The BBC, of course, values the contribution of all our freelance directors and producers and we make sure that they are paid fairly. However, our co-financers and co-producers require us to retain the rights to programmes.

'This means that we have enough money to re-invest in new programmes.'

fields.headline: Women angry as 'rapists go free'
fields.trailText: Conviction rates for rape have fallen to a record low, raising fresh concerns that women who take cases to the police are facing a traumatic struggle through the criminal process with little hope of success.
fields.byline: by Kamal Ahmed, Political Editor and Martin Bright
fields.body:
Conviction rates for rape have fallen to a record low, raising fresh concerns that women who take cases to the police are facing a traumatic struggle through the criminal process with little hope of success.

New figures from the Home Office reveal that, although nearly 8,500 cases of rape were reported to the police last year, only 634 resulted in convictions, a rate of just 7.5 per cent.

Campaigners say the figures reveal a crisis at the heart of the criminal justice system, which appears unable to collect sufficient evidence to produce successful rape convictions.

Last week the Government published its sexual offences review which proposed overhauling rape law to make it easier to bring cases, particularly by redefining the legal definition of consent.

It said action was needed as 'of all the sexual offences, rape is the most serious, the most feared and the most debated'. It said the present law was inadequate.

'This is a shocking figure,' said Helen Jones, of the Rape Crisis Federation. 'There has been a greater awareness of rape since the beginning of the 1990s, which is not being reflected by the number of successful prosecutions.'

In 1985, despite only 1,840 women reporting that they had been raped, 450 men were found guilty, a conviction rate of 24 per cent. That figure had fallen to 17 per cent by 1990.

Jones said the police, under pressure to improve their figures for clearing up crime, were reluctant to pursue long and complex rape cases where there was little hope of a conviction.

'They should investigate these cases with more rigour,' she said. Police say convictions are hard to come by because the allegations often rest on one person's word against another.

The Home Office has now demanded action from the Crown Prosecution Service and the police to push up the low figure.

Campaigning groups say Britain should learn from America, where the use of special advocates who support women through the courts has pushed conviction rates above 50 per cent in Washington and New York states.

The low conviction figure in Britain will reignite the debate about 'court attrition', the process where many victims of crime, particularly rape, give up on their cases because of the trauma involved.

Jones said, of the rape cases brought to the attention of the police, a quarter were 'no crimed', meaning either the police said there was no case to answer or the women withdrew, a further third were dropped because of insufficient evidence, 11 per cent failed because the perpetrator was not identified, 8 per cent were discontinued by the CPS, 7 per cent resulted in acquittal and 7 per cent resulted in convictions for lesser offences.

Every year 50,000 women contact the Rape Crisis Federation. Of those only 7 per cent go on to contact the police.

The low figures for rape convictions come as senior police officers raise further concerns about an upward trend in reported sexual offences. Home Office figures show that, although rates of sex crimes dropped between 1985 and 1995, they have steadily risen since that time.

Police worries will be raised in an article next month in Nexus, the magazine of the National Criminal Intelligence Service, by Norman Trew, head of its Serious Sexual Offenders Unit. He says that, although it is impossible to tell whether there has been an increase in the number of crimes being committed, he believes that increased public awareness of the problem has led to a sharp increase in reporting.

According to Trew, the figures have almost certainly been inflated by the fact that increasing numbers of people are coming forward to report crimes allegedly committed 10 or even 20 years ago. The huge number of investigations into children's homes has also thrown up hundreds of new cases.

A spokeswoman for NCIS said: 'Like institutional corruption, institutional abuse takes a generation to get it out of the system.'

webTitle: Leaks take toll on Labour poll lead

fields.headline: Leaks take toll on Labour poll lead
fields.trailText: Labour's lead has slipped to eight points, its lowest in this Parliament. Taking the main polls this month, and adjusting the raw data to take account of pro-Labour biases in most polls in recent years, Labour stands on 43 per cent (down one since June), with the Conservatives on 35 (up two) and the Liberal Democrats on 15 (down one).
fields.body:
Labour's lead has slipped to eight points, its lowest in this Parliament. Taking the main polls this month, and adjusting the raw data to take account of pro-Labour biases in most polls in recent years, Labour stands on 43 per cent (down one since June), with the Conservatives on 35 (up two) and the Liberal Democrats on 15 (down one).

These figures, part of a computer analysis commissioned by YouGov, the new e-democracy website, reflect the downturn in Labour's lead recorded by Gallup and ICM at the height of the Government's wobbles; their findings are only partly offset by the two-point rise in Labour's lead reported in the latest Mori poll on Friday. Indeed, the latest two polls by Mori (its regular survey for the Times, and a telephone poll for last weekend's Mail on Sunday), both conducted after Gordon Brown unveiled new spending plans 11 days ago, suggest Labour's lead may have recovered. Moreover, Labour remains on course for a big general election victory next year, provided Britain's economy does not nosedive.

This analysis, which The Observer will publish each month up to the election, is the work of Professor David Sanders of Essex University and myself. Our 'Kellner-Sanders Index' builds on lessons learnt in the 90s about polling biases, and about the relationship between party support and such influences as consumer confidence. On our model, Labour should expect to hold a 12-point lead at the moment.

For the moment, we are predicting Labour will revert to a 10-12 point lead over the next two or three months, but that its lead will then slip to eight points next May and - if there is no spring election - six points by October 2001.

These predictions are the same as last month and assume consumer confidence, as measured by Gallup for the Daily Telegraph, will rise gradually, reflecting growth, inflation and interest rate expectations.

If the economy outperforms these expectations, Labour should be able to count on an election land slide on much the same scale as in 1997; if the economy hits problems and consumer confidence declines, Labour would be on course for a more modest win next May - and could lose its majority if Tony Blair delayed the contest until next autumn.

As long as Labour retains a lead of three points or more at the election, it should have a working majority of at least 40. Its current eight-point lead represents a 2.5 per cent swing to the Conservatives; 19 Labour seats are vulnerable to such a swing, leaving the party with a 141 majority.

These figures reflect a big electoral bias to Labour. After all, the Tories won the 1992 election by exactly the same margin of 43-35 per cent - yet this delivered to John Major a majority of just 21. How has the electoral system become so distorted? There are three main factors.

Labour-dominated areas tend to have smaller constituencies than Tory-dominated areas. In Wales and Scotland (which have a total of 90 Labour and no Tory MPs), electorates average 55,000; in England they average 69,000. If constituencies in Wales and Scotland were the same size as in England, they would elect 23 fewer MPs, Labour losing 19 of them.

Turnouts in Labour areas tend to be lower than in Tory areas. In 1997, the 20 seats with the lowest turnouts were all Labour strongholds.

In 1997 tactical voting cost the Tories up to 35 seats they might otherwise have held.

For more details of this survey, visit www.yougov.com.

webTitle: Tiree islanders pray for a rotten summer

fields.headline: Tiree islanders pray for a rotten summer
fields.trailText: Itis fondly described as the Land Below the Waves. But to the residents of Tiree, the literary nickname of their tiny Hebridean atoll is fast becoming a cruel taunt.
fields.body:
Itis fondly described as the Land Below the Waves. But to the residents of Tiree, the literary nickname of their tiny Hebridean atoll is fast becoming a cruel taunt.

More than 13 weeks into a freak drought, the flat landscape is so parched that emergency water supplies are being shipped to the island this weekend to ease the worst shortage for 20 years.

While other parts of Britain are hit by flooding, the unprecedented spell of unbroken sunshine on Tiree, and its even smaller neighbour Coll, in the Inner Hebrides has attracted so many tourists that the islands' populations have doubled.

But while some holidaymakers are welcoming the freak conditions as the upside of global warming, the island residents are praying for rain. The ground has been burnt and crops and livestock are beginning to suffer the effects. A brief cloudburst last week raised hopes of a respite, but the land was so hot and dry that the water evaporated almost immediately on contact.

West of Scotland Water yesterday dispatched two tankers, each carrying 36,000 litres of water, by ferry to Tiree to add to a delivery on Friday.

The operation will continue until the weather breaks, and the island is treated to the same miserable weather afflicting the rest of the country.

webTitle: Tourism tsar may be last resort for seaside towns

fields.headline: Tourism tsar may be last resort for seaside towns
fields.trailText: The image is of buckets and spades, kiss-me-quick hats and melting ice-cream. But behind the facade of bracing good humour, Britain's seaside resorts are in crisis. This week the Government is to launch a major inquiry into how the UK's famous seaside towns can be saved. They have faced years of decline so devastating that the Department of Culture, Media and Sport has put them on a par with the depressed former mining areas.
fields.body:
The image is of buckets and spades, kiss-me-quick hats and melting ice-cream. But behind the facade of bracing good humour, Britain's seaside resorts are in crisis. This week the Government is to launch a major inquiry into how the UK's famous seaside towns can be saved. They have faced years of decline so devastating that the Department of Culture, Media and Sport has put them on a par with the depressed former mining areas.

Chris Smith, the Secretary of State for Culture who has responsibility for tourism, will initially target five towns for increased support.

Blackpool, Great Yarmouth, Scarborough, Minehead and Newquay will be visited by Ministers who want to ensure that regeneration projects do not just go to more typically depressed areas such as inner cities and former steel towns.

Bodies which award lottery money will be ordered to target them, the English Tourist Council will investigate what people require from a British seaside holiday, bids will be made to Europe for an increase in support and the resorts will be encouraged to push on with e-tourism, in which whole resorts are put on websites to encourage younger, affluent visitors.

A task force has now been set up under Peter Moore, managing director of Center Parcs, the holiday sites with large undercover areas which have been a huge hit with families worried about the British weather. Moore, already being described as the 'tourism tsar', will be expected to come up with new initiatives to save the seaside.

'We realised people don't take two-week family holidays to seaside towns like they used to,' said Janet Anderson, Minister for Tourism. 'People now go for single days or a short break, and that has an economic effect. These places are stuffed full of expensive infrastructure, such as promenades and piers, which makes it difficult to keep going.'

The British seaside tourist industry is worth nearly £5 billion a year, with 26.5 million seaside holidays taken in Britain last year. But the big figures mask economic depression and unemployment, particularly in winter. Seaside resorts on average suffer from higher levels of unemployment than the national average and lower rates of economic activity. High numbers of older people, many with little disposable income, mean that shops and businesses struggle to survive. They are also on the edge of transport networks, meaning that industries outside the tourism sector do not want to move to seaside towns.

This weekend is one of the busiest in the holiday calendar, as millions of Britons go on their summer holidays. But rather than head for the North East of England or Cornwall, more and more people are travelling abroad to Spain, the South of France, Greece or Florida.

Cut-price foreign travel has hit our resorts hard. Between 1965 and 1999 the number of Britons travelling abroad on holiday has risen from five million to 27.3 million. 'There is a perception that anything British is obviously going to be worse than anything from abroad,' said Peter Hampson, director of the British Resorts Association. 'It is snobbery and it should change. Seaside holidays tend to be second holidays and they have suffered. There was the recession in the early 90s and the strong pound now which has made trips abroad cheaper.'

In a recent report, Hampson wrote about the problems the resorts face. 'Unlike the case in some industry sectors, such as coal mining and shipbuilding, market decline has not resulted in spectacular closures or high-profile job losses, but rather to a severe cumulative impact,' he said.

'As a result of this slow but nevertheless steep decline, the economic, social and environmental pressures faced by the seaside resort have attracted little attention from successive Governments and policy-makers.'

fields.headline: Bumping along in style
fields.standfirst: For centuries women had to keep their pregnancy under wraps, but fertility is now the height of fashion, reports Amelia Hill
fields.trailText: Madonna makes it look very easy. Catherine Zeta-Jones is still attending premieres and gala openings with barely a hair out of place, Kate Winslet has yet to stop giggling and, God help us all, Zoe Ball is only beginning.
fields.body:
Madonna makes it look very easy. Catherine Zeta-Jones is still attending premieres and gala openings with barely a hair out of place, Kate Winslet has yet to stop giggling and, God help us all, Zoe Ball is only beginning.

Everywhere we look, there's a famous face preceded by a bulging stomach. They come in all shapes and sizes but have remarkably similar guises: either tightly swathed in Lycra or nakedly exposed beneath crop tops, a style proudly sported last week by Madonna in defiance of society's attempt to dragoon men and women into regarding lean, washboard stomachs as the sole model of feminine beauty.

Demi Moore was the first to sexualise pregnancy with That Photo on the cover of Vanity Fair nine years ago but it needed the recent flood of older, richer and more confident women to drive a stake through the heart of the desexed and disempowered, pastelled and pretty, Laura Ashley mum-to-be.

Cherie Blair gave pregnancy back its sophistication, Cindy Crawford gave it glamour, while Madonna continues to defy stereotype by reducing the size of her T-shirts in inverse proportion to the swell of her stomach.

'It's amazing,' said Marina Warner, author and historian. 'For the first time since the early nineteenth century, women are able to take physical pride in their pregnancy. After remaining stuck in the prurience of the nineteenth century for 200 years, this seems to have happened almost overnight.'

In the eighteenth century, there was a robustness to the way in which the female body was portrayed. Artists displayed voluptuous female nakedness, bodily excess and fleshy enjoyment. Pregnancy was depicted as a sensuous condition, endorsing women's power in perpetuating the human race.

But as Classicism gave way to Romanticism, such lush enjoyment faded. As industrialisation sucked the masses from the countryside into the cities, an anxiety over the population boom developed and the desire to control women's reproduction took form in antipathy towards the pregnant body and prurience towards its depiction.

'The slim, female silhouette became desired when the value of pregnancy began to be denied,' said Warner.

This antipathy continued throughout the twentieth century: pregnant women may no longer have been required to relieve society of their presence by retreating into elegant confinement but they were expected to hide the proof of their recent shame and encroaching un-ladylike pain under billowing smocks and sack-like dungarees.

'It seems to me that society has so many double standards about motherhood,' said Kathy Lette, author of Foetal Attraction and Mad Cows, who took delight in wearing skin-tight lame jumpsuits and micro stretch minis during her last pregnancy seven years ago. 'Women are still perceived to have failed in some way if they don't produce progeny and yet when I was pregnant, society suddenly handed me an eviction notice.

'Twenty points were instantly deducted from my IQ and maternity shops tried to force me to dress like a little girl in pinks and pastels, frills and florals and pussy bows,' she added. 'Refusing to conform was my way of refusing to be just a life support system to a womb for nine months.'

Attitudes have been turned upside down since Lette's pregnancy. 'Europe's attitude towards the pregnant form has been revolutionised in the past couple of years,' said Warner. 'The moment the fertility rates began plummeting and the age of women giving birth began to rise, fertility became a precious commodity which was praised and treasured.'

The fertility fright is more than justified: from baby boom, we've come full circle back around to birth death. Fewer babies were born in Europe last year than at any time since the Second World War, while one in six British couples now experiences fertility problems.

Government predictions show the British population will peak and begin to decrease by 2036. 'The nightmare scenario of the human race waking one morning and realising it cannot reproduce is not scaremongering,' said Dr Simon Fishel, director of the Centre for Assisted Reproduction. 'If we carry on like this, it will be a reality.'

Stress, pollution and an increase in sexually transmitted diseases have been blamed for the fall in fertility: the number of couples seeking treatment for conception problems has risen by 55 per cent over five years - while more women decide not to become mothers.

'It's wonderful to see these women enjoying their pregnancies so wholeheartedly,' said author and columnist Nigella Lawson. 'Madonna wears common-or-garden combat trousers and Catherine Zeta-Jones was photographed wearing a perfectly ordinary black, Lycra dress. There are no idealised images here, just a healthy enjoyment in the state itself.

'But, despite the freeing at the top of the pile, normal people are still expected to conform to a more suitable mode of pregnancy,' said Lawson. 'Many men still find it difficult to talk to a pregnant woman with anything other than an almost overpowering condescension, and even some women assume you've suddenly become a baby carrier devoid of intelligence.'

amelia.hill@observer.co.uk

Observer Business Editor Emily Bell is pregnant, too - but she's more worried about stretchmarks than stretch Lycra

The pregnant stomach might be more fashionable this summer than Versace shades, but it is hardly an exclusive accessory.

True, Catherine Zeta-Jones, Madonna and Kate Winslet are all sporting the bow front, while Melinda Messenger, Cherie Booth and Emma Noble have acquired the full-blown baby accessory. But around 800,000 women will share the experience this year, including 14-year-old girls, first time mothers aged 45 and the rest of us in the profoundly moving but essentially untrendy middle ground of maternity.

More pregnant than Madonna, less than Zeta-Jones, I was surprised to be asked my views on the displays of collective pregnancy in last week's tabloids. It is good that women can now wear tight T-shirts and hipster trews while pregnant, as opposed to swathing themselves in a concealing smock/shirt - or, as books 50 years ago advised, only taking marital walks after dark to avoid embarrassment. But the excitement of unwittingly being caught on the breast of a fashion wave leaves me cold.

Clad in something stretchy from Marks & Spencer and an old shirt, I'm more excited by the prospect that if I sit still for long enough, a Japanese bank might buy me and open me as a tourist attraction.

Celebrity pregnancy has enabled (in the main) male editors to celebrate the acceptability of being pregnant and proud by filling their pages with colour shots of glamorous, confident women displaying and dressing their extending midriffs. It is an essentially male take on what should constitute appreciation of this glorious state, as long as it stops there.

What pregnant women really want to know about other pregnant women, famous or not, is the litany of grisly statistics that the tabloids don't want to print. Madonna's admission of dreadful stretchmarks and Messenger's pre-eclampsia nightmare (dangerously high blood pressure, protein in your urine and fingers swollen like sausages), were far more gripping for me than whether they could still fit into their bikinis.

Messenger's bad experience is shared by one in 10 first-time mothers. It is comforting to find that celebrity skin is no different. Whether Catherine Zeta-Jones has piles or varicose veins might be classified as too much information, but women producing a child are voracious for the various weights and states which make up nine months' hard labour.

These, not Maharishi trousers, are the real shared experience of every woman in pregnancy. But don't expect to see that on the front page of the Sun.

fields.headline: Supersonic future looks bleak
fields.trailText: Pilots and passengers everywhere are asking this weekend: Is Concorde safe and does it have a future?
fields.byline: by Joanna Walters, transport business editor
fields.body:
Pilots and passengers everywhere are asking this weekend: Is Concorde safe and does it have a future?

A debate is raging about the safety credentials of this exceptional aircraft and whether last week's horrific crash marks the beginning of the end of commercial supersonic travel.

John Hutchinson, a Concorde captain with British Airways from 1977 to 1992 and the immediate past-master of the UK Guild of Air Pilots, told The Observer: `I regard Concorde as the safest aircraft flying, regardless of this accident. It is built like the proverbial brick lavatory.'

But others disagreed, saying that the close proximity of the two engines to each other on each wing of the aircraft and the fact that they are so close to the landing gear put Concorde at a higher risk than other planes in the kind of incident witnessed at Charles de Gaulle last week.

One serving British pilot said that Concorde would now always be associated with death in the minds of much of the flying public. `The Concorde name is tarnished forever,' he said.

If the cause of the crash is found to be directly related to Concorde's design or unique operating procedures or if the cause ultimately remains a mystery - then experts agree that it is finished on the spot.

But even if this is not the case, it has lost vital credibility and many believe it will be taken out of service in the next two or three years, long before the scheduled retirement date of 2015.

And while aviators believe that there will be a successor to the plane, aerospace companies who have to raise the estimated £20 billion it would take to develop disagree. The advent of Concorde's first crash last week will only have served further to discourage would-be backers of a next-generation supersonic transport.

`There will not be a `child of Concorde'. It is just not economically viable unless governments fund it like they did the original - and they will not,' one French aerospace expert told The Observer last week at the Farnborough Air Show. If Concorde came into existence today, instead of in 1969, it would not get a certificate to operate from the Civil Aviation Authority.

However, one British Airways source said this was not because of safety design concerns but because of modern environmental standards. Its deafening roar on take-off and the excessive emissions from the gas-guzzling engines at high altitude are not acceptable by today's legislative standards.

That means that Concorde is technically obsolete and, although it is given special allowance to fly, any new model would have to be extensively redesigned. The British, French, Japanese and Americans all have the rudimentary makings of a successor to Concorde on the drawing board, but have become increasingly less committed to the project over the last three years.

Europe puts in a negligible £6 million a year into token research on materials and environmental safeguards, but the project is effectively in limbo.

The space agency, Nasa, spearheads the American supersonic passenger project, but in the last two years it has diverted its annual £100m funding into an international space station and Martian research instead. Boeing dropped out when the company got into financial difficulties two years ago.

To make a successor viable, John Hutchinson said that it would need a new engine, because today's Rolls-Royce-Snecma Olympus engines consume too much fuel and make too much noise.

The new Concorde would have to extend its current range, which takes it from western Europe to the US East Coast and Caribbean, so that in future it could fly to California or across the Pacific.

But he said he believed it would happen. `I cannot believe that my grand-children will be telling their children that in the late 20th and 21st centuries we had supersonic travel but now we have not, because it all got too complex. Humankind, its aspirations and technological achievements, will always go forwards not backwards.

`There will be a gap between the end of Concorde and a new-generation supersonic passenger plane, but when it comes they will be much larger, there will be hundreds of them - not just 12 - and they will make today's subsonic jets a thing of the past. The idea that Concorde is the last is ridiculous.'

A supersonic business jet is a possibility, but again the manufacturers are finding it difficult to make the economics add up.

So, for the time being, Concorde is all we have. Hutchinson said it is safer than other aircraft, because it has extra power and safety margins built into it - such as extra thrust capability, even at takeoff at 250mph. It can withstand low-level thunderstorms that have caused other aircraft to crash in the past, and cruises above the weather and other air traffic at 65,000ft.

fields.headline: Onward Christian lobbyists
fields.standfirst: The religious right is dogging Blair's steps and attempting to impose a moral agenda on his programme, writes Kamal Ahmed
fields.trailText: The religious right is dogging Blair's steps and attempting to impose a moral agenda on his programme, writes Kamal Ahmed
fields.body:
On pager 140 of last week's sexual offences review report, among a list of advisers which includes Dr Brenda Rogers of the British Medical Association and the Justice and Victims Unit of the Home Office, comes the name of Claire Wilson-Thomas. Wilson-Thomas is important. She is policy manager at Care. Not many people have heard of Care - it stands for Christian Action, Research and Education.

Care cares about a lot of things. It cares about lowering the age of consent for gay people. It cares about the repeal of Section 28. It cares about women having abortions, the rising number of teenage pregnancies and the decline of the family. It cares about morality and says that it is an organisation concerned with `declaring Christian truth and demonstrating Christ's compassion. We undertake this by campaigning, providing resources, undertaking caring work and bringing Christian insight and experience to matters of public policy, education and practical caring initiatives'.

Ben Bradshaw, the Labour MP for Exeter who is gay and a member of the Socialist Christian Movement, describes them as `a bunch of homophobic bigots'.

The appointment of Wilson-Thomas to the reference group for the Home Office's sex offences review has raised eyebrows. To many in the gay community, Care's name is mud. But at the highest levels of government, its members are part of a new movement of highly politicised Christians which is changing the face of British politics.

These are the new Christian soldiers - well-organised, well- funded, disciplined and committed groups of people who have assiduously courted those in power. Last week saw their political high point - the emphatic Lords defeat of government proposals to repeal Section 28.

The campaign was led by Baroness Young, who has close links with Care and two other leading religious groups that have built themselves into formidable lobbying organisations Ð the Christian Institute and Family and Youth Concern.

Members fly the flag for what they call `moral politics', coalescing around a disparate selection of issues, from genetic experimenta tion to setting up anti-abortion counselling services.

Now they have a new focus. Along with plans for autumn campaigns against lowering the age of consent for gay people, the European directive on discrimination and the sexual offences review itself, the Government's decision to agree to the cloning of human embryos for research is set to stir up protest.

Many of the campaigning techniques dovetail with the American experience where the Moral Majority movement has ensured that `pro-family' religious opinion is heard at the centre of power. Using many of the same techniques - mass letter-writing, forging close relations with politicians, courting newspapers, producing policy papers, finding sympathetic government officials to ply with information - Britain's newly enboldened Christian movement has given the country its first whiff of morality politics.

Organisations such as Care feel they are on fertile territory. Tony Blair, though careful not to wear his religion on his sleeve, is a committed Christian who has raised the profile of religion in politics. In his memo leaked two weeks ago he mentioned `the family, where partly due to gay issues we are perceived as weak'. This is music to Care's ears.

Many members of the Government, from David Blunkett to Paul Boateng to Jack Straw, are also strongly religious. That is not to suggest that any member of the Government has any truck with right-wing Christian groups, but such groups have taken advantage of an atmosphere of religious debate.

`They cannot be dissatisfied with their leverage,' said Richard Kirker, head of Lesbian and Gay Christians. `The problem we have on the Left is complacency. We thought we had won all these battles. We were wrong.'

The campaign against the European directive on employment is set to become increasingly bitter. In a glossy pamphlet produced by the Christian Institute, the arguments that will be deployed are laid out. `The directive would make it illegal for organisations to refuse to employ an individual because of that individual's religious views or sexual orientation.

`Religious groups could be forced to employ atheists or practising homosexuals in key positions. Practising homosexuals who claim to be `gay Christians' will get a legal right to apply for all posts.' Kirker describes the pamphlet as `offensive'.

The booklet says that those opposed to the directive should write to Blair. `You may want to include some of the following points in your letter (in your own words [their italics]),' the booklet says.

It is a classic ploy by the new Christian movement which has targeted the House of Lords in its efforts to overturn disliked legislation. In a note to its members, Family and Youth Concern insisted on the importance of mass letter-writing in the battle against Section 28. `Members took their part in informing a large number of peers about the protection which Section 28 should provide children against the presentation of homosexual relationships as normal and other family types comparable with marriage. The booklet, Bankrolling Gay Proselytising - a selection of `pro-gay' material from local authorities put together by the Christian Institute - was sent to them with a list of peers to whom to write, thus ensuring that all named peers received letters.

`Baroness Young told us that the flood of well-reasoned letters had an enormous influence on the majority vote to retain the clause. Letters do count.'

Young invited the Christian Institute to set up an exhibition in the House of Lords on the issue of Section 28 which displayed examples of `taxpayer-funded materials which promoted homosexuality'. Colin Hart, the institute's director, and Simon Calvert, his deputy, have special access passes to Parliament which allows them to meet Ministers, peers and MPs where it matters, in the corridors of power. Young also wrote to Church leaders, enclosing a summary of the institute's booklet. `It is now essential that Christians write to the Prime Minister and their MP,' the letter said.

`There has always been a moral element to politics,' Calvert said. `It is not about whether morality will have an influence on politics, it is about what type of morality will have an influence on politics. All sides are claiming the moral high ground. We are described as bigoted and homophobic. That is a moral judgment.'

Hart is convinced that groups such as the Christian Institute have `the majority' on their side. `People are worried about their children, about family life, about what is being taught in schools.'

Calvert says he has been invited to meet Straw to discuss the sexual offences review in September. The institute will attack the review's recommendation that offences of gross indecency and buggery, which apply only to men, should be repealed.

Calvert was on one of the working parties that advised on the `abuse of trust' sections of the review which dealt with incest and the relationship between children and adults. The institute has also been seen by Women's Minister Tessa Jowell. Treasury officials invited Care representatives to discuss proposals on how tax breaks could support marriage.

In themedia, there are also the flag carriers. The deputy director of Family and Youth Concern is Cornelia Oddie, wife of William Oddie, editor of the Catholic Herald. The Herald is owned by Conrad Black, who also owns the Daily Telegraph. Both the Telegraph and the Daily Mail have close links with the Christian groups and often campaign on issues, such as Section 28.

Care, as well as supporting Young's office, runs an intern scheme where volunteers sympathetic to the cause are provided for MPs and peers, both Labour and Conservative. Once in Parliament, the interns can influence areas of debate and report back to Care what is coming up in the legisla tive programme that should be ringing alarm bells. The projects do not always run smoothly. During the 1997 election campaign a young volunteer, Caroline Mawson, worked with Bradshaw. She was also a member of Care, something that Bradshaw was initially unaware of, and told the organisation that she would like to work in his office after the election.

Charlie Colchester, executive director of Care, asked Bradshaw for a meeting. `I was questioned in a highly inappropriate way,' Bradshaw said. `They were asking me about my sexual orientation. I was told after that that they were sorry, but the girl would not be working for me.'

Bradshaw has now written to the Charity Commission. `I would urge you to investigate if Care broke charity law by discriminating in this way,' the letter says. `Also, where they stand under charity law regarding political activity.'

Care refused to return calls from The Observer about the issue last week, although Calvert, of the Christian Institute, says that similar allegations of over-politicisation made against it are un-founded. The institute is no more political than the gay rights group Stonewall, he argues.

Groups opposed to Care, the Christian Institute and Family and Youth Concern point out that the influence of the new Christian soldiers has made the Government nervous on a host of progressive issues such as gay rights and sexual equality. Evan Harris, the Liberal Democrat MP and member of the National Secular Society, points out that the Government has only actually moved in one area Ð the repeal of laws banning gay people from entering the Army. `And that was because they were forced to by Europe,' he said.

It is highly unlikely that the Government will act on the controversial sexual offences review before the next election. Section 28 has also been kicked into the political long grass. They are also likely to give ground on the European directive by pushing for religious exemptions from sexual discrimination rules.

Martin Pendergrast, of the group Christians for Human Rights, said that, while the religious Right was increasing in influence, progressive Christian organisations had been sidelined. `I suppose they would rather have them in the tent pissing out, than outside pissing in,' he said. `It's just a pity no one asked us.'
