Last week saw their political high point - the emphatic Lords defeat of government proposals to repeal Section 28. The campaign was led by Baroness Young, who has close links with Care and two other leading religious groups that have built themselves into formidable lobbying organisations Ð the Christian Institute and Family and Youth Concern. Members fly the flag for what they call `moral politics', coalescing around a disparate selection of issues, from genetic experimenta tion to setting up anti-abortion counselling services. Now they have a new focus. Along with plans for autumn campaigns against lowering the age of consent for gay people, the European directive on discrimination and the sexual offences review itself, the Government's decision to agree to the cloning of human embryos for research is set to stir up protest. Many of the campaigning techniques dovetail with the American experience where the Moral Majority movement has ensured that `pro-family' religious opinion is heard at the centre of power. Using many of the same techniques - mass letter-writing, forging close relations with politicians, courting newspapers, producing policy papers, finding sympathetic government officials to ply with information - Britain's newly enboldened Christian movement has given the country its first whiff of morality politics. Organisations such as Care feel they are on fertile territory. Tony Blair, though careful not to wear his religion on his sleeve, is a committed Christian who has raised the profile of religion in politics. In his memo leaked two weeks ago he mentioned `the family, where partly due to gay issues we are perceived as weak'. This is music to Care's ears. Many members of the Government, from David Blunkett to Paul Boateng to Jack Straw, are also strongly religious. That is not to suggest that any member of the Government has any truck with right-wing Christian groups, but such groups have taken advantage of an atmosphere of religious debate. `They cannot be dissatisfied with their leverage,' said Richard Kirker, head of Lesbian and Gay Christians. `The problem we have on the Left is complacency. We thought we had won all these battles. We were wrong.' The campaign against the European directive on employment is set to become increasingly bitter. In a glossy pamphlet produced by the Christian Institute, the arguments that will be deployed are laid out. `The directive would make it illegal for organisations to refuse to employ an individual because of that individual's religious views or sexual orientation. `Religious groups could be forced to employ atheists or practising homosexuals in key positions. Practising homosexuals who claim to be `gay Christians' will get a legal right to apply for all posts.' Kirker describes the pamphlet as `offensive'. The booklet says that those opposed to the directive should write to Blair. `You may want to include some of the following points in your letter (in your own words [their italics]),' the booklet says. It is a classic ploy by the new Christian movement which has targeted the House of Lords in its efforts to overturn disliked legislation. In a note to its members, Family and Youth Concern insisted on the importance of mass letter-writing in the battle against Section 28. `Members took their part in informing a large number of peers about the protection which Section 28 should provide children against the presentation of homosexual relationships as normal and other family types comparable with marriage. The booklet, Bankrolling Gay Proselytising - a selection of `pro-gay' material from local authorities put together by the Christian Institute - was sent to them with a list of peers to whom to write, thus ensuring that all named peers received letters. `Baroness Young told us that the flood of well-reasoned letters had an enormous influence on the majority vote to retain the clause. Letters do count.' Young invited the Christian Institute to set up an exhibition in the House of Lords on the issue of Section 28 which displayed examples of `taxpayer-funded materials which promoted homosexuality'. Colin Hart, the institute's director, and Simon Calvert, his deputy, have special access passes to Parliament which allows them to meet Ministers, peers and MPs where it matters, in the corridors of power. Young also wrote to Church leaders, enclosing a summary of the institute's booklet. `It is now essential that Christians write to the Prime Minister and their MP,' the letter said. `There has always been a moral element to politics,' Calvert said. `It is not about whether morality will have an influence on politics, it is about what type of morality will have an influence on politics. All sides are claiming the moral high ground. We are described as bigoted and homophobic. That is a moral judgment.' Hart is convinced that groups such as the Christian Institute have `the majority' on their side. `People are worried about their children, about family life, about what is being taught in schools.' Calvert says he has been invited to meet Straw to discuss the sexual offences review in September. The institute will attack the review's recommendation that offences of gross indecency and buggery, which apply only to men, should be repealed. Calvert was on one of the working parties that advised on the `abuse of trust' sections of the review which dealt with incest and the relationship between children and adults. The institute has also been seen by Women's Minister Tessa Jowell. Treasury officials invited Care representatives to discuss proposals on how tax breaks could support marriage. In themedia, there are also the flag carriers. The deputy director of Family and Youth Concern is Cornelia Oddie, wife of William Oddie, editor of the Catholic Herald. The Herald is owned by Conrad Black, who also owns the Daily Telegraph. Both the Telegraph and the Daily Mail have close links with the Christian groups and often campaign on issues, such as Section 28. Care, as well as supporting Young's office, runs an intern scheme where volunteers sympathetic to the cause are provided for MPs and peers, both Labour and Conservative. Once in Parliament, the interns can influence areas of debate and report back to Care what is coming up in the legisla tive programme that should be ringing alarm bells. The projects do not always run smoothly. During the 1997 election campaign a young volunteer, Caroline Mawson, worked with Bradshaw. She was also a member of Care, something that Bradshaw was initially unaware of, and told the organisation that she would like to work in his office after the election. Charlie Colchester, executive director of Care, asked Bradshaw for a meeting. `I was questioned in a highly inappropriate way,' Bradshaw said. `They were asking me about my sexual orientation. I was told after that that they were sorry, but the girl would not be working for me.' Bradshaw has now written to the Charity Commission. `I would urge you to investigate if Care broke charity law by discriminating in this way,' the letter says. `Also, where they stand under charity law regarding political activity.' Care refused to return calls from The Observer about the issue last week, although Calvert, of the Christian Institute, says that similar allegations of over-politicisation made against it are un-founded. The institute is no more political than the gay rights group Stonewall, he argues. Groups opposed to Care, the Christian Institute and Family and Youth Concern point out that the influence of the new Christian soldiers has made the Government nervous on a host of progressive issues such as gay rights and sexual equality. Evan Harris, the Liberal Democrat MP and member of the National Secular Society, points out that the Government has only actually moved in one area Ð the repeal of laws banning gay people from entering the Army. `And that was because they were forced to by Europe,' he said. It is highly unlikely that the Government will act on the controversial sexual offences review before the next election. Section 28 has also been kicked into the political long grass. They are also likely to give ground on the European directive by pushing for religious exemptions from sexual discrimination rules. Martin Pendergrast, of the group Christians for Human Rights, said that, while the religious Right was increasing in influence, progressive Christian organisations had been sidelined. `I suppose they would rather have them in the tent pissing out, than outside pissing in,' he said. `It's just a pity no one asked us.'

webTitle: Every move you make, every breath you take...

fields.headline: Every move you make, every breath you take...
fields.standfirst: ... they'll all be watching you. In the digital age, Big Brother has grown into an entire Big Brotherhood, keeping track of all aspects of our lives, writes Antony Barnett reports
fields.trailText: From the moment you wake up tomorrow, nearly every movement you make will be tracked by somebody, somewhere. Walk to your car, turn on your computer at work, visit the local supermarket - all will be noted by cameras or databases deep in the bowels of corporate HQs and within shadowy government agencies.
fields.body:
From the moment you wake up tomorrow, nearly every movement you make will be tracked by somebody, somewhere. Walk to your car, turn on your computer at work, visit the local supermarket - all will be noted by cameras or databases deep in the bowels of corporate HQs and within shadowy government agencies.

Already these databases are bulging with intricate details of every facet of our private lives. Your eating habits, hobbies, whether you have children or prefer hip-hop to grunge - your tastes, preferences and passions have all been downloaded. Never in the history of mankind has personal privacy been harder to secure.

Simon Davies, head of watchdog group Privacy International, says: 'Government and corporations are desperate to turn the world into villages where everybody knows everything about you.

'Everything you have ever done will soon be available at the touch of a button.' As you switch on cable TV, companies are eagerly taking note of your favourite programmes and what time you're at home. Maybe it will help them choose the best hour to call and tell you about a new service. Or maybe they'll offer a personal loan with the bank they've just got into bed with.

As you head outdoors, stepping over the junk mail piling up on the doormat, it won't be long before a CCTV camera's unblinking eye will capture part of your journey on tape. And if you drive to work it won't just be the police's speed cameras that make sure you're rarely out of sight for long. Filling up with petrol may mean you are being listened to as well as being watched. BP was forced to admit a couple of years ago that it uses secret microphones to listen to the private conversations of millions of petrol station customers. Hidden bugs in forecourt shops are picking up every word uttered.

If you think arriving at work provides a sanctuary from prying eyes, then think again. Swiping your corporate security card through a barrier on your way to the office tells your boss what time you arrived and what time you leave.

The moment you log on to your computer is the point when personal privacy really disappears. Emails, as we should all know by now, are not private or secure. The number of employees being sacked after the boss has read a damning email continues to grow. Last summer Kwik Fit sacked two workers who were having an affair after their erotic emails were intercepted by management.

Philip Ryan is a consultant from Peapod, which helps companies spy on workers suspected of wrongdoing. He said: 'Everything an employee does while logged on to a work computer can be watched. The emails that are sent, the websites that are visited. It is difficult to keep secrets on the internet'.

Described as 'dataveillance', the ability to track people by monitoring the shadow they cast in data is now big business. What's more, there are now hundreds of downloaded programmes that secretly snoop inside PCs. The current Time magazine refers to a programme called SurfMonkey, which is supposed to protect children surfing the net. But as well as stopping children accessing porn sites it collects information, including users' phone numbers and email addresses.

Some companies are using 'web bugs' that hide computer codes behind images only a pixel in size on your computer screen to gather information about your web surfing habits. Effectively, this means an invisible dot on your screen is watching every move you make.

These dots mine information about who owns the site you are surfing as well as details about your computer. 'They are a secret way of gathering information about someone,' said David Banisar, a civil liberties expert from the Electronic Privacy Information Centre (Epic) in Washington.

These bugs work best in conjunction with 'cookies' - devices that leap on to your hard drive the first time you visit a particular website. They are your own personal calling card and identify you next time you visit the site, but they also record what sites surfers come from and trace what sites they go to and how long they spend online.

This detailed profile of a computer user is highly valuable marketing information which can be sold to other on-line advertisers. According to Epic, 86 out of 100 tested online companies work with cookies.

But it is not just corporations eager to enhance their profits that are keen to survey your personal internet traffic. Last week the Regulation of Investigatory Powers (RIP) Bill received Royal Assent. To civil liberty campaigners, this represents the most pernicious invasion of privacy ever imposed by a modern democratic state. Under its terms, every UK internet service provider will have to install a black box which monitors all the data passing through its computers and feed this to MI5 headquarters. The State will have powers to snoop, often without a warrant, on the email and internet activities of everyone with an internet connection.

The RIP Act also gives the police unparalleled powers to use the new generation of mobile phones to pinpoint the location of any individual. They will act like a homing device planted secretly on the phone's owner without them realising.

But don't think it's just state-of-the-art technology that challenges your privacy. Paying bills over the internet can also be a risky business as personal details can easily be appropriated by unscrupulous users. This month John Chamberlain decided to test Powergen's security before paying his electricity bill after seeing a Panorama programme on computer hacking. 'In under three minutes I had access to 5,000 credit card details, names and addresses,' said Chamberlain.

Supermarket loyalty cards are another tool through which your habits are monitored. These cards build up pictures of what you like spending your money on. Are you vegetarian? Do you prefer organic food? Do you favour Chilean chardonnay over French? Few things can be hidden these days.

Those who have chosen to make their phone numbers ex-directory will be unhappy to know that with one call this newspaper can find out what that supposedly secret number is.

CD-Roms are available that will allow you to reverse search on phone numbers - the opposite to directory inquiries. You give it a phone number and it tells you whose phone that is and where they live. Other CDs, available at less than £50, are compiled from Britain's electoral register and contain the names and addresses of over 44 million electors. Put in a name and in an instant you can find where that person lives and who else has lived at the property.

The Land Registry will provide anybody with details of the owners of a particular piece of real estate, and reveal if there is a mortage on it and which bank is lending the money. You can even hire a company to check out neighbours before you move into a new home.

Of course, if you are prepared to use a little subterfuge with a confident telephone manner, then much more can be obtained. When the row erupted over Labour millionaire donor Lord Levy's tax bill, the Inland Revenue said it received calls from someone pretending to be Lord Levy, requesting his tax return.

Getting information by deception is a criminal offence, but when the details of Lord Levy's dimunitive tax bill hit the press, Benji 'the binman' Pell was once again a suspect.

Lord Levy argued that his tax details were personal property, but it is clear that when it comes to personal privacy it is not strange-looking men lurking in dustbins that most of us need to worry about.

fields.headline: Picking over the debris
fields.standfirst: The forensic examination of disasters means TV risks reporting before it thinks, writes Andrew Anthony
fields.trailText: The forensic examination of disasters means TV risks reporting before it thinks, writes Andrew Anthony
fields.body:
Just as a road accident exerts a macabre hold over the onlooker, so does an air crash demand the attention of the TV viewer. And when the crash involves Concorde, a pristine symbol of safety and technical supremacy, the need to turn on a television and watch is almost overpowering.

Late last Tuesday afternoon, television news teams were confronted with exactly that demand. By and large, they responded with tremendous speed and a great deal of information. What they were unable to do for the first hour after learning of the disaster, which took place at 3.47pm our time, was show any film from the scene of the accident. As one BBC executive said: `Clearly what people want to watch are the pictures.'

The BBC, as subscribers to Eurovision, were able to get some footage on to their rolling news satellite channel BBC 24 by 5.15pm, which they claim was well in advance of their competitors, Sky News, although Sky say they also ran their first shots from the crash at the same time. What followed over the next two days was probably the most well-documented coverage of an air disaster in history.

The only moment missing on camera was the crash itself. But in the absence of that terrible instant, little was left to the imagination. Such was the devastation captured in the images shown on Tuesday night, that there was a great deal of confusion over whether the Concorde had hit a restaurant or a hotel. Even by the Nine O'Clock News Michael Burke seemed uncertain what had happened.

An air crash and the consequent TV coverage bring together two distinct and often antipathetic cultures. The aviation industry spends months, sometimes years, accumulating evidence in the wake of a disaster. Television is interested only in the present. It needs to know now.

So a bridging language has evolved to accommodate the differing time spans. `I appreciate that it is early days', and, `While it would be wrong to speculate', have become the standard opening lines for presenters when speaking to anyone with professional knowledge of aircraft. But of course coverage at this stage is all about speculation.

Following a previous accident in Paris Ð the death of the Princess of Wales Ð the nature of news coverage changed. Television discovered that with modern media resources, it was possible to explore one story in forensic detail.

For the Concorde crash, the BBC, with 12 TV and radio channels to service, had Jon Sopel on the spot, but sent in a large back-up. Most surprising, perhaps, was the arrival of James Naughtie, who co-presented Radio 4's Today programme from the accident site in Gonesse, north-east of Paris, on Wednesday morning. He had the difficult task of combining introductions and interviews with descriptive reportage.

`As you speak to me,' he intoned with due solemnity, `there's a procession of vehicles heading down to the crash site.' If live radio coverage of a happening event can attain a vividness and create an atmosphere beyond the image-linked confines of TV, then live radio coverage of a past event is as gripping as last week's newspapers.

There was still much hard news to break on Wednesday - the pilot's request that an engine be checked shortly before take-off, and the release of the video of the Concorde on fire by Antenna 3, a Spanish TV station - but the ranks of assembled personnel had to find other stories to justify their presence. And by now the rolling news had gained unstoppable momentum.

Thus locals around Gonesse were interviewed to see if they were worried about another plane crashing on them, when of course the only real danger they faced was the threat from all those flailing cameras.

In attempting to sum up the tragedy, and possibly his reasons for being there, Naughtie closed on Tuesday with these words: `This is a moment in the history of air travel that for obvious reasons we're all going to remember.'

That is probably true. But which moment will we remember? The instant that we learnt of the crash, through the supersonic speed of modern news coverage, or the French villagers patiently explaining that, no, they did not expect to be hit by another aircraft?

fields.headline: Death of a dream
fields.standfirst: As the 100 elated tourists took their seats, they couldn't have known they had 15 minutes to live. But aviation experts have known for 20 years that tyre blow-outs are a risk on `the world's safest plane'
fields.trailText: By lunchtime the technicians in hangar QN had finished. With its engines popping and cracking as they cooled, Air France's oldest Concorde - registration code F-BTSC - sat gleaming under fluorescent lights. The team relaxed. Take-off was due at 2.25pm and the final tests had now been completed. It was 12.30pm.
fields.body:
By lunchtime the technicians in hangar QN had finished. With its engines popping and cracking as they cooled, Air France's oldest Concorde - registration code F-BTSC - sat gleaming under fluorescent lights. The team relaxed. Take-off was due at 2.25pm and the final tests had now been completed. It was 12.30pm.

It had been a tough morning. The plane had arrived from New York at 9.30 the previous evening with some kind of fault. Though the daily shuttle across the Atlantic had passed without incident, the chief engineer had recorded odd readings in his log book. The Concorde was towed to a maintenance bay where a 12-man team of technicians worked on the four Rolls-Royce Olympus 593 engines. At around 2pm the plane was towed to parking bay 2B, close to Air France's headquarters and next to the control tower.

Tuesday was not a good day for anyone at Charles de Gaulle airport. Storms had delayed scores of flights and angry passengers filled the departure halls. There were three-hour queues at the transfer desks and planes backing up all over Europe waiting for slots to land.

One of the delayed planes was the early afternoon flight from Frankfurt. It was carrying 96 Germans on the trip of a lifetime. They were flying to Paris where, courtesy of Deilmann luxury travel company, they were to board a specially chartered Concorde for their 3 hours 45 minutes flight to New York. From there a cruise liner, the MS Deutschland, would take them through the Caribbean.

The group landed in Paris shortly after 3pm. From the main terminals they were bussed to a smaller facility called T9, used by special charters. Again there were delays as their baggage was transferred. No one seemed to care, though. `They were all laughing and singing,' said an Air France official who checked the group in at T9. `They didn't mind waiting at all.'

Perhaps happiest of all was Klaus Frentzem, an eccentric 53-year-old secondary school teacher and Concorde fanatic who had saved for 20 years to fulfil his dream of a supersonic flight. He had brought some of his extensive collection of Concorde memorabilia with him and proudly showed it to others in the departure lounge. A few hundred yards away sat their plane in the muggy July heat. Two Air France technicians were tinkering with motor number 2. This time there seemed to be a problem with its `thrust reverser', the shields that are lowered over the jets' blast to slow the plane. The hydraulic pump which activates the reversers was not working, and though the technicians were full of assurances that the fault would not affect the plane's performance the pilot insisted it be replaced. No spare was available so a pump was taken from another Concorde.

The pilot was Christian Marty, one of the best known at Air France. With only 12 pilots qualified to fly the planes, all the Concorde crews were famous in the company, but 54-year-old Marty, with his shock of blond hair and outrageous achievements as a sportsman, stood out. A few years before he had completed the first crossing of the Atlantic on a sailboard. It had taken 37 days. He was a competition skier and a champion hang-glider too. `He was kind of intense,' said a friend. `He was a very dry, rigorous man.'

It was in character for him to insist on the change. `He would never fly unless everything was 100 per cent,' the friend, a Concorde co-pilot, said. `He was a perfectionist. That's one of the reasons he was such a great pilot.'

By 3.15 the pump had been replaced and Marty was satisfied. With co-pilot Jean Marcot, who had been flying Concordes for more than 10 years, and chief engineer, 58-year-old Gilles Jardinot, he started the pre-take-off checks. Three motors are enough to keep the plane airborne and allow the pilot, after dumping much of the 96 tonnes of aviation fuel, to look for an emergency landing site.

But the plane was travelling at 250mph and had covered 4,200m of runway. It had reached V1 the speed at which it is considered impossible to abort a take-off safely. Though in hindsight it may have been a better option to take a risk, Marty followed the textbook procedure and pulled his stick back. The rear wheels left the ground. Flight AF 4590 was airborne. With a spout of flames and black smoke 40m long behind it.

Seconds later the pilot was on the radio again. It was only 100ft or so off the ground and had no thrust to gain altitude. Even that power was going. As the plane disappeared from view Spinetta quietly asked his secretary to get the Minister of Transport on the line. He had some bad news.

Marc Olivier, a 24-year-old basketball player, was practising with friends in a park near his home near Gonesse when he heard the scream of Concorde's engines. They stopped playing and looked for the plane. For most people in Gonesse - a small, blue-collar town ringed by dual carriageways and industrial estates- the twice-daily flypasts by the world's most famous passenger plane are hardly something to get excited about.

This time Concorde's approach sounded different. `You could hear the engines complaining as they tried to gain height,' Olivier told The Observer. `It was like they were screaming in pain.'

The basketball players watched as the plane started to bank to the left and lose height. Describing a huge arc, it was soon almost facing back the way it had come. Its nose came up until it was almost vertical. Flames continued to spurt from its underside. `It started turning as if to avoid the town and then began swinging around and almost seemed to stand on end,' Olivier said. `The left wing was hitting the tops of the trees. Then the wing hit the ground and the plane flipped over and slid along the ground upside down, and then there were two explosions and everything disappeared in smoke and fire.'

Five people were killed instantly: two young Polish women on a work experience programme were resting in their rooms, and a young Algerian maid who had been taken on the day before was making up beds with Devrance Chundursing, a 42- year-old Mauritian mother of two. The fifth body was found on Friday in the rubble under an engine. It was so badly burnt that identification of the sex was impossible. No one knows who it is.

The death toll could have been much higher. A 21-year-old British student from Kent, Alice Brooking, was talking to her sister in London when the plane struck. She leapt through a first-floor window and suffered nothing more than minor burns and a bruised wrist.

A bus-load of 44 teenagers, members of a Suffolk youth band, had been delayed by traffic. Their late arrival meant hotel manageress MichÁele Ficheteau had given eight of her staff an extended break. It was clear that no one could have survived in the plane. Early rumours of miraculous escapes were quickly proved optimistic. All 109 people on flight AF4590 died instantly. When the heat had subsided, rescue workers marked out the charred corpses and body parts with small plastic cones.

Passengers at the airport were informed that `major problems' had forced a temporary halt of all flights. As stunned Air France staff wandered through the packed halls, news of the disaster quickly spread. In terminal T9, where the passengers had whiled away their wait with songs and card games, airport staff were in tears . `I was crying and crying,' said Marie Segal, a shop assistant. `I had watched all these people having fun. I had sold them newspapers and books for the flight. One told me how flying on Concorde was his life's ambition. He was so excited.'

Yesterday investigators were still combing the jumbled wreckage for clues. The Air France Concorde fleet was still grounded. The press was still full of speculation.

Two main investigations into the crash have been launched by French authorities. One is run by the Bureau EnquÂetes-Accidents (BEA), the official government aviation investigations unit whose duty is to ensure such an accident never happens again. The other is a judicial inquiry which aims to find out who, if anyone, should be charged with `involuntary manslaughter', a serious criminal offence. Usually a single magistrate is in charge. This inquiry has three. The scale of the judicial probe demonstrates both the gravity of the potential charges and the importance of some of the players in the tragedy. Senior staff at Air France, at the airport, even the Minister for Transport himself, are potentially personally liable under French law.

There is a huge amount of data to work through. Just one of the two `black box' recorders contains 600 `parameters' which have to be analysed. Panels of experts including British, German and American specialists have been drafted in to help.

By the end of last week an explanation was beginning to emerge. On Friday investigators from the BEA announced that one, and perhaps two, of the four tyres on the undercarriage under the left wing had exploded as the plane was racing down the runway. Those who know Concorde's history were immediately reminded of an incident more than 20 years earlier. In 1979 two tyres exploded on an Air France Concorde as it took off from Washington's Dulles airport. Pieces of the wheels' magnesium rims and other debris were sent smashing into the plane's body.

A report by the American National Transport Safety Board, published two years later, revealed that `tyre debris and wheel shrapnel [had] resulted in damage to the No 2 engine, puncture of three fuel tanks, and severance of several hydraulic lines and electrical wires. Additionally, a large hole was torn in the top wing skin which covers the wheel well area.'

The plane returned safely to Dulles, but pilots have always remembered the incident. `They were lucky,' said Patrick Augin, vice-president of France's largest pilots' union. 'It did not cause a fire in 1979, but it could have. It's just a matter of where the holes are.'

As no debris from inside Flight AF4590's engines has been found on the runway investigators are playing down the idea that debris might have been sucked into the air intakes of its jets. Concorde is one of the few planes with air intakes situated directly behind its rear undercarriage. Experts point out that, with two huge intakes acting as giant hoovers, it is, whatever the BEA might say, unlikely that the motors themselves would have escaped unscathed.

Any debris inside the engines would cause massive and immediate damage, dislodging dozens of the sharp turbine blades used to compress air. The blades in turn would act like shrapnel inside the engine, smashing it apart and slicing through power and fuel lines. They would also be likely to puncture the fuel tanks held in the wing and cut their way into the twin engine alongside. Just because investigators haven't found any parts from the engine on the runway does not mean they were unscathed when the plane crashed. Another possibility is that a wheel jammed and then burst. The undercarriage would then smash on to the runway. The impact would force it back up into the body of the plane, rupturing fuel lines.

Once the thinly protected tanks in the wings or the fuel lines were damaged - by debris, or the undercarriage, or flying turbine blades- the leaking fluid would have been swiftly lit by a spark or chunk of hot metal. The burning fuel would be sprayed back by the airflow and the Rolls-Royce Olympus motors would have become huge flame-throwers. This would explain why, in the pictures of the stricken plane, the flames appear to originate from in front of the engines, though a plume of smoke and fire follows them. `Imagine a fireman's pressure hose squirting petrol across the mouth of a blast furnace and then multiply 100 or so times. It would have been so hot the metal of the plane itself would have been burning,' one former test pilot told The Observer. Another said the engines would have been converted into `giant cigarette lighters'.

Aviation experts appear to have been concerned about the potential for such a disaster for some time. In 1982 the US Transportation Safety Board recommended - after several more incidents involving malfunction of tyres on the plane - that Concorde should be allowed to land at American airports only after a full inspection of wheels, tyres and landing gear before every flight. Two subsequent incidents, more than a year apart, prompted a mild rebuke of Air France for the ineffectiveness of its earlier directives implementing these recommendations.

Pilots at British Airways, which operates seven Concordes, have long complained about the problem of burst tyres. With its fast take-off speed and sharp profile, Concorde is particularly hard on its undercarriage. On its first ever landing in America in 1976, engineers replaced a tyre which they felt was excessively worn. Some experts last week claimed that even a teaspoon left in its path could cause a blow-out. And the incidents appear to have recurred. At Heathrow in 1993 a burst tyre broke a glass-fibre water deflector and punctured a fuel tank. Earlier that year a tyre-burst due to brake seizure caused significant damage to a Concorde's engine, wing and hydraulics. The problem became so acute that BA installed a special alarm system in Concorde flight decks to alert the pilot on blow-out.

Ever since its launch, experts have also worried about the plane's susceptibility to fire. A report by American fire specialists Blazetech written nearly 25 years ago mentions the vulnerability of Concorde to fires produced by catastrophic engine failures. It also appears that a British Aerospace report in 1976 raised concerns over the fire risk in Concorde's fuel tanks.

A technical idiosyncrasy on Concorde explains why Marty was unaware of any blow-outs. When a tyre is faulty, a red light goes on in front of pilots - but only if Concorde is travelling at less than 150mph. At faster speeds it is impossible to stop, so the alarm is not activated. Marty had no idea what was happening underneath his plane. This explains why Marty attempted to raise the undercarriage - Air France's recommended procedure after a blow-out is to leave it down - after the plane took off.

Implicit in British Airways' decision to continue flying Concorde is the accusation that it was poor management or maintenance that was responsible for the Paris tragedy. BA still clearly believes that the blame is not with the craft itself. `We wouldn't operate the aircraft if we thought it was unsafe,' a spokesman said.

But the plane that crashed on Tuesday had undergone a 10-day inspection that ended on the Friday before the crash. And, with the rest of the Air France fleet, it had been given a complete refit, taking three months, last year. Nor can the company - still largely state-owned - be accused of cutting back on maintenance. Though costs have been slashed elsewhere to bring Air France into profit, Concorde has been seen as a symbol of national prestige and funded accordingly.

Air France is refusing to answer technical questions about the crash. It has yet to confirm that the undercarriage and tyres were properly inspected before take-off. Nor is it yet clear if the repairs to the plane's engines, and particularly the fitting of the cannibalised thrust reverser minutes before take-off, were a factor in the crash. There are also serious questions over the condition of the runway. Was there an undetected flaw that caused a blow-out? Or maybe a rogue piece of uncleared detritus from the scores of flights that use the strip each day? The two technicians who fitted the equipment and many of the ground staff who maintained the strip were undergoing psychiatric counselling last week.

BA's confidence in Concorde is not shared by Air France pilots. Some French unions said their members would refuse to serve on Concorde until the accident was explained. Etienne Lichtenburger, of the SPAC pilots' union, said: `No pilot will take up a Concorde until we have a clear account of what happened and what will be done about it.'

No one has blamed Marty. `He had to face the worst poss-ible scenario,' said Germain Chambost, a former Concorde pilot. `He did what he could, but there was no way out for him.'

Another Concorde pilot, answering questions from The Observer through an intermediary, said: `It could have been any of us. I am still in love with the plane, even if I don't want to fly right now. I keep thinking of him trying to keep control with two engines on fire. It could have been me. What was going through his mind in that minute? And what went through his mind when he knew he was going to die?'

Gonesse was quiet yesterday. On Friday the town had held a silent march to commemorate the dead. Some 2,000 locals, relatives of the victims and Air France staff walked down the high street, past the industrial estates, through the fields and out to the crash site. They were led by the mayor, Jean-Pierre Blazy, and Michéle Fricheteau, owner of the hotel. Blazy was angry in his grief, railing against British Airways' decision to keep their Concordes flying. Fricheteau just let the tears run down her face.

Five hundred metres from the wreckage they halted and hung their heads. Overhead the engines of a 747 roared through the sky.

Bottom of the safety league

Concorde's first fatal crash now puts the aircraft, statistically, at the bottom of the world safety league. The airliner had a superb 31-year crash-free record since its maiden flight in 1969 and entry into commercial service in 1976. Concorde's other incidents include:

1979 Air France plane has catastrophic tyre blow-out on take-off from Washington, damaging wing, fuel tank, engine. BA tyre blows out on take-off from Heathrow.

1989 Damage to BA plane's rudder in flight. 1991 BA plane's rudder breaks up at 56,000ft.

1993 BA plane's tyre blow-out at Heathrow causes fuel leak.

1994 Report reveals outer window panels crack at Mach 2. Safety checks ordered.

1998 BA plane turns back to Heathrow after panel falls off wing. Part of rudder falls off another BA aircraft in mid-flight.

February 2000 Engine failure as BA plane approaches Heathrow.

23 July 2000 BA and Air France report finding 2.5in cracks in the wings of all Concordes.

BA's confidence in Concorde is not shared by Air France pilots. Some French unions said their members would refuse to serve on Concorde until the accident was explained. Etienne Lichtenburger, of the SPAC pilots' union, said: `No pilot will take up a Concorde until we have a clear account of what happened and what will be done about it.' No one has blamed Marty. `He had to face the worst poss-ible scenario,' said Germain Chambost, a former Concorde pilot. `He did what he could, but there was no way out for him.' Another Concorde pilot, answering questions from The Observer through an intermediary, said: `It could have been any of us. I am still in love with the plane, even if I don't want to fly right now. I keep thinking of him trying to keep control with two engines on fire. It could have been me. What was going through his mind in that minute? And what went through his mind when he knew he was going to die?' Gonesse was quiet yesterday. On Friday the town had held a silent march to commemorate the dead. Some 2,000 locals, relatives of the victims and Air France staff walked down the high street, past the industrial estates, through the fields and out to the crash site. They were led by the mayor, Jean-Pierre Blazy, and Michéle Fricheteau, owner of the hotel. Blazy was angry in his grief, railing against British Airways' decision to keep their Concordes flying. Fricheteau just let the tears run down her face. Five hundred metres from the wreckage they halted and hung their heads. Overhead the engines of a 747 roared through the sky. The airliner had a superb 31-year crash-free record since its maiden flight in 1969 and entry into commercial service in 1976. Concorde's other incidents include: 1979 Air France plane has catastrophic tyre blow-out on take-off from Washington, damaging wing, fuel tank, engine. BA tyre blows out on take-off from Heathrow. 1989 Damage to BA plane's rudder in flight. 1991 BA plane's rudder breaks up at 56,000ft. 1993 BA plane's tyre blow-out at Heathrow causes fuel leak. 1994 Report reveals outer window panels crack at Mach 2. Safety checks ordered. 1998 BA plane turns back to Heathrow after panel falls off wing. Part of rudder falls off another BA aircraft in mid-flight. February 2000 Engine failure as BA plane approaches Heathrow. 23 July 2000 BA and Air France report finding 2.5in cracks in the wings of all Concordes.

fields.headline: Eta shoots dead retired politician
fields.trailText: Gunmen assumed to be working for Eta, the Basque separatist group, shot dead a retired Spanish politician yesterday, their seventh killing this year and the latest victim of an escalating summer campaign of violence that has seen attacks in Madrid and Málaga, as well as the Basque Country.
fields.body:
Gunmen assumed to be working for Eta, the Basque separatist group, shot dead a retired Spanish politician yesterday, their seventh killing this year and the latest victim of an escalating summer campaign of violence that has seen attacks in Madrid and Málaga, as well as the Basque Country.

Juan María Jáuregui, former civil governor of Guipúzcoa province, was shot in the back of the head twice by two men as he sat drinking in the Café Frontón Beotibar in Tolosa, south of San Sebastián, where he was on holiday from his new home in Chile. He was taken to hospital but died 90 minutes later.

Jáuregui, married with a 19-year-old daughter, was the seventh person to die since Eta called off a unilateral ceasefire in December, angered by the government's refusal to negotiate and by Basque politicians' failure to build cross-border institutions. A former Communist, Jáuregui was jailed during the Franco era and, during his two years in Guipúzcoa, began an investigation into police torture which led to the jailing of a Civil Guard general involved in the torture and murder of two Eta members during the Eighties.

There was anger and immediate condemnation from all parties save Euskal Herritarok, widely perceived as the separatist group's political wing.

`Eta has chosen today to strike again,' said Jaime Mayor Oreja, the hardline Interior Minister. `It is trying desperately to make the government modify its policy with these cruel blows.'

The leader of the Basque government, Juan José Ibarretxe, who has tried to bring the radical nationalists into the political fold with little success, said yesterday: `What will Eta do? Kill all of us who disagree with them?'

That seems to be the only criterion for choosing Eta's victims. Jauregui, Madrid's senior representative in the Basque province of Guipúzcoa from 1994 to 1996, was in Eta's sights back in 1996, after which he retired from politics and began working for Aldeasa, which runs the duty-free stores in Spanish airports.

The businessman, who was posted to the Canary Islands and then Chile, normally travelled with a bodyguard. But he was unprotected yesterday because he was on holiday.

A wave of attacks over the past three weeks testifies to Eta's determination to impose a long, hot summer. On 15 July it shot dead José María Martín Carpena, a local councillor for the ruling Popular Party in the seaside resort of Málaga. It has also planted at least eight bombs this month.

On Friday police detained two suspected Eta members and searched a flat in the city of Zaragoza, east of Madrid. According to police, they were planning to kill the mayor using a bomb.

fields.headline: Zimbabwe braced for strike violence crackdown protesters
fields.trailText: Zimbabwe was last night bracing itself for a new escalation of violence as opposition leaders expected a massive deployment of the country's armed forces in response to a call for a national strike this week.
fields.body:
Zimbabwe was last night bracing itself for a new escalation of violence as opposition leaders expected a massive deployment of the country's armed forces in response to a call for a national strike this week.

The Zimbabwe Congress of Trade Unions on Friday endorsed the three-day national stoppage and has been backed by hundreds of white farmers and civic groups. The strike was called to protest against the violence used by President Robert Mugabe's supporters against white farmers, their workers and city residents.

`The people are saying `No more' to Mugabe's oppression,' said Michelle Maponga, a Harare secretary. `Zimbabweans do not like to see laws being broken and people being beaten, whether it is white farmers threatened by war veterans or township residents beaten by the army. People are standing up to the Mugabe government and saying, `You may have won the elections by hook or by crook, but you cannot oppress us all'.'

For nearly a month army units have patrolled Harare townships, meting out beatings at random.

`No one at our factory is going to work on Monday because they are afraid of the army,' said Felicity Manyanga, production manager at a pottery.

Hopes that Zimbabwe would return to normal after the violence of the June parliamentary elections, when 32 opposition supporters were killed, have been dashed by an increase in occupations of white-owned farms by Mugabe's supporters. Last week two white farmers were beaten unconscious and one white farm mechanic was beaten to death. Scores of farm labourers were also beaten.

The call for a national strike began with white farmers in the Glendale and Karoi areas who closed down their operations to protest against continued violence and lack of police protection. Support for a stoppage spread during the week to Harare and other cities.

`This has been a spontan-eous call by ordinary citizens demanding a return to the rule of law,' stated one leaflet distributed in industrial areas. `It includes people of all colours and creeds who demand a return to civil order in the high-density suburbs [townships] in the rural areas and on the farms.' Faced with growing support for the strike among its members, the Zimbabwe Congress of Trade Unions backed the strike. Zimbabwe's opposition party, the Movement for Democratic Change (MDC), has not officially organised or sanctioned the strike, but its leadership and members support the action.

MDC president Morgan Tsvangirai said urban workers decided to take action in solidarity with farm workers living under constant fear of losing their lives or jobs. `Workers are being beaten up. How do you expect them to be productive under such conditions?' he said.

He also warned that the protests by the farmers must not be misconstrued as a fight against land redistribution, but for a peaceful and just process.

Jonathan Moyo, Mugabe's new Minister of Information, alleged the strike had been hatched by white farmers who were trying to hang on to the land stolen from the African people during the colonial era.

`Government has expeditiously responded through the police, who have also put in place adequate security arrangements wherever need has been demonstrated,' he said. But Tendai Biti, the MDC's secretary for agriculture, denounced `the haphazard manner' in which the Mugabe government had dealt with the land issue. `It has resulted in the current chaos on commercial farms,' he said. `The government must move swiftly to restore the rule of law and remove land occupiers from the farms, pending implementation of a proper process.'

The MDC proposes a land commission composed of all stakeholders, to make proposals for a coherent, sustainable land reform process.

fields.headline: World in brief
fields.trailText: A drought in North Korea has set back efforts to end five years of famine, destroying rice paddies at the height of the growing season and slashing projected corn harvests, an aid worker said.
fields.body:
North Korean drought

A drought in North Korea has set back efforts to end five years of famine, destroying rice paddies at the height of the growing season and slashing projected corn harvests, an aid worker said.

Fiji coup leader jailed

George Speight, the Fiji coup leader who held dozens of hostages in the country's parliament for eight weeks, was imprisoned on an island to await charges that could include treason, the military said.

Speight and six key advisers were taken yesterday morning to an islet less than a mile wide, near Suva, which the military had declared a `prison' zone.

Out of the nuclear race

An international team of scientists detonated a controlled explosion yesterday to destroy the last of Kazakhstan's nuclear test sites. The blast, with a force equivalent to 100 tonnes of dynamite, effectively removed the former Soviet republic from the list of nations capable of launching nuclear weapons.

Aborigines' rights

The Australian government yesterday defended its treatment of Aborigines against United Nations criticism of mandatory sentencing laws that the world body says hurt the indigenous community.

Transsexual dilemma

After Marshall Gardiner of Kansas died last year, a friend suggested there might be more to his widow than met the eye. So Gardiner's only son, Joe, hired an investigator and discovered his stepmother, J'Noel Gardiner, was once a man. The two are now in a legal battle over Gardiner's $2.5m estate in a case that could affect the rights of transsexuals in marriage across the United States.

fields.headline: Bush campaign looks well-oiled
fields.standfirst: George W. Bush's run for the Presidency is controlled by a loyal team who have stood by their man since 1994, writes Ed Vulliamy in New York
fields.trailText: George W. Bush arrives at the Republican convention in Philadelphia tomorrow flanked - in defiance of his rival, Al Gore - by a White House-in-waiting.
fields.body:
George W. Bush arrives at the Republican convention in Philadelphia tomorrow flanked - in defiance of his rival, Al Gore - by a White House-in-waiting.

While Gore deliberates over his choice of running mate, Bush will present Dick Cheney, a nomination charged with meanings both political and dynastic. But the Bush entourage goes deeper than that. While Gore lurches from reshuffle to reshuffle with his staff, Bush's team is almost unchanged from his first victorious race for the Texas governorship in 1994. They call it `Team Bush'.

To the fore is Cheney, whose appointment weaves three strands into the tapestry of the Bush candidacy. The first is generational: although Cheney is only a few years 'Dubya's' senior, he looks like a father-figure - and is one. Cheney helped Bush the Elder free Kuwait's oil fields from Saddam Hussein.

This made Cheney's next career move - and the second strand he weaves into the Bush campaign - a logical one. It is not for nothing that Bush-Cheney is called 'The Big Oil Ticket'. Within four years of the war, Cheney was chief executive of the Halliburton oil company, which happened to do most of its business with the Arab countries that had sided with the US in the war. Within two years of Cheney's arrival, the company's stock value had trebled.

The third strand Cheney weaves is ideological: he fits into Bush's mantra of 'compassionate conservatism'. For all his fatherly image - President Clinton called him a `good man' - Cheney is an arch-conservative, described by Democrats as `right of Newt Gingrich'.

This makes Cheney a curious appointment given Bush's battle for the middle ground, which he must prise from the 1996 electorate that returned the President to power. Democrat Jim McGovern recalled Cheney's opposition to the release of Nelson Mandela. Cheney's criticisms of the child-opportunity 'Head Start' programme fits awkwardly with Bush's pledge that 'no child will be left behind'. He voted against federal funding for abortions, even in cases of rape and incest.

`Team Bush' is one of the most tightly woven ever to fight a Presi dential election. Public disagreements and leaks among the team are unheard of. The downside, Democrats say, may be that Bush never gets tested by critical advice. But the result is a `relaxed' campaign, based partly on the premise that if Bush is not inevitable, he is nothing. The nonchalance is deceptive; it is one of the most disciplined campaigns in memory.

It was forged partly by communications director Karen Hughes, a former TV anchor. Hughes controls all access to Bush, protecting a man who lacks much of the basic knowledge and savvy expected of a presidential contender.

Hughes, however, is not the Kingmaker. That title goes to the intriguing figure of chief strategist Karl Rove. There is a cartoon above Rove's desk in his office in Austin, Texas: as Gore and Bush scratch each other's eyes out, Bush screams for help: 'Call Rove!'

Rove has managed almost every Republican campaign in Texas for the past two decades. He is often compared with the legendary Lee Atwater, credited with winning the 1988 election for George Bush senior. Rove's dedication has few parallels: at Bush's request he sold his consulting business so his attention would be undivided.

After Hughes and Rove, there is a third point to the `Iron Triangle', a 275-lb, 6'4'' giant called Joe Allbaugh. Allbaugh, chief-of-staff in waiting, is like a political bodyguard - quiet, considered and ruthless Ð who believes that 'there isn't anything more important than protecting him and the first lady'.

The campaign packaging is the work of Maverick Media - Mark McKinnon, a disillusioned Democrat and former country musician who came to Nashville to write songs for Kris Kristofferson, and, among other staff, Stuart Stevens, who says regarding Al Gore's take-no-prisoners team, `we're not going to run that kind of race'. McKinnon produces shots of Bush and his wife Laura bathed in sweet sunlight as though advertising hair conditioner, not the privatisation of social security.

Foreign policy is famously Bush's weak point, with his confusions between Greeks and Grecians, Slovenia and Slovakia. But even this is partly contrived: to some degree Americans prefer it that way. Condoleeza Rice is the diva-in-waiting of US politics: bright, beautiful and about to become the first ever black and the first ever woman to be appointed National Security Adviser.

It remains to be seen whether Bush will entice the one person onto his team that he wants more than any other. If General Colin Powell was Secretary of State, that would clinch the election. His absence is the black hole at the core of Team Bush.

webTitle: Lovers' conviction for Las Vegas murder under fire

fields.headline: Lovers' conviction for Las Vegas murder under fire
fields.trailText: At first, it was a relatively simple case for a Las Vegas murder, involving the death of casino magnate Ted Binion, $15 million in bullion buried in the desert and two jealous, homicidal lovers.
fields.byline: by Nick Paton Walsh, Las Vegas
fields.body:
At first, it was a relatively simple case for a Las Vegas murder, involving the death of casino magnate Ted Binion, $15 million in bullion buried in the desert and two jealous, homicidal lovers.

But last week, after allegations of misconduct on the part of jurors and lawyers, the improper use of a jailhouse informant and a reported film and book deal involving the Mob, lawyers for Rick Tabish and Sandra Murphy - convicted of the murder of millionaire Binion - will demand a new trial alleging serious irregularities in court proceedings.

Tabish and Murphy were found guilty on 19 May of the murder of Binion, who died from a drug overdose and suffocation in his Las Vegas home on 17 September 1998. Murphy was a topless dancer and Binion's live-in girlfriend, and Tabish her lover. They were also convicted of stealing from Binion's personal fortune, out of which $15m in silver coins is missing, presumed buried in the Nevada wilderness.

A Clark County court will hear from defence attorneys how jurors broke court rules, including reading documents they should not have seen. There have also been claims that a juror read media reports of the case on the internet using her hand-held Palm Pilot computer. Lawyers for the pair will subpoena the trial jury in an effort to confirm these allegations by a woman juror.

They will also claim that the authorities acted improperly when, during Tabish's time in custody, they placed an informant in a cell near Tabish to enable him to steal confidential documents relating to the case.

Attention will also be drawn to the fact that Murphy and Tabish were tried together, although Murphy was not charged with some of the 11 counts levied against Tabish. Her defence counsel will argue that these charges cast a dark shadow over Murphy's involvement and impeded her fair trial.

Tabish was defended by Louis Palazzo who, it has been alleged, did not provide a competent defence. It has been claimed that Palazzo was implicated in a book and film deal between Tabish and a man named Joseph Cusumano. Cusumano report edly agreed to help Tabish with his legal fees in return for a share of his film rights. Palazzo was cleared of any wrongdoing by local authorities last year and has made his financial records open to Tabish's new lawyers.

But the most curious claim from the defence lawyers involves an FBI report about a separate Mob plot to kill Binion that Murphy's attorney, John Momot, says should have been disclosed to him before the original trial. Momot says he came across the report by accident, when an associate found it. The report, dated April 1999, refers to the Mob murder of 'Fat' Herby Blitstein in 1997.

It suggests that the same Mob kingpin who hired a hitman to kill Blitstein spoke to the same man about killing Binion. The murder method discussed involved a plan to make it look like a drug overdose and contains several similarities to the death of Binion.

webTitle: Six die in riots as Fujimori sworn in

fields.headline: Six die in riots as Fujimori sworn in
fields.trailText: A woman awaits news of friends trapped in the blazing state-run Banco de la Nación in Lima in which six workers died after it was allegedly set on fire by rioting opponents of Peru's President Alberto Fujimori, write agencies.
fields.body:
A woman awaits news of friends trapped in the blazing state-run Banco de la Nación in Lima in which six workers died after it was allegedly set on fire by rioting opponents of Peru's President Alberto Fujimori, write agencies.

Street fighting rocked the Peruvian capital on Friday as tens of thousands of demonstrators from across the country marched to protest against the inauguration of Fujimori, 62, for an unprecedented third five-year presidential term. The unrest has followed a 28 May run-off in elections that many opposition supporters claim were rigged in Fujimori's favour.

Demonstrators set fire to other government buildings, threw rocks at the president's official residence - and fought running battles with units of 40,000 riot police. Hospital officials said at least 80 people were injured. Photograph by Ricardo Mazalán

webTitle: Time for the monarchy to move aside

fields.headline: Time for the monarchy to move aside
fields.standfirst: Crown remains a symbol of privilege over people, chance over endeavour
fields.trailText: Crown remains a symbol of privilege over people, chance over endeavour
fields.body:
The world into which the Queen Mother was born did not have aeroplanes, never mind supersonic jets. In 1900, there was no radio, television, mobile phone, nor computer; no genetic testing, nor nuclear missile. Women did not have the vote. In the 100 years of her life, the world has endured two global wars and one cold one. The British Empire, which girdled the globe on her day of birth, has been reduced to a few specks in the Pacific and dots in the Caribbean. Life has been turned inside out by revolutions sexual, social, communist and technological. Through all this upheaval, the British monarchy has survived; testimony to the durability and the guile of the House of Windsor so embodied in the Queen Mother.

But what does it say about the rest of us that, in the first year of the third millennium, Britain still selects its head of state by birth certificate? Are we content with the prospect of having a hereditary monarch in another 100 years' time?

This is not a question that politicians want to address. The ludicrous recent furore when Mo Mowlam mildly wondered whether the Windsors might move into a more modern home is testimony to the neuralgia among politicians about any discussion of becoming a republic. Surely, though, the centenary of the Queen Mother is an excellent moment to open up the debate.

Unlike nearly every other democracy in the world, the British constitution treats us as subjects, not as free, equal and sovereign citizens. Well, who cares? Don't we all know it is a fiction? The Queen reigns; the Prime Minister rules. The powers are in her name, but they are really wielded by Number 10. Her honours list and her bishops are selected in Downing Street. The monarchy is just a glittering delivery carriage for the decisions of the Government. That actually makes things much, much worse. Under the magisterial cloak of royal prerogative, the Prime Minister enjoys quasi-dictatorial powers covering everything from making war to signing treaties. Until that is sorted out, Britain will never have a balanced constitution.

One case for keeping the monarchy is that it somehow provides the nation with a mystical bond of continuity with history. This is ancestor worship, at which we would smile if it were practised by a native tribe, and much of it bogus at that. The royal family are descended from Hanoverians imported by early eighteenth-century MPs to solve a political-religious problem. The flummery associated with the royals was principally invented by Disraeli, the first great spin-doctor, in the late nineteenth century. In any case, if Britain has a problem, it is hardly a lack of history. The past weighs on us to the detriment of the future. Royal ritual continues to aspic our culture and attitudes in yesterday at the expense of tomorrow.

Some argue for retaining the royal family on the grounds that they are a tourist highlight of Heritage Britain. This is a thin proposition. The French dispensed with their crowned head more than two centuries ago and tourists still flock there; in rather larger numbers, in fact, than they do to Britain. Visitors do not come to these islands on the off-chance of seeing the Queen. Windsor Castle will still be there, as will the Tower of London. Everyone, not just those in receipt of a gilded invitation, could soon have the opportunity to wander the gardens of Buckingham Palace.

Determining that Britain should at some point in the near future become a republic implies no disrespect to the Queen, who has done a remarkable job for half a century. Relieving her from the burdens of office would give her a few years to enjoy a quiet retirement. All her family could retain their titles should they wish. Prince Charles would be saved from another two angst-ridden decades of awaiting his mother's death and Camilla could quietly become Duchess of Cornwall. Princess Anne would no doubt wish to carry on her widespread public works. Prince William could spend his winters in St Moritz and summers in Bali. Should the Windsors wish to be involved in politics, that would be a matter for them. However, serious radical discussion on issues of vital importance might no longer be shut out by their discordant - and often contradictory - contributions.

This leaves the unwritten role for the monarch as the the nation's spokesperson at time of triumph or trial. Leave aside whether anyone can or should attempt to speak for a heterogenous nation any more, does the present elderly Queen speak convincingly for all of her people? Can we expect her confused son to do any better? It remains instructive that at the time of the death of Diana, mother of their heirs, it was none of the royal family who articulated the emotion sweeping much of Britain, but the Prime Minister. Ah, the monarchists will always cry, who would you have in charge of the Republic of the United Kingdom? President Branson? The bearded balloonist would not be our choice. But if the people wanted President Branson as their head of state in preference to the descendants of George I, then they should be allowed so to choose. That is the point of living in a democracy, and that is what we will never quite be for so long as our head of state is hereditary.

The monarchy remains symbolic of privilege over people, of chance over endeavour, of being something, rather than doing something. We elevate to the apex of our society someone selected not on the basis of talent or achievement, but because of genes. For all the lip-service that politicians of all parties pay to meritocracy, for so long as we have a hereditary monarchy, Britain enthrones and glorifies the exact opposite.

A republic will not happen overnight, and cannot happen without a referendum. But we now believe its time has come.

webTitle: The day Kuwait wants to forget

fields.headline: The day Kuwait wants to forget
fields.standfirst: Kuwait's rulers want to erase 2 August 1990 from memory, but for many the horror will never go away, Brian Whitaker reports
fields.trailText: When the Iraqis invaded Kuwait on 2 August 1990, Muhammad Ben Naji's first thought was to call the police. He was eating breakfast in a cafe when trouble broke out in the street. Hearing shots, the customers rushed to the window. 'A man in uniform saw us watching and pointed his gun. The window shattered and the owner of the cafe, an Indian man, fell dead with a bullet in his head.'
fields.body:
When the Iraqis invaded Kuwait on 2 August 1990, Muhammad Ben Naji's first thought was to call the police. He was eating breakfast in a cafe when trouble broke out in the street. Hearing shots, the customers rushed to the window. 'A man in uniform saw us watching and pointed his gun. The window shattered and the owner of the cafe, an Indian man, fell dead with a bullet in his head.'

Naji rushed upstairs and hid for several hours. It was only when he ventured downstairs that he learnt what had really happened. By then, Iraqi checkpoints were all over the city but he made his way home by pretending to be a Palestinian. 'Every day for seven months I was expecting to die,' he says. 'They would come into our houses and search them. If they found a typewriter or a camera, everyone would be killed. Every house has bad memories of that time.'

To remember - or to forget. That is Kuwait's dilemma as it approaches the tenth anniversary of the invasion on Wednesday. In whatever way it marks the occasion (officials say cryptically that 'nothing has been announced'), one thing is sure: most Kuwaitis will be somewhere else.

Midday July temperatures in Kuwait reach 50C in the shade. Every gust of wind burns the eyes, every breath sears the nostrils. The shaded colonnades in front of shops may look inviting, but there the unwary are hit by scorching blasts from the wrong side of air conditioning units. In August the weather gets worse. Damp air generated by the Indian monsoon pushes humidity up to 90 per cent. You can't even sweat properly. In the annual exodus, 60 per cent of Kuwaitis (around 500,000) go abroad until the worst has passed, leaving behind 1.4 million foreigners - mainly Indians, Pakistanis and Filipinos - to keep the country ticking over.

That is how it will be this year, and how it was in 1990 on what Saddam Hussein still refers to as 'The Day of the Great Call', when the unsuspecting Indians, Pakistanis, Filipinos and a handful of Kuwaitis were suddenly joined by half a million Iraqi troops. Kuwait, the world's richest country in proportion to its size, became the nineteenth province of Iraq.

Kuwaitis have two very different memories of that event. There are those who experienced the torment at first hand, in some cases fighting with the resistance, and those - the majority - who were abroad and watched it on television with horror but in comfort. To ask a Kuwaiti 'What did you do in the war?' is to risk causing either pain or embarrassment.

Outwardly, the collective memory has been wiped almost clean. Looking at the city today it is as if nothing had happened: a huge restoration programme has returned it, as closely as possible, to its pre-invasion state. The only major building preserved in ruins is, appropriately, the national museum.

The urge to forget is reflected in many ways, not least in Kuwait's growing alcohol, drug abuse and suicide problems. There are 29,000 registered addicts, and last year 57 people died from drug overdoses.

Dr Abdullah al-Hammadi runs a government-funded clinic specialising in post-traumatic stress disorders (PTSD) arising from the conflict. Since the war, his clinic has treated 1,600 people but, 10 years on, it still gets six new clients a month. Avoidance is a symptom, and many sufferers take years to accept they have a problem. One woman, who had been used as a human shield in Iraq, suppressed her symptoms for 10 years before seeking help. Others take refuge in drink or drugs; some become aggressive; some avoid parts of the city that bring back memories.

'People don't want reminders,' says Hammadi. 'They don't like therapy and they don't want the stigma of psychological disorder. When they come to us for treatment it's usually because of complications: the effect on their social life, their work or their family life.'

An estimated 15,000 Kuwaitis were detained by the Iraqis during the occupation - some for a few hours, but others for months. At least 60 per cent were tortured physically or psychologically, according to Hammadi. A study carried out three years after the war found that 19 per cent of adults had symptoms of PTSD; 16 per cent of children had PTSD, and 40 per cent had behavioural problems.

Among the 'martyr families' (where a relative was executed in front of the family or killed in combat) the PTSD rate was higher still, at 25 per cent.

Worst of all are the 220 resistance fighters who were injured. Their experience has been similar to that of disabled US veterans who returned from Vietnam.

'They think nobody appreciates what they did,' says Hammadi. 'One man with 600 pieces of shrapnel in his body was seen by the best doctors but became hostile because nothing could be done.'

Some, as young as 25, have been deemed unemployable and given state pensions. But that, Hammadi said, makes the problem worse: they have less money than before, and nothing to occupy their time.

While many Kuwaitis try to forget the invasion, others are anxious to remind them of the 600 people still missing - referred to in Kuwait as the prisoners of war, although Iraq denies holding them. 'The number may not sound large,' Sulaiman Majed al-Shaheen, Kuwait's Information Minister, says, 'but it's one person in a 1,000 - equivalent to 57,000 Britons.'

The government last week offered to meet Iraq for direct talks if it freed 10 per cent of the prisoners as a goodwill gesture.

One further memory affects almost all Kuwaitis: an event which may yet return to haunt them. At the end of the war retreating Iraqi forces set fire to hundreds of oil wells, which continued to burn until November 1991 - long after most Kuwaitis had returned home. The burning oil gave off cancer-causing hydrocarbons. Hammadi believes that most of the population inhaled a toxic dose.

It will take another five to 10 years before the effect is known. Until then Kuwaitis can only hope that Saddam Hussein's ultimate time-bomb is not ticking away in their lungs.
