webTitle: Don't patronise us over Europe, Mr Blair

fields.headline: Don't patronise us over Europe, Mr Blair
fields.trailText: Democratically speaking, Britain is in a shameful mess over the single currency and, indeed, its future role in the European Union. This is partly the result of prolonged attempts by governments to manipulate opinion. The public is disaffected and mistrustful. Our arranged marriage with the Common Market of 1973 has dwindled into loveless cohabitation. Assertions about the desirability of continued political and economic integration by those who welcome that prospect are as unconvincing to the sceptics as were the assurances given to Little Red Riding Hood.
fields.body:
Democratically speaking, Britain is in a shameful mess over the single currency and, indeed, its future role in the European Union. This is partly the result of prolonged attempts by governments to manipulate opinion. The public is disaffected and mistrustful. Our arranged marriage with the Common Market of 1973 has dwindled into loveless cohabitation. Assertions about the desirability of continued political and economic integration by those who welcome that prospect are as unconvincing to the sceptics as were the assurances given to Little Red Riding Hood.

We understood the original 'democratic deficit', but 27 years later the gap has become a gulf. Today, the ignorance is as profound as ever and is energised by resentment. Few know the name of their MEP or have much sense of belonging to, or ownership of, the so-called union.

Not a quarter of the electorate was moved to vote in the May 1999 European elections, partly because the electoral system, where one could only vote for a party, was rightly seen as a cynical fix. The EU Commission's latest Eurobarometer (a six-monthly, cross-community, mass opinion survey) shows that support here for the single currency is down to 22 per cent with only 25 per cent thinking our membership is 'a good thing'. What business or institution with a comparable 27-year record would still be around to be able to continue peddling its still unfulfilled claims?

The British hate being misled and patronised, of which there are few worse instances in our entire history than the endless pretence that the single currency is merely an economic matter. The Government knows full well that most people are genuinely worried about the broader political and cultural implications. Very occasionally, Ministers will acknowledge that, but only then on the basis, as the Prime Minister put it in the House of Commons on 21 June, that the non-economic issues have been 'resolved by the Government'. Thanks!

Year by year since 1973, a nation which, in the last world war had to call on every ounce of patriotism for its very survival, has seen control of its own affairs pooled in Europe. Most people have experienced a steady loss of political power and control of their lives.

This has led to the political equivalent of what psychologists call 'learned helplessness', which has, in turn, contributed to what Betty Boothroyd on Wednesday described as the growing cynicism and alienation of voters. It is a syndrome which leads to civic passivity and disengagement and even to a sense of subjection.

The metropolitan riposte is that national sovereignty is anyhow bound to go on diminishing (as if one is less keen to hang on to what one has because it is so little). The chiding is often accompanied by the 'more fool you' rebuke that `ever closer union' is written into the Treaty of Rome, and that we should all have read the small print. No wonder `ordinary' people feel conspired against.

What also causes deep offence to the multitude who doubt the wisdom of fur ther political union is the charge that they are being faint hearted or simply playing the little Englander.

Rather, some say, the ones lacking moral fibre are those who can't face the challenge of standing apart from the single currency and fast-track convergence. Both points of view have more than their fair share of caricature but sadly there is little middle ground. What is certainly true is that for very many of those hostile to further integration, love of their country is a powerful impulse. It crosses class divides. That patriotism, scoffed at by the sophisticates, finds little outlet in Europe. Rather, too many Euro-initiatives seem insensitive to those idiosyncratic, familiar things which are so valued by 'the little battalions'.

This strand of antipathy to Europe may be coalescing around the general countryside 'revolt', which is also bound up with the preservation of traditional and peculiarly English aspects of life (hunting or the WI, for example) which are felt - often wrongly - to be under threat from the EU, with its endless change and homogenisation. There may even be a developing sense of mismatch between it and faith communities which tend to be independent and conservative. There is in all this more than a touch of the old Reformation attitudes towards this modern Rome.

Europe has also become part of the social exclusion problem in that the dynamic minority for whom it presents a real opportunity are, by their preoccupying involvement with Europe, likely to become even more detached from home problems which need their care if they are to have any prospect of resolution. That is undoubtedly exacerbated by the new capitalism and growing earnings divide.

One must say, too, that for a government which consults at the drop of a hat, big European issues have been bizarrely ignored. The Tories were no better and the EU has been a remarkably ineffective populariser of its own affairs. Meanwhile, the problems of impersonality, uniformity and vaunting complication get ever worse. As one small indication, last week's Parliamentary 'EEC papers' itemise 103 publications for us to choose from. These do not include the gusher of EU laws, which last year took up 10 feet of shelf space.

All this is inseparable from seeking to govern a continent of disparate countries. It is creating a world fit mainly for lawyers. Its bulimic regime encourages rejection via growing corruption (the invariable response to over-regulation), bureaucratic stasis and arbitrariness of implementation. All of this fuels yet more regulation.

If there is a way of redeeming the present self-defeating disgrace, it must start with honesty within and across the political parties. Imaginative attempts must be made to give everyone, however unsophisticated, the chance to take part in what must become a great debate. That process should start now, properly and fairly financed, ending with a referendum after the next general election. It would do wonders for its efficacy if it was, like the 1975 one, cross-party, thus drawing in the huge majority who have no fixed political abode. Such a referendum could just about save the day, so that its result will be right, whichever way it goes. Lord Phillips of Sudbury is a solicitor and life peer.

The chiding is often accompanied by the 'more fool you' rebuke that `ever closer union' is written into the Treaty of Rome, and that we should all have read the small print. No wonder `ordinary' people feel conspired against. What also causes deep offence to the multitude who doubt the wisdom of fur ther political union is the charge that they are being faint hearted or simply playing the little Englander. Rather, some say, the ones lacking moral fibre are those who can't face the challenge of standing apart from the single currency and fast-track convergence. Both points of view have more than their fair share of caricature but sadly there is little middle ground. What is certainly true is that for very many of those hostile to further integration, love of their country is a powerful impulse. It crosses class divides. That patriotism, scoffed at by the sophisticates, finds little outlet in Europe. Rather, too many Euro-initiatives seem insensitive to those idiosyncratic, familiar things which are so valued by 'the little battalions'. This strand of antipathy to Europe may be coalescing around the general countryside 'revolt', which is also bound up with the preservation of traditional and peculiarly English aspects of life (hunting or the WI, for example) which are felt - often wrongly - to be under threat from the EU, with its endless change and homogenisation. There may even be a developing sense of mismatch between it and faith communities which tend to be independent and conservative. There is in all this more than a touch of the old Reformation attitudes towards this modern Rome. Europe has also become part of the social exclusion problem in that the dynamic minority for whom it presents a real opportunity are, by their preoccupying involvement with Europe, likely to become even more detached from home problems which need their care if they are to have any prospect of resolution. That is undoubtedly exacerbated by the new capitalism and growing earnings divide. One must say, too, that for a government which consults at the drop of a hat, big European issues have been bizarrely ignored. The Tories were no better and the EU has been a remarkably ineffective populariser of its own affairs. Meanwhile, the problems of impersonality, uniformity and vaunting complication get ever worse. As one small indication, last week's Parliamentary 'EEC papers' itemise 103 publications for us to choose from. These do not include the gusher of EU laws, which last year took up 10 feet of shelf space. All this is inseparable from seeking to govern a continent of disparate countries. It is creating a world fit mainly for lawyers. Its bulimic regime encourages rejection via growing corruption (the invariable response to over-regulation), bureaucratic stasis and arbitrariness of implementation. All of this fuels yet more regulation. If there is a way of redeeming the present self-defeating disgrace, it must start with honesty within and across the political parties. Imaginative attempts must be made to give everyone, however unsophisticated, the chance to take part in what must become a great debate. That process should start now, properly and fairly financed, ending with a referendum after the next general election. It would do wonders for its efficacy if it was, like the 1975 one, cross-party, thus drawing in the huge majority who have no fixed political abode. Such a referendum could just about save the day, so that its result will be right, whichever way it goes. Lord Phillips of Sudbury is a solicitor and life peer.

fields.headline: Sarah's killer plays mind games
fields.trailText: The killer of schoolgirl Sarah Payne is believed to be playing a chilling game of cat and mouse with detectives, watching every move in their manhunt.  A psychological profiler has told detectives that the killer's decision to leave clues that point to his identity are the classic signs of a disturbed man eager to watch and try to outwit the investigators. The killer will be avidly following coverage of the case in the press and planning his next move.
fields.body:
The killer of schoolgirl Sarah Payne is believed to be playing a chilling game of cat and mouse with detectives, watching every move in their manhunt. A psychological profiler has told detectives that the killer's decision to leave clues that point to his identity are the classic signs of a disturbed man eager to watch and try to outwit the investigators. The killer will be avidly following coverage of the case in the press and planning his next move.

The theory - one of a number being investigated - is based on the discovery of Sarah's right shoe close to the village of Coolham, around five miles from the murder site, casually tossed into a roadside hedge from a car. No attempt had been made to hide it and it was clear that it would be found.

More clues were provided when police found eight-year-old Sarah's body dumped alongside the A29 near Pulborough nearly 20 days after she was last seen alive. Although it was partly covered and obscured from the roadside, little attempt had been made to ensure it would not be discovered by passers by. The two elements also point to the route taken by the killer on his way to or from the murder site. In contrast, extensive searches of the area have so far failed to turn up any more items of clothing. Her Fred Perry-style blue dress, other shoe and underwear are still missing. Scraps of material thought to be from Sarah's dress and the sole of a shoe have both been eliminated from police inquiries.

Sarah vanished on 1 July after playing `Dinosaurs' with her two brothers and younger sister near her grandparents' home in Kingston Gorse, Ferring, West Sussex. As the hunt for the killer enters its fourth week, Sussex police have brought in three psychologists in a bid to draw up a picture of the likely suspect. They are believed to have come up with a number of scenarios but all three conclude that the most likely candidate is a white male in his thirties with a history of sexual relationships with children. He is likely to have planned the crime for some time before carrying it out. He may even have made several visits to the field Sarah vanished from. The murder initially prompted a nationwide series of interviews with known sex offenders but a police spokesperson confirmed that the investigation is now being confined to a far smaller area of Sussex, prompting speculation that a local man is the killer.

Locals have been asked whether they spotted a white Transit-style van or any suspicious activity in the area between the A272, the A29 and the A24 up to a month before Sarah's disappearance. The van, which was spotted by several people as well as Sarah's 13-year-old brother, Luke, is believed to have had its rear doors altered. Police are visiting mechanics and vehicle workshops to see if the person responsible for the work can be found.

fields.headline: Human embryos to be cloned
fields.standfirst: Church fury over 'spare parts' research
fields.trailText: Scientists are to get the go-ahead to clone human embryos, raising the prospect of them growing 'spare parts' for ill or disabled people.
fields.body:
To the fury of religious groups, permission for the use of so-called 'Frankenstein technology', to be announced by Ministers in September, may ultimately mean that cells from embryos can be cloned and used to grow new tissue for medical use. Initially, however, scientists will be allowed to clone embryos only for research purposes.

The decision will allow British scientists to take a world lead in cloning research. By taking cells from the embryos, scientists will not only be able to grow new brain tissue to replace damaged material, but also new skin for grafts for burns' victims and ultimately new organs such as hearts, kidneys and livers.

Cloning would also allow people to have a 'tissue bank' to deal with any illness from lung disease to diabetes. Eventually whole limbs could be grown in laboratories. It will mean an end to waiting for donor organs, a situation that often ends in the death of patients.

Although the news will be greeted with delight by the scientific community, it will plunge the Government into a new battle with 'pro-family' groups and religious organisations who argue that using embryos is tantamount to sacrificing one human being's welfare for another.

'We are fundamentally opposed to any such development,' said Tom Horwood, spokesman for the Catholic Church. 'A human embryo is a human life. It is creating a human life for the purposes of cloning.'

Lord Alton, the pro-life peer, has described the technique as 'technological cannibalism'. But Richard Dawkins, the leading Oxford University biologist, said that any ethical attack on the research should be dismissed.

'The moral implications of using human embryos are rather less than those connected with using mammals and other species for scientific experiment,' he said. Cloning embryos is one of the most controversial scientific procedures. It was banned two years ago because Ministers feared a public backlash against scientists who were accused of 'playing God' with people's lives.

The technique involves taking cells from adults, creating an embryo and injecting it into a human egg donated by a woman.

Last year the Government asked the Chief Medical Officer, Professor Liam Donaldson, to investigate the issue. His report, sent to Ministers in May and yet to be published, is thought to back cloning with certain ethical safeguards.

Scientists will not, for example, be allowed to use cells taken from aborted human foetuses. The cloning of whole people will also remain banned.

Lord Sainsbury, the Science Minister with responsibility for the issue along with the Department of Health, announced the Government's decision in an unguarded comment yesterday.

In an interview, he said: 'The important benefits which can come from this research outweigh any other considerations one might have.'

Although he said it was 'a personal view', official sources admitted he was reflecting the Government's mood.

However, Sainsbury's comments have caused irritation in Government circles. Ministers wanted to publish the Donaldson inquiry first, to show that the science community backed their decision. Critics now say that the Donaldson report was merely a smokescreen to cover up the fact that the Government had already made a decision.

'Surely the Government should have published the report, allowed a debate and then come to a decision,' said John Smeaton, national director of the Society for the Protection of Unborn Children.

fields.headline: Sellafield faces prosecution
fields.trailText: The troubled Sellafield nuclear reprocessing plant is to be prosecuted by the Health and Safety Executive, it was disclosed last night.
fields.body:
The troubled Sellafield nuclear reprocessing plant is to be prosecuted by the Health and Safety Executive, it was disclosed last night.

A spokesman for British Nuclear Fuels (BNFL) revealed that the Cumbrian plant was to be prosecuted for allegedly failing to improve its management of sealed radioactive sources. The sealed source is a piece of equipment which safely contains a known and usually small quantity of radioactivity.

It is used to test and calibrate equipment which detects or measures radioactivity.

The sources are usually encased in metal or plastic. There are about 3,500 sources in 180 Sealed Source Stores on the Sellafield site.

The Nuclear Installations Inspectorate (NII) served a notice on BNFL in March demanding improvements to its management of sources.

But the NII alleges that the company has not done this, and BNFL has been summoned to appear before magistrates at Whitehaven in Cumbria on 24 August.

The Health and Safety Executive alleges that some of the sealed sources at Sellafield have gone missing, while others are not properly registered.

A BNFL spokesman said: 'We will consider the charges to be brought by the HSE and following appropriate legal advice will plead accordingly.'

There was also a high-level management shake-up at BNFL after a damning report by the NII which threw up serious concerns over the lack of a safety culture at the plant, following disclosures that some data had been falsified.

webTitle: Police to track mobile phone users

fields.headline: Police to track mobile phone users
fields.trailText: Police are to be given new powers to track people using satellite technology that can pick up signals emitted from mobile phones.
fields.body:
Police are to be given new powers to track people using satellite technology that can pick up signals emitted from mobile phones.

In a move denounced as sinister by civil liberties campaigners, software being fitted into the new generation of mobiles will enable police to pinpoint the exact whereabouts of a person whenever the phone is switched on.

But privacy campaigners fear the police could use the new phones as homing devices that will allow them to carry out mass surveillance without those targeted knowing about it One campaigner likened it to putting an `electronic tag' on large swathes of the population.

The Government and the police say the powers are needed to fight certain crimes, including drug trafficking. They believe the technology will guide paramedics and firefighters to the locations of emergencies.

These unprecedented powers are part of the Regulatory of Investigatory Powers Bill which received Royal Assent on Friday. They will allow the security services to intercept private emails.

Privacy campaigners and Opposition peers urged the Government to ensure that the read-outs of physical location produced by the new mobile phones should be made available only after a warrant is obtained from a judge. But the appeals were rebuffed. The police will be able to track somebody's movements on the authority of a police superintendent.

Caspar Bowden, who runs the Foundation for Information Policy Reseach, the internet policy think-tank which brought these concerns to light, last night expressed alarm over the move.

`Anyone using the new phones will be able to be tracked with pinpoint accuracy at the click of a mouse, for very broad purposes,' he said. `It's like putting an electronic tag on most of the population.'

John Wadham, of the civil liberties group Liberty, said: `This technology is of great concern, and the legislation is simply not keeping up with it. It is frightening what the police will be able to do without having to go before a judge. Under the Act, the only authority overseeing these capabilities will come from an Interception Commissioner, who does not have to be notified pro-actively of their use, or whether tracking data is passed between government departments once acquired.

Currently, police can obtain information about where a call was made from a specific mobile, if they can satisfy telephone operators there is sufficient evidence for their suspicions. Under the RIP Act, the authorities will be able to bypass the phone companies.

The mobile phone companies believe these new location facilities in their products will be hugely popular because they will allow users to find the nearest bank or Indian takeaway, and then get precise directions to the restaurant. The companies also believe it will give callers greater security knowing that the emergency services can track them down in a crisis.

A spokeswoman for Vodafone said: `It is true that under this new Act the police will not have to get our approval to access this information any more. But we believe the new software in the phones will bring many benefits to our customers and will be warmly welcomed.'

The National Criminal Intelligence Service denied that the new technology would mean the age of mass surveillance in this country . A spokeswoman said: `We will not speculate about how police will use technology that does not yet exist. But we will still be governed by Data Protection Act and believe the RIP bill has strengthened the rights of individuals, not weakened it.

fields.headline: Overdraft! What's that?
fields.standfirst: Ryanair chief Micheal O'Leary tells Natalie Sutton why he doesn't believe in borrowing
fields.trailText: Ryanair chief Micheal O'Leary tells Natalie Sutton why he doesn't believe in borrowing
fields.body:
Michael O'Leary, chief executive of Ryanair,owns 10 per cent of Europe's largest low-fares airline and applies the no-frills concept to his own personal finances, too.

And having just announced soaring company profits for the tenth year running, O'Leary has every reason to believe that his budgeting skills and financial strategies are successful.

The son of an Irish farmer, O'Leary was one of six children. He earned his first pocket money at 13 and, apart from a very short period of 'ducking and diving' after he graduated from Dublin's Trinity College, he has been a self-confessed workaholic ever since.

He got into the aviation business by accident: he was working as an accountant for the Ryan family. 'I couldn't get a real job,' he admits 'It just sort of fell out of the sky.'

Before he knew it, O'Leary had risen up the management ladder from financial director in 1990 to deputy chief executive in 1993. He is now worth just under £200 million.

O'Leary mirrors the Ryanair company policy in his personal finances, where the philosophy is: 'Make it first, then spend it.' The aim is to run the airline at a profit and then use the cash to buy more aircraft. There are no operating leases or hire-purchase deals on Ryanair planes.

Likewise, O'Leary shudders at the thought of borrowing money himself and has never had so much as an overdraft. He uses credit cards but only for ease, and the balance is always paid off immediately.

Online banking is something that doesn't appeal to him, although he rates the internet as a valuable tool for the travel business.

The Ryanair website, www.ryanair.com, is an important way of cutting out travel agents and their com missions,leading to lower flight costs for passengers. Currently up to 35 per cent of Ryanair's bookings are made via the internet.

With such strong capital behind him, O'Leary doesn't see the need for a pension. 'Anyway,' he says, 'I'll never stop. Better to wear away than to rust away.'

When asked about interests and hobbies, O'Leary looks surprised and says: 'Work, of course!'. Travelling? After all, he has quite a list of possibilities to choose from, given that Ryanair flies to 35 European destinations. 'Only on business,' he answers. Holidays? 'I like work - it's like a holiday.'

He concedes that owning a large farm in Ireland, where he rides horses and rears Angus cattle, is one of his few pleasurable pastimes but fast cars and gambling are not for him.

'I drive the tractors and the quads sometimes,' he offers hopefully. 'Oh, and I like antique furniture and paintings, but I don't spend too much on them. I haven't really got the time - I'm always working.'

O'Leary suspects that one of the secrets for his financial good health is the fact that, at 39, he is not married and, more importantly, he grins, 'not divorced'. 'I can't find the right one,' he says in despair.

It would be unfair to leave the impression that he is parsimonious or lacks spontaneity. When I cheekily asked him to sponsor a run for charity, he immediately offered a personal cheque for £100.

fields.headline: Not tired of London - but needing a life
fields.standfirst: High prices in the capital are forcing one couple to move out of town - despite making 50 per cent on their current property
fields.trailText: High prices in the capital are forcing one couple to move out of town - despite making 50 per cent on their current property.
fields.body:
Nick and Sam Noble moved into their two-bedroom flat in North London two-and-a-half years ago and have seen it rise in value by some 50 per cent to around £190,000.

Pleased as they are with this, they are worried that they cannot move into a larger property in the same area, as the prices of houses locally have risen even more, and supply is tight.

So they are now planning to move to Hertfordshire, which is convenient for Nick's job as a graphic designer for a software company, and that crucial bit cheaper. Nick first entered the housing market in 1984, made a killing on his first property, and then spent four years in negative equity with his second, bought in 1988, just ahead of the stock market crash.

His parents told him of their experience of the previous house price crises of the Seventies and he chose to sit tight. 'I just decided I had to weather the storm,' he says.

He hung on to the property he bought for £65,000 in 1988 until 1997, when he sold it for £85,000. During the worst of the crisis, it was worth just £52,000. His frustration now at the effect of rising prices is much greater than at the time of the crash.

He considers himself reasonably well paid but the rises of the last three years have made London houses unaffordable. 'It does not seem unreasonable to want a three-bedroom house,' he says.

fields.bodyText: Nick and Sam Noble moved into their two-bedroom flat in North London two-and-a-half years ago and have seen it rise in value by some 50 per cent to around £190,000. Pleased as they are with this, they are worried that they cannot move into a larger property in the same area, as the prices of houses locally have risen even more, and supply is tight. So they are now planning to move to Hertfordshire, which is convenient for Nick's job as a graphic designer for a software company, and that crucial bit cheaper. Nick first entered the housing market in 1984, made a killing on his first property, and then spent four years in negative equity with his second, bought in 1988, just ahead of the stock market crash. His parents told him of their experience of the previous house price crises of the Seventies and he chose to sit tight. 'I just decided I had to weather the storm,' he says. He hung on to the property he bought for £65,000 in 1988 until 1997, when he sold it for £85,000. During the worst of the crisis, it was worth just £52,000. His frustration now at the effect of rising prices is much greater than at the time of the crash. He considers himself reasonably well paid but the rises of the last three years have made London houses unaffordable. 'It does not seem unreasonable to want a three-bedroom house,' he says. webTitle: Heather Connon: Whitener for water plan that won't wash

fields.headline: Whitener for water plan that won't wash
fields.trailText: It looked generous. Kelda, formerly Yorkshire Water, planned to give all its pipes, reservoirs and pumping stations to its customers through a mutually owned company. What better reply to those who complained about fat cat directors?
fields.body:
It looked generous. Kelda, formerly Yorkshire Water, planned to give all its pipes, reservoirs and pumping stations to its customers through a mutually owned company. What better reply to those who complained about fat cat directors more concerned with pleasing shareholders than the public?

Unfortunately, the generosity applied only to Kelda's shareholders, and the company was finally forced to ditch the scheme.

It is easy to see why Kelda, like its fellow water companies, wants to restructure. For years, relatively loose regulation allowed the industry to raise prices, invest in improved water quality and keep paying generous dividends. Last year, that changed. The regulator ordered big price cuts and big hikes in capital spending.

Shares plunged. So did some dividends: Hyder slashed its payout from 50.4p to just 7p. Kelda held its dividend, and the City thinks that will go on. But its shares have lost a quarter of their value in a year.

Kelda wanted to get rid of the bit of the firm which was dragging them down: the water company. The £2 billion or so which the mutual would pay for this business would allow Kelda to make a generous one-off payment to shareholders. With no need to pay dividends, the mutual, could borrow money a full 1 per cent cheaper than the combined firm could. Everyone, Kelda thought, should be happy. In fact, almost everyone was unhappy. The regulator worried about who would take responsibility for water quality and supply if there was a drought. He feared that the mutual would not be independent of Kelda, and asked what was in it for customers, insisting that they be properly consulted.

Kelda's retreat, however, is, unlikely to be permanent. It is already planning to separate the regulated business from the rest, stopping short of hiving it off, to demonstrate that the structure can work. Its advisers are doubtless already working on ways round the objections, and the rest of the industry is examining similar schemes.

Anyone still holding water shares should sit tight. They are excessively low, and yields on the likes of Kelda, Thames and Severn Trent, where dividends are probably safe, are attractive.

Eventually, doubtless, some banker will come up with a whizzo scheme to satisfy the regulator, and that could spark a sharp re-rating of the shares.

fields.headline: Will they have to pay the piper?
fields.standfirst: The state will meet nursing fees... but personal care will come out of your own pocket, writes  Neasa MacErlean
fields.trailText: The state will meet nursing fees... but personal care will come out of your own pocket, writes Neasa MacErlean.
fields.body:
Last week's government announcement on the future of long-term care contained good news for some, but thousands of elderly people will be worse off as a result. The proposals pave the way for higher charges for those who receive some assistance in their own homes.

The good news is that an estimated 35,000 people in nursing homes will get state funding for the nursing care part of their fees. There will also be much greater emphasis on rehabilitation, with an extra £900 million to be spent on rehab by 2004.

'There will be real benefits here for someone who has broken a hip, for instance, and wants therapy and extra nursing care to restore their confidence and mobility after the operation,' says Tessa Harding of Help the Aged.

On nursing care costs, the Government estimates that people in nursing homes 'could save up to around £5,000 for a year's stay in a nursing home'.

A long-awaited paper published by the Department of Health last week, 'The NHS Plan - the Government's response to the Royal Commission on Long Term Care', states: 'There can be no justification for charging people in care homes for their nursing costs.'

It is establishing a principle that no one - whether in hospital, in a home or in their own home - should pay for nursing care.

The flipside is the Government's stance that people should pay for 'personal care' - the costs of providing meals on wheels, for instance, helping people get dressed or perhaps keeping a watchful eye on someone who suffers from dementia.

Ministers have rejected proposals from the Royal Commission that residents in homes have all their 'personal care' costs met.

It is another small but logical step for the Government to suggest that people receiving personal care at home should pay for this themselves. In fact, last week's announcement included the information that 'statutory guidance on home care charges' will be issued to local authorities by next April at the latest.

'There could be swings and roundabouts in this,' says Harding. 'You could find that those local authorities which currently do not charge very much for these services fall below what the Government recommends in its guidelines.'

Peter Gatenby of Age Concern Financial Partnerships says: 'At the moment, lots of local authorities charge, but they don't end up collecting the money. This move could mean more services are charged for by more authorities. They will be looking to charge commercial rates.'

Research conducted by the Audit Commission and published in May found that 94 per cent of councils charge for personal care. But charges for the same service - say helping someone get out of bed and have a bath - could vary from £5 a week in one area to £150 in another. Although the statutory guidance will make the charging procedures more consistent, it will not necessarily make them cheaper.

Campaigners for the elderly were astonished at the lack of further support for people in nursing and residential homes. The cost to the Government of paying the nursing care element could be as little as £30m a year - a tenth of the amount of money that is being put into developing banks in post offices, for instance.

Campaigners are puzzled that so little should be going to the elderly residents of homes at a time when the economy is buoyant enough for public expenditure to be increased by £43 billion in this month's comprehensive spending review.

Harry Cayton of the Alzheimer's Society was 'very disappointed' by the proposals and the 'narrow definition' which the Government plans to put on nursing care.

It is clear that nursing costs will include the payment of wages to registered nurses, the dispensing of drugs and the application of dressings. But the country's 700,000 dementia sufferers could find that little of their nursing home fees are deemed to be for nursing care. 'We will have to fight very hard on the definition of nursing care,' says Cayton.

Help the Aged will be writing to Ministers expressing 'devastating disappointment' over the plans, and the National Association of Citizens Advice Bureaux is to urge Ministers to increase the £15.45 weekly 'pocket money' which residents of homes are allowed. Members of the Royal Commission were last week said to be 'extremely upset' at the Government's response to their proposals.

There will be some other measures aimed at sugaring the pill, however. An estimated 30,000 people a year are predicted by the Department of Health to benefit from its plan to exclude the value of their home from the means-test calculation during their first three months in a nursing home. This part of the proposals is due to come into force in April.

Also starting in April is an increase in the 'upper capital limit' when people are assessed for financial assistance. At the moment you must pay all the fees for staying in a home if you have assets worth more than £16,000. This figure is to rise to 'more than £18,000'.

From October 2001, councils will be encouraged to give loans to people who do not want to sell their own family home immediately when they go into care. But this will provide just a temporary reprieve: at some stage their house will have to be sold.

In a further move, the Treasury is to consult this autumn on the desirability of regulating the sale of long-term care insurance plans - further tacit recognition that the Labour party now supports the growth of the private sector in funding the cost of long-term care.

 Copies of the proposals are available from the Department of Health, PO Box 777, London SE1 6XH, by fax on 01623 724524 or by email at doh@prolog.uk.com. The paper can be read on www.nhs.uk/nhsplan

fields.headline: On the market
fields.standfirst: Standard Life With Profits Bond
fields.trailText: Standard Life With Profits Bond
fields.body:
Contact 0845 606 0100 or your independent financial adviser

Aim To provide sustained capital growth which can be drawn as income if required.

Bells & whistles Standard Life believes the main attractions of its first with-profits bond are: mutuality, financial strength and flexible income options.

How it works A with-profits bond is a lump-sum investment into the with-profits fund of an insurance company. Returns are distributed as annual bonuses, which cannot be taken away once allocated to a policy, and a final bonus when your policy matures.

Minimum: £10,000, with £1,000 minimum for additional investments.

Charges: The allocation rate is 102 per cent, which means that a sum equivalent to 102 per cent of your money will be invested in the with-profits fund. The bid offer spread is 5 per cent. No early exit charges.

Tax: Returns earned by the with-profits fund are taxed at the basic rate. If you are a higher-rate taxpayer, you can make annual withdrawals of up to 5 per cent of your original capital, deferring further tax until the bond is completely encashed.

Risk: Low/medium

Should you invest? Ian Beestin of Nottingham discount broker The With Profits Bond Shop says the mutual has excellent with-profits performance: more than 12 per cent a year for the past five years. Patrick Connolly of Bath adviser Chartwell believes Standard Life may have scored an own goal with the low bonus rate. 'Standard Life says it doesn't want to give investors unrealistic expectations by setting a 7 or 8 per cent annual bonus upfront. That's very honourable, but investors do get sucked in by high bonuses. The insurer is almost being too honest!'

Points out of 10: Beestin - 8, Connolly - 7

fields.headline: Building society mistake adds years to mortgage
fields.standfirst: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.trailText: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers.
fields.body:
I have always paid at least the minimum required on my Woolwich repayment mortgage to ensure that the term is not exceeded. The original term is due to end in 16 years and nine months, but my annual statement shows that my mortgage will not be paid off for another 23 years and three months. I would have to pay an extra £69 a month to repay the loan in the original term.

I was stunned by this. I have telephoned and, apart from one letter of acknowledgement, am no further forward than I was in January.

Please help. I am at my wits' end with worry over this.
MB, Ringwood

Woolwich has finally realised that it made an error when calculating last year's repayments. At the time, the bank asked you to pay £63.40 less than it should have done, which extended the term of your mortgage.

When banks make this mistake, they pay compensation for the extra cost of repaying the loan within the original timescale and for inconvenience to you according to a formula based on the Banking Ombudsman's guidelines.

The upshot is you would have to pay an extra £390 to pay off the mortgage within the original time.

Because of the problems you have had getting a response, the Woolwich has increased the compensation to £650, which it is deducting from the capital you owe.

Hole in the wall: Glitch in cyberia

My husband died in January and the Alliance & Leicester said it would change our joint account to my name only. I could continue using my debit card but should destroy my husband's.

In March, I tried to withdraw money from my village cash machine but access was denied. The bank said my account had been accidentally closed down but all was now fine. And it was - until June, when I tried to use my card in my village supermarket and access was again denied. I teach in the local school and some of the parents work in the shop. It was full of customers who knew me.

You can imagine my distress and embarrassment. In my current account at the time, there was about £6,000 and my bill was for just over £10.

VH, Reading

Alliance & Leicester admits to making mistakes. You should have been able to use your old card until the bank issued a new one. This process started but the computer did not complete the changeover or send a new card by the time your old one became outdated.

You had been able to use it without difficulty elsewhere because your other purchases were below the shops' floor limits - the amounts above which authorisation must be sought - so they did not need authorisation. Your village shop must have had a nil floor limit for your £10 purchase to cause a problem.

It was unfortunate that you were told you could continue using your card after the first hiccup because that just extended the problem. Alliance & Leicester is sending you £50 as a goodwill gesture.

Cover quibble: Cat's breakfast

I had two cats who are covered by Royal & SunAlliance on an extension to my home insurance policy. Last September one of them, Tigger, had to be put to sleep.

Royal & SunAlliance met the claim promptly and I assumed it would adjust my premium. In March I noticed that I was still paying for both felines, so I notified the insurer.

Going through my bank statements in June, I could not see any refund, so I wrote again. Royal & SunAlliance said that I did not inform them about the death until March and then the refund of £12.66 was divided into three installments. I have never seen such a tortuous way of providing a small refund.
DTS, Norwich

Royal & SunAlliance says it collects the premiums for your house insurance in monthly installments. It gives refunds the same way by the administratively easy route of taking less under your direct debits.

As there were three months left on this year's policy, the six months' refund was paid back over April, May and June.

From March, the premiums were reduced as, Royal & SunAlliance admits, they should have been last September.

Pibs: Where do I find them?

I have permanent interest-bearing shares (Pibs) in Coventry, Leeds & Holbeck and the Birmingham Midshires (now Halifax). Despite searching diligently through the Financial Times , I have been unable to find any reference to their present values. Can you tell me when they appear? Do I have to go through a stockbroker to sell the shares?
WF, Worcester

Look in the Money supplement of the Saturday Financial Times . In the section headed Databank, under a dripping tap logo, you will see Pibs and perpetual subordinated bonds, which is what Pibs become when building societies demutualise.

Birmingham Midshires' Pibs are now one of the four Halifax perpetual subordinated bonds, the one showing a coupon of 9.37 per cent.

The Halifax has its own share-dealing service, but does not deal in Pibs or perpetual subordinated bonds. To sell, you need a more traditional stockbroker.

Family bonds: Unhappy returns

I have a number of 10-year family bonds with Family Assurance Friendly Society that are approaching maturity. Given the spectacular performance of the market over the last decade, these bonds have performed poorly.

Is there any possibility of friendly societies demutualising with the potential for windfalls?

If so, I would not cash them in on their tenth anniversary.

WMcG, Belfast

Nothing can prevent friendly societies from demutualising if the members vote for it.

They would no longer be friendly societies but convert into ordinary insurance companies and lose the right to sell tax-free savings products. There is no suggestion that this might happen at Family Assurance.

Friendly society policies are comparatively expensive because they deal only in small amounts of money. Family says that 10-year policies maturing this month are paying £1,661, a return of 8.22 per cent a year tax-free.

Remember that only the first £9 has been invested for the full 10 years; the final contribution is invested for just one month before being repaid. If you had put £1,080 as a lump sum 10 years ago at 8.22 per cent it would now be worth £2,380.

fields.headline: Cashpoints
fields.trailText: It pays to stay on track for higher Isa performance | BSkyB banking | Minding the gap
fields.body:
It pays to stay on track for higher Isa performance
Funds that track stock market indices dominate the top-10 league tables for the projected performance of Individual Savings Accounts compiled by Money Marketing magazine and the research firm Standard & Poors. Assuming a standard rate of growth of 7 per cent, and deducting managers' charges, the researchers calculated projected returns over various period up to 10 years.

For UK growth funds the top return over five years would come from M&G's Index Tracker, which would turn £3,000 into £4,124, assuming a growth rate of 7 per cent, followed by tracker funds from Scottish Widows, Royal & Sun Alliance, Legal & General and Dresdner RCM. Ten companies feature in the top 10 over one, three, five and 10 years, including Scottish Widows, Equitable Life, Legal & General, Dresdner RCM, Fidelity, Norwich Union, Marks & Spencer, Tesco and Direct Line. The M&G fund was top over one, three and 10 years. For European-invested funds, excluding the UK, M&G's Euro Index Tracker came top over all periods.

Results of actual performance produce dramatically different results, though there is no guarantee that these will be repeated. Over five years, the top fund was Solus UK Special Situations, turning £3,000 into £11,338. The worst was M&G UK Equity, returning £4,309.

Copies of the survey are available at £4.95 each from Money Marketing customer services, tel 020 7292 3730.

No guarantees
Equitable Life and its policyholders have begun to pick up the pieces from the insurer's failed battle to avoid paying guaranteed pensions on 100,000 pension policies. Equitable confirmed that policyholders who have with-profits investments will receive no investment growth from 1 January this year to 31 July in order to meet the £1.5 billion it expects to have to pay to honour the guarantees.

The insurer aims to recoup the lost growth through finding a buyer. Insurer Prudential confirmed last week that it is interested in the mutual, as did Abbey National.

Equitable hopes to announce in two weeks plans for compensating holders of its guaranteed policies who cashed in their funds before the House of Lords decision. Advisers are now looking at how to get them the best deal.

People with guaranteed annuities, where rates are up to 13 per cent of the value of their funds, may find that there are drawbacks with the policies, despite the Law Lords' judgment. Not all pay pensions to spouses on the death of the policyholder: Stuart Bayliss of Annuity Direct says these people may need to consider buying life insurance to pay a lump sum to their spouses.

Bayliss says that where spouses' pensions are not being paid, Equitable should do so, even if the pensions it agrees to pay to survivors are lower than the insurer would normally have paid. Some people may do better elsewhere, and Bayliss will ask Equitable to consider paying them a cash sum.

BSkyB banking
If you think that poring over your bank account may be more interesting than summer television programmes, it is time to swot up on television banking. Abbey National is launching what it claims is the most advanced e-banking service available through digital television. Users of the service can view balances, obtain online statements, move money between accounts, pay bills, change standing orders and request changes to overdraft facilities.

The service is available to subscribers to Open, the interactive television service on BSkyB. To obtain access, you need a set-top box and dish, which will cost around £40, according to Abbey, and there will be a monthly subscription fee to BSkyB, whose price will vary depending on the package.

Although the service is available only through BSkyB's Open service at present, Abbey has signed agreements with other digital television operators - NTL, Cable and Wireless, OnDigital and Telewest - and aims to expand access over the next 12 months.

Minding the gap
Gap year students planning to leave shortly for their backpacking trips are being offered special insurance deals.

Club Direct is offering a 10 per cent discount on its Discovery policy, which covers 12 months' travel, with an option to extend the period. The policy has £10 million of medical cover and includes cover for working abroad and for risky sports such as white water rafting and bungee jumping. The 'silver' version of the policy, which excludes baggage and cover for cash, costs £179.10 for a year's cover worldwide. The 'gold' version, which includes baggage and cash, costs £251.10. Tel 0800 074 4556.

Primary Direct offers £5 million of medical cover, £500 of cover for baggage and also covers a range of risky sports for £221.11 for a year. Tel 0870 444 3434.

Go as you like
Families who think this summer's holiday will be one of at least two over the next 12 months may benefit from taking out an annual policy.

Preferential Direct is offering multi-trip policies covering Europe at £65 for a family of two adults and two children. Tel 01702 423 393 or www.preferential.co.uk

webTitle: Wealthcheck: The nest's fine - the egg isn't

fields.headline: The nest's fine - the egg isn't
fields.standfirst: Helen Pridham on finding a cure for nurse Diane Kenny's ailing pension fund
fields.trailText: Helen Pridham on finding a cure for nurse Diane Kenny's ailing pension fund.
fields.body:
Age 48
Lives in Kendal
Occupation District nurse
Earns £21,000
Mortgage £34,000
Debts £3,000 car loan
Investments £4,000 in Tessa; £1,000 in building society account; savings plans
Pension Member of occupational scheme
Aims To plan for retirement

Diane Kenny is anxious to boost her pension as she knows time is running out. One of her regrets is that she didn't take her pension more seriously when she was younger. Although she paid into the NHS pension scheme when she first started nursing, she says she 'foolishly' took a refund of her contributions when she stopped work to have children. The money was not wasted - she and her husband used it as a deposit to buy a home - but it has left her with less of a pension .

After having her two children, Andrew, now 21, and Jane, 19, Diane returned to part-time nursing but did not start contributing to an NHS pension again until 10 years ago.

The family's finances have been stretched recently. Diane's husband Peter, 49, had to take ill-health retirement four years ago because he suffers from Parkinson's disease. He receives a modest pension but the past year, with both children at university, was difficult. Andrew graduated this year and is liv ing at home again while he looks for a permanent job. Jane has another three years of study. Although she has taken student loans, these cannot meet all her needs. Her parents pay her rent of £200 a month during term time, plus another £160 towards her keep.

Diane is not sure how long she can keep working as her husband's health is deteriorating; she feels she may have to give up her job by the time she is in her mid-fifties in order to look after him.

So she wants to boost her pension now and wonders if she should buy 'added years' or not. She explains: 'I have been told I can buy back four added years of superannuation at £187 a month.' This would boost her pension at age 55 from £5,064 a year plus a lump sum of £15,194, to £6,483 a year plus £19,541. She hopes she will be able to work until age 58, as this is when the couple's mortgage is due to be paid off.

On the savings front, Diane and Peter have £4,000 each in a Tessa, which is money from Peter's retirement lump sum. A further £1,000 was placed in another building society, account, which is coming up to maturity. Diane is considering using that money to top up the Tessas.

She also has £500 in an ordinary savings account with Bradford & Bingley. She has two savings policies with the Royal National Pension Fund for Nurses, for £20 a month each, and is also trying to pay £50 a month into a mini cash Isa, so she can help Jane pay off her student loans when she graduates.

Her £3,000 three-year car loan has two years to run. She has a credit card, but it is rarely used except at Christmas and for emergencies.

Adviser 1: Amanda Davidson

Added years would have the advantage of increasing Diane's pension within an extremely good scheme, that of the NHS. The attraction of any pension top-up (whether added years or investment) is that there is tax relief on payments, though there is a lack of flexibility on how the money is taken out.

However, buying added years in the NHS scheme is about as rock solid an additional pension as you can get. If Diane were to take an investment top-up scheme, on the other hand, the pension she would get would depend on its investment performance, which carries risk. Also, as a woman, she would get a worse annuity rate/eventual pension than a man of the same age , as she would be expected to live longer.

However, with added years, care needs to taken in case she needs to retire earlier than expected, as there may be some penalty. She should check what the position would be in this situation.

A tax-efficient alternative to a pension top-up is to invest in an Isa. Although there is no tax relief, there is flexibility on how the money can be taken out, and it will be tax-free. Diane could invest in an equity Isa. She could put £3,000 into a mini-equity Isa this tax year, but this stock market investment does carry risk.

 Amanda Davidson works for financial adviser Holden Meehan.

Adviser 2: Gillian Cardy

Diane is paying her mortgage at the standard variable rate of 7.29 per cent. She may wish to consider a remortgage. Nottingham Building Society has a fee-free discount mortgage, which would save her £42.50 a month in interest over five years.

She could invest these monthly savings into an equity Isa. The Leeds & Holbeck cash Isa is paying interest at 7.2 per cent but it is only paying 6.2 per cent on Tessa money. The Tessas could be transferred to a different provider. At maturity she could use the proceeds to fund low-risk equity Isas for growth, which could be switched to income funds for extra tax-free income.

She should not forget that she will qualify for a state pension at 62, and she should obtain a state pension forecast using form BR19. She should check whether she will receive a spouse's pension from Peter's scheme after his death.

She could discuss with her union whether she is one of the part-time workers benefiting from recent European Court rulings. She could consider the option of transferring out of the NHS pension scheme just before she retires. The transfer value will allow for the full value of a spouse's pension, and she may get a higher monthly pension.

 Gillian Cardy works for financial adviser Professional Partnerships.

Write, including daytime and evening telephone numbers, a brief list of circumstances and any investments, to: Wealthcheck, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, or e-mail: cash@observer.co.uk You must be prepared to be interviewed and photographed.

webTitle: Maria Scott: Axa fiasco makes orphans of consumers

fields.headline: Axa fiasco makes orphans of consumers
fields.trailText: Another week, another fiasco in the insurance industry. This time, the problem is Axa's scheme to distribute 'orphan assets' - surplus profits whose ownership is unclear.
fields.body:
Another week, another fiasco in the insurance industry. This time, the problem is Axa's scheme to distribute 'orphan assets' - surplus profits whose ownership is unclear.

The row revolves around the proportion of the assets built up over years being distributed to shareholders, versus the share going to policyholders. The Consumers' Association claims the policyholders are getting a raw deal - receiving, at best, 55 per cent of the £1.7 billion, and perhaps as little as 35 per cent.

But one of the difficulties is the complexity of the scheme; the CA cannot make a final estimate without more information.

Policyholders must choose between a one-off payment averaging £400 now - most will get less than £1,000 - plus a larger final bonus when their policies mature, or to forgo the one-off money in return for a possibly larger return in future.

But there are no guarantees, so the temptation will be to go for jam today, even if policyholders' share of the pot is too thin.

The CA is right to question the deal, even if only because it is too complicated for policyholders to assess for themselves. They have until 16 October to make up their minds, and should be in no rush to say yes.

The row underlines the shortcomings of the with-profits method of investment, where all the deci sions about how much profit is distributed are made by insurance company directors behind closed doors. This is fine in theory, but the execution is proving tortuous, and policyholders cannot judge whether they are being offered a good deal.

Often the misjudgment - or miserliness - of directors becomes clear too late for policyholders to put up a fight. In future, investors may judge that they would do better taking their chances with a direct investment in the stock market.

Halifax is contacting mortgage customers paying its standard rate - a sky-high 7.74 per cent - inviting them to switch to lower-cost loans. It is a laudable move in an industry that has got fat by allowing existing customers to subsidise the cheaper deals of new ones.

But if Halifax was serious about helping longstanding clients, it would simply cut its standard rate. It is revealing, perhaps, that only 10 per cent of those approached so far have swapped.

fields.headline: Chasing the house of the rising sum
fields.standfirst: Falling prices mean conditions are good for buying, right? If only it were that simple
fields.trailText: Falling prices mean conditions are good for buying, right? If only it were that simple.
fields.body:
If you are thinking of buying for the first time

For those who have been put off buying, particularly in the south of the country, by rising prices, now could be the time to move, according to the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors.

It would be tempting to put off buying for the moment in the belief that prices are going to fall month by month but if you believe the forecasters (always dangerous, but what else is there to go on?) prices are still expected to rise on an annual basis, albeit at a more sedate pace.

Cambridge Econometrics, an independent think-tank, believes that national house price inflation will fall from 12 per cent this year to 5 per cent next, putting it more or less in line with wage inflation.

No one has yet dared suggest that prices nationally are going to start falling on an annual basis, so putting off buying any longer could cost you. But the circumstances are such that you should proceed with caution. There is a risk of further monthly price falls in areas where affordability had got out of kilter, such as London, meaning that those people who take out 100 per cent mortgages could be in danger of the dreaded negative equity.

Obviously, if you have been renting, you may not have been able to save a deposit, but do not allow your desperation to get on the housing ladder lead you into the mistake made by so many in the late Eighties.

Another warning is that there are, according to some studies, areas where house prices have shot up so high that they are now bound to come down. Obviously, these should be treated with caution.

According to Experian, a consumer data and credit information company, these include some very attractive locations such as Maida Vale in London, St Agnes in Cornwall, York, Lyme Regis in Dorset, Ashford in Kent, Sheffield in Yorkshire, Chesham and Milton Keynes in Buckinghamshire, Reading in Berkshire and Staines in Surrey.

If you are thinking of buying to let

Despite the current downturn in prices, the attractions of buying a house or flat to let remain quite strong, particularly when annuity rates suggest that pensions alone may not see you through retirement.

Owning your own property means that you are in control of your own destiny; you can sell it to raise cash when you wish, you get a regular income and you will have something to leave to your children. The downside, of course, is that you have to look after the cursed thing, which can be expensive and time-consuming.

Not everyone is cut out to be a landlord. But if you have the stomach for it, it can be rewarding if you choose the right location to buy. There is still a great shortage of private rented accommodation and there are plenty of peo ple, including students and debt-saddled recent graduates, looking for a roof over their heads.

Although there has been talk of an over-supply of rental property, a report by estate agent Frank Knight suggests that some landlords sold during last year's rampant market, and that this pushed rents up 5 per cent in the capital, leaving space for new entrants as landlords.

A recent survey of 665 landlords by buy-to-let home loans specialist Paragon Mortgages found that the average landlord is enjoying a gross yield of 11.7 per cent, though the return after running costs is 6.7 per cent. It also found that 92 per cent of properties were let and the average period a property was empty per year was 27 days. The general advice to buy-to-let landlords is to expect one or two months a year without tenants.

If you are thinking of selling a property

You may well find that it is not quite as easy as it would have been six months ago. Estate agents report that properties are typically staying on the market for a lot longer, although they are not seeing the stagnation of the early to mid-Nineties.

The most difficult properties to sell are one-bedroom flats, whereas demand for family homes remains quite steady, estate agents say.

Ray Boulger, senior technical manager with John Charcol, the mortgage broker, says you should not have too much trouble if you ask a realistic price. 'People are now comparing what they are receiving with an idea of prices that were never really there anyway,' he said.

Good quality properties in pleasant areas will continue to sell reasonably quickly, he added, but it will be more difficult to sell property that is in bad condition and not in a great area.

In theory, those with property in a 'hot spot', such as parts of London and Edinburgh, could try to play the market by banking some of the gains and moving out to something cheaper in the provinces.

In practice, you could come unstuck if you want to move back into an expensive area in a few years' time, and find that big city prices have moved ahead once again.

Estate agents report that properties are typically staying on the market for a lot longer, although they are not seeing the stagnation of the early to mid-Nineties. The most difficult properties to sell are one-bedroom flats, whereas demand for family homes remains quite steady, estate agents say. Ray Boulger, senior technical manager with John Charcol, the mortgage broker, says you should not have too much trouble if you ask a realistic price. 'People are now comparing what they are receiving with an idea of prices that were never really there anyway,' he said. Good quality properties in pleasant areas will continue to sell reasonably quickly, he added, but it will be more difficult to sell property that is in bad condition and not in a great area. In theory, those with property in a 'hot spot', such as parts of London and Edinburgh, could try to play the market by banking some of the gains and moving out to something cheaper in the provinces. In practice, you could come unstuck if you want to move back into an expensive area in a few years' time, and find that big city prices have moved ahead once again.

fields.headline: All you need is the air that you breathe
fields.standfirst: New laws on enironmental pollution could cause a stink in the property market, writes  Neasa MacErlean
fields.trailText: New laws on enironmental pollution could cause a stink in the property market, writes Neasa MacErlean.
fields.body:
You probably suffer from it if you live in a city, close to a major road or anywhere else where there are fumes but little wind. Poor air quality is something millions of people put up with, often without knowing it. But a new website, Home check, is making it very easy to find out what the air quality is like for any given postcode. And the likelihood is that would-be homebuyers will start checking air quality and other environmental factors before they make an offer on a property.

You do not have to be one of the nation's 3.4 million asthmatics to be interested in local air quality. As well as telling you about the ozone layer in your area, the site gives readings on carbon dioxide levels, lead, benzene, butadiene, radon gas and other nasties in the air you breathe. The greater availability of all sorts of environmental information - from land contamination and the type of clay or rock your home is built on to the quality of the air - is going to have a profound effect on the way we view properties, according to the experts.

'The market is going to be in apoplexy - perhaps in a few months,' says surveyor Philip Wilborn, spokesman for the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors. 'We will see quite substantial changes in the values of some properties.'

Legislation came into force in April this year, requiring local authorities to identify polluted land and ensure that the land is cleaned up if it still poses a danger. The authorities have until next July to work out their strategies for implementing this particularly difficult part of the Envi ronment Act 1995. Different authorities will react in different ways. They have a fair amount of latitude in how they interpret the requirements of the Act, and in the way they implement them.

The worrying issue for Mrs Bloggs of Acacia Avenue is that she could be forced to pay for clean-up costs. While the Act works on the basis that the polluter pays for the clean-up costs, Mrs Bloggs will pay instead if the polluter has disappeared or if she has bought the property. Most local authorities will try to avoid this sort of controversial move - and, in fact, there will be government money available to help with decontamination costs. But some people could get stung.

Some pollution cases come to light simply because the pollution is so bad. Wilborn advised on a case where a woman started getting bad headaches and gradually realised that these often happened after she opened a ground-level cupboard in her kitchen. It turned out that her house and the rest of those on the estate were built on an old mine. The underground galleries had gradually filled with water and were now leaking gas with high levels of carbon dioxide. 'The mineshaft had to be capped and vented off,' says Wilborn. 'The valuers marked down the prices on those houses considerably.'

In other cases, the existence of contamination may be known by people who have lived in an area for a long time, but may not be spotted by others moving in. Devon and Cornwall have high levels of radon gas, according to Homecheck. Fixing this is fairly easy - a membrane over floor and basement areas - but costs can run into the thousands.

Many people will be surprised to find that their home is built on contaminated land. There are 400,000 disused industrial sites in England and Wales, and another 275,000 'infilled' waste sites, according to Landmark, another company which provides environmental information. Many estates have been built on the sites of old factories, gasworks and other buildings which may have left a nasty chemical legacy.

Local authorities, solicitors, surveyors and mortgage lenders are all starting to get to grips with the new requirements. 'This is something we will all have to face up to soon,' says John Mason, assistant general manager of the Ecology Building Society. 'This is an area where there could be a lot of buckpassing.'

Surveyors are now required in their valuations to take environmental issues into account. It could take the odd solicitor or surveyor to be sued for neglecting the environmental aspects of a home purchase to encourage other professionals to do their homework. The danger is that solicitors, with a lack of technical environmental expertise, could develop a kneejerk reaction and start warning buyers off properties that are actually sound.

Meanwhile, the issue is rising up the agenda for some businesses. At least one big property developer plans to start giving environmental reports on all its developments soon. And at least one local authority is being forced by a resident to use the powers in the Act to require a neighbour to clean up some contaminated land.

 www.homecheck.co.uk

Real world

Cowes, on the Isle of Wight, is regarded as the premier yachting centre in Britain and is home to the Royal Yacht Squadron. Cowes is split in two, East and West, situated each side of the River Medina.

Properties at the lower end of the market are one-bedroom converted or purpose-built flats costing £40,000 upwards. A glimpse of the Solent immediately raises the price. Four-bedroom penthouse apartments on the seafront and larger houses higher up the hill go for £300,000 or more.

Dream home
Complete with a single-kiln oast house, Little Catts Farmhouse is situated in five acres of beautiful Kentish pasture.

The Grade II listed farmhouse, which is in need of some work, is offered by G W Finn & Sons, Canterbury at £300,000. A further 32 acres of additional land is available for £100,000.

webTitle: Help - who decides whether my claim gets paid?

fields.headline: Help - who decides whether my claim gets paid?
fields.trailText: Not necessarily your insurance company, these days. Insurers, particularly travel specialists, are increasingly outsourcing the work traditionally done by in-house claims departments.
fields.body:
Not necessarily your insurance company, these days. Insurers, particularly travel specialists, are increasingly outsourcing the work traditionally done by in-house claims departments. The trend started some 10 years ago and has gathered momentum. A number of firms now offer claims-handling services, mainly for settling holiday insurance claims but increasingly covering motor and household cover, computers and white goods warranties.

Some insurers employ external claims handlers for one particular aspect of the job. Others pay claims administration companies to take over the entire role of insurers' own claims department. They deal with all aspects of claims with the full authority of the insurer - operating 24-hour call lines, rejecting or agreeing claims and sending out cheques.

Insurance companies which pay outsiders to handle their claims want the operation to work smoothly and accurately. Neil Harris, insurance director of Broker Direct, says: 'Most insurers are pretty searching when choosing a claims-administration company. There is competition in handling, so they have a choice.'

For holiday claims (where fraud is common), insurers want claims handlers to check all claims thoroughly before deciding. Some claims handlers employ overseas agents to check up on policyholders, perhaps making sure the theft was reported to police or that a receipt is genuine.

If you are not happy with the way a claims handler is dealing with your claim, or you disagree with the reasons for rejection, you can contact the insurer directly. Most insurer will be loth to second- guess the handler's decision, but the insurer still must respond.

Claims handlers are paid by the insurance companies under contract and want to keep insurers happy. One way could be to restrict amounts paid out in claims. But while insurers want to avoid paying invalid claims, they do not want to upset customers unnecessarily. A safeguard for policyholders is claims handlers' awareness that too many justifiable complaints mean the end of their contract.
