webTitle: Property: Prices come home to roost

fields.headline: Prices come home to roost
fields.standfirst: Sarah Cunningham  on the new reality as sanity returns to the property market
fields.trailText: Sarah Cunningham on the new reality as sanity returns to the property market.
fields.body:
Houses may only be piles of bricks and mortar and buying and selling them may be an expensive and tedious business, but vivid memories of the last great price crash at the beginning of the Nineties, when the term 'negative equity' entered common usage, mean that the housing market can inspire strong emotions in normally phlegmatic people. So how, given the news that the latest nationwide housing boom has come to a somewhat abrupt end, should we be feeling now?

If you have bought in the last 12 months, you have every right to feel a little cheesed off, as you may have assumed that your property would be worth some 15 per cent more in a year's time. If you have bought in London and some other parts of the country that had seen prices shooting higher, you may be doubly cheesed off by the realisation that your newly purchased property may actually be worth less than this time next year.

But if you are thinking of moving, and are already sitting on big gains on your current property, or if you are a prospective first-time buyer, then you should be greatly relieved that property prices have gone into decline or steadied across the country. It is also good news for those on a variable rate mortgage, as the chances of further rate rises diminish in a stable housing market.

Fears of a repeat of the 1989-90 debacle should not be given too much space to grow. Circumstances are now very different, and a 0.4 per cent month-on-month fall in prices, as reported by the Halifax in June, should not inspire fear or despair in even the most nervous houseowner. Now, unlike then, the economy as a whole is fairly sound. Moreover, in large parts of the country, particularly the North, prices are still rising.

Still, too much optimism would not be appropriate. It is normal for house prices to start to fall in London and the South and for the rest of the country to follow. And the national picture is that the slowdown is genuine if not dramatic. The Halifax's fall in June was the fourth in five months, and it takes the annual rate of house price inflation to 9.2 per cent, down from a peak of 16 per cent in January. By contrast, the Nationwide's most recent data showed that house prices actually rose 0.4 per cent in June to an average of £81,452, but that followed a 0.3 per cent decline in May, suggesting that prices are generally stable. Statistics, for July are due from Nationwide this week. The building society itself did not interpret the June rise as a sign of market buoyancy.

'We believe that house price inflation has been running at an unsustainable pace in the past year and it was natural and expected that some slowing would take place,' a spokesman for the Nationwide said. Both the Halifax and the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors have highlighted a slowdown in London as a key factor in the national steadying. The Royal Institution said last week that, for the three months to June, 'the slowdown in price inflation at national level disguises wide regional variations. In London prices actually declined for the first time since 1998.' Jeremy Leaf, who is spokesman for the RICS and runs an estate agent business in north London, said: 'In some cases people have had to take small cuts in price because there are no longer queues for each property.' All in all, he believes, 'it is a more balanced market.'

The slowing in pace of annual house price inflation is being painted as something of a triumph for sound management of the economy. Four interest rate rises between September last year and this February, plus the final abolition of Miras in April, all undoubtedly contributed to the situation. But equally important was that in some areas, particularly London and the South-east, house prices had simply got ridiculously, off-puttingly high. 'No one wants to be known as the person who bought at the top of the market,' one estate agent said. Even Madonna complained bitterly about London prices before shelling out £10.5 million on a four-storey property near Harrods in June, perilously close to the market peak.

While 'affordability' has remained at a reasonable level nationally, with the average house costing 3.6 times average earnings, close to the historical norm, in London, the ratio had reached 4.7 times in the first quarter. Although London is traditionally less affordable than the country as a whole, this was a historically high level and it meant that first-time buyers have been unable to purchase in the capital. Relatively few people have been willing to overstretch themselves with 100 per cent mortgages and borrowings from family. Unlike the late-1980s, there is no longer the faith that property prices will always rise when you want them to, there are far fewer tax benefits to buying, and, importantly, recent graduates are quite likely to be carrying several thousand pounds of debt.

One feature of the recent housing boom is that it has been very regional; some areas have not had price rises, while some have been on a par with central London. In Edinburgh's Georgian West End and New Town, for example, property prices have risen dramatically, fuelled to some extent by Londoners in the financial services industry moving north of the border. In nearby Glasgow prices have been far calmer. With London and the South-east now the fastest to slow down, the rest of the country has had a chance to do some catching up.

The latest RICS survey backs up reports from others, such as the Bradford & Bingley estate agents, in claiming that house sales are speeding up in the North of England while they are steady or falling in the South. The RICS survey found prices falling in London, a slowdown in the East Midlands, East Anglia, the South-east, South-west and North-west, and rises in Yorkshire, Humberside and the West Midlands.

In the next few months psychology will play as large a part in the development of house prices as supply and demand. Traditionally, many people put their houses on the market in the early autumn. Unless August brings a huge reversal in recent trends, those prospective buyers will be fully aware that prices are starting to come down. Estate agents are saying that sellers may have to take slightly lower offers to get moved before Christmas. If this scenario is played out, it should lead to further pressure on prices, but no rout.

As Martin Ellis, the Halifax's economist, puts it: 'Our view is that prices should steady. There has already been a bit of a correction, but the fundamentals are very different to the late Eighties and early Nineties. Unemployment is continuing to fall, interest rates are near their peak and affordability is near its average.'

And he reminds the faint-hearted of the advantages of investing in the housing market: 'Property tends to rise broadly in line with average earnings, which is 1.5 to 2 per cent above retail price inflation. That accumulates a nice little return over time.'

Buy to let - and let the profits roll in

Ashley and Jo Seager are about to add two more flats in London to their property portfolio. They first got into the buy-to-let business almost by accident, when they bought a flat in Shepherd's Bush in 1991, near the bottom of the market and at a time when they were expecting to return to London from working abroad. Instead they stayed overseas, and let the flat.

When they returned in 1996 they had small children and needed more space. So they bought a four-bedroom house in Herne Hill which needed a lot of work. But they also carried on letting the flat which, due to lower interest rates and a rise in rents over the previous few years, had become very profitable.

The value of their Herne Hill house has now more than doubled to £400,000-plus so they are remortgaging in order to raise the money to pay the deposits on two properties - one in North Dulwich and the other in Brixton - and are taking out buy-to-let mortgages on both. They prefer professional people as tenants so buying the right sort of property in the right sort of area is crucial.

Keeping the flats in good condition is also important and cuts the amount of time they are unlet to a minimum. Neither Ashley nor Jo minds the business side of dealing with tenants and they see the flats as excellent investments.

'They are good long-term investments and alternative pensions, and they are under our complete control,' said Ashley. With an eye firmly on the long-term, he is not concerned by what he sees as a 'correction' in prices.

fields.headline: Hold that e-photo memory
fields.standfirst:
US holidaymakers have film processed via the internet, says Jamie Doward. Now Kodak is joining in, and the boom is to focus on Britain
Special report: e-finance
Net news
fields.trailText: US holidaymakers have film processed via the internet, says Jamie Doward. Now Kodak is joining in, and the boom is to focus on Britain
fields.body:
If you have just returned from sunnier climes, the chances are that one of the first things you'll want to do is send off your holiday snaps for developing.

When you pick up the prints, you will then perform a ritual repeated up and down the land at this time of year. It goes as follows: step one: moan about how many of the photos are a) out of focus or b) have the 'red eye' effect, which makes everyone look like the living dead; step two: question whether taking 23 shots of the inside of your apartment was really necessary; step three: wish you had removed the lens cap on several occasions; and, step four: return to the store to obtain the few reprints you think are good enough to send to friends and family. A palaver.

But this post-holiday ritual may not last much longer. A raft of online 'e-photo' firms are competing via the internet to process your photographs, and save you time and money.

The e-photo industry which, inevitably, started life in the US, works like this. You send off your film in a freepost envelope obtained via the web or from a store. The e-photo company then scans the photos and emails you a web address where you can look at the snaps.

You choose the ones you want printed and email them to friends so that they can order their own copies. The company then posts the prints and the negatives.

Most firms in this field scan the films free, and charge only for the prints you order. There are various degrees of privacy, so users can if they wish bar other people from looking at their photographs.

And, because all the online technology allows for interactivity, you can do lots of clever things, such as compile albums of your snaps, choose different borders and captions and, in some cases, touch up the photos to get rid of, say, that annoying red eye. Customers can also have their snaps printed on to everything from T-shirts to mouse pads to mugs.

'This will be the biggest event in the photographic print industry since the launch of 35mm film,' said Ernie Gilburd of easyMemories.com, an e-photo firm soon to be launched in the UK.

Well Gilburd, who until recently headed Minit UK, the firm which owns SupaSnaps, would say that wouldn't he? However, he does join a long list of very big names who are betting on the same hunch.

In the US, Jim Clark, founder of Netscape, has backed Shutterfly.com, which is owned by internet investment giant CMGi; the sector's second-largest firm, ememories.com, is supported by the likes of Goldman Sachs, Disney and George Soros. Jim Barksdale, Netscape's former chief executive, is an investor in ofoto.com, the third-largest e-photo business.

Now the giant of film processors is interested. Last week Kodak, which in 1999 had sales of more than $14 billion and can't afford to see its market dominance threatened, took a stake in ememories to complement its earlier investment in snapfish.com.

In the UK Boots, which processes twice as many films as its nearest rival, will launch its own e -photo service, bootsphoto.com, within the next two weeks. Photo-Me International, the company behind the booths at train stations is also launching a service.

Evangelists for the new industry point to synergies between the internet and photography. 'This sort of service uses a real internet business model,' said Cameron Crockett, a founder of ideaShed, the internet incubator behind easyMemories. 'It's visual and it's light. It's easy for people to see and the service is available to everyone.' easyMemories claims its processing prices will be cheaper than in the high street. Crockett believes the business is adaptable to digitising and distributing both audio and video footage.

So how big is the e-photo industry going to be? Wildly conflicting estimates show just how immature this industry is. According to analysts at Infotrends Technology Group, sales of prints developed by online firms will be worth more than $2.5 billion in 2005, compared with $20 million last year. Lyra, the photography research firm, suggests that in Asia and the Pacific Rim e-photo services will be worth nearly $650m in 2002.

Crockett argues that the internet will expand the photography market. 'When APS technology [the new sort of film which makes it easier to index your prints] came out, the number of reprints as a percentage of sales went up. With these new e-photo services, in just three clicks everybody's got the index to your photos.'

Similarly, he believes that the rise in the number of digital cameras will not threaten the e-photo firms: they will still make their money from printing the snaps, even if they no longer have to process them.

In fact companies such as Zing.com, the market leader, are working with hardware partners to create digital cam eras with built-in modems which link directly to the web.

But the revenues generated by the e-photo firms tell only part of the story. One of their strengths is their sites' 'stickiness' - meaning they draw in visitors on a regular basis. This helps to build communities of internet users united around common interests, which in turn attract more visitors as the word spreads. And, where there are communities, there is the chance to sell them things, creating other earnings streams from e-commerce and advertising.

'It's the Hotmail model - uniting users around a common interest. It allows for viral marketing,' Crockett said.

According to technology market research firm PC Data Online, in April the top five e-photo websites in the US attracted nearly 7.5 million users - 10 per cent of the country's internet population. Infotrends says the figure for the whole year will total nearly 100 million.

For this reason the big portal sites have started offering their own online photo ser vices. America Online has its You've Got Pictures service in the US (although not in Europe at the moment), while Yahoo! has struck an alliance with Shutterfly.

One online community site, PhotoPoint.com, even went as far as to offer a fortune to the winner of its 'Million-Dollar Moment' competition, a move which generated huge publicity for the company in the US.

More public relations stunts are inevitable in the coming months as the e-photo companies - of which there are now scores - attempt to grab more market share.

Many of them are unlikely to survive. Lydia Loizides, an analyst with Jupiter Communications, was quoted in Upside Magazine, a technology publication, as saying that the sector is: 'fickle, promotion-intensive and can't make money'.

Crockett agrees that there will be some sort of a shake out. 'In the US there are a considerable number of players. It makes sense for there to be only a few [e-photo firms] in the long term,' he says.

Given the signs of an impending cull, some of the e-photo firms may not remain so snap-happy for long.

fields.headline: @large
fields.trailText: Breathe's hot air | Wake-up call
fields.body:
Breathe's hot air
Hot on the heels of Line One's suspension of its unmetered internet service - because the system couldn't cope with the demands - comes the shabby tale of the Breathe 500. Breathe.com (you must have seen those trendy ads) has banned 500 users from its unmetered service for the bonkers-on-stilts reason that they are using it too much. So now you know. Unmetered access is only unlimited if you, er, limit your use.

Wake-up call
Whatever happens in the Napster court case, it is to be hoped the presiding judge has a better understanding of the issues than was displayed by US District Judge Marilyn Hall Patel. On Wednesday, she slapped an injunction on Napster preventing it from distributing copyrighted music on its site, was apparently oblivious to the fact that the company was not the only one offering free music downloads. Things became so tense that Napster's lawyers complained Patel wasn't listening. Patel told them to take a seat.

May blossoms Here's a fascinating fact. UK mobile phone users sent 500 million text messages in May, compared with 50 million sent at the same time last year. Globally a whopping 8 billion text messages were sent during the month, according to the Mobile Data Association.

Bonus provider
Which should bode well for WAP - if it ever gets off the ground. The good news is that statistics suggest we are prepared to pay for services on our mobiles. The bad news is that a Computer Sciences Corporation survey found consumers were prepared to pay only an average monthly fee of £5-6 for WAP services. Not nearly enough to pay for Chris Gent's £10 million bonus.

webTitle: Is the Sillars volcano still active?

fields.headline: Is the Sillars volcano still active?
fields.standfirst: Arnold Kemp talks to the former MP whose influence in the SNP has yet to wane
fields.trailText: For a man who insists he has been out of front-line politics since 1992, a man who, indeed, says politics is an `absurd and childish' game, Jim Sillars still casts a large shadow over the SNP.  As the party prepares to elect a new leader to succeed Alex Salmond, there has been muttering from unidentified sources that his sudden resignation was a stratagem designed to crush the `Sillarsites' once and for all.
fields.body:
For a man who insists he has been out of front-line politics since 1992, a man who, indeed, says politics is an `absurd and childish' game, Jim Sillars still casts a large shadow over the SNP. As the party prepares to elect a new leader to succeed Alex Salmond, there has been muttering from unidentified sources that his sudden resignation was a stratagem designed to crush the `Sillarsites' once and for all. But Sillars himself scorns the idea that he is some sort of eminence grise, though he can see why some people may be spreading it around. As a `political volcano' he is extinct, not dormant, he insists.

Sillars' career has been an extraordinary obstacle race. He started as a talented young Labour MP, responded to the rise of nationalism by founding the short-lived Scottish Labour Party in 1975 and finally joined the SNP, winning the Govan by-election in 1987. Throughout this, Alex Neil, left-wing fundamentalist candidate for the leadership, has been a close companion.

Sillars married the seasoned SNP campaigner Margo MacDonald in 1981. In the Scottish Parliament his wife has increasingly run foul of the leadership with her complaints that the party is in danger of submerging its core aims as it acts as the opposition to the ruling Labour and Lib Dem coalition.

Speaking in his London office last week - he is assistant to the secretary-general of the Arab-British Chamber of Commerce - he told The Observer that party leaders couldn't have it both ways. It was, he recalled, Mike Russell, the party's former chief executive and now its manager of parliamentary business, who had called him an `extinct volcano' in the first place. He said there `seems to be some degree of contradiction' with the idea that he was a sinister influence in the background.

The `Sillarsite' tag had been hung around Neil's neck to discredit his bid for the leadership, he believes: `I seem to be a bogeyman for some of them.' Neil is expected to take on John Swinney in a straight fight at the party conference in September, but Sillars denies that his friendship had influenced Neil. `He is a mature individual. He has very considerable international business experience. He has formed his own opinions. `He and I share the same philosophy. We come from the Ayrshire labour movement; that's where our roots are. Alex is the son of a miner, I'm the son of a railwayman.' Sillars makes `no bones' about using his column in the Scottish Sun to influence opinion.

When Salmond announced he was stepping down from the leadership after 10 years, Sillars used the column to dismiss him as `manipulative to the end'. He said: `I don't share the general mythology of Alex's leadership. I don't share it at all. I've seen it from inside and outside.' There was a whole range of policies `enunciated' by Salmond which in fact never occurred, he said. Salmond had softened the party's attitude to devolution and could have extracted much more from Labour. Sillars himself abstained in the devolution referendum because the Parliament, he judged, had insufficient powers. His criticism of Salmond's policies extends to his style Ð or the lack of it. He had been disturbed by leaks in the press that Salmond and his followers wanted to `crush' the Sillarsites and `silence them forever'. `This makes the blood run cold in a democratic society,' he said. `There's an authoritarian streak that's part of the legacy of Alex Salmond's leadership.' He thought Salmond would continue to exercise influence, but added: `He's history, like me.' Sillars believes that Westminster, with its long experience of dealing with quasi-colonial situations, had sucked the SNP into the devolution settlement. Instead of being critical of the Scottish Parliament, the SNP had been seduced into happily sitting on committees and drafting speeches. If at some point in the future the SNP grew restive, Westminster would concede a little more, while retaining control of the real levers of power. If Sillars were running SNP policy he would run that `incremental' technique in reverse. He would keep trying to win a little more power. `I have never believed the orthodox view that Scotland's public finances are in structural deficit. Gordon Brown himself has said that the oil revenues have been wasted'. In his view, the next general election had to be fought with the purpose of expanding the core nationalist vote and, as a fallback, on the platform of increasing the powers of the Scottish Parliament. Sillars, who regards England as a `friendly foreign country' where he happens to earn his living, said one of the most urgent problems facing Scotland was its alienated underclass, treated not as victims but as culprits. They were, he said, part of what Thatcherism produced. `I think that Scottish society has a better chance of dealing with them because there's an egalitarianism and still a very significant social conscience.' According to Sillars, they had found a champion in Tommy Sheridan, MSP. Sillars believed his Scottish Socialist Party posed a threat both to Labour and the SNP. He said: `I'm very fond of Tommy as an individual. I went through the poll tax with him. People shouldn't underestimate the genuine anger that fuels Tommy Sheridan and the people who are joining his party.' But the problem for Tommy `and for me', said Sillars, was that Sheridan was part of a broad socialist movement which was at a low `theoretical and intellectual ebb'. Is he a threat to the SNP? `Of course he is. We haven't given him enough reasons to join.' Sillars has often despaired of the political mission he has embraced. Once he said it was like pushing water uphill. At another time, he said the Scots were `90-minute patriots', meaning their nationalism lasted about as long as the football games into which they used to vent so many of their feelings. Does he still believe it? Sillars looks a little sad. `Yes,' he said, `except that now that rugby's the game, I suppose you can make that 80 minutes.'

fields.headline: Media diary
fields.trailText: The curious silence of Rebekah Wade | Gender-ation game
fields.body:
Silence of the damned
Hats off to top Press Gazette press reporter Jean Morgan for getting News of the World editor Rebekah Wade to break her 'naming and shaming' silence. A front-page piece on the affair laden with quotes from Wade describing how she had taken the decision on her own, how she doesn't want readers to take vigilante action, blah blah blah, was all very instructive. Odd then, and a quirk of deadlines with which we sympathise, that the Press Gazette lambasts Wade in its leader column for keeping schtum, under the banner headline 'The curious silence of Rebekah Wade'. Curiouser and curiouser.

Breaking w_what?
The newly launched and curiously named Breakingviews.com - a website for City types who want to know what to think about deals, lost no time last week in establishing its credentials as an independent arbiter of opinion. Rumour has it that a shareholder in the new venture is City PR supremo Roland Rudd, an old friend of Breakingviews founder and former FT journalist Hugo Dixon and the head of successful financial PR agency Finsbury. Could be compromising? Apparently not, as Breakingviews somewhat boldly opined on Friday morning that Carlton Communications was the 'big loser' in the ITV ownership shake-up, forlornly sitting on the sidelines until it is snapped up by Granada. A harsh judgment some might say. And Carlton's financial PR agency? Why Finsbury, of course.

Gender-ation game
With the Guardian Edinburgh International TV Festival looming, it is a fitting time to reflect on the deeds of C4 boss Michael Jackson in the past 12 months. Careful readers of Media Diary will remember that Mr Jackson, who deserves some kind of civic award for screening the incomparably brilliant Big Brother, became the 'Good Samaritan' after seeking to deter 'just one viewer' from an auto-erotic asphyxiation death by screening a sensitive documentary on the last hours of rock star Michael Hutchence.

So, we ask ourselves, how is the Good Samaritan's report card looking a year on? Pretty awesome: in the past 12 months Channel 4 has done its bit to stop just one viewer from a) marrying David Beckham (Victoria's Secrets), b) spending the day as a vapid spokesmodel (Being Caprice) and c) becoming a child star and starving to death (Lena Zavaroni documentary).

Now it has another new crusade: C4 has commissioned a programme in which six people swap genders for 'at least three weeks', to find out what it's like to be on the other side of the gender divide. Apparently after the gender-swap team have undergone 'deportment' lessons and pyschological counselling, they will be expected to return to their jobs or 'try to find new ones'! The programme will no doubt be called 'Big Brother/ Sister, Whatever', and one hopes the Good Samaritan will be finding work in the C4 building for any of the unemployable gender benders.

Pretty awesome: in the past 12 months Channel 4 has done its bit to stop just one viewer from a) marrying David Beckham (Victoria's Secrets), b) spending the day as a vapid spokesmodel (Being Caprice) and c) becoming a child star and starving to death (Lena Zavaroni documentary). Now it has another new crusade: C4 has commissioned a programme in which six people swap genders for 'at least three weeks', to find out what it's like to be on the other side of the gender divide. Apparently after the gender-swap team have undergone 'deportment' lessons and pyschological counselling, they will be expected to return to their jobs or 'try to find new ones'! The programme will no doubt be called 'Big Brother/ Sister, Whatever', and one hopes the Good Samaritan will be finding work in the C4 building for any of the unemployable gender benders.

webTitle: The slow but inevitable death of the ministry of self-loathing

fields.headline: The slow but inevitable death of the ministry of self-loathing
fields.trailText: The DTI is a department in search of a vocation. Its officials are in the paradoxical position of being in a ministry whose purpose they cordially dislike.
fields.body:
The DTI is a department in search of a vocation. Its officials are in the paradoxical position of being in a ministry whose purpose they cordially dislike.

Few believe in state intervention, public enterprise, institution-building or any form of government support unless it has gone through the prism of competition - the endless parade of challenge funds. Nor do they believe in an active trade policy. Rather, they see their role as persuading the Secretary of State not to do anything proactive, for fear it might upset the proclivities of the market.

So their salaries are paid on the supposition that there is a job of work to be done by the Department of Trade and Industry, but they devote their lives to undermining this. It is the department of self-loathing.

This is partly the loss of self-confidence in the role of government that is one of the defining characteristics of the age. Britain may have industrialised behind steep tariffs and tough trade protection, as the US, Germany, France and Germany did, but this is not part of the tapestry of current belief. The dynamic component of contemporary society is business and the private sector - and it flourishes best when left well alone.

The DTI needs little convincing. It can point to few success stories of British intervention, and plenty of disasters. Its view of native British enterprise is so despairing that the only policy or subsidy with which it feels comfortable is inward investment; millions more have been lavished on this than would ever have been spent on any British company.

Three Labour Secretaries of State for Trade and Industry have perched uneasily in the DTI's offices and tried to find a rationale for the department that fits with Labour's aims, the department's prejudices and those of the world beyond. Margaret Beckett tried to initi ate some genuine corporate and financial reform, notably championing the minimum wage and setting in train the long overdue reform of company law - but at heart she didn't trust British business and it didn't trust her. Her shortlived successor, Peter Mandelson, produced a promising paper on the knowledge economy and had a genuine feel for how the new currents in the economy might be fostered, but he was almost too pro-business. And Stephen Byers has survived, but so far left little trace.

One vignette describes his problem. At the Labour party conference last September he launched the idea of a Knowledge Bank to support fledgling knowledge companies with business mentoring and customised bank loans.

However, the Treasury didn't like it any more than the DTI did. Officials felt public initiative might take away the incentive of the private sector to solve the evident market failure - the ultimate argument for never doing anything. Finally, nine months later, a consultation paper has been released, but with no mention of the Knowledge Bank. It has been quietly and effectively killed.

But if not a Knowledge Bank, what? It could be the champion of the notion of the just enterprise and the network economy. It could be a hothouse of scientific and technological ideas. It could be the standard-bearer for patient finance and a culture of business-building. It could foster new British clusters of excellence. It could develop new elite business schools and a new professional managerial class. Instead, it sets out to stifle anything constructive for fear it might fail or be portrayed as interventionist. With no friends on the Left or Right and unable to develop a mission, its abolition is inevitable. Sad.

 Will Hutton is chief executive of the Industrial Society

webTitle: Astounding: A bank that tries to keep customers

fields.headline: Astounding: A bank that tries to keep customers
fields.trailText: It has taken a while, but financial services companies are finally realising their best customers are the ones they have got. Two years ago, so many of Halifax's customers were defecting that a 15 per cent share of new mortgages turned into a 3 per cent fall in loans when redemptions were included. Now, its share of new loans is a little higher but its success in reducing remortgaging means it took 12 per cent of net lending in the first half of 2000.
fields.body:
It has taken a while, but financial services companies are finally realising their best customers are the ones they have got. Two years ago, so many of Halifax's customers were defecting that a 15 per cent share of new mortgages turned into a 3 per cent fall in loans when redemptions were included. Now, its share of new loans is a little higher but its success in reducing remortgaging means it took 12 per cent of net lending in the first half of 2000.

Its formula is simple: it asks its customers if they would like a better deal. So far, it has asked 500,000 of them and 10 per cent have taken up the offer. The upside is Halifax keeps the customer - and has opportunities to sell more products while the new deal is being arranged. The downside is it makes less profit from the mortgage.

In the first half, there was virtually no impact on margins but chief executive James Crosby warns they will shrink by about 5 per cent in the full year, and 10 per cent next. He is confident margins will not fall further. Others are less confident. Last week's figures from Egg suggest it is finding growth a little harder to come by than expected but, even so, the internet will inevitably decrease margins and increase customer mobility.

The winners will be the companies that anticipate that and acting accordingly. Halifax's internet bank launch may have been delayed but its plans sound a bit more structured than those of some rivals. Crosby sounds more confident than he has for years. The shares discount too much bad news and should be bought.

ICI transformed
ICI is a changed company, says chief executive Brendan O'Neill. The problem is, the City has failed to appreciate its transformation. If it had, it would no longer be concerned about its £2.9 billion of net debt - £1bn more than the assets on its balance sheet.

It would be happy its interest bill now takes up only about a quarter of its profits and that proportion has been falling steadily for more than a year.

The City would also appreciate that, while profits from old ICI could fluctuate by billions from the top to the bottom of the cycle, at new ICI the difference between a good and a bad year will be far less pronounced. But he failed to give any hints as to whether investors should also now accept that the group's dividend policy be consigned to its imperial past. The interim payout was maintained at 12.5p but that represents 40 per cent of the total for the year. It will not give a hint on future payments until it announces full year results next February.

O'Neill should bite the bullet and cut it to a more realistic level. Earnings have been more than twice the level of dividends in only one of the last seven years and, on current forecasts, it will be at least 2003 before they reach that level again. Cutting it now would not only allow the group to start growing its payout again, it would also free resources to invest elsewhere in the business.

O'Neill's problem has been that the City could have interpreted a cut in previous years as a distress signal, a sign that he was not confident the transformation from indus trial chemicals monolith to a customer-focused business that happens to use some bulk chemicals as its raw material would be a success.

That should no longer be an issue. Last week's interim results show sales are moving decisively upwards; in all its core divisions margins are improving and there is a new confidence about the group. There are still a few hangovers in the form of old-ICI businesses still to be sold. But these are increasingly irrelevant. O'Neill has proved he can transform the group. He should now transform its dividends.

The right fit
BAAN, the Dutch software group, must be pretty special. Invensys, the industrial controls group buying it, has put up with a revolt from one group of shareholders, complaints about tax from another, rumblings from the unions - and is obliged to pay out €100m to avoid collapse. But will the deal be worth the heartache?

Allen Yurko, Invensys' chief executive, is confident it will be. The fit between the two groups is perfect. Invensys supplies much of the standard automation equipment on most factory floors. Baan provides the software that helps companies tailor products to customer ordering. Put them together and you can offer state-of-the-art manufacturing systems to blue-chip customers as diverse as Boeing and AT&T.

The theory is sound but will it work? Baan's poor condition when Invensys made its offer makes it even harder to judge than usual. Invensys is no doubt right that Baan's problems are not because of its products but its financial management. It expanded too far, too fast and failed to cut costs when orders dipped last year. But Baan has been financially unstable for more than two years and the longer that continues, the more likely operations will be affected. There are signs of that happening: Baan's share of the business software market is down from 10 per cent to 4 per cent in two years.

Yurko has talked to its top 10 customers, believes they have been deferring orders and is confident they will come back once financial stability has been achieved. He may be right. But there is also a risk they will be tempted away to rivals such as Oracle - which will not have been slow to take advantage of Baan's problems. And how motivated will Baan's workforce have been to keep developing innovative products?

At least Invensys is not betting the company. The cost, including debt taken on, is less than £550m. It will spend a further £260m on restructuring, but believes that will produce savings of £160m a year by 2002. It is promising at least 10 per cent return on sales by the same date, with further increases thereafter.

If that is achieved, the deal will look a reasonable one - and any synergy benefits from getting new customers for its existing business will be icing on the cake. The problems could turn out to be worse than expected and the €100m cash injection last week may mark the start, not the end, of the rescue package. Yurko says he has done more due diligence on this than any other deal in a decade with the group. His record is good enough for shareholders to trust his instincts.

webTitle: ITN needs scoops if it's to beat the 24-hour troupe

fields.headline: ITN needs scoops if it's to beat the 24-hour troupe
fields.trailText: Dumbing down the news, part two. Apparently, a Russian TV station has taken to hiring nude presenters for its news bulletins in order to halt a ratings slide. Since this information comes from the impeccably researched news pages of the Daily Star, its veracity cannot be in doubt. The honourable tradition of half-naked Norwegian weather girls and the much-lamented News Bunny - bequeathed to us by Kelvin Mackenzie when he ran the cable channel L!ve TV - is now burrowing its way into the newly liberated culture of Eastern Europe. For this, the Berlin Wall came down.
fields.body:
Dumbing down the news, part two. Apparently, a Russian TV station has taken to hiring nude presenters for its news bulletins in order to halt a ratings slide. Since this information comes from the impeccably researched news pages of the Daily Star, its veracity cannot be in doubt. The honourable tradition of half-naked Norwegian weather girls and the much-lamented News Bunny - bequeathed to us by Kelvin Mackenzie when he ran the cable channel L!ve TV - is now burrowing its way into the newly liberated culture of Eastern Europe. For this, the Berlin Wall came down.

If the Russians think they have a ratings problem, spare a thought for our own 24-hour news channels. While Sky News, BBC News 24 and CNN barely register on the BARB Richter scale (respectively 0.4 per cent, 0.1 per cent and 0.1 per cent of audience share according to ITC figures), they will be joined on Tuesday by a fourth 24-hour news service from ITN. ITN's boast is that, while its rivals have book reviews, chat shows and other time-filling distractions, its own service will be news, all the news and nothing but news (I paraphrase, but that's the gist).

Given that the marketplace in news channels is not so much crowded as seriously uncomfortable for sardines, two questions about the ITN enterprise come to mind. First, why do it? CNN was first into the field, made lots of mistakes, but established itself as world leader. Sky pioneered the British version as Murdoch's placatory loss-leader to Margaret Thatcher, but Sky News is generally regarded as doing a fair job.

The BBC simply could not afford to let it go: you can't expect to remain the most authoritative source of news in a multi-channel world if you don't have a 24-hour news presence (even if two-thirds of homes aren't interested in the TV revolution). For the BBC not to have a 24-hour news channel would be like not having Radio 4.

But ITN? It might share the BBC's reputation for trust and impartiality but, as with FA Cup Finals and Royal Weddings, it will always come a poor ratings second when going head to head with the nation's public broadcaster. Ultimately I suspect that ITN is there simply because its rivals are, and is seriously worried about being able to sustain its heavyweight reputation without a 24-hour presence.

This gives a clue about resolving a second question: how are these channels going to make their mark, given that audience size and profitability are unlikely to be the main criteria for success? How will they stand out from the crowd?

For CNN in the UK this is a largely redundant question, although its history offers some interesting pointers to establishing a reputation: this was less to do with dogged journalism and more with a combination of sheer cunning and opportunism.

According to last week's Broadcast magazine, CNN's famous 'scoop' of the Challenger space shuttle breaking up was actually NASA material distributed by CNN. And its equally famous 'exclusive' of the first live coverage of the Gulf War was actually audio with still pictures.

Its reputation of being 'first with the news' relies heavily on international contacts and international partners.

For the BBC, there is simply the brand. Any time a big story breaks, the BBC is still the first port of call, and this model of audience behaviour will apply as much to 24-hour news channels as to terrestrial bulletins.

Sky News has established something of a following since it was the first British operation into the field, and its brand has not yet been 'contaminated' (pace Philip Gould) by its connection with the Murdoch empire. What ís left for ITN?

The answer might be some real investment in good old-fashioned investigative journalism. It would be expensive, it would need commitment and promotion as well as a pool of dedicated journalists with time to dig around for stories. But a 24-hour channel that breaks stories would be a genuine contribution to diversity.

There was a good example of this on Radio 4's PM programme 10 days ago. It led its bulletin on an exclusive story about the UK's role as the centre of a trafficking scheme which involved Nigerian women being sold for sex. On the day that every other bulletin was leading on Prescott's transport spending plans and the discovery of a shoe in the Sarah Payne murder case, PM came up with its own exclusive and gave it plenty of air time.

If ITN's service is given the resources to break new ground with original and first-rate journalism (just as it did in 1955 when it challenged the BBC news monopoly) it could enhance its own reputation as well as making a real contribution to an informed democracy. Alternatively, it could go down the Russian route and ask Sir Trevor to get his kit off.

S.Barnett@wmin.ac.uk

fields.headline: Stockwatch
fields.trailText: 365 Corporation | Geest | Weeks Group
fields.body:
365 and counting
The dramatic slump in the value of internet stocks has prompted analysts to start saying that some online companies may now be undervalued. Nevertheless, when the likes of mighty Amazon continue to slide, the prospect of bargain-hunting will seem daunting to some investors.

Nevertheless, those with an appetite for risk may want to look at the debris that is now the dotcom sector.

Take 365 Corporation, the online content provider with sports and music sites. Its share price now stands at a paltry 65p, barely above its year low of 62p. The company is valued at a fraction under £120 million; before the crash, it was worth more than £300m.

Yet 365, which distributes its content via web, telephone, email, television and mobile phones, produced relatively strong preliminary results, beating analysts' expectations. Like every other dotcom, 365 failed to make a profit in the 12 months to March, but turnover totalled nearly £22.5m. For this financial year, analysts predict turnover to rise to about £50m.

In addition, the company has £50m in its coffers, which goes some way to assuaging anxieties about its cash burn rate. Given the consolidation in the sector, 365 is a potential bid target. After all, Sports Internet, which had 1.5 million users, was sold to BSkyB in May for nearly £300m.

Saucy Geest
Geest has gone from strength to strength since selling its banana business in 1996. The Anglo-Irish company has moved into the chilled convenience food market with aplomb, cleaning up with prepared foods, salads, sauces and pizzas.

These account for 95 per cent of Geest's profits and three-quarters of its sales. The group has grown by 22 per cent a year in the past five years, and should gain from Marks & Spencer and Waitrose rationalising suppliers.

The UK food manufacturing sector has been underwhelming. Geest has set its sights on continental Europe, beginning with strategic purchases in France and the Low Countries. Ready-made meals and sauces are set to grow more popular across the Channel, say analysts at CSFB, as the British trend for one-person households and declining cooking ability spreads to Europe.

Analysts at CSFB upped their price target from 525p to 600p. Geest now stands at 494p and does not look like slipping up.

Weeks' strength
An estimated £17 billion will pour into the UK construction sector over the next three years, thanks to Gordon Brown's £43bn Comprehensive Spending Review announcement 12 days ago.

Only the major-league companies are likely to pick up significant orders from the anticipated building boom, but a few quoted engineering consultancies are likely to score more work from this bonanza.

Chief among them is Weeks Group, a small AIM-listed engineering consultancy which has positioned itself smartly to exploit an increased workload.

Weeks operates at the support service and intelligence end of the industry. It employs 400 people in the UK in two divisions: consultancy and laboratories. The consultancy division specialises in work that takes place before major projects begin.

In the past year, Weeks has expanded into London's West End and the housing sector; it has also started a pavement engineering business and beefed up its subsidence unit.

All this made the firm's pre-tax profits dip by 8 per cent last year to £613,000. But first-quarter figures suggest Weeks' turnover should top £17m this time - £2m better than its last full-time figures

Broker Seymour Pierce believes Weeks' prospects make its current share price of 4p 'look very inexpensive indeed...' We agree. Buy.

Its share price now stands at a paltry 65p, barely above its year low of 62p. The company is valued at a fraction under £120 million; before the crash, it was worth more than £300m. Yet 365, which distributes its content via web, telephone, email, television and mobile phones, produced relatively strong preliminary results, beating analysts' expectations. Like every other dotcom, 365 failed to make a profit in the 12 months to March, but turnover totalled nearly £22.5m. For this financial year, analysts predict turnover to rise to about £50m. In addition, the company has £50m in its coffers, which goes some way to assuaging anxieties about its cash burn rate. Given the consolidation in the sector, 365 is a potential bid target. After all, Sports Internet, which had 1.5 million users, was sold to BSkyB in May for nearly £300m. Saucy Geest Geest has gone from strength to strength since selling its banana business in 1996. The Anglo-Irish company has moved into the chilled convenience food market with aplomb, cleaning up with prepared foods, salads, sauces and pizzas. These account for 95 per cent of Geest's profits and three-quarters of its sales. The group has grown by 22 per cent a year in the past five years, and should gain from Marks & Spencer and Waitrose rationalising suppliers. The UK food manufacturing sector has been underwhelming. Geest has set its sights on continental Europe, beginning with strategic purchases in France and the Low Countries. Weeks' strength An estimated £17 billion will pour into the UK construction sector over the next three years, thanks to Gordon Brown's £43bn Comprehensive Spending Review announcement 12 days ago. Only the major-league companies are likely to pick up significant orders from the anticipated building boom, but a few quoted engineering consultancies are likely to score more work from this bonanza. Chief among them is Weeks Group, a small AIM-listed engineering consultancy which has positioned itself smartly to exploit an increased workload. All this made the firm's pre-tax profits dip by 8 per cent last year to £613,000. But first-quarter figures suggest Weeks' turnover should top £17m this time - £2m better than its last full-time figures Broker Seymour Pierce believes Weeks' prospects make its current share price of 4p 'look very inexpensive indeed...' We agree. Buy.

webTitle: MPs to probe Corus role in steel crisis

fields.headline: MPs to probe Corus role in steel crisis
fields.trailText: Anglo-Dutch steel giant Corus is facing an inquiry by a committee of MPs into its role in the steel industry crisis which has seen it announce almost 4,000 redundancies in the past month.
fields.body:
Anglo-Dutch steel giant Corus is facing an inquiry by a committee of MPs into its role in the steel industry crisis which has seen it announce almost 4,000 redundancies in the past month.

The Commons Trade and Industry Select Committee will grill Corus executives and unions in the autumn.

In the past two months Corus has announced three waves of redundancies: 1,200 at its Rotherham and Sheffield engineering steel operations; 1,200 at its Scunthorpe and Teesside works; and 1,300 at Port Talbot and Llanwern in South Wales.

It has consistently blamed the pound's strength against the euro for putting it at a competitive disadvantage.

But last week the select committee chairman Martin O'Neill accused Corus - formed last year from British Steel and Dutch manufacturer Hoogovens - of merging in order to close UK plants and take production overseas.

'I think we ought to question the motives of the company,' O'Neill said.

Unions are concerned that there may be further job losses, particularly at Llanwern, where Corus is deciding on whether to invest £35 million in relining a blast furnace. Its decision is expected next month. Welsh Secretary Paul Murphy and Rhodri Morgan, Wales's First Secretary, are both understood to be putting Corus under pressure to make the investment.

Both the Iron and Steel Trades Confederation and the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union say the remaining 2,500 jobs at Llanwern are dependent on this. They also say there will be knock-on effects from Llanwern on other Welsh plants.

Corus joint chief executive John Bryant is due to meet ISTC general secretary Michael Leahy on 16 August, and union officials are hoping for a decision by then.

The ISTC has been asked to prepare a memo for the committee following a letter it sent on 21 July, when the Llanwern and Port Talbot redundancies were announced.

Leahy told The Observer last week: 'Now at last we can see what Corus's intentions are. Until now it has been very difficult for anyone to know whether they plan to invest in the UK or whether they intend to do so in Poland and mainland Europe.'

webTitle: The holiday king who sent Cook's packing

fields.headline: The holiday king who sent Cook's packing
fields.standfirst: Joanna Walters  meets Michael Frenzel, high-flying chief of Germany's Preussag , whose purchase of Thomson should give him the biggest deckchair in the industry
fields.trailText: Joanna Walters meets Michael Frenzel, high-flying chief of Germany's Preussag , whose purchase of Thomson should give him the biggest deckchair in the industry
fields.body:
Dr Michael Frenzel escaped from communist East Germany when he was nine years old, hiding on a train with his father.

He now stands poised to become the global king of package holidays, the epitome of capitalist consumerism for the masses.

Where would he have ended up had he stayed behind the Iron Curtain? 'I just cannot imagine. But I know life would have been very different,' he told The Observer last week.

Frenzel jetted off on holiday last Friday having just received the stamp of approval from Brussels for his German leisure group Preussag to take over the company that has been at the top of the British holiday business for 25 years, Thomson Travel, for £1.8 billion.

The 53-year-old has a reputation for enjoying the finer things in life, dressing sharply and whizzing around in his company jet. Surely he is not taking one of his own package holidays?

'Of course!' he said, full of mock indignation.

That'll be two weeks in Benidorm then, beating the Brits to the sunbeds at dawn?

Not quite. Frenzel, his wife Gabi and their three children are off to Crete to one of Preussag's Robinson Clubs - a very upmarket sort of resort/holiday camp with the best beaches, diving and golfing Greece can offer.

Exclusive, but a package holiday none the less. And he is flying squashed in with the plebs on one of the ordinary charter jets operated by his company's airline Hapag Lloyd.

He intends to spend the next few weeks splashing around, strolling on the golf links and 'relaxing with a glass of wine' to celebrate his coup.

Back in May, Preussag was the heavyweight that pounced at the eleventh hour and snatched Thomson from the clutches of Germany's second largest travel company, C&N Touristic.

Observers had not fully expected the move because Preussag already owned the best-known travel brand in the world - Britain's Thomas Cook - and had promised to turn it into the UK's market leader ahead of Thomson and Airtours in a few years' time.

But when it came to the crunch, Thomson was irresistible. Frenzel and two of his closest associates held a boardroom huddle and made the decision to ditch Thomas Cook for Thomson.

Preussag went on a share-buying frenzy, persuaded the original Canadian Thomson family shareholders to sell up and trumped C&N to the purchase.

The newly combined Preussag-Thomson will become the biggest package holiday company in the world, overtaking Britain's Airtours, which was built from scratch by home-grown Lancashire entrepreneur David Crossland.

There has been much gloating in the German press, invoking the sort of 'landing on the beaches' clichés that some Brits and Germans never seem to tire of.

Frenzel said: 'There is no reason for [the British] to feel defeated. Quite the opposite. What we are creating with Thomson is the biggest [holiday] company in the world, with huge potential. The customers will immediately feel a positive effect.'

Frenzel, born in Leipzig, has come a long way since he boarded a train in East Germany in 1956 and ended up in the Federal Republic.

He recalls: 'My mother had already travelled west with my two sisters when the border was still open for visiting.

'I went with my father in a battered old Opel. We abandoned the car in Potsdam, took the subway to Berlin and went through to the west side by train. We went as visitors but then stayed. It was not legal but, because the wall had not gone up, it was possible.'

They flew to Hanover 'and that was the beginning of my career in the west'.

The nine-year-old Michael thought the whole thing a huge adventure. He mostly remembers his first encounter with the image of Mickey Mouse and being taken to a proper cinema to watch the film of Jules Verne's 20,000 Leagues Under the Sea .

The Frenzels settled down in the west and Michael studied law at Ruhr University in Bochum, near Dortmund. He became a scientific assistant at the university, where he completed his doctorate.

But he never became a lawyer or a scientist - perhaps realising that power and wealth were best pursued in the world of business and finance.

He joined Westdeutsche Landesbank (WestLB) in Düsseldorf in 1981 and got a taste for industry when he managed the industrial equities department two years later.

WestLB is a 33 per cent shareholder of Preussag, and when Frenzel jumped from banking to business the company was a heavy industrial conglomerate covering everything from mining and shipbuilding to engineering - but nothing as fluffy as a package holiday.

The transformation in the six years since Frenzel became chairman has been staggering. In a high-risk move he ditched the stodgy industrial interests and turned it entirely into a leisure giant.

The Thomson move has set Preussag on the road to world domination in the land of sun, sea and sand, although the deal has left some Thomas Cook people very disappointed. Frenzel reportedly failed to warn his Cook's colleagues he was going to jilt them for Thomson until the deal was virtually done.

One travel industry source said: 'There was a lot of trust between Thomas Cook and Preussag. Frenzel said he was going to build Cook's into market leader. That would have taken two or three years, of course, but he seemed very committed, and when he sprung the Thomson deal people did feel betrayed.'

Others attest to the size of his ego in the context of the ferocious competitiveness between Preussag and C&N.

Sources now say that senior Thomas Cook executives selflessly advised Frenzel in February, when the Thomson share price was down around 70p, that if he wanted to be 'biggest and best' he should ditch Cook's and snap up Thomson.

Frenzel reportedly shunned the idea, only to return to the fray when C&N began to woo Thomson, eventually offering 160p a share. He denied this version of events last week, but did not sound convincing.

One former Thomson executive said: 'Preussag is paying a lot for the business. It is unlikely to generate sufficient cashflow to justify that kind of expenditure. This deal was as much about stopping their major rivals from doing it as the deal itself.'

The ex-executive did concede, however, that Frenzel's handling of the transformation of Preussag and its holiday brand Tui had been impressive and Frenzel was 'chic and charismatic'.

He is certainly in a much more glamourous business with holidays than a state-owned bank or steelmaker, and that seems to suit him.

Frenzel has often been seen as the heir apparent to the chairman of WestLB, Fiedel Neuber, who retires in the next year or two. Neuber groomed the budding Frenzel as his protégé.

But Frenzel dismissed this idea last week. 'That is a very old rumour and the truth is completely the opposite. It is the biggest challenge for me to build up the leading travel company in the world. My place is here in Hanover.'

Title: Chairman of Preussag

Date of birth: 2 March 1947

Other directorships: Axa insurance group; Deutsche Bahn Railways

Hobbies: Golf, diving, sailing

fields.headline: Item Club slams Brown's review
fields.trailText: Chancellor Gordon Brown will be sharply attacked tomorrow in a report from a respected forecaster that uses the same economic model as the Treasury.
fields.body:
Chancellor Gordon Brown will be sharply attacked tomorrow in a report from a respected forecaster that uses the same economic model as the Treasury.

The summer forecast from the Ernst & Young Item Club will assert that tax increases and a slowdown in growth next year will be inevitable consequences of the Chancellor's Spending Review.

It will issue a 'stealth warning' that 'yet more tax hikes' are likely as a means of countering the inflationary impact of increased public sector spending.

The Item Club's forecast uses language that is overtly political compared with the sober tone of many economic analyses.

It refers to 'Gordon's cunning public relations plan' and speaks of the British economy looking 'increasingly backward' in the face of Germany's newly won tax-cutting credentials.

The report predicts problems from attempting to pour money into services starved of funds for some time.

'Previous stop-go episodes have shown that you cannot get value for money if you run your procurement policy like a concertina,' it says.

Growth is predicted to fall from 3.1 to 2.6 per cent next year with a further drop to 2.1 per cent in 2002.

The figures differ from the bullish predictions of the National Institute for Eco nomic and Social Research, released last Friday, which forecast growth of 3.6 per cent next year.

The National Institute said that interest rates may have to rise by half of one per cent to dampen the inflationary stimulus of the extra public spending.

The Item Club commentary assumes that the Government will use fiscal policy to head off inflationary fears rather than give the Bank of England Monetary Policy Committee any reason to increase interest rates.

The MPC meets on Wednesday to set interest rates. The decision on whether to make a change is expected to be close.

webTitle: A minuet instead of a Virginia reel

fields.headline: A minuet instead of a Virginia reel
fields.trailText: The American economy is at it again. Friday's GDP figures showed a growth rate of 5.2 per cent, which was a nasty shock for ol' Alan Greenspan, Head of the Fed, who had been expecting far slower rates of growth.
fields.body:
The American economy is at it again. Friday's GDP figures showed a growth rate of 5.2 per cent, which was a nasty shock for ol' Alan Greenspan, Head of the Fed, who had been expecting far slower rates of growth.

Indeed prior to Friday's figures there was every expectation that the US was cruising to a perfect soft landing. Instead it has seen its strongest four quarters of consecutive growth for 17 years and, far from having the brakes on, the whole economy continues to emulate the runaway train. She's gone over the hill and we're now just waiting for her to blow.

The trade deficit is alarmingly large, the great American public is collectively barely saving a cent, and the spend cycle continues unabated. Add into this what would still appear to be a hideous overvaluation of the stock market and the economic miracle still bears all the hallmarks of being an unsustainable conjuring trick.

As Greenspan is effectively driving the economy, but doesn't yet seem to have worked out how to stop it, there is just as much reason as ever to be afraid - in fact, to be very afraid. It seems inevitable now that interest rates must rise further, maybe even quite sharply, which will leave the markets holding their breath and losing their points.

And what more poignant moment for this to be happening than on the eve of convention season?

With George Bush Junior looking alarmingly like a potential winner, despite having picked some variant of Attila the Hun as his running mate, the whole thing takes on the feeling of déjà vu. For here we could have George Junior picking up the shovel and clearing away the inevitable mess created by the ordure-fan interface brought about by this potent economic brew.

Well, if he needs any advice on how to sweep up after the Lord Mayor's show he should ask his dad, who did exactly the same job after the Reaganomics party came to an inevitable end.

The warning signs in the US economy continue to mirror those seen in Japan 10 years ago and, while it is tempting to comfort oneself with the view that the 'new economy' has truly worked a miracle, the more persistent and nagging voice is that of JK Galbraith with his unswerving and almost undoubtedly correct view that 'there are no new paradigms'.

George Junior already has some fairly strange ideas about how to conduct the fiscal wellbeing of the nation. Take, for instance, the remarkably strange idea that state pension money should be put on the stock market, as that seems a pretty good place to invest your money. Up to a point, Lord Copper, as they say.

This inevitably affects our own economic outlook because, in economic issues as in politics, our destiny seems more closely bound to the US than elsewhere. Just as surely as Reagan followed Thatcher and Blair followed Clinton, so our market and economy tags along behind the US. We already have a high exposure to financial services and a stock market which closely mirrors the US.

Granted, we don't hear quite as much enthusiasm from government benches as we used to for recreating the American experience in our own back yard. The babbling about the desirability of emulating their high-growth, low-inflation, full-employment model by giving everyone a free computer has somewhat abated.

But if we are choosing our dancing partners on the global stage we would do better to abandon the US during the gentlemen's Excuse Me and waltz to the other end of the ballroom to polka with the eurozone countries.

Their currency may be weak and our criteria not yet fully convergent, but seeking shelter from the storm in an economic alliance which may prove more robust in the face of a crash in the US could be a canny move.

And expediency, if nothing else, is as strong an argument for joining the euro as anything one is likely to find in a leaked Tony Blair memo.

emily.bell@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Byers gears up for mission improbable

fields.headline: Byers gears up for mission improbable
fields.standfirst: After an annus horribilis, the Department of Trade and Industry is heading for a relaunch.  Oliver Morgan reports
fields.trailText: After an annus horribilis, the Department of Trade and Industry is heading for a relaunch. Oliver Morgan reports
fields.body:
Being the Secretary of State for Trade and Industry can seem rather like being the Prince of Wales. It is often seen as a job en route to greater things. The challenge is to be useful while not creating a mess or being damaged by events.

But the current incumbent has had an annus horribilis. Faced with Rover and Ford crashes, a steel meltdown, unravelling textiles, sinking shipbuilding, manufacturing pounded by sterling, coal in the pits, Stephen Byers has been hopping from one crisis summit to another.

Armed with sums paltry by other departmental standards (the flagship DTI regional selective assistance budget for industry is £120 million) he has tried to stem disgruntlement in Labour's industrial heartlands while avoiding the charge of returning to picking winners and supporting lame ducks.

This week, however, Byers wants to relaunch the DTI as an organisation with a mission rather than one battered by events. Sceptics will return to Nicholas Ridley's famous remark: 'What is this place for?'

Digby Jones, director-general of the CBI, says: 'The biggest task of the DTI is to be a champion of business across government and to ensure that the impact of regulations is at the front of people's minds when they draw them up.'

Peter Robinson of the Institute for Public Policy Research says: 'The DTI has several core competencies - ensuring effective competition and regulation, preventing market failure in product markets, striking the right balance in Labour markets, and spending on science.'

In all these core areas, Labour has acted - bringing in the Competition Act to stamp on anti-competitive practices, rebalancing power in labour markets through the minimum wage and working time regulations, and boosting the science budget.

But according to officials, Byers wants to argue that there is more to the DTI than overseeing competition and regulation policy and cutting red tape - a natural instinct for a politician with a public profile to think about.

The DTI can have an active industrial policy without going back to the Sixties and Seventies by stimulating the 'new', knowledge-based economy while trying to help old industries take greater advantage of its fruits.

It will be a difficult trick to pull off: there is deep suspicion of bureaucratic intervention in markets and in business.

Jones says: 'It is not the role of the DTI to pick winners and losers. We need a strengthening of productivity, so that our traded goods and services become more competitive.

'Those industries that have been in decline for many years, if they are not at the value-added end of production, will face problems. The inevitable will happen - commoditised production will go off to other economies with cheaper labour, and they will not compete.'

But he concedes that there is a role. 'The DTI must focus on assisting industries which are interfacing with the value end of the economy.'

The challenge is huge, and slippery. First, assessing where Britain's strengths and weaknesses lie is difficult. Second, it seems there are too many weaknesses. Third, and perhaps most difficult of all, is working out whether and how to help.

Measuring Britain's competitive position has been a key priority for the DTI since Margaret Beckett took over in May 1997. In its November 1997 document, 'A Benchmark for Business', the DTI found the UK struggling. It pointed to GDP per head below OECD average, a productivity gap with the US of 20 per cent and with France and Germany of 25 to 30 per cent, and investment gaps at similar levels.

Focusing on the 'knowledge economy' paints a no less challenging picture. Despite talk of Britain leading the way in areas such as biotechnology and aerospace, OECD statistics comparing Britain with its competitors present a different picture.

On one level, Britain has been doing well. It is sixth in the OECD league table in spending on information and communications technology (ICT), channelling 8 per cent of GDP into IT hardware, software/services and telecoms.

The UK has among the highest inward investment in research facilities from global players such as Microsoft, and the third-highest number of graduates entering science and engineering as a proportion of the labour force.

However, the OECD figures show some more worrying trends. The UK's research and development spending as a proportion of GDP has fallen dramatically - from 2.4 per cent in the early Eighties to 1.9 per cent in 1997. Ît is now below the EU average - although, as in the US, this is partly caused by a fall in defence spending. Business's spending on R&D and innovation is not good - it stands below the OECD average in total, and has been shrinking since 1990.

The effect on UK trade is intriguing. One OECD indicator attempts to calculate the technology trade balance, and finds the UK in deficit by about 0.1 per cent of GDP, while countries such as Switzerland, Sweden, the US, Japan and Holland have positive balances.

OECD research economist Michael Freudenberg says: 'One thing you could say - hesitantly - is that the UK exports fewer high-quality, high-technology goods than it imports.'

Another table shows that the UK is below both OECD and EU average in terms of the price and quality of goods that it exports.

The report states: 'High quality _ depends on R&D expenditure, labour qualification, specific organisation of the procedures of firms.' The implication is that the UK is reaping a thin harvest from past underinvestment.

Clearly the DTI's task of forging a strong position in the new economy is huge.

The OECD itself has specific suggestions. It says vigorous competition is needed to keep ICT costs down, to encourage new entrants and greater productivity. It advocates flexible labour markets, funding of science, more effective conversion of research into commercial ideas, and policy support for R&D and venture capital.

It also suggests investment in 'human capital' - encouraging immigration of highly skilled people to counter brain-drain effects. It also recommends the use of share options in start-up companies to promote entrpreneurialism.

Paul Geroski of the London Business School says: 'You have to be careful not to create white elephants such as the Sinclair C5, but the DTI can be useful in forging relationships between science and industry.

'It can do this by strengthening venturing and venture capital. And it should not forget that one of the biggest buyers of knowledge-based products is the Government. It's no mistake that advances in IT grow up around procurement by government agencies such as the US Department of Defence.'

Some of the OECD suggestions may have a familiar ring to them. The Government has announced a sharp increase in the science budget, from £1.6bn this year to £2.2bn in 2003/4, and last week's science White Paper acknowledged the challenge of getting ideas from universities to companies.

Labour has set up tax incentives for corporate venturing and regional venture capital funds. It has also widened availability of share options to small company employees, encouraged investment by altering capital gains tax regulations, and promoted R&D tax credits. And last week, there were suggestions of a relaxation of immigration policies for the highly skilled.

The Government has pursued increased competition in ICT, perhaps not as quickly as elsewhere, but pressure to open up BT monopoly 'local loop' services has grown. Since free internet service providers (ISPs) such as Freeserve have emerged, Oftel, the telecommunications watchdog, claims the UK has among the world's lowest internet connection costs.

But this leads to another problem for the DTI: much of its advice has already found its way into policy. Unless there is some truly radical thinking, Byers is unlikely to be able to relaunch his DTI around revolutionary new policies.

A downside for Byers is that much of the thunder in all of this has been stolen by Gordon Brown. But then many of the reforms involved have been of the tax system.

But Brown has been roaming in DTI territory - earlier this year, for example he demanded that BT open its local loop more quickly than planned.

The final problem is that all of these good works have been eclipsed by the crisis in Labour-voting 'old economy' sectors. Byers needs to promote British success in the future economy while not abandoning the politically vital manufacturing past.

TUC chief economist David Coates meets the prospect of talk on the 'new economy' with a groan. He points back to productivity and investment gaps and says it is as important to find ways to close these in traditional sectors to ensure their future as it is to concentrate on new-economy companies.

The DTI has, he believes, a role in 'helping industry through difficulties, enabling employers and unions to respond by increasing productivity and raising skills levels'.

The CBI's Jones does not seem to disagree with that. He believes the DTI should help either through direct financial assistance or by the creation of incentives or, perhaps most importantly, through training, to help companies that have a future.

The acid test for intervention, he says, is whether industries, old or new, are working their way towards producing higher-quality, higher-value goods.

This however, could be said to smack of picking winners for the future. The IPPR's Robinson has qualms: 'Talk of promoting the new economy sounds ominously like support for "infant industries" which George Brown and Harold Wilson used to talk about.'

But perhaps this is being over-churlish, particularly to a politician trying to expunge memories of an annus horribilis this year in time for a general election next.
