fields.headline: Builders must master craft
fields.standfirst: Labour is relying on construction firms. Can they deliver, asks  Nick Mathiason
fields.trailText: Labour is relying on construction firms. Can they deliver, asks Nick Mathiason
fields.body:
Everyone knows that plumbers, chippies, sparks and bricklayers rub each other up the wrong way; that subcontractors hate contractors for relentlessly squeezing their margins; and that contractors reckon architects are not on the same planet. Yet everyone working in construction is united about one thing: customers never know what they want.

You hear about construction companies only when they are involved in projects that go hopelessly over budget, badly wrong or when they raise environmental or ethical concerns.

But in the hands of this maligned sector lies Prime Minister Tony Blair's dream of a twenty-first century Britain where new homes, schools, hospitals and transport systems spring from the £43 billion windfall that was announced in Chancellor Gordon Brown's Comprehensive Spending Review 12 days ago.

Judging from the financial market's reaction to Brown's statement, construction com panies, which traditionally have been shunned by investors worried about low margins and high risk, are set for a renaissance.

Shares in Amec, one of the leading rail contractors, have risen in value by nearly 20 per cent since Brown's statement. Those in Balfour Beatty, Britain's biggest contractor, have risen by more than 10 per cent since 18 July.

Industry watchers expect shares in Carillion, the construction company spun out of Tarmac last year, to grow since it is a specialist builder of social housing, which is expected to have nearly £2bn invested in it over the next three years.

Builders merchant Travis Perkins is expected to see a sharp revival thanks to rising sales of timber, doors and plasterboard.

The value of the work done by the UK construction industry has grown steadily by an average of 1.75 per cent a year since 1996, buoyed by a housing boom and Lottery-funded millennium projects. Now that growth is forecast to double, according to research by merchant bank Robert Fleming.

'Contractors in particular have effectively been re-rated since Brown's speech,' said its construction analyst, Alastair Stewart.

'Gordon Brown's money is pretty much set in stone but because most of the emphasis of this review is towards refurbishments and upgrading, we believe contractors rather than building aggregates groups will benefit.'

The global construction industry is in the middle of consolidation. Already this year Amec has bought Canadian project management firm Agra for £220m.

Two weeks ago, Vinci, the construction arm of Vivendi, agreed a deal for Groupe GTM, making it the biggest European construction company, while Bouygues, the sector leader until Vinci's announcement, has bought up all the remaining shares in Colas, its road-building arm.

Blue Circle, Britain's biggest cement producer, last May narrowly fought off a hostile takeover bid by French group Lafarge. Now Blue Circle is eyeing corporate opportunities abroad.

Britain's biggest construction customers are rapidly slashing their list of contractors and giving performance incentives to those that remain in a bid to match the efficiency gained by the rationalisation in most sectors.

But while top construction firms are now embracing modernisation, there are concerns that the Government's spending plans, which will bring an extra £17bn into the sector, may falter because these companies are not in a position to deliver.

Graham Watts, chief executive of professional body the Construction Industry Council, warns: 'The real issue is whether the industry can cope with this much work. At professional levels, there are not enough building service engineers, civil engineers and construction managers. We lost 500,000 workers in the Nineties recession. They haven't been replaced, and we've got great problems recruiting graduates. It's not deemed a sexy industry in the dotcom age.'

Watts believes a shortage of workers will lead to wage inflation. 'My concern is that an upward spiral in wages will see the Government getting less for its money. What worries me is that we've seen a construction boom drive the economy into recession during the late Eighties. Wage inflation in construction feeds inflation in the rest of the economy. History could repeat itself.'

But others say Watts is alarmist. New technology is making up for the worst effects of skills shortages.

These days, new homes can be built in factories, delivered to a site by lorry, like flatpack furniture, and assembled there. Laser-guided bulldozers and new initiatives to recycle materials are all reducing costs.

This is the future and it sounds convincing. But last week, the Health and Safety Executive revealed that the the number of deaths on British building sites increased to 86 in the year up to last April - 20 more than the previous year.

This is partly because the industry is doing more work, but some fear standards are allowed to slip.

'There are fewer labourers today but they've got to work harder,' said one project manager who wished to remain anonymous.

'Subcontractors are still being taken advantage of by the big guys. Maybe because these new projects are virtually guaranteed, the temptation to undercut won't be so great in future. But this industry is rubbish on the "soft skills" - talking to people and working together. That's why there are deaths and accidents.'

The industry has long been an investment backwater. Now it is in the spotlight, charged with regenerating Britain. It is unclear whether it is up to the challenge.

Soft spot under the hard hats

You may think that the day a group of builders indulges in role-playing games and 'trust exercises' will be the day the Tower of London falls down. Well that day has come, and the tower is still standing.

Last year, a group of architects, builders, subcontractors and residents from Pollards Hill estate in Mitcham, south London, took part in two days of team-building exercises as a precursor to a £36 million facelift for a place starved of cash and blighted by serious racial incidents.

The regeneration is now a Government demonstration project aimed at proving that 'partnering' can improve the quality and cost of projects.

The concept of partnering, begun in the US, was proposed for this country by the Government's Construction Task Force in 1998. The body called for a 'totally new approach to the delivery of the construction product'.

At Pollards Hill, home to about 5,000 people, residents were involved in selecting the leading contractor, Higgins Construction. Everyone involved in rebuilding the estate signed an agreement setting out the objectives.

So far the regeneration has been an unmitigated success. Residents seem excited and pleased. Normally, a number of people object to being 'decanted' during work on their homes. This time, there have been few objections.

The first, £7m, phase of the project came in £500,000 under budget, allowing Higgins to guarantee the price of the remaining work. Fears that this would squeeze the budgets of subcontractors are denied by Hugh Raven, a consultant there. 'There is five years' guaranteed work left on this project,' he says. 'Subcontractor prices reflect that.'

Meetings between the residents and the builders to discuss progress are held every three months.

fields.headline: What's Brown's exchange rate?
fields.trailText: One of the less noticed aspects of the torrent of leaks pouring out of the 'Yes Minister' world of Tony Blair's government is the absence of any obvious interest on the part of the Prime Minister in the economy. You could argue that the economy is going so well (the fashionable view, about which I have reservations) that he does not need to concern himself with it.
fields.body:
One of the less noticed aspects of the torrent of leaks pouring out of the 'Yes Minister' world of Tony Blair's government is the absence of any obvious interest on the part of the Prime Minister in the economy. You could argue that the economy is going so well (the fashionable view, about which I have reservations) that he does not need to concern himself with it.

It could also be said that Blair is happy to leave the economy in Gordon Brown's hands. Brown certainly breaks all the rules of the European Union working-time directive in the number of hours he puts in on the economy - although, if it is true that he only begins work at 6am he still has to catch up with Sir Stafford Cripps, Labour Chancellor after Hugh Dalton's 'Budget leak' resignation in 1947, who began work at 5am.

If members of this Government had to resign every time there was an embarrassing leak, there would be no Cabinet left by now. No doubt a much smaller cabinet would suit the Prime Minister well, because, as he is finding to his cost, democracy and colleagues can be tiresome when one has ambitions to break the mould of British politics. Nigel Lawson once joked that Thatcher's ideal was a Cabinet of one: herself.

Nevertheless, the delegation of almost everything concerned with the economy to the Chancellor (with occasional intervention in things like the minimum wage) is unusual: if one looks back over the past 50 years, Macmillan, Wilson, Heath, Callaghan, Thatcher and Major all took a much greater interest in the economy than Blair seems to. Perhaps there was a greater sense of crisis then. Perhaps it doesn't matter very much.

Nevertheless it is intriguing, and the Chancellor's overlordship of this area must contribute to what some insiders fear is a duumvirate that could collapse in classic Roman style.

Some people are making comparisons with the Thatcher/Lawson/Walters era. In some ways the tension between Nos 10 and 11 Downing Street is not as bad as it was then; but in others it is even worse. Unlike Brown, Lawson never took himself seriously as being prime minister material - although there was a moment, when he was being feted as the Greatest Chancellor, when others began to take him seriously.

Thatcher did not take kindly to that kind of thing. Nevertheless, she was genuinely bemused by Lawson's resentment of Walters; and, people forget, Lawson was not fired. He resigned, in considerable style, on a day when his senior officials thought they had safely packed him off to Germany.

The general view is that Blair certainly cannot afford to lose Brown from the Treasury this side of the election; Whitehall seems to be more divided on whether the Chancellor is a racing certainty to be reappointed after the election (if Labour wins) or will be put on the spot by being offered the Foreign Office.

Geoffrey Howe was happy to move to the Foreign Office after the 1983 election. Thatcher, too, thought the time had come and noted: 'It seems a kind of psychological law that Chancellors naturally incline towards the Foreign Office.' Indeed she thought it the 'next logical step'.

Number 10 has its own views on the Chancellor's psychological laws. Brown may think differently from Howe - as Chancellor he is at the centre of power and no doubt wishes to stay there until he can become prime minister. One watches all this with interest: there seemed a certain 'third way' aspect to Blair's response last week to rumours about his not wanting a full second term - indeed, I thought him somewhat Delphic. But the response was duly spun into a firmer commitment than his words seemed to warrant.

There was a time when I wondered whether Brown, too, shared Blair's lack of interest in the economy. That was when, early on, the Chancellor hived off demand management to the Bank of England. But one soon learnt that, among other things, that was to give the Chancellor more time to work on his mission to improve the supply side of the economy, and devise complex schemes to narrow, or at least block, the widening gap between rich and poor.

Last week the Chancellor told the parliamentary Treasury Committee that the economic stability he aims at is an 'essential part' of the economic convergence required by his five tests for joining the euro. But a day later the Confederation of British Industry came out with a quarterly trends survey that suggested there was still a lot of 'instability' in the manufacturing sector, caused by the high pound.

For, while people's attention has been distracted by leaked memos and fundamental spending reviews, the pound has been creeping up again. The prospects for exports have deteriorated sharply in recent months, new investment plans are weak, and the CBI fears that manufacturing could be in danger of the kind of downturn that would not be too popular with the CBI or electorate.

Nick Reilly, head of Vauxhall Motors and of the CBI's economic affairs committee, says there is a lot of evidence that more and more businesses are switching to overseas sources for supplies - hence the recent surge in imports.

Kate Barker, the CBI's chief economist, observed: 'People say industry is "adapting" as if that were not a problem.' But whereas companies may survive by downsizing their UK operations and buying and investing abroad, that is not much good for the long-term potential of the 'supply side' the Chancellor works on from 5 - sorry 6 - am.

The Bank of England's Monetary Policy Committee has made its concerns about the damaging level of the pound known, but there is little it can do given its remit. The Government seems to have no strategy other than to wait and see. While one waits and sees what happens to British industry, however, there are wonderful exchange rates available for the summer holidays.

fields.headline: BA will buy 10 A3XXs - Airbus
fields.trailText: British Airways will boost Airbus Industrie's A3XX project by buying up to 10 of the 'superjumbos', a senior source at the manufacturer predicts.
fields.body:
British Airways will boost Airbus Industrie's A3XX project by buying up to 10 of the 'superjumbos', a senior source at the manufacturer predicts.

The source at the European aircraft consortium told The Observer he believed BA would sign up this autumn.

A prototype of the giant airliner is expected to be flying by 2004 and to start commercial services a year later.

The source said Airbus was in 'serious, two-way' talks with BA about the A3XX, talks which had gone beyond unsolicited sales pitches.

Airbus already has orders from Air France, Middle East airline Emirates, and US leasing company ILFC. It hopes BA and Lufthansa will soon follow suit, but believes that signing up a major US airline will take longer.

Under previous chief executive Bob Ayling, BA appeared to be turning against the A3XX. He froze orders for the current largest aircraft, the Boeing 747, and instead bought more of the smaller, twin-engined 777s.

New boss Rod Eddington is sticking to smaller aircraft and shrinking capacity by 12 per cent over the next three years, to boost profits. But he has not ruled the superjumbo out, although it seems unlikely BA will sign up for A3XX as quickly as the hard-talking Airbus predicts.

A source close to BA said: 'There are routes we could imagine using the A3XX on, routes where you cannot offer high frequency because there is only a small time window in which you can take off and land at sensible times, such as Australia and Japan.'

webTitle: Malls fight for extra Sunday trading

fields.headline: Malls fight for extra Sunday trading
fields.trailText: Britain's leading out-of-town shopping centres are planning to open for longer on Sundays in a move that could lead to to a head-on clash with the shop workers' union, Usdaw.
fields.body:
Britain's leading out-of-town shopping centres are planning to open for longer on Sundays in a move that could lead to to a head-on clash with the shop workers' union, Usdaw.

A meeting tomorrow between the owners of Manchester's Trafford Centre, Bluewater in Kent, Merry Hill in the West Midlands, the Metrocentre in the North-east, and Lakeside, Essex, will co-ordinate pressure on the Government for an extension to the six hours now allowed.

'Our aim is to get all 700 shopping centres open for the full day,' said James Lindsay, business director of the Trafford Centre.

But a furious Usdaw official said: 'We are diametrically opposed to this, and we expect a Labour government to uphold the rights of workers.' The union claims many retailers are reducing Sunday overtime rates.

Many shopping centres say their busiest periods are on Sundays. Manchester's Trafford Centre attracts 3,000 more people an hour on Sundays than on Saturdays.

The biggest retailer, Tesco, has found a loophole that allows it to offer home delivery of goods ordered on its internet site for 12 hours on Sundays.

webTitle: Dump the pump is no solution

fields.headline: Dump the pump is no solution
fields.standfirst: Despite the tabloids, the public backs constraints on car use to get Britain moving, says  David Begg
fields.trailText: Despite the tabloids, the public backs constraints on car use to get Britain moving, says David Begg
fields.body:
This week we are all being told to 'dump the pump' in protest at rising petrol prices. But just as the oil producers control the flow from well-heads in the sand, we are all being asked to bury our own heads in the space left behind.

The tabloid media and the motoring sector rage at the current level of pump prices, take simplistic soundings of public opinion to back their case and demand instant action. But the campaigners could more usefully direct their concern towards the sharp increases in public transport fares since 1974. While there has been no increase in the real cost of motoring since then, bus passengers have faced an 80 per cent hike in fares and rail passengers a 53 per cent rise.

While one appreciates the impact of rising fuel prices on low-income motorists, there are four times as many low income bus users who could do with a little support.

No one would quarrel with the basic fact that fuel prices have rocketed in recent months. But the public are much more sophisticated than any single-issue lobby would give them credit for. A Mori poll has shown they are not afraid to see higher prices or car constraint where this delivers direct benefits. More people backed congestion charges for driving into city centres at peak times if fuel and vehicle excise duties were reduced (41 per cent) than opposed them (35 per cent).

People recognise that there is a finite amount of road space; that in a growing economy you are not going to be able to stop a rise in car use or deliver improved public transport without introducing price constraints where congestion is worst.

By any comparison, motoring is a cheap form of transport and has been getting cheaper for years. Petrol is now only around 9p a litre more than it was at its highest point during the Opec production squeeze of the Seventies. In that time car engines have become more fuel efficient and the cost of manufacturing and operating cars has become cheaper. As a result the number of vehicles has vastly increased.

In 1950 the average car travelled five miles a day. Today it is 25 miles and by 2020 it is forecast to be 60 miles. This small island doesn't have the space to sustain that.

With the public growing resistant to any major expansion of the road network it is obvious that an ever-growing number of vehicles on finite road space will lead to gridlock unless the price mechanism is used to constrain demand. Good public trans port on its own is not enough - if it were, why should Paris, with one of the best public transport systems in Europe, suffer worse congestion than most British cities?

While the 'dump the pump' lobby trumpets the high costs of petrol compared with the rest of Europe they should also examine our record in using cars. We own fewer than the Germans and French, we are a smaller country - yet we use our cars more.

The campaigners do have a point about high fuel duty hitting the rural motorist hardest. In a crofting household in Caithness popping out for a loaf of bread can mean a five-mile journey on some of the least-used roads by someone paying some of the highest petrol prices in the UK but earning one of the lowest incomes. Meanwhile in Surrey you have some of the highest incomes in the UK and your car is contribut ing to some of the worst congestion - with the Council for the Protection of Rural England predicting up to 100 per cent further growth on minor rural roads.

It is true that, in the longer-term, fuel duty is too blunt an implement to crack congestion. Yet the dump the pump campaign will not take us closer to a solution.

 Professor David Begg is chairman of the Commission for Integrated Transport.

webTitle: Wall's has ice-cream market licked despite clouds

fields.headline: Wall's has ice-cream market licked despite clouds
fields.trailText: Unilever's shareholders may not be familiar with the name Naomie Ditzler, but she is almost the only thing standing between a lousy summer and a slump in ice cream sales at the company's Wall's subsidiary. Despite June having seen the worst weather for sales on record, the Swiss-born New York-based model, the face of Wall's Magnum bars, is having a profound impact on the company's bottom line.
fields.body:
Unilever's shareholders may not be familiar with the name Naomie Ditzler, but she is almost the only thing standing between a lousy summer and a slump in ice cream sales at the company's Wall's subsidiary. Despite June having seen the worst weather for sales on record, the Swiss-born New York-based model, the face of Wall's Magnum bars, is having a profound impact on the company's bottom line.

'Last year we sold around 88 million bars,' said Simon Stevens of Wall's. 'This year we reckon we'll sell more than 150 million bars, up nearly 80 per cent on the pre vious 12 months.'

The impact of the Ditzler campaign, which features the model chomping through a Magnum bar and is seen on poster sites across the land, is estimated to have been largely responsible for increasing overall ice cream sales by 7 per cent on the previous year. Surveys show the Magnum series of posters scores the third highest level of consumer awareness after campaigns for mobile phone operator One 2 One and the energy drink Lucozade featuring the video game character Lara Croft.

The rise is surprising, considering last month's dreadful weather. In a good week during the summer Wall's would expect to sell 50 million ice creams. Poor weather would see this slashed to around 30 million. The company uses a weather index to gauge conditions for sales. A 100 rating is average; June's rating was 93.9. 'It's never been that low at the half-year - ever,' Stevens said.

Unilever seeks to position Magnum as a 'power brand', which can compete with products such as Kit Kat and Walkers Crisps. The company has dramatically increased its Magnum marketing spend from a budget of £2.5 million in 1999 to £7m this year.

fields.headline: Consumer fury over Axa assets
fields.trailText: The Consumers' Association is demanding that Chancellor Gordon Brown call a summit meeting with the insurance industry to investigate the way companies hand out windfall profits, known as orphan assets, which are estimated to be worth £20 billion.
fields.body:
The Consumers' Association is demanding that Chancellor Gordon Brown call a summit meeting with the insurance industry to investigate the way companies hand out windfall profits, known as orphan assets, which are estimated to be worth £20 billion.

CA's demand has been provoked by anger at the plan drawn up by insurer Axa for distribution of its orphan funds worth £1.7 billion.

CA believes the scheme may award as little as 35 per cent of the assets to policyholders, with the remainder going to shareholders. The watchdog believes that policyholders should get 90 per cent, while shareholders receive 10 per cent.

The orphan assets are surplus profits that the insurers have not paid out to with-profit policyholders in past generations.

One of the CA's criticisms of the Axa deal is its complexity. It says it cannot be certain what proportion of the assets Axa's 600,000 policyholders will get until it has more information.

CA has arranged a meeting with the Financial Services Authority, the chief financial services regulator, which has approved the Axa deal, next Thursday to raise its concerns.

But it also wants the Chancellor to call insurers to a meeting to discuss the issue publicly. Several insurers are drawing up schemes to distribute their orphan assets and CA fears that the Axa deal could become a model for others.

The row over distribution of surplus profits comes as thousands of mortgage customers are being asked to find money from their own pockets to fund shortfalls on endowment policies.

Prudential is estimated to have between £7billion and £9bn in orphan assets, CGNU £5bn, and Britannic about £1bn.

Mick McAteer, a policy and research officer with CA, said: 'We want Gordon Brown to have a summit where everyone can argue the issues in public.'

Sheila McKechnie, director of CA, was scathing about the FSA's approval of the scheme: 'In effect the FSA has given approval for it to be put to policyholders. They are, de facto, endorsing it. That is disgraceful.'

The FSA defended the proposal and said it had been drawn up in private because it was a market-sensitive issue. CA is appealing for Axa policyholders to contact it to look into the possibility of representing them in the court hearing that will be held to examine the merits of the plan. Policyholders can email CA on orphan@which.net

Axa is offering policyholders cash bonuses averaging £400 each - most people will get less than £1,000 - and special bonuses once their policies mature. Policyholders who reject the windfalls will also receive the special final bonuses, but in exchange for forgoing the cash will share in possible further payments in future.

But there is no guarantee what, if any, further payments this group will receive. Policyholders must vote on the proposal by 16 October and after that it will go to a court hearing.

McKechnie said: 'We are very concerned about the fact that the deal is being put to policyholders before there is a court case.'

CA is to ask the Financial Services Authority if it can put its view of the deal into the information pack sent to Axa policyholders.

fields.headline: Maxwell firm bouncesback
fields.trailText: Kevin Maxwell's hopes of making it back into big- time business have received a significant boost. Shares in Telemonde, the beleaguered telecoms company he chairs, are to be relisted on the OTC Bulletin Board, the US stock trading service for small companies from which it was recently barred.
fields.body:
Kevin Maxwell's hopes of making it back into big- time business have received a significant boost. Shares in Telemonde, the beleaguered telecoms company he chairs, are to be relisted on the OTC Bulletin Board, the US stock trading service for small companies from which it was recently barred.

Earlier this year, Maxwell's company suffered the ignominy of being ejected from the OTC because it failed to comply with US reporting requirements. Maxwell, formerly the UK's biggest bankrupt and the son of late newspaper proprietor Robert Maxwell, hopes his firm will ultimately gain a listing on Nasdaq, the US market for hi-tech stocks.

Telemonde had to restate its most recent set of financial results following a review by the Securities and Exchange Commission, the US markets watchdog. It was forced to acknowledge that its net loss for 1999 was actually $61 million, rather than the $42m it stated originally. As the company amended its accounts to win SEC approval, Telemonde's shares were demoted to the off-exchange 'pink sheets', an obscure market for penny shares.

The company has been battered by bad news in recent months. Telemonde leased capacity from a number of telecom companies with a view to selling it on to other firms, but took a hammering when bandwidth prices fell.

This raised tensions with the company's suppliers who in March were owed more than $84m. The firm told the SEC then: 'If we fail to obtain necessary capital, or obtain an insufficient amount of capital, we would harm our prospects and [this] could jeopardise our existence.'

A company spokeswoman declined to reveal to what extent Telemonde had settled its difficulties, but said: 'We are working with our suppliers to resolve these issues.'

Maxwell, formerly the UK's biggest bankrupt and the son of late newspaper proprietor Robert Maxwell, hopes his firm will ultimately gain a listing on Nasdaq, the US market for hi-tech stocks. Telemonde had to restate its most recent set of financial results following a review by the Securities and Exchange Commission, the US markets watchdog. It was forced to acknowledge that its net loss for 1999 was actually $61 million, rather than the $42m it stated originally. As the company amended its accounts to win SEC approval, Telemonde's shares were demoted to the off-exchange 'pink sheets', an obscure market for penny shares. The company has been battered by bad news in recent months. Telemonde leased capacity from a number of telecom companies with a view to selling it on to other firms, but took a hammering when bandwidth prices fell. This raised tensions with the company's suppliers who in March were owed more than $84m. The firm told the SEC then: 'If we fail to obtain necessary capital, or obtain an insufficient amount of capital, we would harm our prospects and [this] could jeopardise our existence.' A company spokeswoman declined to reveal to what extent Telemonde had settled its difficulties, but said: 'We are working with our suppliers to resolve these issues.'

fields.headline: We're child-free - and we're happy
fields.standfirst: 'My mum was a bit disappointed. She expected to be a grandmother...'
fields.trailText: 'My mum was a bit disappointed. She expected to be a grandmother...'
fields.body:
Ed and Mary Adams

The Adamses are 36 and have been married for six years. 'We started out thinking children would just happen one day,' said Ed.

'But then one or two subtle things happened that made us wonder why we wanted to do this.

'My parents split up when I was 12. I became aware that as a parent you can just end up replicating your childhood. And, after my father remarried and had another child he once told me, "It's hell". And they had money and nannies and financial support and no problem with school fees or anything like that.

'When it came to it, Mary didn't want to give up her work. She had worked with children in the past and began to feel then that she didn't really want them.

'There's that thing about a natural maternal instinct. But it's just another societal pressure. It's rubbish.

'A lot of women sacrifice their careers and realise they can't pick them up properly again. I could have become a house-husband but I didn't want it.

'I've now had a vasectomy. It was very easy. My mum was a bit disappointed; she had expected to be a grandmother one day. With my dad we never discuss it. It's off the agenda. Mary's parents are even more traditional and Christian. It's the old religion thing with them.

'There's a shibboleth about having children that must not be challenged in our society.

'If you bring a small being into the planet, you can't rehouse it. You're stuck with the thing. And too many parents are.

'People think they have a sacrosanct right to have children. But the world doesn't need more children. We're screwing the planet into the ground as it is.'

Jackie Arnold

'It's an issue of reproductive choice for me. If women get married and have children then they worry about taking on new jobs. Men just don't worry so much. Men don't get stuck with the label of being a parent as much as a woman. It's just not a subject brought up for them.

'When I was sterilised I went to a Marie Stopes clinic. They made me wait for three months. When I was there I had to see seven different people over five hours; you're required to have all sorts of counselling. But I still think it was one of the best things I could have done.'

Root Cartwright

A 50-year-old gardener from Hertfordshire, Root Cartwright has been determined for almost all his adult life that he would not be a parent: 'I had this feeling even before 20 years of constant news stories about IVF and the constant undue emphasis on the desire to have a child come what may.

'Having children should be something that people positively choose. I have nothing against children myself. There are people who say, "Why should we pay taxes for the education of other people's kids?" But I disagree because I want to live in a society full of sensible, educated people.

'I don't think having kids is something you do from a sense of civic duty. It's something completely selfish; you do it because you want to. But you shouldn't be made to feel bad or awkward or different because you don't.

'A big part of the issue for me is quite simply the willingness to accept difference, to be prepared not to take an authoritarian position. Thankfully not many people listen to the Pope nowadays.'

fields.headline: Wish you were queer
fields.standfirst: Two funny lesbian Scots, Denise Van Outen as Val Doonican, a love song from Phoebe? It must be summer
fields.trailText: Two funny lesbian Scots, Denise Van Outen as Val Doonican, a love song from Phoebe? It must be summer.
fields.body:
Rhona BBC2
Glasgow Kiss BBC1
Operation Good Guys BBC2
Friends C4

You can tell we're deep into summer scheduling hell because last week was a very good week for Scots sapphics. Obviously this isn't quite as minority as terrestrial telly drama can get (that'll be in August when, mark my words, there will be subtitled love stories set in Latvian circuses and featuring persons of restricted growth), but I'm sure you'll agree that two wisecracking Scottish lesbians in one week is two more wisecracking Scottish lesbians than you've probably had in your living room all year. Unless, of course, you're a wisecracking Scottish lesbian yourself, in which case your living room is presumably heaving with smart sisters rolling their eyes, tutting and saying: 'Women! Pah! Can't live with 'em... pass that copy of Hustler .'

Anyway, the week's first Scottish lesbian was the much-hyped Rhona Cameron bouncing busily around her eponymous sitcom. With a title sequence inspired by the Seventies sitcom Rhoda , friendships inspired by Seinfeld , humour inspired by undergrad surrealism and all of it wrapped up as a cuddly twenty-first century cultural signifier, Rhona practically screamed: 'Look at me! I'm not scary at all, am I? Not relentlessly gay like that Ellen or Queer as Folk .' Indeed, Cameron was clearly at such pains not to make an issue of her gayness that for the lily-livered non-lesbians among us, the show really wasn't gay enough. Take away the prospect of girls snogging in that gaspingly slo-mo porno style that always makes me think goodness-is-that-the-time-already? and what is there left apart from a few cute, Friends -funny lines like:

'If you sleep with your friends who do you complain to about your lovers?'
'Friends you're waiting to sleep with.'

(Smart, but wrong. All women, whatever their sexual proclivities, know that the real answer is one's dog.) Still, Rhona-the-show was cute like, say, a wee lesbian mouse tapdancing there on the stair right there and Rhona-the-star tried awfully hard, but unfortunately the combination of Rhona plus Mel Giedroyc and Dave Lamb as her (straight) best friends was so desperately unsexy that when they all ended up in bed together it was a bit like watching Eric and Ernie sharing their queen size with Angela Rippon.

The week's second Scottish lesbian cropped up as Iain Glen's housemate (or sister? or friend with a spare set of keys? - who knew?) in Glasgow Kiss, a love story that, having been relegated to scheduling hell, could have been about semi-professional headbutters in the Gorbals but in fact turned out to be a love story between a sports hack and a management consultant set against the backdrop of an ailing Glaswegian tabloid newspaper. On second thoughts, the perfect combination for some volatile romantic headbutting.

Despite feisty lines like: 'I cannae find anyone who lasts longer than a leg-wax' and, to Glen: 'You're housetrained, you don't smell, you've get your own teeth. Christ, if you wore a dress I'd shag you meself...' - even when murmuring: 'I must get out more' while leafing through a dusty copy of Mayfair - the lesbian really only existed as a cipher for Glen's character to cry on. None the less, I'm hoping that this fleeting evidence of primetime gal-pal sauciness might give Rhona the confidence to throw an Ann Summers party and invite Denise Van Outen, the girls from Steps, Martina Navratilova and some ex-Gladiators.

But the pet lesbian hardly got a look in after the plot kicked off. Glen plays widowed Stuart, a football writer and owner of both a very winsome son and a trampled heart. Meanwhile, single thirtysomething consultant Cara (Sharon Small) has been having an affair with her married boss when he demands some space and dispatches her on a 10-week mission to turn around the fortunes of Glen's ailing paper. Searching for a canteen, Cara is soon spotted by Stuart and his smart-arse colleague who mistakes her for 'the new girl from features'.

'How do you figure that?'
'Well, she's lost. You know what they're like - brown's the new black, stupid's the new clever!'

Laugh? I nearly understood the offside rule. Anyway, I assume women are meant to identify with this gimlet-eyed management minxstress, which is unnerving because soon she was coming across like a dyed-in-the-fur boiler of bunnies. At the leaving do for a squealing bimbette from features, which apparently got itself confused with a hen night (complete with gifts of small plastic penises on legs and stripping policemen), Cara copped off with Stuart after establishing he was single. Later, post-coitally, back at his place, in the middle of the night, apropos of nothing, she whispered: 'Stuart, do you think I look happy?'

In the real world, this is the sort of feminine behaviour that sends the average adult male straight into the arms of an uncomplicated younger woman who is 'a bit of a laugh' and probably keeps a small plastic penis with legs Blu-Tacked to the top of her computer. But despite failing this test and being very lucky not to get kicked out of his bed, Cara was soon poking around Stuart's bathroom cabinet, discovering boxes of Tampax and bottles of Chanel.

Thus gripped with the mania that comes of discovering the man with whom you've just had a one-night stand might not actually be a virgin, Cara was soon fossicking in wardrobes, finding frocks, dried bouquets and wedding photographs. Naturally, seconds later, she was also pacing Stuart's kitchen and spraying the words LYING BASTARD on his walls. In the real world, of course, this would merely confirm men's hunches that all desperate thirtysomething women and needy management consultants are several sheets short of a full flip chart. But not Stuart. No, instead he got Cara round to repaint his walls, meet his son and have a nice cup of tea. 'You must think I'm a complete nutter!' said Cara. But oddly, instead of responding with a heartfelt 'Yes. And could you please leave immediately while I phone a locksmith', Stuart just smiled empathetically and said: 'I take it you've been lied to before...'

As the credits rolled, Stuart was to be seen weeping and sniffing his dead wife's clothes. Don't really want to go there? No, me neither! In fact, rather than watch Cara and Stuart hurtle toward their unfeasibly happy ending, I rather fancy spending the next six Tuesday nights curled up on the sofa with the dog, a copy of Anthony Clare's On Men: Masculinity in Crisis and a tub of Ben and Jerry's Chubby Hubby ice cream.

Excellent to see a third series of Dominic Anciano and Ray Burdis's sniggeringly deadpan and surreal faux police docusoap Operation Good Guys . No lesbians this time, but alongside the usual suspects the line-up included a (headbutting) person of restricted growth; Denise Van Outen as Val Doonican, the BBC's entertainment chief, Paul Jackson, Michael Fish, a white-faced, black-lipped, monochrome minstrel, and a final scene which reminded me of an old Culture Club video.

If you don't know Operation Good Guys then this description won't have helped you very much. And if you do then you'll recognise that it's police business as usual. Of all the comedy shows on TV, this is the one where everybody involved looks as though they are probably having even more of a laugh than we are.

I used to think the same of Friends, but now I'm not so sure. The women get skinnier and skinnier but don't look any younger, while the men look like they should quit goofing around in Central Perk and take their kids off to a Little League game, so there's a slightly jaded air hanging over the cast these days. But Friends can still fizz, and last week Phoebe got all the best lines. Shortly after she'd 'fessed up to a hitherto secret roommate called Denise, we were treated to a new song: 'I found you in my bed/ How'd you wind up there?/ You are a mys-ter-y/ Little black curly hair...'

At this rate, she'll soon be inviting Monica and Rachel over for Ann Summers parties and making guest appearances on Rhona. I mean, come on - when did we last see Phoebe with, like, a guy?

fields.headline: It's written all over her face
fields.trailText: Shirin Neshat
fields.body:
Shirin Neshat The Serpentine, London W2

It is a collection of opposites: male, female; active, passive; enclosed, free; silent, noisy. And apart from one face covered in red Farsi writing, Shirin Neshat's collection of work at the Serpentine is black and white.

In 1974, aged 17, Neshat was sent from Iran by her father to study in America. Because of the revolution and war she was unable to return home for 16 years. Now based in America her work reflects the two cultures that influence her.

The exhibition comprises a trilogy of videos - Turbulent, Rapture and Fervor - which look at the roles of men and women in Islam. They are more statement than judgment; the women come over as feisty, unabashed. In Rapture (filmed in Essaouira, Morocco), the men are inside the fort, staging rituals, swaggering on the battlements. The women are outside, swooping along the beach in their chadors like crows. Free as birds they drag a rowing boat to the water and six of them set off out to sea. Two screens sit at opposite ends of the room; the men on one, women on the other. As the action takes place in one group, the other falls still to observe.

Neshat turns the camera on herself for her Women of Allah series of photographs. In Rebellious Silence her serene face, covered in Farsi calligraphy, is bisected by a gun barrel. In Allegiance with Wakefulness a gun protrudes between the vulnerable soles of her feet.

 Laura Cumming is away

fields.headline: Flying tonight
fields.standfirst: While One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest enjoys a storming revival, Arthur Miller sinks without trace
fields.trailText: While One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest enjoys a storming revival, Arthur Miller sinks without trace.
fields.body:
One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest Barbican, London EC2
Mr Peters' Connections Almeida, London N1
Moving on Bridewell, London EC4

The Steppenwolf Theatre Company of Chicago have come to the Barbican to show how a crack ensemble can light up a stage. One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest is a hippy old piece, full of heart and full of holes. But as directed by Terry Kinney, a co-founder of the company, it storms along.

Dale Wasserman's play, based on the novel by Ken Kesey, was first performed in 1970 and made famous by Milos Forman's 1975 screen version starring Jack Nicholson. Its story - of a sane man who goes into a mental asylum to escape criminal charges and awakens its institutionalised patients to the knowledge of their abuse - is a real Sixties' creation. The authorities are repressive; the inmates are victims of the system; hardly anyone is really mad or dangerous. There is an amiable giant watching a flock of geese.

The play is a study of society in miniature. It has the anger and the kindness of the era. It also has a cruel blank spot: it's difficult to imagine anyone nowadays so confidently pitting the rights of a band of full-blooded fellows against an emasculating spinster.

The point of Steppenwolf is the company's wonderful pulling together: no nook of the stage is dead; everyone is always concentrated; something is always on the move; it makes you realise that stretches of most productions are vacant.

But the point of the play is anti-ensemble - it celebrates an individual's power to disrupt and change. And there's no question that a considerable part of the evening's power comes from the brimming-over energy of another Steppenwolf founder. Gary Sinise makes the Jack Nicholson part his own - he's so bristlingly full of himself as he struts around in his denims and lumberjack shirt that you feel his temperature rising. In one memorable moment, as he tries - and fails - to exercise his power, his whole face changes colour.

He helps make the play an infinitely more subtle occasion than Forman's film. As does Amy Morton, who plays the tyrant nurse with level-toned, syrupy compassion. You believe she believes in what's she doing, which make her much more dangerous. Anyone interested in acting should see this play.

This should have been a good month for another American playwright. The National is staging a full-on production of one of Arthur Miller's best-known plays, All My Sons . And now the Almeida has provided an English platform for a piece written 50 years later, and first seen in the US two years ago.

But Mr Peters' Connections is a dreary occasion. An elderly man's after-dinner sleep takes him into a limbo in which the past and present, the living and the dead, fact and speculation become jumbled, as fragments of his life occur to him. His middle-aged wife appears, as does the ghost of a young lover. Played here as a curvy, fur-clad blonde, she inevitably evokes Monroe - and if Miller had wanted to avoid any possibility of an association with Norma Jean, he might have called her something less double-barrelled than Cathy-May. A young couple chat in a modern vocabulary which baffles him; a dead brother reminds him of halcyon days. In one corner, an all-seeing black hobo cackles and lets loose an occasional irritating general statement.

More than once, Mr Peters complains of a bewildering fluency in himself and others, and of an inability to find in this torrent of words a real subject-matter. It's a complaint that, not unreasonably, extends beyond his own troubles to embrace the condition of America.

The trouble is that the play merely mimics these complaints. It's all meander. Spurts of epigrams - 'I was never conservative enough to be a communist' - don't add up to an argument. A sentimental lurch at the end doesn't amount to a conclusion. Michael Blakemore's production creeps along. Peter J. Davison's design is awkward rather than unsettling: skyscrapers slant away in the background without looking vertiginous; a pile of furniture in one corner looks like a tidy person's attempt at putting a muddle together. As Mr Peters, John Cullum looks - as well he may - perplexed but never threatened.

The Bridewell Theatre has two musical modes. There's new and daring. This is the theatre that has brought the British musical a new, blue-grass hope by presenting the work of Richard Rogers's grandson, Adam Guettel. And there's assured and elegant - as in the new Sond heim tribute, Moving On. Twenty-five years ago, David Kernan created a hit with Side by Side by Sondheim . The new revue, which he has devised and directed, includes the composer's more recent work.

Moving On is a crisp and sweetly caustic night's music. The songs of the urban ironist, who hymns the delights of a place with 'grass on the sidewalk but not in the park', are staged on a series of wide steps bathed in mauve light, with a stiff line of ornamental trees in the background. Five singers glide, and, in one instance, tap-dance, over these, declaring their friendship as they pointedly upstage each other.

fields.bodyText: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest Barbican, London EC2 Mr Peters' Connections Almeida, London N1 Moving on Bridewell, London EC4 The Steppenwolf Theatre Company of Chicago have come to the Barbican to show how a crack ensemble can light up a stage. One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest is a hippy old piece, full of heart and full of holes. But as directed by Terry Kinney, a co-founder of the company, it storms along. Dale Wasserman's play, based on the novel by Ken Kesey, was first performed in 1970 and made famous by Milos Forman's 1975 screen version starring Jack Nicholson. Its story - of a sane man who goes into a mental asylum to escape criminal charges and awakens its institutionalised patients to the knowledge of their abuse - is a real Sixties' creation. The authorities are repressive; the inmates are victims of the system; hardly anyone is really mad or dangerous. There is an amiable giant watching a flock of geese. The play is a study of society in miniature. It has the anger and the kindness of the era. It also has a cruel blank spot: it's difficult to imagine anyone nowadays so confidently pitting the rights of a band of full-blooded fellows against an emasculating spinster. The point of Steppenwolf is the company's wonderful pulling together: no nook of the stage is dead; everyone is always concentrated; something is always on the move; it makes you realise that stretches of most productions are vacant. But the point of the play is anti-ensemble - it celebrates an individual's power to disrupt and change. And there's no question that a considerable part of the evening's power comes from the brimming-over energy of another Steppenwolf founder. Gary Sinise makes the Jack Nicholson part his own - he's so bristlingly full of himself as he struts around in his denims and lumberjack shirt that you feel his temperature rising. In one memorable moment, as he tries - and fails - to exercise his power, his whole face changes colour. He helps make the play an infinitely more subtle occasion than Forman's film. An elderly man's after-dinner sleep takes him into a limbo in which the past and present, the living and the dead, fact and speculation become jumbled, as fragments of his life occur to him. It's a complaint that, not unreasonably, extends beyond his own troubles to embrace the condition of America. The trouble is that the play merely mimics these complaints. It's all meander. Spurts of epigrams - 'I was never conservative enough to be a communist' - don't add up to an argument. A sentimental lurch at the end doesn't amount to a conclusion. Davison's design is awkward rather than unsettling: skyscrapers slant away in the background without looking vertiginous; a pile of furniture in one corner looks like a tidy person's attempt at putting a muddle together. fields.headline: It's a big venue. Make that six percussionists
fields.standfirst: Holst's Planets get a new ending, and Maxwell Davies goes out with a parp
fields.trailText: BBC Proms: Holst's Planets get a new ending, and Maxwell Davies goes out with a parp
fields.body:
BBC Proms Royal Albert Hall, London SW7

Seventy two concerts spread over two months, in a hall twice the size of your average concert hall: it's no surprise that so much of the music at the BBC Proms is so familiar. You wouldn't get the audiences any other way. The wonder is that, amid all the Greatest Hits, there is so much new music, so enthusiastically received. Nor do you get the sense that the applause is simply dutiful or polite, as it often appears at new music events.

Simon Rattle once described Magnus Lindberg as 'one-man living proof that the orchestra is not dead', and the fact that Rattle of all people expressed it in those terms tells us that there are indeed those who do see the symphony orchestra as superannuated. Not Lindberg. Last Saturday, Rattle's old band, the City of Birmingham Symphony Orchestra, gave the UK premiere of Lindberg's Fresco . If it didn't prove that Lindberg has reinvented the orchestra, he nevertheless finds new configurations, new colours in familiar places: the bass clarinet that bubbled away with sinister intent, the mighty battery of five percussionists beating out secret messages to each other.

Fresco plays with the Balinese gamelan's division between 'loud' (outdoor) and 'soft' (indoor), but the results are surging without relying on symphonic structure: no statement, no development - rather a capacious orchestral sweep seething with gorgeous detail. A shame that the work's closing gesture was at least partially compromised by the merry tinkling of a mobile phone.

Lindberg's piece was conducted by Rattle's CBSO replacement, Sakari Oramo, a crusader on behalf of the music of his native Finland, including Lindberg's. The rest of his programme, though, could hardly have been more British, more Proms: Elgar's Sea Pictures , sung with poise by Louise Winter; and Holst's The Planets , robustly played and with the addition of Colin Matthews's six-minute coda, 'Pluto the Renewer', receiving its London premiere.

No doubt there were many present who wanted to applaud Holst's 'Neptune' ending, but the way the violin seamlessly grafts Matthews's addendum on to the original denies them that pleasure. 'Pluto' begins low and slow, the trombones ominous, but it soon gallops away. ('Solar winds were my starting point,' says Matthews.) Twinkling strings, flutes and celesta create a suitably spacey atmosphere, raucously interrupted by brass and timpani. Then, reconnecting with the main work, Matthews introduces, for the briefest moment, the ghostly offstage chorus of Holst's last movement. The Planets will survive without it, but 'Pluto' is a worthy homage.

The previous evening, Peter Maxwell Davies conducted the London premiere of his Seventh Symphony in a performance by the BBC Philharmonic. The composer feels that the Seventh is the last in a cycle, from which the promised Eighth will stand apart, and his programme note acknowledges the influence of Haydn's symphonies and quartets, discernible, perhaps, in a certain good humour that continually bubbles to the surface. The symphony requires no fewer than six percussionists, but did not feel percussion-heavy. Indeed, the tiny rhythmic filigrees for cymbal and the melancholy little trumpet statements that punctuated the piece had an airy, jazzy feel, while the final movement had several fragments of what I can only call tunes.

No great fan of Max's sym phonies, I was gripped for most of its 45 minutes. Its fits and starts seemed eminently dramatic, from the busy rush of the introduction to the single trumpet parp which brings the work to a sudden and apparently provisional close. Maxwell Davies is never the most elegant of conductors, and his podium exer tions left him visibly exhausted, but he communicates well with these players, for whom the Seventh is a kind of valedictory tribute.

Last Tuesday, the BBC National Orchestra of Wales under Tadaaki Otaka gave the world premiere of Rhian Samuel's Tirluniau (Landscapes) . Samuel provides all but Ordnance Survey grid references for the locations that inspired her, but these matter less than the landscape she herself creates. In the opening movement, 'Cromlech', the piquant combination of xylophone and piccolo hovered over sighing strings that in the second movement ('The Old Man of Storr') seemed to be reassembling shards of Debussy's Pelléas et Mélisande .

Samuel suggests that the third movement, 'Castell y Bere', ends in 'the cold resignation of despair'. That isn't how it felt to me: the effusive melody that had spread through the orchestra had too much life for that, and prepared the way for the exuberantly urban, almost minimalist surge of the final section, 'Lights in the Bay'. The orchestra dead? Not on the evidence of these four pieces.

 Last Tuesday's Prom is rebroadcast at 2pm tomorrow on Radio 3

 Fiona Maddocks is away

fields.headline: You've heard of walking on water...
fields.trailText: Fleeting Opera | Royal Ballet
fields.body:
Fleeting Opera River Thames

Royal Ballet Royal Opera House

'Hi', said the man on the mobile phone. 'I'm at the opera. I'd like to share this with you.' He was standing on the Peace Pagoda in Battersea Park, watching two barges tugging Max Couper's collaborative Fleeting Opera downriver. On board were Royal Opera singers and musicians, hugely amplified, and Deborah Bull and Tom Sapsford from the Royal Ballet, dancing Sapsford's choreography.

Battersea dogs, roller-bladers and late-night joggers were startled by the howling, shrieking racket bouncing off the water. Those forewarned of the performance, part of the London String of Pearls Millennium Festival, had brought picnics, cameras and phones. Everyone had a grin on their face. The 'waterborne artwork' delighted because it was so improbable - and so brief.

The illuminated barges, dragon boats with tall, serrated sails, moved against the tide for some 15 minutes, before returning at speed to repeat the spectacle. Trevor Wishart's music assaulted the ears; Sapsford's choreography was baffling and intriguing; the event had something to do with celebrating the river, life and all that, which was fine with us.

Sapsford and Bull have been involved in the Artists' Development Initiative programme, extending the Opera House's resources beyond its usual boundaries. Bruce Sansom, Royal Ballet dancer for the past 18 years, has also assisted as an administrator. He gave his last performance as a company principal on Tuesday, retiring at the age of 36 to learn (thanks to a training attachment with San Francisco Ballet) how to run a large ballet company.

Sansom made his first and last appearance as Lescaut, the heroine's polecat of a brother in MacMillan's Manon . He was paired with Gillian Revie as Manon, a trusting girl who bought his view that poverty was to be avoided at any price. Sansom transformed himself into a Lescaut syphilitically sick with corruption. His drunk scene with his mistress - Belinda Hatley, making a welcome return after eight months' absence through injury - was all the nastier for her bright insistence that nothing was wrong.

Sansom was given a warm-hearted, flower-filled farewell by company and audience alike. Royal Ballet supporters have had plenty of chances to hail dancers taking on new roles this season, from Sansom, Revie and Carlos Acosta in Manon to Darcey Bussell and Sylvie Guillem being daffy in The Concert. Johan Kobborg finally came to the fore as The Concert's manic lecher and as an unusually sympathetic Albrecht in Giselle.

He brings the Danish tradition of detailed characterisation to the role. His Albrecht is deeply smitten by Giselle (Miyako Yoshida). He kisses her hand so tenderly that when she replays the gesture in the mad scene, you want to weep for both of them. He almost cannot accept that his life is worth saving when she fends off the Wilis and disappears to her grave.

Thursday's 'white' act was underdanced by the matinée cast, with the exception of Kobborg. He is a valuable addition to the company, especially now that Acosta is going on to a guest contract. French guests Laurent Hilaire and Nicholas Le Riche were brought in to boost the Hochhauser summer season: gorgeous though they are, Jonathan Cope is their equal, and incomparable in the Royal Ballet repertoire. He has reached an astonishing peak this year - and he has the best legs in the business.

webTitle: Edinburgh festival: Julian Barratt and Noel Fielding

fields.headline: Dark side of the loons
fields.trailText: Julian Barratt and Noel Fielding are just good friends. Well, not just good friends: they are also The Boosh, the hippest, hottest comedy duo in the country.
fields.body:
Julian Barratt and Noel Fielding are just good friends. Well, not just good friends: they are also The Boosh, the hippest, hottest comedy duo in the country. They have been to Edinburgh twice. In their first year, as The Mighty Boosh , they won the Perrier Best Newcomer award. In their second year, as Arctic Boosh , they were nominated for the award proper. This year, with a radio show in the pipeline, and 'TV people seriously interested', they are strong favourites to win the Perrier and become the first millennial youth icons of British comedy. You hate them, don't you?

Don't. I know it sounds sickly, all this youth and good looks and hipness. I know they're featured in magazines such as the Face and Jockey Slut , and they have the kind of just-got-out-of-bed haircuts that require 30 minutes' preparation every morning... but The Boosh are not like that, really. Certainly, they have a tastefulness in fashion, films and music alien to most comics (who traditionally prefer brown suits, Carry On Up the Khyber and Oasis), and a pop-starry charisma alien to most pop stars these days. But they also have talent, a work ethic and an interpersonal chemistry.

So... just good friends. During the photoshoot, as they fondle each other's 'man-boobs' and chat in low tones, I mention the H-word: homoerotic. Fielding, the 27-year-old, long-haired, narcissistic, elfin one with the mockney accent, flinches. The 'gay love' aspect of their partnership has been overemphasised, he complains, seemingly unaware that he looks exactly like Mark Owen, the 'cute one' from Take That.

None the less, there is definitely a core of mutual affection and understanding between Barratt and Fielding. 'I think almost all of our chemistry as a duo is down to being close friends,' nods Barratt, the 32-year-old, tall, brooding, existentially troubled one with the rich Yorkshire accent (whom you may recognise from the Metz television advert, where he plays a 'freelance scientist' who talks about 'the judder'). He laughs bitterly. 'After all, we spend every fucking day together! We play tennis and hang out. If you took away the affection, you'd remove a big part of the dynamic.'

You play tennis? 'Yeah,' Fielding smiles, 'we're doubles partners, we play against the guys from Sneaker Pimps [with whom Barratt lives]. He's got really powerful groundstrokes and I'm the master of the net.'

Do you have girlfriends? They both smile knowingly. 'Yeah, and they both joke about us being married,' says Fielding. Pause. 'And the sex gets on their nerves a bit,' Barratt adds, scratching his nose.

This is as close to a conventional gag as The Boosh get, either in interview or on stage. In conversation, they are, like most comedians, unremittingly intense and sincere. As for their show... well, it's hard to describe, but one thing it's not is conventional comedy. They've been compared to Morecambe and Wise and Alice in Wonderland, Reeves and Mortimer and Beckett; they've been labelled Dadaist, surrealist, and plain goddamn weird.

Their debut Edinburgh show, The Mighty Boosh , was a loose ragbag of non-sequiturs and postmodern slapstick, based around a narrative in which two zookeepers are sucked through their boss's eye into a jungle. Last year's Arctic Boosh was more structured and mature, featuring a sweet-and-sour love story of two postmen and their quest to find a magic egg in the North Pole.

This year's show, which I saw as a work-in-progress at London's Riverside Studios two weeks ago, is noticeably darker. Entitled Auto Boosh , it is the tale of two friends going on holiday to a country cottage. Barratt's character, depressed by his sidekick's cheeky whims, drives off and picks up a psychotic hitch-hiker seemingly modelled on the scary character from The Shamen's 'Ebeneezer Goode' video. Conducted mostly in half-darkness, it descends into a child's nightmare - Chitty Chitty Bang Bang meets Blue Velvet .

'Yeah, it is a bit darker,' muses Barratt. 'We didn't want to repeat ourselves, but we wanted to maintain the Booshness of it... it's been really difficult to write, this one. In fact,' he says, rubbing a bloodshot eye with the ball of his thumb, 'the last two months have probably been the hardest of my life.'

'We kept changing our minds about where we wanted it to go,' Fielding elaborates. 'It's been quite tortuous, actually.'

(They don't mention the pressure, but their publicist acknowledges that there is a huge expectation this year. 'They're at a point where, if they don't win the Perrier, it will look like a disappointment,' she says.)

'We always have loads of weird coincidences when we write a show,' says Fielding, sounding slightly unhinged. Everything's been eyes recently...'

'I play the rationalist card,' Barratt interposes. 'Your mind is so focused on the show that everything becomes linked with it...'

'Our characters are boiling, they're bleeding...'

By now, they are talking over each other, sounding ever more manic and making hardly any sense at all. I ask about their new 'third member', Dave, who does neither photographs nor interviews, but plays several important characters in the show.

Fielding's eyes go all gooey. 'Dave's really positive and happy,' he smiles. 'Or rather, he was until he got involved with us. Working with me and Julian, it's all black, fizzing nightmares.'

 Auto Boosh is at Pleasance Two, 7.30pm, 2-28 August

Barratt's character, depressed by his sidekick's cheeky whims, drives off and picks up a psychotic hitch-hiker seemingly modelled on the scary character from The Shamen's 'Ebeneezer Goode' video. Conducted mostly in half-darkness, it descends into a child's nightmare - Chitty Chitty Bang Bang meets Blue Velvet . 'Yeah, it is a bit darker,' muses Barratt. 'We didn't want to repeat ourselves, but we wanted to maintain the Booshness of it... it's been really difficult to write, this one. In fact,' he says, rubbing a bloodshot eye with the ball of his thumb, 'the last two months have probably been the hardest of my life.' 'We kept changing our minds about where we wanted it to go,' Fielding elaborates. 'It's been quite tortuous, actually.' (They don't mention the pressure, but their publicist acknowledges that there is a huge expectation this year. 'They're at a point where, if they don't win the Perrier, it will look like a disappointment,' she says.) 'We always have loads of weird coincidences when we write a show,' says Fielding, sounding slightly unhinged. Everything's been eyes recently...' 'I play the rationalist card,' Barratt interposes. 'Your mind is so focused on the show that everything becomes linked with it...' 'Our characters are boiling, they're bleeding...' By now, they are talking over each other, sounding ever more manic and making hardly any sense at all. I ask about their new 'third member', Dave, who does neither photographs nor interviews, but plays several important characters in the show. Fielding's eyes go all gooey. 'Dave's really positive and happy,' he smiles. 'Or rather, he was until he got involved with us. Working with me and Julian, it's all black, fizzing nightmares.'  Auto Boosh is at Pleasance Two, 7.30pm, 2-28 August

fields.headline: You're going to die laughing
fields.trailText: Cabaret Balkan | Butterfly's Tongue | The Flintstones in Viva Rock Vegas | Titan AE
fields.body:
Cabaret Balkan (100 mins, 18) Directed by Goran Paskaljevic; starring Miki Manojlovic, Nebojsa Glogovac, Mirjana Jokovic

Butterfly's Tongue (95 mins, 15) Directed by José Luis Cuerda; starring Fernando Fernán-Gómez, Manuel Lozano

The Flintstones in Viva Rock Vegas (90 mins, PG) Directed by Brian Levant; starring Mark Addy, Stephen Baldwin, Kristen Johnston, Alan Cumming

Titan AE (94 mins, PG) Directed by Don Bluth and Gary Goldman; starring the voices of Matt Damon, Nathan Lane, Drew Barrymore, Bill Pullman

John Frankenheimer's attractively titled thriller Reindeer Games was released here last month as Deception and did even worse at the box office than in the States. Are titles important? Can a good one make a movie successful? Can a bad one ruin its chances? Clearly no one in the business has a clue. So for a century film companies have been switching titles at random, invariably showing foreign movies under titles that have no connection with the originals.

I raise the matter now because Stephen Daldry's Dancer, which attracted good notices in Cannes, is to be released in Britain as Billy Elliot, and the Yugoslav film that has picked up prizes all over Europe as The Powder Keg (a literal translation of the original) arrives here as Cabaret Balkan, the title bestowed on it by American distributors.

Written and directed by Goran Paskaljevic, the original title refers to the powder keg of Belgrade in 1998, when every situation and everybody seem on the point of exploding. The American title is intended to evoke Bob Fosse's Cabaret, and indeed the movie makes intermittent use of a master of ceremonies at a sleazy Belgrade night club called the Cabaret Balkan. A sort of chorus figure, he rants obscenely and nihilistically about the absurdity of life, the beauty of death, how outsiders laugh at the Balkans and how all who live there hate themselves. The film, however, isn't at all pretentious, though it's certainly black and wild.

Like a good many films recently - Pulp Fiction, Short Cuts, Wonderland, Magnolia, for instance - it contains a succession of stories in which numerous lives intersect, often without them realising. Here, a taxi driver plies his trade in Belgrade one wintry night, transporting people to rendezvous with mayhem and death. Anger and frustration are everywhere - a boxer mur ders his oldest friend in a gym shower after hearing confessions of treachery; a professor-turned-bus driver kills a psychotic hijacker; a mild-mannered professional goes berserk after his old VW Beetle has been damaged by a joyrider; a girl produces a hand-grenade in a railway compartment to lethal effect; and so on. The taxi driver himself is responsible for crippling a policeman who had once beaten him so badly he'd been left sterile. There are three attempted rapes and at least seven violent deaths.

Exuding a terrible energy, Cabaret Balkan depicts a fractured society canalising its natural exuberance into self-destructive rage. The mode is black comedy, but there are few occasions for mirth and the most terrible and unexpected killing comes after the most blatant invitation to laughter.

José Luis Cuerda's Butterfly's Tongue is a gentle rites-of-passage movie set in a small town in north-west Spain in the summer of 1936. Through the wonderfully expressive eyes of the eight-year-old Moncho (Manuel Lozano) we view a decent, tight-knit community that within a few months will be divided by a brutal civil war. Moncho's father is the local tailor, a man of Republican sympathies, his mother is a strict Catholic taught by her priest to hate the government. But the greatest influence on the boy is an elderly schoolmaster (a rich performance by veteran Fernando Fernán-Gómez), a left-wing humanitarian with anarchist leanings, a deep commitment to liberty and an understanding of nature.

This is scarcely a picture that bears comparison with The Spirit of the Beehive, Víctor Erice's masterpiece that touches on similar themes just after the civil war. But it's an observant, kindly film with a good feeling for time and place, and it has quite a kick in its final sequence.

Having laughed like a drain at Stonehenge Kit the Ancient Brit, the comic strip in doggerel that appeared weekly in Knockout from 1939 to 1950, I'm in no position to throw the first, or any stone, at the inane The Flintstones in Viva Rock Vegas. This is a prequel to The Flintstones, the 1994 live action version of the 1960s Hanna-Barbera TV cartoon, and explains how tubby Fred Flintstone (Mark Addy) and his thin sidekick Barney Rubble (Stephen Baldwin), the moronic prehistoric ancestors of Laurel and Hardy, came to meet their spouses, Wilma (Kristen Johnston) and Betty (Jane Krakowski). The performers manage to keep embarrassment at bay (no mean feat) and, as Wilma's bitchy socialite mother, Joan Collins reprises her Dynasty role.

As we approach Kubrick's numinous 2001 the brave new world promised by his space odyssey seems farther away than it did in 1968. Why, then, does the widescreen animated movie Titan AE seem so flat and stale? Because it has no new light to throw on the future, its blueprints for the year 3028 AD being carbon copies of other people's ideas.

The hero, Cale (voiced by Matt Damon), a surly lad, is charged with saving mankind and recovering Earth from evil aliens by finding his father's spaceship, the Titan. This is watered down Star Wars and the visuals, while technically competent, are unimaginative.

fields.headline: Keith, still the keyboard king
fields.trailText: Keith Jarrett
fields.body:
Keith Jarrett
Royal Festival Hall, London SE1

To borrow a phrase from Duke Ellington, Keith Jarrett is a musician 'beyond category'. His talents are apparently infinite. He has a complete grasp of the jazz idiom, has won awards for his recordings of Bach and Shostakovich, and has proved over and over again that he can produce hour-long solo piano improvisations so perfectly realised that they sound like fully worked-out compositions. One of these, The Köln Concert , recorded in 1975, has notched up sales of more than two million and is still selling. It is the most popular solo piano record ever.

For the past 16 years, one constant strand in Jarrett's diverse career has been a trio consisting of himself, bassist Gary Peacock and drummer Jack DeJohnette. Usually called the 'Standards Trio', because its material is drawn largely from the classic American song repertoire, this group has achieved superstar status on its own account. Last week, with tickets costing up to £50 each, it packed the Royal Festival Hall for two nights.

This was Jarrett's first British appearance since 1992, and he was reportedly still recovering from the debilitating ME which had kept him from performing for the past four years. No one knew what to expect. In the event, the concert, though understandably quite short, was a triumph.

It started with a surprise. For the whole first half, not even the briefest wisp of a standard tune surfaced in the Standards Trio's performance. Instead, they followed the typical Jarrett impro method - like lighting a fire using a match and a few small twigs and gradually adding to it until you have a good blaze going. A tiny phrase, a handful of notes, was all it took to set them off on a half-hour journey through a constantly changing landscape.

The group looks like a conventional piano-bass-drums jazz trio, and it can play conventional jazz trio music superbly, but can also do a great deal more. There are, for instance, very few solos. Instead, the focus is in constant motion. On a few occasions, DeJohnette's drums actually dictated the melody while Jarrett supplied percussion on the top notes of the keyboard. At one point, this became so outrageous that they both burst out laughing and Jarrett ended it by banging the piano lid down. Their friendship goes back to 1966, when Jarrett was 20 and DeJohnette 23. It shows.

When Jarrett is playing, he is possessed by the music and this is reflected in his body language. He plays standing up most of the time, sometimes bending his head right inside the piano. At other times, he leans far back on the piano stool, twists his body, kicks his legs out straight. It all seems quite normal after a while, partly because the gyrations reflect what is going on in the music. There was one particularly glorious passage, which started as a grave, hymn-like tune, complete with solid Victorian harmonies (leaning back, chin in the air). Gradually, this mutated into passionate, gospel-soul (standing, shaking head) until dying away in a sequence of quiet, minor-key chords (sitting, nose almost touching keys).

A few standards finally emerged towards the end of the concert, to the obvious delight of the crowd. Even here, Jarrett's phrasing is impossibly slippery and asymmetrical, yet exquisitely simple and clear, too. That is what makes his music, even his hour-long solo improvisations, so attractive to so many people.
