webTitle: Film of the week: The Perfect Storm

fields.headline: The price of fish...
fields.standfirst: It's hard enough earning a living at sea. Add a hurricane or two and things get really difficult
fields.trailText: It's hard enough earning a living at sea. Add a hurricane or two and things get really difficult
fields.body:
The Perfect Storm (129 mins, 12) Directed by Wolfgang Petersen; starring George Clooney, Mark Wahlberg, John C. Reilly

Wolfgang Peterson's vivid account of life aboard a German submarine in the Second World War, Das Boot, is one of the great movies about seafaring. His new film, The Perfect Storm, though not quite in the same class, is, nevertheless, fit to be moored alongside it.

The film is adapted by Bill Wittliff from Sebastian Junger's riveting documentary book about 'the storm of the century' that occurred around Hallowe'en 1991, when a hurricane moving north from Bermuda collided off the north-west coast of America with an Arctic blast moving south and an unusual cold front coming across Canada from the Great Lakes. In this context 'perfect' is an ironic meteorological term meaning 'the worst imaginable'.

At the centre of the book and the film is a swordfishing boat, the Andrea Gail, working the Grand Banks from the port of Gloucester, Massachusetts, where the walls of the old town hall, seen in the opening sequence, record the names of the 10,000 fishermen lost at sea since 1623. We're introduced to the ship's captain, Billy Tyne (George Clooney), and his crew as they return with a catch much inferior to that of a friendly rival, the Hannah Boden, skippered by Linda Greenlaw (Mary Elizabeth Mastrantonio).

Is Tyne's luck running out? Is the Grand Banks fishing ground becoming depleted? The crew are disappointed with their rewards, the owner of the Andrea Gail (unsympathetic Michael Ironside) sneers at the captain he employs. In consequence, Tyne decides to put to sea again two days later in a last attempt to retrieve a bad season.

The Perfect Storm is much influenced by Howard Hawks. It's the story of dedicated professionals who work together at dangerous jobs, respecting each other's skills. Fishing is what they do - because they love it or because it promised to pay well or because it's all they know. The women stoically stand by or they act like the men (Mastrantonio is an archetypal Hawksian woman) or they go away.

Most of the men are either anguished divorcés, dedicated loners or on the point of giving up the sea for a woman. In a traditional scene at their gathering place, the Crow's Nest Tavern, their characters are established ready for the central business of the film - the effects of the storm. Like miners, they belong to a close community that practises a physically demanding trade living with memories of tragedies and knowing that disaster might strike any time.

Eventually, the Andrea Gail puts out to sea, John Seale's photography giving the movie a crisp, clear, bracing feel, James Horner's emphatic score underlining the heroic aspect of the adventure. At first, the fish are brought in steadily on the 40 mile-long nets. But there's conflict between the unhappy Murph (John C. Reilly) and the difficult newcomer Sully (William Fichtner), which is broken up by the reliable Bugsy (John Hawkes) and the happy-go-lucky Jamaican, Alfred Pierre (Allen Payne).

Then a shark they accidentally land injures the first mate, Bobby (Mark Wahlberg) and Murph is dragged overboard and nearly killed. When the catch drastically falls off, Tyne persuades them to go further out to a better fishing ground. Meanwhile, the meteorologist at a Boston TV station starts noticing the freak weather pattern.

This is a story of man against an implacable, remorseless nature, not a factitious tale of confronting sea monsters or waterborne terrorists. But at its centre are the effects of economic imperatives. The boat is out because the crew need the money, and at a crucial juncture the ice-making machinery breaks down because of the owner's cost-cutting, so no more fish can be taken.

A choice arises between heading home through the storm with their catch or evading the storm by going further out and thus having to ditch a catch they can't preserve. The voyage begins with them thinking of their living; it ends with them fighting for their lives.

The storm is a stunning, gut-wrenching piece of film-making that leaves the spectator shattered. Petersen cuts between the community's agonies on land in Gloucester and the events at sea. In addition to the Andrea Gail, there's a foundering yacht to be helped, a rescue helicopter in desperate need of aerial re-fuelling, a merchant ship whose containers are being swept away like so many Lego bricks, and the Hannah Boden from which Greenlaw is relaying messages to the increasingly isolated Andrea Gail. The special effects are astonishing, but they never detract from the human story, which is old-fashioned in the finest sense.

The cast look like real working men who've lived hard, open-air lives. Their dialogue is laconic and given our postmodern times and the fact that even at sea they watch a lot of action videos, they are perhaps aware of the roles they act out. After one fisherman is thanked by a hostile colleague whose life he's helped save, he remarks: 'You'd have done the same for me - isn't that what I'm supposed to say?'

I was caught up in this movie far more than I was in Jaws and there's a memorial service in the Gloucester church that is every bit as moving as the funeral of Spencer Tracy in Captains Courageous, a picture that inevitably comes to mind. The first chapter of Junger's book has an unforgettable epigraph from Walter Scott's novel, The Antiquary : 'It's no fish ye're buying, it's men's lives.' I wish they'd quoted this in the film.

fields.headline: Sweet Williams
fields.standfirst: Kathryn Williams is up for the Mercury Prize. She certainly needs the cash
fields.trailText: Kathryn Williams is up for the Mercury Prize. She certainly needs the cash.
fields.body:
Kathryn Williams has spent the morning sleeping off a hangover. The day before, she made it on to this year's Mercury Music Prize short list. She had to scrape together the £200 entry fee and, second time around, the gamble has paid off. 'Bloody hell... God... wow,' she says softly, poring over my crumpled bit of Guardian . Nearly all the papers concentrated on the 26-year-old singer-songwriter from Liverpool who made her first album for £80 and runs her own label from the spare room of her terraced house in Newcastle. Fellow nominee Richard Ashcroft hardly got a look-in.

Williams is occupying the novelty space given over in recent years to the token folkie on the list of 12 - Kate Rusby, Eliza Carthy, Norma Waterson - except she isn't a folk singer. 'There's no tradition in what I do,' she says, almost apologetically, in a small, Scouse voice softened by a few years on Tyneside. 'There's no tradition in the lyrics, in the sort of chords I use or anything. I just happen to use an acoustic guitar and sing quietly.'

It is the still, clear quiet of her delivery that has had critics rolling over. Her nominated second album, Little Black Numbers (Caw Records) is a set of melancholy, introspective songs - most begin 'I' or 'You' - backed by double bass, cello, percussion, the odd saxophone riff and shimmer of Hammond organ. Van Morrison's Astral Weeks is an obvi ous touchstone, up there with Joni Mitchell, Carole King, Bob Dylan. Her lyrics are meaningful in a vague sort of way: The opening line is: 'You said clichés come from the truth/ Of beauty everyone feels they can own.'

At her Camden Town gig last Thursday, rapt twentysomethings sat on the floor like infants for storytime, nodding proprietorially, hugging their knees. 'The album was made with emotion. I try and sing it every time with emotion. If I'm putting all that effort in, you should cry,' she tells me, with pretend menace.

Williams still seems shellshocked after yesterday's media scrum. We're sitting at either end of a big sofa in her PR's office; her head is sunk into her shoulders and she's holding her arms together in front of her as if I may be about to hit her. 'I'm not in it to be famous,' she says, sinking further into the cushions. 'I love my life. It's simple, quiet. Some would say boring as hell - a nice night in with a pizza and the telly and the cats, a walk on the beach. And this is my job and now I'm a bit scared.'

This is the woman who has boldly rejected the lucrative advances of every A&R person in London. 'Someone heard "Soul to Feet" and said, "Can you write seven or eight more like that one?"' she says, remembering one of the more dismal encounters. 'I choose to have control and no money. I'm not on a crusade. All I'm doing is putting the music and myself first.'

She agrees that penury concentrates the creative mind. Her double bassist tries to sound like a theremin on 'Fell Down Fast'; Laura Reid, her cello collaborator, simulates feedback. But having no money is 'a worry... if I can sell about another three or four thousand albums, I'll be just about sorted as far as debts are concerned'.

If she won the £20,000 Mercury Prize in September, (she is currently the 20-1 outsider) she would tax and MOT the car, go on a foreign holiday with her boyfriend. 'It's a hell of a lot of money,' she says. 'I'd be able to make a new album. It's half written. I don't want to be a charity case - "she should win it cos she's poor" - and I don't think I will win. I'm just writing songs; I'm not trying to be astounding.'

Kathryn Williams, mistress of self-deprecation, moved from Liverpool to Newcastle to study art, gave up gouache for the guitar, and spent a year in bed writing songs. Her big break came last autumn at the Barbican's tribute evening to Nick Drake. Way down the bill, she stole the show before she opened her mouth to sing 'Summer Sun', by virtue of being so visibly terrified. 'I went to get my coat and they said you're on, and they put the guitar in my hands and basically pushed me towards the stage. It was like floor-to-ceiling people and then the orchestra didn't start... I was meant to give the cue... when I got off stage, it was amazing, the sound of clapping, it was deafening.'

After the Barbican, P.J. Harvey's engineer, Head, offered to be her producer and her lo-fi became inten tional. 'Head always says that hiss is our friend,' she laughs. 'You let imperfections go by if there's an emotion there.'

Often in her songs, feeling seems to stem from a sense of being wronged. 'I think it's the only way that I can be that honest and say, "Look, you are a fucking wanker, fuck off", because if I saw them on the street I'd go "Hi!"' Otherwise, her songs are about the little things in life: 'Why am I here?; Do I believe in a god or don't I?; What's the point of me?... you know, just things.'

She must find the Queen of Bedsit Angst' tag annoying. 'Well, yeah,' she says, pulling herself out of the sofa finally. She says that Leonard Cohen has the same problem (not the queen bit), even though he's quite humorous really. So if she were to sum herself up? 'If I was to sum myself up, I'd say 20-1.'

fields.headline: The fringe
fields.trailText: I'm outraged! Recently on ITV, during a Saturday afternoon showing of  The Man With the Golden Gun, the famous 'he's got three nipples' scene is cut to 'he's got three...' for fear of offending some voracious letter writer from deepest Middle England. And yet Keith Chegwin is allowed to wave his penis about on Channel 5 willy-nilly. Meanwhile, in the Edinburgh Festival Fringe office, a young comic (me) is banned from using a word. Not a swear word. A word that means a cheap, low-class, ill-mannered and possibly ugly Jew which, aside from the ugly, is sort of what I am.
fields.body:
I'm outraged! Recently on ITV, during a Saturday afternoon showing of The Man With the Golden Gun, the famous 'he's got three nipples' scene is cut to 'he's got three...' for fear of offending some voracious letter writer from deepest Middle England. And yet Keith Chegwin is allowed to wave his penis about on Channel 5 willy-nilly. Meanwhile, in the Edinburgh Festival Fringe office, a young comic (me) is banned from using a word. Not a swear word. A word that means a cheap, low-class, ill-mannered and possibly ugly Jew which, aside from the ugly, is sort of what I am.

My show this year is called A Little Piece of Kike. But the Festival Fringe office said the word 'kike' is offensive and obscene. There then followed one of the most bizarre conversations of my life as we negotiated over asterixes. They wanted K***. I wanted K*KE. We settle on K**E. Confused? You might be. A Little Piece of Kite? Kale? Knee?

This nonsense goes on all the time. Before performing a short comedy routine on Pebble Mill at One , I had to clear every word of my act with a researcher. The crunch came when I mentioned the word 'arse'.

'You can't say arse on Pebble Mill ,' she said.

'How about bum then?' I asked.

'Hang on a minute,' she said.

There was a brief, muffled consultation. She said: 'You can't use bum on daytime TV.' 'What about bottom?' 'No bottoms,' she says. 'Behind?' I ventured. 'Surely behind is OK?' 'Yes, behind is perfectly acceptable'. 'How about "Up the Gary Glitter?"' I said, but she didn't get the joke.

I understand that there have to be limits. I don't want my two-year-old son catching Milo from the Tweenies using 'alehouse language', as my Auntie Irene calls it. But we're all adults, aren't we? So we should express ourselves in a grown-up fashion.

I was interviewed about the Kike controversy twice in one day on the same radio station. On the early show I was allowed to say it, but they weren't. By the evening, we all kiked happily away. I'm a kike and proud of it. But someone has taken it upon themselves to act as guardian of the Hebrew nation. The funny thing is, the Hebrew nation couldn't give a fuck. (Well, my Auntie Irene's not too happy but...)

 A Little Piece of Kike is at the Assembly Rooms, 3-28 Aug

webTitle: Edinburgh festival: Our critics' choice  of what to see

fields.headline: Our critics' choice  of what to see
fields.standfirst: Tunes from the tenth century and Mozart marathons, Dutch treats and  New York break dancing, bolts of lightning and Martian invasions
fields.trailText: Tunes from the tenth century and Mozart marathons, Dutch treats and  New York break dancing, bolts of lightning and Martian invasions
fields.body:
Music and opera by Fiona Maddocks

Music of the Millennium: Ten concerts featuring music from the past 1,000 years, starting with the Music of Bruno of Toul (1000-1100) and Hildegard of Bingen (1100-1200) sung by Gothic Voices. 14 August, Rosslyn Chapel and 16 Aug , St Mary's Cathedral. Continues with Dufay, Josquin, Palestrina and (on 27 Aug) Monteverdi's Vespers performed by the Taverner Consort. Ends on 2 September with Nono, Kurtag and MacRae.

Mozart piano concertos: A typical Edinburgh marathon in which Christian Zacharias, as pianist and director, performs Mozart's piano concertos with the Scottish Chamber Orchestra. Usher Hall, 14, 16, 18, 20, 22, 27 Aug

Ensemble Modern: This virtuoso ensemble in Steve Reich's Drumming Part 1 and Music for 18 Musicians. Edinburgh Playhouse, 1, 2 Sept

Stuttgart Opera
makes its festival debut with a production by Jossi Wieler of Handel's popular Alcina. Edinburgh Festival Theatre, 14, 16, 17 Aug

Scottish Opera embark on Wagner's Ring cycle in a new staging by Tim Albery over four years. In the first of the four operas, Das Rheingold , Wotan is sung by Matthew Best, Alberich by Peter Sidhom. Edinburgh Festival Theatre, 21, 23, 26, 28 Aug

Opera North visit the festival with a new staging by David Pountney of Schumann's Genoveva, hard on the heels of Garsington. King's Theatre, 31 Aug and 2 Sep

Also look out for concert performances at the Edinburgh Festival Theatre of Chausson's Le Roi Arthus with Simon Keenlyside in the title role (22 Aug) and Fauré's ravishing Pénélope (27 Aug).

Dance by Jann Parry

New York City Ballet: Long-awaited return of the top-notch company George Balanchine founded to serve his vision of New World ballet. There are three programmes of all-time favourites, displaying the company in depth. Edinburgh Playhouse, 17-19 Aug

Nederlands Dans Theatre: Director Jirí Kylián's farewell season brings all three NDT companies from The Hague. Edinburgh Festival Theatre, 29, 30 Aug and 1, 2 Sep. Playhouse, 30, 31 Aug

NDT1 performs his early works, with the Czech Philharmonic and Sir Charles Mackerras in the pit; NDT2 (juniors) and NDT3 (seniors) share a mixed bill; all three combine for Arcimboldo 2000, a spectacular conclusion.

Break! Among the Fringe offerings is this exposition of break dancing, popping, locking and tap from inner-city New York. Dynamic Earth, 2-13 Aug. Tickets 0131 530 3557

Poetic and Feral: Solos by David Hughes and Jan de Schynkel, both ex-Rambert, in a mixed bill. Dynamic Earth, 22-28 Aug

Déjà Donné: Lenka Flory's acclaimed Czech company perform Aria Spinta, a 'tragi-comic metaphorical dance cabaret' about life at the cutting-edge. St Bride's Centre, 21, 22, 27, 28, 30, 31 Aug. Tickets 0131 346 1405

Theatre by Susannah Clapp

Thunderstruck: Lightning kills the parents of three backwoods brothers and their 'somnambulant but magically glowing' sister. The Canadian group One Yellow Rabbit are surreal. Traverse Theatre, 16-26 Aug

Hamlet: Directed by Peter Zadek, the German actress Angela Winkler takes the title role and has been acclaimed as 'the Hamlet of the century' in the production from the Deutsches Schauspielhaus, Hamburg. Royal Lyceum Theatre, 30 Aug to 2 Sept

Abandonment: This comedy by the Whitbread Prize-winning novelist Kate Atkinson features woodworm, chaos theory and a girl who wants to be alone. Traverse Theatre, 3-26 Aug

War of the Worlds: The Siti Company of New York have created a production examining the mysteries and genius of Orson Welles and, for one night, they also perform a theatrical adaptation of the radio broadcast that terrified America. Royal Lyceum Theatre, 24-27 Aug; radio play 25 Aug

Splendour: Vicky Featherstone directs Abi Morgan's play about 'decadence, desire and dictatorship'. Traverse Theatre, 5-26 Aug

Medea: Before embarking on a national tour later in the year, Liz Lochhead's new version is in Edinburgh. Assembly Rooms, 3-11 Aug

Mil Quinientos Metros Sobre el Nivel de Jack: A special area has been built backstage for this Spanish play about a deep-sea diver and a woman who lives in a bath. Edinburgh Festival Theatre, 23, 24, 26, 27 Aug

The Green Room: William Cash's sexual comedy is about A.J. Ayer, free will, and near-death experiences. Komedia @ Southside, 4-13 Aug

Art by Laura Cumming

Paul Klee: The Bürgi Collection: The only British showing of this 130-strong private collection of the Swiss artist's work. Scottish National Gallery of Modern Art, 12 Aug to 22 Oct

Constable's Clouds: Around 80 works on loan alongside the gallery's own Dedham Vale. National Gallery of Scotland, 11 Aug to 29 Oct

Men of the Clyde The huge paintings from Stanley Spencer's 1940-47 wartime commission to paint Glasgow's shipyards are a truly monumental commemoration of those who worked in them. Scottish National Portrait Gallery until 1 Oct

Jon Schuyler Fine exhibition on loan from the artist's widow reflecting his love of a small Scottish village which he visited annually. Ingleby Gallery

Comedy by Sam Taylor

Dave Gorman: Are You Dave Gorman? He's different from other comics, in that he has ideas. Last year's was to create a better world. This year's is to track down 100 other Dave Gormans. Pleasance Above, 7.10pm

Rich Hall is Otis Lee Crenshaw: One of America's finest stand-ups presents the further musical and carnal adventures of his wondrous, ex-con country singer. Pleasance Cabaret Bar, 9.25pm

Jerry Sadowitz: The world's most infamously misanthropic magician does amazing close-up tricks and swears at you. Assembly Rooms, Edinburgh Suite, 8pm

Websites

International Festival
Fringe
Film Festival
Gilded Balloon

Tourist information: 0131 473 3800

For tickets for International Festival: 0131 473 2000

For tickets for Fringe: 0131 226 5138

For Traverse tickets: 0131 228 1404

fields.headline: The rock'n'roll years
fields.standfirst: You can tell something about the state of the nation at any given time from which rock bands are the most popular. So what do Coldplay and Travis say about Britain in 2000?
fields.trailText: You can tell something about the state of the nation at any given time from which rock bands are the most popular. So what do Coldplay and Travis say about Britain in 2000?
fields.body:
In 1966 it was The Beatles and The Rolling Stones, the election of Harold Wilson, and the start of the great psychedelic trip. In 1977 it was the Sex Pistols and The Clash, the early rise of Margaret Thatcher and the death of Elvis Presley. In 1983 it was Duran Duran and Culture Club, Union Jacks in the street and the impending demise of heavy industry. Over the past 35 years the nation's favourite bands have been more than just signals of changing fashion; they have served as little mirrors to the nation itself.

I was thinking about this as I listened to 'Yellow', the current hit single by Coldplay, on the car radio. It was followed by the usual hurried, bellowed Radio 1 news segment: reports on the latest disillusioning government leak and the mountain of flowers and teddy bears growing near the spot where Sarah Payne's body was found. Beside me on the passenger seat, the Daily Mail 's front page screamed for 'the return of hanging'. In the traffic-jammed street where I drove in first gear, rain fell monotonously. The sky was a clammy grey.

The middle of July, and Britain felt shrivelled, unhappy, stuck in a twentieth-century timewarp (another politician letting us down, another explosion of sentimental grief for a stranger, another clamour to bring back the noose). And in the midst of this sad drip-drip-drip of leaks and drizzle, the nation's favourite band is... Coldplay, No 1 in the album charts and freshly nominated for the Mercury Music Prize with their debut, Parachutes. Coldplay are a taciturn, introverted, melancholic group of young men from Oxford; their music sounds like the eternal muted sigh of English desperation.

Alongside Coldplay at the top of the album charts are David Gray, another Englishman peddling low-key melancholia, and Travis, who have dominated the past 12 months with their wistful Scottish ballads. 'Why Does It Always Rain On Me?' Fran Healy sings... and a nation sings mournfully along.

Of course Coldplay et al are not the only sound of Britain in 2000. At the opposite extreme is the whooshing, good-time vibe of UK garage, and somewhere between them the perpetual stream of vacuous boy bands and teen queens selling sex and sentimentality to young children. But this divide is in itself indicative of a regressive change in British music in recent years: the segregation of rock and dance, which at one time seemed destined to interbreed with glorious results. Coldplay is what rock sounds like with all groove, happiness and hipness removed.

Think back 10 years. There were riots on the streets in protest at the poll tax, Thatcher was on her way out, and Britain's favourite rock bands were Happy Mondays and Stone Roses, two 'Madchester' groups whose guitar-bass-drums sound was looped into the euphoric vibes and electronic beats of acid house. The year began with the Roses' mighty 'Fools Gold' single and ripened into a summer of Gazzamania, Ibizan all-nighters and the Mondays' languid masterpiece, Pills'n'Thrills & Bellyaches. Under Tory rule, in the depths of economic depression, this was the sound of the counterculture, rebellious and hedonistic.

The following year was darker in tone, more progressive musically. While grunge skidded over like a dark cloud from Seattle and Operation Desert Storm turned warfare into 24-hour entertainment, British bands reached a new peak of experimentation. Primal Scream, formerly retro guitar losers, collaborated with DJ Andy Weatherall on Screamadelica, which still sounds futuristic nine years on. Meanwhile Massive Attack (whose very name was banned from broadcast during the Gulf war) brought songs and soulfulness to clubland. The future seemed bright.

The next two years were disappointing. America ruled, in the shape of Nirvana and R.E.M. The Roses, Mondays, Primals and Massive all vanished, leaving us the scant consolation of Stereo MC's, whose million-selling Connected album offered a lighter twist on the rock-dance hybrid. In 1993 - year of Jamie Bulger's murder and IRA bombs in the City of London - the desperate music press went overboard for Suede, and their glam-trash pop debut hit No 1. Image and articulacy became valued currencies again.

I remember hearing about Kurt Cobain's suicide on a car radio, driving to Brixton to see Primal Scream. During a dull concert, showcasing the band's retrogressive new album, Bobby Gillespie dedicated a song to Cobain and the music scene seemed suddenly directionless. In hindsight, however, that was the moment Britpop was born: the spectre of grunge was exorcised and, within months, new boys Oasis were being attacked on stage by drunken fans and Blur were top of the charts with Parklife .

All sorts of people now claim to hate Parklife - not least Blur themselves, who began to feel trapped inside its more cartoonish moments. Nevertheless, it remains a great album and a time capsule of rare potency. This was the sound of British guitar pop facing up to its own magnificent history and incorporating it into an exciting present of economic boom, social liberalisation, mass hedonism, and the decline and fall of the Conservative Party. But the euphoria let loose darker spirits - nostalgia, laddism, nationalism, corporatism - which would eventually sour and spoil the whole party a couple of years down the line.

At the time, though, the sudden elevation into the mainstream was exhilarating. After years of the debate over the nation's favourite band being confined to the letters page of NME, now it was on the Nine O'Clock News, Blur and Oasis battling it out for the No1 singles spot. Pundits stepped over each other to assign symbolism to this spat: it was North versus South, working-class versus middle-class, rock'n'roll yahoos versus art-school snobs. But the point was: here were two British bands who mattered, at least in Britain.

This was 14 August 1995 and, as Stuart Maconie noted in Q last year, it marked the beginning of a golden year when Britain became Cool Britannia (the New Labour rebranding came later, abruptly killing whatever cool was left) - which took in Oasis's multi-million-selling (What's the Story) Morning Glory? and their epochal concerts at Loch Lomond and Knebworth, the A-list celebrity coupledom of Damon Albarn/Justine Frischmann and Liam Gallagher/Patsy Kensit, a swarm of new platinum-selling British groups (Pulp, Supergrass, Elastica, the Boo Radleys), the corporate rise of dance music (Ministry of Sound, Cream, plus 'bands' such as the Chemical Brothers), and interrelated British success stories in fashion, football and art.

Radiohead's OK Computer presented a more claustrophobic, paranoid view of these pre-millennial years, but even here there was a kind of optimism. On 'Lucky' and 'Airbag', Thom Yorke sang of miraculously surviving car and plane crashes. Though the storm clouds were gathering ominously, there were still brilliant shafts of light.

By 1999, the musical barometer had changed again. The threat of a storm had cleared - people had stopped worrying about the millennium bug; only a few nutters feared the end of the world - but mass disillusion had set in. The Dome stood, a massive void bereft of ideas, as a symbol of the Government's hubris and inertia. Diana's legacy had become a squalid squabble over commercial rights and positive PR. Inflation and unemployment were low, but so was our sense of expectation. The monarchy was solid, commuters looked away glassily on the Tube and the British rock scene was moribund. People talked once again of the genre having passed its sell-by date. Britpop and Madchester seemed aeons away.

Most of the British bands who have mattered in the past 10 years have either disbanded (Happy Mondays, Stone Roses, The Verve,) or have turned into a self-parody (Oasis, Suede) or an irrelevance (Primal Scream, Blur, Pulp). The others - Radiohead and The Prodigy - appear to have given up trying to be commercially successful. Into this void have slipped the determinedly modest Travis and Stereophonics and their successors, Coldplay. Imageless, inarticulate, sensitive and serious, these are groups who 'let the music do the talking'.

But what is it saying? It may sound like an inoffensive, conventional mush of tuneful guitar pop, but if you listen closely you can hear its subliminal message: don't get your hopes up. These are just songs, we are just bands, it's pointless to expect more. We live on a sad little island, the drugs don't work, the news is always grim, the government will always be Tory, our sportspeople will always be losers. And it's raining.
fields.bodyText: In 1966 it was The Beatles and The Rolling Stones, the election of Harold Wilson, and the start of the great psychedelic trip. In 1977 it was the Sex Pistols and The Clash, the early rise of Margaret Thatcher and the death of Elvis Presley. In 1983 it was Duran Duran and Culture Club, Union Jacks in the street and the impending demise of heavy industry. Over the past 35 years the nation's favourite bands have been more than just signals of changing fashion; they have served as little mirrors to the nation itself. I was thinking about this as I listened to 'Yellow', the current hit single by Coldplay, on the car radio. It was followed by the usual hurried, bellowed Radio 1 news segment: reports on the latest disillusioning government leak and the mountain of flowers and teddy bears growing near the spot where Sarah Payne's body was found. Beside me on the passenger seat, the Daily Mail 's front page screamed for 'the return of hanging'. In the traffic-jammed street where I drove in first gear, rain fell monotonously. The sky was a clammy grey. The middle of July, and Britain felt shrivelled, unhappy, stuck in a twentieth-century timewarp (another politician letting us down, another explosion of sentimental grief for a stranger, another clamour to bring back the noose). And in the midst of this sad drip-drip-drip of leaks and drizzle, the nation's favourite band is... Coldplay are a taciturn, introverted, melancholic group of young men from Oxford; their music sounds like the eternal muted sigh of English desperation. fields.headline: 'I wasn't ever a Butlins redcoat. I just used to go there a lot'
fields.trailText: Three years ago, Johnny Vegas meandered on to an Edinburgh stage as if by accident and with no apparent strategy. Drunk, dishevelled and unruly, he was a complete contrast to all those unflappable, smart-aleck, observational comics.
fields.body:
Stand-up comedians often talk about the technique of their craft, sometimes adopting a macho lingo of their own, as if they were World War I pilots unwinding in the mess room.

It was a relief then, three years ago, when Johnny Vegas meandered on to an Edinburgh stage as if by accident and with no apparent strategy. Drunk, dishevelled and unruly, he was a complete contrast to all those unflappable, smart-aleck, observational comics.

Johnny was lecherous, out of control and he stumbled out in front of the audience with a potter's wheel under his arm. This last gimmick, naturally, marked him out from the crowd, but it was not simply a stunt. Vegas, whose real name is Michael Pennington, is a devoted potter and he was prepared to prove it on stage.

'It was like the audience were thinking, "Well, if it is true about the pottery, maybe all the other stuff he is saying, like about being a redcoat, is real too",' Vegas remembers.

The novelty pottery act worked like a dream, chiefly because audiences were looking for more than just another comedy 'character' along the lines of Al Murray, the pub landlord. Johnny's personality was interchangeable with that of his creator.

'In fact, though, I wasn't ever a Butlins redcoat. I just used to go there a lot for my holidays due to a kind of inverted snobbery,' he says.

Vegas, 29, is a determined debunker and is about as far away from a theatrical darling as it is possible to imagine. So it is surprising to learn that he is taking to the boards this festival in his first scripted play, The Erpingham Camp , by Joe Orton.

'The comics probably won't talk to me this year,' he says. 'There is a kind of rivalry between actors and comics and so I was worried about meeting the cast at first. I really didn't want to be another comedian who thinks he can act. At first we were going to do the play just with comedians, but it is much better like this.'

Vegas says the cast have generously taught him a lot. He has also had to learn to sing and dance a little. 'I have to do, "It was in a little gypsy tearoom", and it's done me throat in,' Vegas explains in a croaky Lancastrian lilt. 'The singing teacher said I reminded her of Josef Locke,' he goes on proudly, 'though on the second day she wasn't so sure.'

Vegas is cast as a put-upon, ultimately homicidal, holiday-camp entertainer and he has tried to bring all his fictional redcoat history to bear. Less fortuitously, he has had to have a radical haircut for the part. This would not matter so much if Johnny Vegas, the comic, was not also supposed to be in Edinburgh this summer.

'We are doing a game show for five nights,' he explains. 'We'll have prizes for each night, including a car for the end, I think. It is partly a crack at what the Fringe has become these days and it is partly because I wanted to make my act more interactive.

'The idea is Johnny hasn't worked out that as a host you are supposed to be impartial. He is so fickle, one minute rooting for team A then team B, which is what drunks are like, saying, "I love you" or "I hate you".'

Tales of Johnny's own drinking habits are already folklore on the circuit, but before the play at least, he has agreed to steer clear of his usual vodka and red wine chaser. The Erpingham Camp is a dark and violent bit of comedy and the actors need their wits about them.

'My dad is coming up to see the show, but I don't know what he will make of all the violence. He loves Fiddler on the Roof .'

Vegas, who grew up in St Helens, is the attention-seeking youngest child of a carpenter. 'I have two brothers who went into joinery like my dad. I am the black-sheep potter of the family,' he says.

For a while Vegas considered becoming a priest and went on to work at Argos. But pottery was his salvation; his work has now been exhibited around the country and four months ago one of his 60-second teapots was accepted by the Victoria and Albert Museum.

'I even did a show there and half the audience were potters, so all the jokes about glazes went down really well.'

At the same time, he is sceptical about a growing serious interest in his ceramic work. 'People want to buy my pots now in case I pop my clogs,' he notes.

 The Erpingham Camp is at the Assembly Rooms from 3-27 August

fields.headline: Diary
fields.standfirst: Our crime correspondent had found a director, a title, a star and a festival venue. But he still had to write his script...
fields.trailText: Our crime correspondent had found a director, a title, a star and a festival venue. But he still had to write his script...
fields.body:
1 January, 2000

After a lifetime of sitting in cinemas and saying: 'I could do better than that', I'm going to give it a go. I'm going to make a short film. I decide to take all my holiday and attend an eight-week filmmaking course in New York starting in August.

2 January

My girlfriend, Emma, announces, unexpectedly, that she is pregnant. Our baby is due 19 August.

4 March

Emma and I reach a compromise. I sign up for a weekend directing course in London. I also get a vague idea for a short film about a gangster's moll. On the course, I meet Sarah McGuinness, a former musician and theatre director who now wants to move into acting. I see her perform and decide she would be perfect for the part. I sit down to write but nothing comes. I give up on the moll and write a script based on a real-life road-rage incident.

18 April

I finish Rage! Sarah loves it but points out that the only parts are for Rastafarians. She asks about the moll piece. I tell her it's going well, then stare at a blank screen for a few hours.

27 April

I awake to find Sarah has left two messages on my voice mail and two more on my mobile phone. She sounds panicky. I call her back.

'Tony, hi. You know that piece you're writing.'

I bite my tongue. 'Yeah.'

'Well, rather than 10 minutes, do you think you could make it a monologue and stretch it to 50 minutes? If you could, we could take it to Edinburgh. The Gilded Balloon has one slot left. I need to know soon.'

'How soon?'

'Well, actually, I needed to know yesterday. In fact, I've already said yes. We have until this afternoon to come up with a title and a blurb for the Festival programme.'

After three hours of word association we come up with Whacked! , partly in tribute to my hero Neil Labute, whose play Bash! I had seen a few weeks earlier. Our tag- line is: 'A play about the thin line between loving someone and wanting to smash their face in with a baseball bat.' I still have no idea what it will actually be about.

10 May

I go through old interviews with gangsters and their girlfriends. What appeals is the way their lifestyle mixes glamour and the mundane. I jot down a few ideas - cleaning cocaine off the kitchen table in order to serve dinner, being annoyed about someone being stabbed in your living-room because you can't get the bloodstain out of the carpet.

16 May

Sarah starts calling in favours and working hard to get people excited about the project. She calls to tell me that Gari Jones might be willing to direct. He is a long-time collaborator of Harold Pinter's - he directed him in The Caretaker . He's only 29! Sarah explains that she has sent him the Rage! script and asks how Whacked! is coming. I change the subject.

18 May

Gari calls me. He loves Rage! He can't wait to read Whacked! Neither can I.

27 May

I don't know if it's any good. I send a few pages to some friends. The response is pos itive. I press on.

2 June

I feel I'm halfway there. I read it through and reach the end in 15 minutes. I start to panic.

4 June

Sarah calls to gently remind me that she needs at least six weeks to rehearse. And the script. I spend all day on it and write one new paragraph.

7 June

I come up with a sick twist. A really sick twist. I worry that it might be over the top. Then I meet Gari for the first time. He looks like a chain-smoking extra from Interview With a Vampire. He loves the twist. He starts asking detailed questions about the background of the character, Annie. It's an inspiration. I finish that same night.

8 June

There's a section in Whacked! where Annie describes in great detail a man being beaten to a pulp by her boyfriend. She does this in a matter-of-fact way as if she is talking about baking a cake. I wanted her doing something mundane, so I had her going behind a screen and changing her clothes. Gari moves the scene to another part of the play where it has greater significance. He also points out that, as the character is alone, the screen is unneces sary. Sarah shrieks: 'You bastards' then joins a gym and goes on a sushi and mineral-water diet.

10 June

Sarah calls to tell me that Sandy Powell, one of the world's most sought-after costume designers, has agreed to work on Whacked! She won the Oscar for Shakespeare in Love and also worked on Velvet Goldmine and Orlando . Good thing I didn't go to New York.

18 June

Sandy comes up with Annie's look. 'She's a bit like Victoria Beckham. Tacky but expensive.' Two days after delivering a brilliant costume, Sandy leaves to work on the new Scorsese film.

4 July

Rehearsals start. Gari takes Sarah through the text line by line. 'I want to make sure we have the right voice. I want Annie to be a real person.' Hearing the lines read out for the first time leads to a few rewrites and changes.

26 July

Disaster. The Gilded Balloon's programme puts Whacked! in its comedy section. On hearing the news, Gari speaks for all of us: 'But it's not fucking funny.'

 Whacked! is at the Gilded Balloon II, August 4-28. at www.whacked-the-performance.com

She does this in a matter-of-fact way as if she is talking about baking a cake. I wanted her doing something mundane, so I had her going behind a screen and changing her clothes. Gari moves the scene to another part of the play where it has greater significance. He also points out that, as the character is alone, the screen is unneces sary. Sarah shrieks: 'You bastards' then joins a gym and goes on a sushi and mineral-water diet. 10 June Sarah calls to tell me that Sandy Powell, one of the world's most sought-after costume designers, has agreed to work on Whacked! She won the Oscar for Shakespeare in Love and also worked on Velvet Goldmine and Orlando . Good thing I didn't go to New York. 18 June Sandy comes up with Annie's look. 'She's a bit like Victoria Beckham. Tacky but expensive.' Two days after delivering a brilliant costume, Sandy leaves to work on the new Scorsese film. 4 July Rehearsals start. Gari takes Sarah through the text line by line. 'I want to make sure we have the right voice. I want Annie to be a real person.' Hearing the lines read out for the first time leads to a few rewrites and changes. 26 July Disaster. The Gilded Balloon's programme puts Whacked! in its comedy section. On hearing the news, Gari speaks for all of us: 'But it's not fucking funny.'  Whacked! is at the Gilded Balloon II, August 4-28. at www.whacked-the-performance.com

fields.headline: Moral muse
fields.standfirst: I'm no longer in love with my girlfriend
fields.trailText: I'm no longer in love with my girlfriend
fields.body:
I've been seeing my girlfriend for four months and at the beginning of the relationship I was happy and madly in love with her. However, things have progressed and as she has become obviously attached to me, my feelings for her have diminished. Although I still fancy her, I know that we do not have enough shared interest between us. Is it just the usual question of cold feet or should I trust my instincts and get out before it develops into something which could hurt both of us?
E.M. of London

Your letter provokes speculation about the nature of sexual attraction, an enduring mystery which hopefully will never be reduced to a formula.

However, there seem to be two distinct components, like so many aspects of human behaviour; one primitive and physical, the other more cerebral and rational.

For a really good, enduring partnership the two have to be right. There is some scientific evidence, however, that within certain cultural constraints, attraction is remarkably random. This suggests that the primitive magnetism gets to work first, assisted by the hormones and probably physical gratification.

Then the process of imprinting - mutual exploration - tightens the bonds and the pairing off may be a fait accompli long before the spoilsport intellect manages to have a say in the matter.

Our superior brain power as well as modern mobility, which facilitates a larger field for exploration, should in theory enable us to pair off more rationally. I'm not sure, however, that theory is born out in practice.

Anthropologists believe that the male of the species is geared to seek for sex widely, working the field indiscriminately, motivated to spread his sperm around as profusely as possible.

Women, on the other hand, tend to be more selective, behaving as if looking for extra-special genes to pass on to future progeny.

Men seek quantity, women look for quality. Your letter encapsulates this difference neatly.

You seem to have a strong sexual attraction to the current infatuation but not much else. She, however, seems to be ready to commit to you.

Many men relish the excitement of the challenge, the chase, the mesmerising and the courtship - all the early stages of pair-bonding - so much that having conquered, they lose interest and want to repeat the whole exhilarating process with someone new.

This is the male equivalent of gypsy Carmen and like her you are put off in proportion to your friend's growing attachment.

Presumably the butterfly life-cycle habitually lasts about four months, and if this is the usual duration of your passion, it would be better to stop fooling yourself and the lady of the moment into thinking that this is anything other than a young man's lighthearted fancy.

You are just not ready for a long-lasting relationship. Cold feet are a euphemistic irrelevance.

Rather, your hot hormones and compliant gonads are leading you by the nose.

When you begin to engage your brain at the start instead of the close of a relationship, you might find your soul mate and put an end to the trail of broken hearts.

Readers' replies

You don't say in your letter how old you are. If you are still a young man in your twenties or early thirties then loyalty and commitment will come with maturity.

If, however, you are in your late thirties or forties then I would not hold out much hope of you maturing to the stage that you could hold down a steady relationship. You are obviously self-centred, unreliable and not worth bothering about. My advice would be to prepare yourself for a very lonely, bitter old age - it's not that far away.
K.T. of Wandsworth, London

Next week's dilemma

My 16-year-old son has been going out for some months with his first serious girlfriend. She is the same age. When my son spends the night at her house her parents allow them to share a bed. But when the girl comes to our house I insist on separate rooms.

I think they are too young for this kind of sexual relationship and I would feel very uncomfortable knowing that it was happening in my house. If they both were a couple of years older I would feel differently.

My attitude is causing some conflict with my son and I have been told that I am old-fashioned and out of step with the times.

My husband sympathises with my point of view but thinks it would be easier to turn a blind eye.

Oddly enough our daughter, who is in her mid-twenties and recently married, agrees with me.

I would like to know your views on the subject.
V.C. OF London

Write to Observer Review or email margaret.cook@observer.co.uk. Views on each week's problem to reach us by Wednesday. Margaret Cook writes for Woman's Journal

fields.headline: Sorry, no children
fields.standfirst: We live in a child-friendly society. But what about people who don't want to have kids? In America, the 'child-free' are already a political pressure group. Could it happen here too?
fields.trailText: We live in a child-friendly society. But what about people who don't want to have kids? In America, the 'child-free' are already a political pressure group. Could it happen here too?
fields.body:
Jackie Arnold is one of Britain's new generation of the child-free. 'I used to see too many women where I was working who, if they were married, would be worried about taking jobs on. I just didn't want that.'

Arnold is having none of this. She has taken a radical path. At the age of just 21, she has been sterilised: 'It's the easiest decision I've ever had to make about anything.'

This young London magazine writer is one of tens of thousands of Britons who have become child-free activists in the last year. They are all men and women who want to remain childless and feel cheapened by a society which still puts a relentless cultural and even political premium on reproduction. To be child-free in this context means giving more thought to not having children than most parents give to having them.

Britain's childless adults have been inspired by a recent surge of fury at 'family fascism' in America. What has crystallised their personal angst into political anger is the more progressive approach to employees with families which many regard as one of the few enlightened aspects of early twenty-first-century capitalism.

But they also protest at ostracism and endless hours of office chatter about other people's babies. And they hate the way that parents - often older and more affluent than they used to be - are allowing children to overrun hotels, restaurants and holiday resorts which were once child-free zones.

Concern about covering for colleagues who have children turns out to be widespread in Britain. A poll carried out this week among 2,000 managers for Management Today found that 55 per cent said that childless staff can resent family-friendly policies in the workplace.

Ed Adams who lives in Gloucester is typical: 'If I took the afternoon off because the dog had a cold,' he says, 'my colleagues wouldn't accept it for one moment. But if I had a child, they'd be falling over themselves to let me go home. Why should parents get more breaks and time off?'

The 36-year-old accountant, accustomed to being regarded as eccentric for his decision not to have children, is now finding that his voice resonates with legions of others.

'When we needed to breed the things to go off and fight the Germans,' said Adams, 'that was one thing. We don't need them now. Who could think that children would make you complete as a couple? Children are much more likely to break a couple up. Imagine a woman's sex life if she's been up all night two nights running and she's been breast-feeding.

'Flexible holidays, time off for school plays, paternity leave. I don't resent them having it,' says Adams. 'But what am I getting? I do the same day's work.'

In America, those without children have been campaigning for a decade for fairer treatment at work. They started by commandeering a vocabulary - 'child-free' and 'unburdened' - that does not carry the barren stigma of the word childless.

The movement has flourished on the internet where, and we are talking America, they are 'sharing their pain' at the social exclusion they felt. The cyber encounters led to the establishment of No Kidding!, an organisation that now has chapters in 47 North American cities. On this and other sites such as Brats!, the words used for kids include 'anklebiters', 'crib lizards' and 'sprogs'.

The founder of No Kidding!, Jerry Steinberg says: 'Conversations with my child-burdened friends became monologues. I'd say "How's it going?" and they'd bombard me with information about their kids.' Admirers of Steinberg have just started the first UK No Kidding! chapter in Birmingham.

Supporters of the child-free movement are dubbed 'Thinkers' - two healthy incomes, no kids, early retirement. Better a thinker, they say, than a 'Sitcom' - single income, two children, oppressive mortgage.

What prompted the transformation of the American child-free movement into a political thorn was the publication last year of a book which now serves as a child-free bible. Elinor Burkett's Baby Boon: How Family-Friendly America Cheats the Childless has made the author a Betty Friedan of the childless. Burkett and her supporters are determined to debunk the political mystique surrounding the family: 'This is about a political and economic structure which relegates the childless to second-class citizens. Parents are getting more than non-parents.'

In the meantime, however, American parents have been deluged with even more tax breaks by a 'family-friendly' Bill Clinton. Last year, the US tax credit for every child was increased to $900. 'And who subsidises that tax break?' asks Burkett. 'You're looking at her. In this wonderful world where welfare has allegedly been transformed, the poor lose federal benefits if they don't work, but the doctors and lawyers who don't work after they have kids can receive cheques from Uncle Sam.'

What American child-free campaigners are now demanding from their political representatives is for a range of benefit options to be offered to employees. People should have a cash value of perks they can take from the employer. Some could take healthcare for children, others might prefer sabbatical time instead.

And employers should stop abusing the childless too. 'Every time someone takes time off for that sick child, someone else has to do the work,' complains Burkett. 'Management always supposes that the person without kids is more able - and it's true - to do that than a parent. But it happens again and again. After a while, you're doing two jobs for one salary.'

For the American campaigners, being 'unburdened' is not just about resentment of other people's tax perks. 'It's beyond my comprehension how any intelligent, thinking person could ever wish to produce or raise children,' says 33-year-old Steve Fricke, a computer operator in Illinois.

'I simply don't like being around kids. They're obnoxious, annoying, messy, little people who only behave appropriately when asleep. In addition to that, I consider time and money to be two of the most valuable things a person can have. Children cost a lot of both, and very often yield no appreciable reward.

'Not that most pregnancies occur as the result of a thoughtful, carefully planned consideration of whether breeding would be wise. I consider life to be grievously burdensome, often painful and not generally a thing to be desired. Not that I'm unhappy. But only the most ignorant and base consider life to be a good and pleasant thing.

'My views have made it difficult for me in some ways,' admits Fricke. 'I insist upon two qualities in a potential mate. She must be a born-again Christian, and she must be willing to never have or raise children.' Fricke has not yet found a long-term girlfriend.

Fricke and the American adult childless now make up more than 10 per cent of the US electorate. It is inconceivable that they will not be recognised as a discrete political entity before long.

In Britain the child-free movement is gaining ground, so that Jackie Arnold and her contemporaries find themselves representative of the age. In 1998, 26 per cent of people were married or co-habiting and had no children. A generation earlier, in 1979, the figure was just 20 per cent. Nearly 25 per cent of women born in Britain in 1973 will be childless at 45. Just 10 per cent of those born 30 years earlier would reach middle age without bearing children.

Arnold is sensitive to one of the biggest worries of the child-free, whether straight or gay. ' I've told my parents they're not going to be grandparents. But they don't know I was sterilised. Until now, I was worried that they'd regret my decision.'

Almost all child-free activists are heterosexual. While lesbians and gays have been characterised - or stigmatised - for decades as anti-child, they are now revealing to the world for the first time a truth about their child-rearing, that for some of them it has been going on for decades. But as Barry and Tony Drewitt-Barlow announce to the tabloid press that they are proud gay dads, it is their straight counterparts - the ones who have faced, or endured, the automatic expectation of reproductive activity - who are saying enough is enough.

For those who do still want to be parents, effective contraception and changed career patterns have meant that parents are having children at an older age when they are often more affluent. With more cash has come the ability to take them to restaurants or hotels where once they would have been priced out of the market.

But that can mean frustration for the child-free. 'We went to Malta last year,' says Adams. 'We made the mistake of not checking and there were children everywhere in the resort. They are just irritating and self-centred. People might say, "you were a child once". But if I'd behaved the way that children do now, I'd have got a thick ear.'

In response, more British businesses are starting to satisfy the commercial demands of the child-free, providing leisure facilities where children are not allowed. Sara Turnbull, proprietor of the Thornhill Hotel in Wimborne, Dorset, said: 'We just don't want children rushing up and down stairs disturbing other guests.

'I might occasionally admit older girls, but there is always a danger of sticky hands and scribbles on the wall. And the noise. Not all parents control their children properly. We know we have some guests who specifically choose us because they're aware of our policy. I would always warn them in advance if there might be any children around at all.'

Sir Roy Strong, former director of both the Victoria and Albert Museum and the National Portrait Gallery, recently said: 'I welcome it when efforts are made to accommodate children in museums. However, it would be nice if they started considering child-free days too when there are not hordes of small people fluttering around.'

But Root Cartwright, chairman of the fast-growing British Organisation of Non-Parents, insists the personal still needs to be addressed by many child-free activists as well as the political: 'Being child-free isn't about the mythical lives of couples with no children spending their weekends dashing about in helicopters and expensive hotels just because they have no children. It's a very fundamental thing.

'People need to recognise that not having kids means making choices too. On an individual level, child-bearing can be fairly described as an indulgence. People don't have kids out of a sense of civic duty. It's because they want to. Not having kids isn't trivial, it's quite the reverse. We all face a litany of accusations about being irresponsible and feckless. People still find it difficult to accept difference. Even nowadays, conformity is easy and comforting.

'Wanting to be child-free is a process of self-knowledge. It goes to the very heart of identity. It's about finding out where you are, a kind of parallel with sexuality. You have to come out to others, as far as it's allowed. But first you have to come out to yourself.'

Giving children a bad name

W.C. Fields remarked, in Fields for President , upon the question of whether he liked children: 'I do if they're properly cooked!'

He also said: 'Ah, the patter of little feet around the house. There's nothing like having a midget for a butler.'

Groucho Marx: 'You've got the brain of a four-year-old boy and I'll bet he was glad to get rid of it.'

Dorothy Parker: 'The best way to keep children at home is to make the home atmosphere pleasant and let the air out of their tyres.'

Philip Larkin: Man hands on misery to man/It deepens like a coastal shelf./Get out as early as you can,/And don't have any kids yourself.

Sam Levinson: Insanity is hereditary: you can get it from your children.

W.H. Auden: 'Only those in the last stage of disease could believe that children are true judges of character.'

Cyril Connolly: 'There is no more sombre enemy of good art than the pram in the hall.'

George Bernard Shaw: 'Youth is a wonderful thing. What a crime to waste it on children.'

Francis Bacon: 'The noblest works and foundations have proceeded from childless men.'

www.child-free.net

Philip Larkin: Man hands on misery to man/It deepens like a coastal shelf./Get out as early as you can,/And don't have any kids yourself. Sam Levinson: Insanity is hereditary: you can get it from your children. W.H. Auden: 'Only those in the last stage of disease could believe that children are true judges of character.' Cyril Connolly: 'There is no more sombre enemy of good art than the pram in the hall.' George Bernard Shaw: 'Youth is a wonderful thing. What a crime to waste it on children.' Francis Bacon: 'The noblest works and foundations have proceeded from childless men.' Links www.commline.com/ukmoders/bon/choice www.child-free.net

fields.headline: True confessions
fields.standfirst: 'They think I'm a lonely spinster. But I have a secret'
fields.trailText: 'They think I'm a lonely spinster. But I have a secret.'
fields.body:
I live alone. Sometimes, I sit for hours in silence except for the ticking of my father's old clock and the soft sounds of my own breath and body. I am 45 years old, female and alone. I cared for my parents for many years and now they are gone. I have never been married. I feel that I have given up on many things but I regret few of them. I no longer believe, if ever I did, that love is a solution to anything.

Every weekday, I leave my quiet house and go to work in the same office where I have worked for many years. I notice that now most of my colleagues are younger and they have many things that I don't have and don't want - marriages, affairs, divorces and Thai kick-boxing classes. They tell me about their lives before they leave to take better jobs, promotions or new careers. Sometimes, I catch a glimpse of something in their eyes when they look at me. What is it? Pity? Laughter?

I am healthy. I eat well and treat myself to good wine. At first, when I saw my body falling with age, I was depressed. Now I try to embrace my sags, wrinkles and lines. Nevertheless, I am glad that my skin is still soft and smooth. Yet today, there is a distinct tightness and tenderness low in the middle of my back so that I take care as I lean back in my chair.

This tenderness pleases me. I know that very soon I will go again to the mirror, take off my shirt and turn until I can get a good look at my back. This is what I want to tell you. My back is covered by a tattoo of a turquoise and sea-green seahorse. His horned head rests on my left shoulder; his finned tail traces my lower spine. He is my gift to myself and my compensation for the quiet clock ticking away my quiet life.

For the past six months, after the Thursday accounts meeting, I have left my office early and walked into the old part of the city. I turn along a dim alley which leads to the tattoo studio. Inside, I sit in front of the tattooist, turning my back to him and baring my skin.

At first, I hear the soft hiss of his breath and then only the nagging singing of the needle. I feel the sting and pressure it causes. I am soothed and comforted by the soft, regular wipe as the artist cleans the excess ink and blood from my skin. Sometimes, passers-by peer in through the dim windows. I look straight into their eyes and they turn away.

I have watched others taking this step. I have seen giggling girls arrive in packs to have Chinese letters tattooed on their ankles or thighs. Just last month, I watched a young man's firm, muscled body constrict in pain as red, black and bloody flames grew slowly around his stomach and side.

But I have seen others like me take this pleasure and pain and wrap it inside them like a secret treasure. I have recognised the soft smiles on their faces as they remove their shirts and sit again in front of the tattooist. Their faces firm up in concentration and I am sure that I have seen a secret pleasure leaking from their eyes. Today is Thursday. And today my seahorse is complete. He is my glowing secret, a blue-and-green, smooth-and-scaly vision. I will carry him on my back forever. I feel that I have sacrificed my own plain skin to some older, more reckless god.

 If you have a true confession, email kim.bunce@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Meet the new Jaeger meister
fields.standfirst: Bella Freud - Lucian's daughter and saucy, funny fashion designer - has signed with the sedate Jaeger. No wonder she's in high spirits
fields.trailText: Bella Freud - Lucian's daughter and saucy, funny fashion designer - has signed with the sedate Jaeger. No wonder she's in high spirits.
fields.body:
'Bella Freud for Jaeger': at first it looks improbable. Freud's clothes are nonchalant and saucy: they often make you laugh. Jaeger is sedateness itself. Yet look again, and Freud's announcement that she has signed a three-year contract with the firm is less surprising: both parties are committed to tailoring and good quality, to tweeds and to knitwear. Freud thinks it's 'a real soul-match'.

The contract, part of a general revamping of the Jaeger brand, requires the 39-year-old to produce two collections of about 75 pieces a year. They'll feature the slinky tailored suits and jackets which have made her famous; she is also hoping to develop other areas, such as accessories. She has already started to pore over the Jaeger archives, looking for points that can be elegantly modernised, seeking to recapture the glamorous advertisements she remembers from her childhood. Sellotaped to the mirror of her Kensal Road home are some 50 ink drawings of scarves and jackets and knickers; one instruction reads: 'Mac with bonkers lining'. There are swatches of blue tweed lying around, and a tiny torso on the table clad in tight lace. She aims to bring 'high-spiritedness' to Jaeger.

High spirits touch every detail of Freud's enterprise. She herself is grave, dignified and reflective - which is to say, totally humorous. Her logo - which she will keep for her non-Jaeger work - was drawn by her father Lucian Freud. It shows a lean-faced dog with its tongue sticking out: it is grinning; it is sleek but wolfish. The names she gives to her clothes are almost a novel in themselves, reminding you that she comes from a family - Esther Freud, Rose Boyt, Susie Boyt - who write as well as paint. She has designed a New York Doll dress in dappled green tiger chiffon and a hooded Black Madonna dress in purple leopard-print jersey. There's a Paris le Trash Mac in policeman blue.

And there's the garment named after the infant toff whose portrait Freud spotted in a history book. He was wearing a seriously tailored jacket, with a double row of buttons. Freud adapted the item, keeping all the buttons, but taking away the formality, to make a feminine version in which a girl could feel like Elizabeth Taylor. She called it the Baby Earl jacket.

She looks for ideas 'every second of the day', and finds them all over the place: 'galleries, landscapes, architecture, rubbish, old ladies'. The clothes these inspire are worn by Tilda Swinton and Lucy Ferry, Courtney Love and Kylie Minogue, Kate Moss, Jerry Hall, Gillian Anderson and Marianne Faithfull. Jools Holland and Nick Cave get into her jumpers. Geri Halliwell and Eddie Izzard have been seen - separately - wearing the same Bella Freud coat. Her publicist sports a Freud T-shirt with a huge tattoo-style heart inscribed with the word Daddy and pierced by an arrow. One arm reads 'Bella'; the other has a semi-naked lady on it. The two wrists read 'Justa love... hate thing'.

Suits - with trousers or skirts - are the basis of her collections. Ever since her twenties, when she studied fashion in Rome, she's been fascinated by Coco Chanel, and the idea of an ensemble: 'There's nothing like a suit to catch someone's eye and follow the shape of the body.' But 'now that everyone looks younger', her suits have a different emphasis: they're no longer to do with going to the office but with showing off the body. Inside the shell of the suit, her knitwear - bobbled or smooth, deceptively meek or ingeniously patterned - also has to be 'alive': when the jacket's off, the interior mustn't 'go to sleep'.

'Playful' is a word Freud uses a lot. She thinks it's a good sign when people are amused by her clothes: 'Beautiful things often do make people laugh. People forget that.' Ten years ago, when pastels were associated with prams and romper suits, she decked out her models in pink and powder-blue tailored suits. And she always uses fabric provocatively. She'll take a piece of tweed and try to tease out aspects that are normally hidden, aiming to 'change its atmosphere'. Colours that usually dissolve into a 'heathery blur' can be made to 'bash against each other' by introducing a stripe. Instead of being used for bulky leather-patched jackets, her tweeds become weeny skirts.

She's also re-thought the way clothes can be presented to the public. For her second collection in 1991, she took her models to Newbury racetrack and filmed them - with music from Bryan Ferry, Fats Waller and Hendrix - watching the races and having lunch. The clothes - suits in pale blue, 'whippet' and oyster - looked wonderful, although the girls were surrounded by startlingly unpleasant men muttering about tarts. In 1997 she showed her collection - orange zebra patterns and lilac safari suits - at the Fridge in Brixton and called it 'The Best Dressed Chicken in Town'. Round Liquorice Allsorts handbags were dangled while 'My Boy Lollipop' played. On the catwalk, along with Kate Moss, were Sophie Dahl and, in gunmetal grey, the artist Sarah Lucas. Her autumn 2000 collection was presented in the form of a magazine: pictures for it were shot in Anita Pallenberg's London flat. It was Pallenberg, as the Sixties' bad girl in Barbarella and Performance , who had inspired the clothes.

And there are Freud's videos. A year ago, deciding that catwalk shows meant a lot of effort for little reward, she returned to the idea of filming her collections, loving the idea that they could be switched on anywhere. A friend suggested John Malkovich might be interested in directing, and Freud, having met him briefly, thought he might be 'eccentric enough to go for it: that his taste might be perverse enough'. She tracked him down in Paris where he was filming; she showed him some fabric; they talked for half an hour, and he agreed. The result was Strap Hanging , which shows a model-crammed tube train, with the women languorous, dynamic and overwhelming, and a man trapped by them and his inflatable underpants. They filmed for a day and a half; they edited non-stop for 24 hours; they showed it in New York the next day. Its success led to another Malkovich project, Lady Behave , featuring a slatternly girl and an etiquette school run by the dominating Arielle Dombasle and starring Jodie Kidd, Susie Bick and Lizzie Jagger.

Film suits Freud's liking for 'undercurrents, double-entendres, mixed messages'. The catwalk demands an expansive theatricality: 'You need to be really, really blatant. On film you can be more circumspect.' The meeting of Freud and Jaeger is another mixed message. The first 'Bella Freud for Jaeger' collection will be seen in winter 2001. It looks as if they'll be well-suited.
