fields.headline: Still fighting the bad guys
fields.standfirst: In the Sixties Caroline Coon was famous for helping people caught in drugs busts. In the Nineties she defended her right to paint penises. Now, at 55, she insists her battles are far from over
fields.trailText: In the Sixties Caroline Coon was famous for helping people caught in drugs busts. In the Nineties she defended her right to paint penises. Now, at 55, she insists her battles are far from over.
fields.body:
Caroline Coon is a morning person. When I arrive to interview her at midday, the artist, activist, and 'High Priestess of the Sixties Counterculture' has already been up for seven hours. In the Sixties, Coon would get up early to run Release, the help centre for people in trouble with the police over drugs, which she famously set up with Rufus Jones in 1967.

These days, Coon uses the early hours to paint, read or make agitprop fly-posters ('Purdah Murder'; 'Poverty Kills'). Until very recently, Coon also had to find time to immerse herself in law books, in order to be able to represent herself in her two-year legal battle with Random House, the company responsible for publishing Jonathon Green's 1998 book, All Dressed Up: the Sixties and the Counter-Culture .

In Green's book, a passage related how 'a young woman from Release' would give oral sex to rock stars in return for large donations. The book goes on to describe how George Harrison complied, while Mick Jagger accepted the sex, but sneered afterwards: 'If she thinks I'm going to give her a grand for a blow job, she's crazy.' It was all untrue.

Financially speaking, Coon was in no position to sue, but she did anyway. In June this year, she was awarded £73,000 in costs and damages (some of which she donated towards setting up an official Release archive), and All Dressed Up was withdrawn from sale.

'Defending myself was terrifying,' says Coon, as we sit in her pristine, bohemian west London living-room, surrounded by her colourful, sensual paintings. 'Technically, I hadn't done anything like it before so it felt like trying to drive a Ferrari down a coal mine.'

Coon reveals that one of the reasons she decided to take on Random House was the 'deeply misogynistic' reaction to her protest at the false allegations. 'I was told that although it was an untrue story, it was an amusing untrue story. I was lectured that if I hadn't prostituted myself for Release, then maybe I should have done, because it would have been a heroic act.' She smiles wryly. 'This was the reaction I was getting from what I could call unreconstructed Sixties Man.'

In Coon's opinion, it was a much more serious matter. 'To me, it amounted to verbal rape,' she says, calmly but emphatically, in her husky, genteel tones. 'It wasn't just this "funny" thing about a woman giving blow jobs to rock stars - it was one big pornographic humiliation fantasy. And there were racist elements to it, too. The paragraph before said something like, "Caroline Coon was upper class, but she slept with black boys which increased her exotic appeal".' Coon looks at me incredulously, and then lets out a short whoop of anguished laughter: 'And this is supposed to be 2000!'

Coon has had a lifetime of being misunderstood. Her provocative art has taken in a range of subjects including flowers, mythology, war and murder. However, she is mainly known for her work dealing in the diverse beauty of the human nude, in particular her studies of naked black men who also happened to be her friends and lovers. This has led to to Coon being referred to dismissively as 'the artist who likes to paint black men' or, even more bluntly, 'that woman who likes penises'.

Coon has long professed to be incensed by the double standards: 'Why is the penis hidden in culture? How many female nudes are there?' She was similarly amazed by the uproar in 1995, when the Liverpool Tate decided not use her painting, Mr Olympia, directly inspired by Manet's female nude, Olympia, because the black model had a semi-erection.

'I paint my life,' says Coon simply. 'My friends have always been multicultural.' Later, she says: 'What's wrong with painting penises? Journalists always come round and say [she adopts a sombre tone], "Caroline Coon is an artist who likes penises". But the idea that women will make love to men and not like the penis is to me psychopathic, pathological. We draw the penis into us; you have to love it. If you don't, then what is happening here?'

Coon herself is bisexual, though she prefers to keep that as quiet as possible for fear of titillating the general public. 'I try to be as private about my private life as I can be,' she says. 'But I still think it's very important to keep on discussing the theory of sexual liberation. My position is that I am not perverse at all. They are perverse. They are the bigots. They are the hypocrites. They are the ones in denial of their sexuality.'

Coon is sitting on the floor of her living-room, wearing dazzling white leggings and a matching top. The sun is streaming through the window and bouncing off her sleek hair, a mop of avant- garde, black-and-white stripes. At 55, her body is as taut, trim, and 'yoga-fit' as a woman half her age. While Coon has the courage of her sociopolitical convictions ('I consider myself part of a leftist project that wants change'), she acknowledges that her own situation is far from hellish.

'The world I live in, the heaven of Ladbroke Grove, means that any moan I might have about inequality is as nothing compared to what other people have to live through,' she says. Indeed, Coon cheerfully reveals that, in a rare bit of money luck, her heavenly west London home cost her only £15,000 because her Fenella Fielding accent got her on to some spurious, upper-income council list. 'Now that's what I call an interesting story about class,' she drawls mischievously.

Croline Coon was born in 1945 to a family of wealthy, ecologically conscious Kent landowners. It was an environment, Coon says, where women were regarded as little more than 'marriage-meat'. Influenced by this, she spent her youth loudly rejecting marriage, domesticity and motherhood, claiming, where the latter was concerned, that she 'wanted to be free to commit suicide'.

This decision starts looking even more complicated when you learn that Coon was sent away to board at the prestigious Legat Russian Ballet School at the age of five, mainly because her father abused her.

'I've had to say no to many men in life,' she says softly. 'And the first was my own father.' Although she had written passionately in the past on the subject of incest, Coon only went public about her own abuse very recently. However, reading past interviews, one is struck by how many times Coon hints at a terrible darkness in her background. It's as if, despite her best efforts, the secret she was keeping kept popping up into her mind like some sexually traumatic jack-in-the-box.

These days, Coon believes that her father was abused himself, and that she may have been sent to boarding school for her own protection.

Despite being severely dyslexic, she was happy at Legat, thriving in the disciplined, artistic, multicultural, 'gender-fluid' atmosphere. At 16, after a final row with her parents ('I wouldn't marry the next-door millionaire'), she decamped to London and her real life began in earnest. Along the way, Coon has dabbled in, among other things, modelling, movie-making, punditry and music journalism (during which she was the first to coin the term 'punk rock'). However, she is probably still best known for co-founding Release when she was still at art school.

Release helped everybody from homeless runaways to rock stars. At one point, the organisation was handling one-third of all drug busts in Britain. Coon attracted a lot of individual attention for a variety of reasons - her feminist mettle (she is one of Germaine Greer's dedicatees for The Female Eunuch) ; her feral beauty (she was known in London circles as 'Caroline Swoon'); and last, but not least, her unapologetic poshness and love of high culture.

She might have proudly marched alongside the newly politicised working classes in the Sixties, and been among the first to report on the likes of The Clash (whom she managed for a short period), but chez Coon, it was more about Anna Pavlova, Maria Callas and Stravinsky.

Then as now, Coon's main political beef was with sexual inequality. 'The idea that women are still perceived as second-rate is shocking,' she says disgustedly. 'People say this is a postfeminist age, but misogyny is still such a hot current in our culture. We need feminists in the vanguard more than ever.'

In the past, Coon's adversaries numbered other feminists who took exception to her appearance and behaviour. 'I was labelled decorative and beautiful and accused of being so just to attract men,' she recalls, 'whereas actually I didn't need to attract men. I was young! When you're young, you're up against the wall with offers.

'Women like me wanted love relationships without entering into the commercial exchange of marriage,' she continues. 'To our horror, we were called sluts, whores, easy lays, loose. It was so shocking that many women started going around, saying, "Oh no, I'm not an easy lay".'

In response to this, Coon famously put up a poster in her flat which read: 'Yes, yes, I'm an easy lay.' It was a protest against the then-prevalent belief that 'nice girls' had to be forced or tricked into sex, or they automatically ceased to be nice.

'Then as now, a lot of sex was just about playing out some sick rape scenario,' says Coon. 'It's all about men getting hard only as an aggressive act. It's a cheap, self-hating way for men to get hard and I'm not interested. It seems to me that men can get hard in a different, slower way. They can get hard by loving someone.

Well,' she finishes archly, 'that's the only "hard" I've ever been interested in.'

Coon resigned from Release in 1971, when the poverty, back-breaking work, sexist insults and inverted snobbery finally got too much. 'We're all performers, aren't we? I would never show it in public, but very often, I would just go home and weep.'

These days, people mainly seem to remember Coon for causing minor sensations, like wearing a transparent blouse for the Oz trial, putting red dye in the fountains at Trafalgar Square in protest at the Vietnam War, or getting herself jailed for a fortnight for brandishing fake spliffs at a demonstration. The irony of that last incident isn't lost on Coon. Despite her pro-drugs activism, she has never been into drugs herself, nor drink for that matter. For the interview, she graciously whips up some bucks fizz, but declares herself 'pissed' after one small glass.

It has to be said that, during the time I spend with her, Caroline Coon is extremely good company, fixing us lunch, breaking off in the middle of rants to relax into a little light gossip about sexist radioheads and chatting about art. Her favourite artists are Bridget Riley, Frida Kahlo and Georgia O'Keeffe, but she also has a lot of time for Rachel Whiteread and Tracey Emin.

'I think Tracey Emin is fantastic,' she says. 'I just hope she can cope with the vicious sexism with which she is now being interpreted. As an artist, I hold my breath for her.' As for Coon's own ongoing artistic-political-spiritual odyssey, she seems determined to regret nothing.

fields.bodyText: Caroline Coon is a morning person. When I arrive to interview her at midday, the artist, activist, and 'High Priestess of the Sixties Counterculture' has already been up for seven hours. In the Sixties, Coon would get up early to run Release, the help centre for people in trouble with the police over drugs, which she famously set up with Rufus Jones in 1967. These days, Coon uses the early hours to paint, read or make agitprop fly-posters ('Purdah Murder'; 'Poverty Kills'). Until very recently, Coon also had to find time to immerse herself in law books, in order to be able to represent herself in her two-year legal battle with Random House, the company responsible for publishing Jonathon Green's 1998 book, All Dressed Up: the Sixties and the Counter-Culture . In Green's book, a passage related how 'a young woman from Release' would give oral sex to rock stars in return for large donations. The book goes on to describe how George Harrison complied, while Mick Jagger accepted the sex, but sneered afterwards: 'If she thinks I'm going to give her a grand for a blow job, she's crazy.' It was all untrue. Financially speaking, Coon was in no position to sue, but she did anyway. In June this year, she was awarded £73,000 in costs and damages (some of which she donated towards setting up an official Release archive), and All Dressed Up was withdrawn from sale. 'Defending myself was terrifying,' says Coon, as we sit in her pristine, bohemian west London living-room, surrounded by her colourful, sensual paintings. 'Technically, I hadn't done anything like it before so it felt like trying to drive a Ferrari down a coal mine.' Coon reveals that one of the reasons she decided to take on Random House was the 'deeply misogynistic' reaction to her protest at the false allegations. 'I was told that although it was an untrue story, it was an amusing untrue story. I was lectured that if I hadn't prostituted myself for Release, then maybe I should have done, because it would have been a heroic act.' She smiles wryly. 'This was the reaction I was getting from what I could call unreconstructed Sixties Man.' In Coon's opinion, it was a much more serious matter. 'To me, it amounted to verbal rape,' she says, calmly but emphatically, in her husky, genteel tones. 'It wasn't just this "funny" thing about a woman giving blow jobs to rock stars - it was one big pornographic humiliation fantasy. And there were racist elements to it, too. The paragraph before said something like, "Caroline Coon was upper class, but she slept with black boys which increased her exotic appeal".' Coon looks at me incredulously, and then lets out a short whoop of anguished laughter: 'And this is supposed to be 2000!' Coon has had a lifetime of being misunderstood. Her provocative art has taken in a range of subjects including flowers, mythology, war and murder. However, she is mainly known for her work dealing in the diverse beauty of the human nude, in particular her studies of naked black men who also happened to be her friends and lovers. This has led to to Coon being referred to dismissively as 'the artist who likes to paint black men' or, even more bluntly, 'that woman who likes penises'. Coon has long professed to be incensed by the double standards: 'Why is the penis hidden in culture? How many female nudes are there?' She was similarly amazed by the uproar in 1995, when the Liverpool Tate decided not use her painting, Mr Olympia, directly inspired by Manet's female nude, Olympia, because the black model had a semi-erection. 'I paint my life,' says Coon simply. 'My friends have always been multicultural.' Later, she says: 'What's wrong with painting penises? Journalists always come round and say [she adopts a sombre tone], "Caroline Coon is an artist who likes penises". But the idea that women will make love to men and not like the penis is to me psychopathic, pathological. We draw the penis into us; you have to love it. If you don't, then what is happening here?' Coon herself is bisexual, though she prefers to keep that as quiet as possible for fear of titillating the general public. 'I try to be as private about my private life as I can be,' she says. 'But I still think it's very important to keep on discussing the theory of sexual liberation. My position is that I am not perverse at all. They are perverse. They are the bigots. They are the hypocrites. They are the ones in denial of their sexuality.' Coon is sitting on the floor of her living-room, wearing dazzling white leggings and a matching top. The sun is streaming through the window and bouncing off her sleek hair, a mop of avant- garde, black-and-white stripes. At 55, her body is as taut, trim, and 'yoga-fit' as a woman half her age. While Coon has the courage of her sociopolitical convictions ('I consider myself part of a leftist project that wants change'), she acknowledges that her own situation is far from hellish. 'The world I live in, the heaven of Ladbroke Grove, means that any moan I might have about inequality is as nothing compared to what other people have to live through,' she says. Indeed, Coon cheerfully reveals that, in a rare bit of money luck, her heavenly west London home cost her only £15,000 because her Fenella Fielding accent got her on to some spurious, upper-income council list. 'Now that's what I call an interesting story about class,' she drawls mischievously. Croline Coon was born in 1945 to a family of wealthy, ecologically conscious Kent landowners. It was an environment, Coon says, where women were regarded as little more than 'marriage-meat'. Influenced by this, she spent her youth loudly rejecting marriage, domesticity and motherhood, claiming, where the latter was concerned, that she 'wanted to be free to commit suicide'. This decision starts looking even more complicated when you learn that Coon was sent away to board at the prestigious Legat Russian Ballet School at the age of five, mainly because her father abused her. 'I've had to say no to many men in life,' she says softly. 'And the first was my own father.' Although she had written passionately in the past on the subject of incest, Coon only went public about her own abuse very recently. However, reading past interviews, one is struck by how many times Coon hints at a terrible darkness in her background. It's as if, despite her best efforts, the secret she was keeping kept popping up into her mind like some sexually traumatic jack-in-the-box. These days, Coon believes that her father was abused himself, and that she may have been sent to boarding school for her own protection. Despite being severely dyslexic, she was happy at Legat, thriving in the disciplined, artistic, multicultural, 'gender-fluid' atmosphere. At 16, after a final row with her parents ('I wouldn't marry the next-door millionaire'), she decamped to London and her real life began in earnest. Along the way, Coon has dabbled in, among other things, modelling, movie-making, punditry and music journalism (during which she was the first to coin the term 'punk rock'). However, she is probably still best known for co-founding Release when she was still at art school. Release helped everybody from homeless runaways to rock stars. At one point, the organisation was handling one-third of all drug busts in Britain. Coon attracted a lot of individual attention for a variety of reasons - her feminist mettle (she is one of Germaine Greer's dedicatees for The Female Eunuch) ; her feral beauty (she was known in London circles as 'Caroline Swoon'); and last, but not least, her unapologetic poshness and love of high culture. She might have proudly marched alongside the newly politicised working classes in the Sixties, and been among the first to report on the likes of The Clash (whom she managed for a short period), but chez Coon, it was more about Anna Pavlova, Maria Callas and Stravinsky. Then as now, Coon's main political beef was with sexual inequality. 'The idea that women are still perceived as second-rate is shocking,' she says disgustedly. 'People say this is a postfeminist age, but misogyny is still such a hot current in our culture. We need feminists in the vanguard more than ever.' In the past, Coon's adversaries numbered other feminists who took exception to her appearance and behaviour. 'I was labelled decorative and beautiful and accused of being so just to attract men,' she recalls, 'whereas actually I didn't need to attract men. I was young! When you're young, you're up against the wall with offers. 'Women like me wanted love relationships without entering into the commercial exchange of marriage,' she continues. 'To our horror, we were called sluts, whores, easy lays, loose. It was so shocking that many women started going around, saying, "Oh no, I'm not an easy lay".' In response to this, Coon famously put up a poster in her flat which read: 'Yes, yes, I'm an easy lay.' It was a protest against the then-prevalent belief that 'nice girls' had to be forced or tricked into sex, or they automatically ceased to be nice. 'Then as now, a lot of sex was just about playing out some sick rape scenario,' says Coon. 'It's all about men getting hard only as an aggressive act. It's a cheap, self-hating way for men to get hard and I'm not interested. It seems to me that men can get hard in a different, slower way. They can get hard by loving someone. Well,' she finishes archly, 'that's the only "hard" I've ever been interested in.' Coon resigned from Release in 1971, when the poverty, back-breaking work, sexist insults and inverted snobbery finally got too much. 'We're all performers, aren't we? I would never show it in public, but very often, I would just go home and weep.' These days, people mainly seem to remember Coon for causing minor sensations, like wearing a transparent blouse for the Oz trial, putting red dye in the fountains at Trafalgar Square in protest at the Vietnam War, or getting herself jailed for a fortnight for brandishing fake spliffs at a demonstration. The irony of that last incident isn't lost on Coon. Despite her pro-drugs activism, she has never been into drugs herself, nor drink for that matter. For the interview, she graciously whips up some bucks fizz, but declares herself 'pissed' after one small glass. It has to be said that, during the time I spend with her, Caroline Coon is extremely good company, fixing us lunch, breaking off in the middle of rants to relax into a little light gossip about sexist radioheads and chatting about art. Her favourite artists are Bridget Riley, Frida Kahlo and Georgia O'Keeffe, but she also has a lot of time for Rachel Whiteread and Tracey Emin. 'I think Tracey Emin is fantastic,' she says. fields.headline: My left foot
fields.standfirst: Sophie Radice is 36, female and has never drunk a drop of port. Not an obvious candidate for an attack of gout then
fields.trailText: Sophie Radice is 36, female and has never drunk a drop of port. Not an obvious candidate for an attack of gout then
fields.body:
Gout is a disease with the distinctive personality of an old buffer stuck in the armchair of a gentleman's club, which is why - despite being agonisingly painful - sufferers have to endure smirking and even disapproval from family and friends. Known as the 'disease of kings and the king of diseases' since the 5th century BC, it has long been associated with good living and overindulgence of every kind. Cartoons by Rowlandson, Cruikshank and Hogarth come to mind of stout, ruddy-faced boozers with bloated legs sitting on 'gout' stools next to an empty bottle of port.

No wonder then that when I recently found myself hobbling out of the doctor's having been diagnosed as having gout, I decided I would only tell my mother and my husband (one smirked and the other was disapproving, and I bet you can guess which way round it was). I had been woken suddenly in the early morning by a searing pain in my left big toe, which soon became hot, red and swollen, as well as extremely tender on the sole side of my foot. Later on that morning, I was forced to use a stick to get me from the car into my children's school and then to abandon the car and get a taxi home because I could not bear to push down on the foot pedals. But gout! I simply could not accept the diagnosis. It made me feel unfeminine (gout afflicts eight times as many men as women, and very rarely attacks a pre-menopausal woman) as well as geriatric (my grandfather, who was in India for years and always liked a bit of a snifter, was a sufferer).

As I have never been much of a drinker and have never so much as tasted a glass of port, it also seemed deeply unfair.

The doctor explained that gout is one of the most common types of arthritis which afflicts three in every thousand people. The problem was that I had a build-up of uric acid in my blood which had formed crystals around the joint of my big toe, although the ankle, foot, knee and hand joints may also be affected. Uric acid builds up through increased levels of purines, which are produced by the digestion of certain types of proteins.

There are various reasons for the build-up of uric acid. Some people simply have a genetic tendency to make too much, but for others it can be due to excessive alcohol consumption and eating large amounts of meat, dried peas, seafood and beans, hence the ancient reputation of gout as the disease of the rich. The reason that port, in particular, is associated with gout is that it was often served in lead-crystal glasses, and lead poisoning is thought to be another cause.

I was given a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug, and after a few days it cleared up. As there has never been a reoccurrence and I was told that it is perfectly possible to have one attack in a lifetime, I chose to simply forget about my unglamorous affliction. Until, that is, a 39-year-old friend Marco Oddi, slightly liberated me from my shame by admitting that he had suffered from regular bouts of gout for the past seven years. Like me, he rarely drinks and is likely to have inherited his condition.

His most recent attack was a couple of weeks ago, and came just a month after the last one. He still isn't walking with his usual springy step and has acquired a slight shuffle, which I'm afraid to say reminds me a little of my grandfather. Marco has always treated his gout with anti-inflammatory drugs and by cutting out various foods - but naturally enough only does this when the memory of an attack is sufficiently fresh in his mind. He has so far taken drugs only as a reaction to an attack, but has come to the conclusion that he will have to take Allopurinal, a preventative drug that inhibits the formation of uric acid. 'I was resisting this because I'm not really happy about having to take a tablet every day. I have decided to give it a try now, though, otherwise I'll always be dreading the next attack.'

Frank McKenna, consultant rheumatologist at Trafford General Hospital in Manchester, says that those who suffer from hereditary and frequent gout would definitely benefit from taking Allopurinal. 'Another situation in which we would strongly advise taking Allopurinal would be if the patient has started to develop tophi, which are small, hard lumps of uric acid that form under the skin. Allopurinal should be taken after a gout attack has definitely ended because the drug may cause the level of uric acid to rise slightly before it falls, but once levels have been brought down, the patient should be able to live a completely gout-free life.'

A few days later, another young, fit friend, hearing that I am writing about gout, decides to phone and admit that she, too, has had a solitary attack. Jenny Wearing, 35, says that her bout of gout was confirmed by the removal of fluid from the toe joint and the discovery of uric acid crystals. She had been too embarrassed to tell anyone about the diagnosis and had pretended that she had trodden on a nail. In the end, we both decide that although gout is a disease associated with a patrician past, it is still lurking around, cloaked perhaps even from medical statisticians by the embarrassment and mortification of its thoroughly modern victims.

fields.headline: Domestic science
fields.standfirst: Take a mundane kitchen gadget, place it in the hands of product designers Richard Seymour and Dick Powell, and what do you get? A revolutionary swing bin
fields.trailText: Take a mundane kitchen gadget, place it in the hands of product designers Richard Seymour and Dick Powell, and what do you get? A revolutionary swing bin
fields.body:
Last Tuesday, Richard Seymour and Dick Powell, two of the UK's most influential and prolific product designers, gave the British public a really smart new idea: a central-locking system for the home. When you leave your house, you simply press the button on your key fob and every lock in the place clunks shut. It's one of those simple, sensible ideas, and you can't help but wonder why it hasn't been done before. Later this month, their magic bin will be unveiled as part of Better by Design, their six-part series for Channel 4.

Richard and Dick are to design what the Two Fat Ladies were to cookery. They have become the most famous double act in product design. Instead of Clarissa and Jennifer's motorbike and sidecar, they travel around in Richard's silver Audi TT, speeding from their west London studio to various factories around Britain in search of a manufacturer with money to invest on a better version of a product already in production. Under their eagle-eyed scrutiny go the airline seat, the razor, the shopping trolley, the life jacket, the home security system and the kitchen bin.

The bin is an unlikely subject for a gripping TV programme. But as they revel over the inadequacies of the standard swing-top bin - the lid gets splattered with baked beans as it flips, and pulling out the liner is about as arduous as giving birth - we are sucked into the Seymour-Powell world.

These are the sorts of everyday problems they most enjoy solving. There are an infinite number of badly designed products cluttering our lives - there simply because we've got used to them and because there is no alternative. A swing bin is a swing bin. We fill it with rubbish. And that's that. But by the end of the bin programme, we won't be happy until we've swapped the swing top for a Seymour Powell Magic Door bin (the lid snaps open, leaving a void for the beans, and to change the bag, the bin simply opens at the front).

The designers are all too aware of the consumer excitement such programmes generate. But it can take up to six years before a product reaches the shop floor. 'The intention of this series was to create potential solutions to problems we all have, not to push the things through into final manufacture,' explains Seymour. 'These were demonstration pieces to show how things could be better, and then the consumers want it now. The six products featured on the TV series are just prototypes, but they offer hope. Right now at the Seymour Powell studios, there are 30 other products all on their way into production.

'We get very impatient with things being wrong and we want to do something about it,' says Seymour. 'The word design is not understood very well. Invention is part of design; engineering is part of design. We don't use the "s" word often [style], but the appearance of an object - how it interfaces visually and "tactiley" with you - is part of design. Its appearance is a part of the process.' Nevertheless, we now have several generations of consumer who buy a gadget simply because they like the way it looks.

Take the toaster. Look in any kitchen store and you will see 10 or 12 of the things, from the rectangular £20-something Kenwood to the state-of-the-art £140 Dualit. There's even a brushed-steel one made by Porsche. Despite the huge variety of sizes and finishes, they are all basically the same design - boxes with slots for the toast and a couple of knobs to make the bread go up and down. When Seymour Powell were asked by Tefal to make a better toaster, however, they came up with two simple but radical answers to two questions: a) Why are the controls on the side rather than on the front of the toaster where you want to use them? b) Why do you have to bend over it to see your toast cooking and risk singeing your eyebrows?

'We put the controls on the front rather than on the side,' says Powell. 'And we tilted the toaster up so you can see your toast cooking.' Confronting issues often throws up more problems. 'The first prototypes threw the toast across the kitchen,' he admits. But eventually, they arrived at just the right angle. The Avanti toaster is priced from £39.99 for the four-slice machine (£49.99 if you want it in chrome). It arrived in the stores in June.

The Seymour-Powell design philosophy begins with observing human behaviour, and the realisation - and acceptance - that we often use appliances the 'wrong' way. 'When we design something, we always start with how people are,' says Seymour. 'And how we are is very interesting because we're extremely adaptive, so we make up for inadequacies in the object. It's very arrogant to create a product that people have to learn how to use.'

Their 'future kettle', like their toaster, is designed with human misuse in mind. A prototype designed with Tefal for an episode of Equinox about Dream Machines, it is still to be put into production. 'You should fill up an electric kettle with just enough water to make the quantity you want,' says Seymour. 'Most of us fill the thing up, which means you're boiling lots more water than you need to.' The solution? A thermal lining, as in a Thermos flask. 'You boil the water, and it is kept at a very high temperature. It is much more efficient in the way it uses energy, and takes into account the fact that the consumer is using the product "wrongly".'

Seymour and Powell believe there is a move towards people buying appliances designed to last. 'Things are much more reliable than they were. That's very laudable.' They also want to see a return to the repair culture, whereby the appliance can be fixed rather than thrown away.

Seymour Powell are masters of the domestic appliance, but they can turn their hands to anything. They've created a range of luxury luggage for Connolly, G-Shock and Baby-G watches for Casio, the interiors of the new-ish trains on London Underground's Northern Line, as well as motorbikes for Yamaha and - every boy's dream bike - the MZ Skorpion. 'We have been altering the landscape for quite a long time - on wrists, in homes, on floors, in kitchens, in living rooms,' says Seymour.

Since they launched their company in 1984, they have been quietly changing the shape of people's lives. This autumn, their Bioform bra is launched for Charnos. It started life as a problem for last summer's Channel 4 design programme, Designs on Your... 'There was a groundswell of public opinion that said "We want this", and that was enough to push it forward,' says Powell. Just over a year later, consumers will be able to buy it and see for themselves if it really is better by design.

 Better by Design continues on Tuesday evenings on Channel 4 at 8.30pm until 22 August.

When Seymour Powell were asked by Tefal to make a better toaster, however, they came up with two simple but radical answers to two questions: a) Why are the controls on the side rather than on the front of the toaster where you want to use them? b) Why do you have to bend over it to see your toast cooking and risk singeing your eyebrows? 'We put the controls on the front rather than on the side,' says Powell. 'And we tilted the toaster up so you can see your toast cooking.' Confronting issues often throws up more problems. 'The first prototypes threw the toast across the kitchen,' he admits. But eventually, they arrived at just the right angle. The Avanti toaster is priced from £39.99 for the four-slice machine (£49.99 if you want it in chrome). It arrived in the stores in June. The Seymour-Powell design philosophy begins with observing human behaviour, and the realisation - and acceptance - that we often use appliances the 'wrong' way. 'When we design something, we always start with how people are,' says Seymour. 'And how we are is very interesting because we're extremely adaptive, so we make up for inadequacies in the object. It's very arrogant to create a product that people have to learn how to use.' Their 'future kettle', like their toaster, is designed with human misuse in mind. A prototype designed with Tefal for an episode of Equinox about Dream Machines, it is still to be put into production. 'You should fill up an electric kettle with just enough water to make the quantity you want,' says Seymour. 'Most of us fill the thing up, which means you're boiling lots more water than you need to.' The solution? A thermal lining, as in a Thermos flask. 'You boil the water, and it is kept at a very high temperature. It is much more efficient in the way it uses energy, and takes into account the fact that the consumer is using the product "wrongly".' Seymour and Powell believe there is a move towards people buying appliances designed to last. 'Things are much more reliable than they were. That's very laudable.' They also want to see a return to the repair culture, whereby the appliance can be fixed rather than thrown away. Seymour Powell are masters of the domestic appliance, but they can turn their hands to anything. They've created a range of luxury luggage for Connolly, G-Shock and Baby-G watches for Casio, the interiors of the new-ish trains on London Underground's Northern Line, as well as motorbikes for Yamaha and - every boy's dream bike - the MZ Skorpion. 'We have been altering the landscape for quite a long time - on wrists, in homes, on floors, in kitchens, in living rooms,' says Seymour. Since they launched their company in 1984, they have been quietly changing the shape of people's lives. This autumn, their Bioform bra is launched for Charnos. It started life as a problem for last summer's Channel 4 design programme, Designs on Your... 'There was a groundswell of public opinion that said "We want this", and that was enough to push it forward,' says Powell. Just over a year later, consumers will be able to buy it and see for themselves if it really is better by design.  Better by Design continues on Tuesday evenings on Channel 4 at 8.30pm until 22 August.

fields.headline: Life support
fields.standfirst: When artist Franko B gives a blood-letting performance, Stuart Barclay is the one who's watchng in the wings. It's a relationship based on mutual respect and trust - after all, there's more at stake than just friendship
fields.trailText: When artist Franko B gives a blood-letting performance, Stuart Barclay is the one who's watchng in the wings. It's a relationship based on mutual respect and trust - after all, there's more at stake than just friendship
fields.body:
Franko B If I only take one person with me to do a performance, it's Stuart. We met through a friend, two years after I first went public back in 1993-94. Stuart's my bodyguard, my pal. He looks after me. We are totally honest with each other and he knows when I'm going overboard. We have a similar background but different lives.

I came to Britain in 1979 aged 19. I'd had a difficult upbringing - I spent the first seven years of my life in an orphanage, and four years in a school run by the Red Cross in Italy. I was homeless and I worked in an Italian restaurant, washing up; then I began to construct my life.

I've always been very expressive and I wanted to make something of my life, so I started doing pottery classes and this led on to a foundation course at Camberwell, and a degree in fine art at Chelsea. Now I have a studio near Brick Lane in east London where I make my sculptures. I'm now able to make the work I want to make, because people have had faith in me at the right moment.

There is a cathartic element in my work, but I also want to make something beautiful. To me, the red cross is a symbol of protection - a feeling of belonging. My first red-cross tattoo was a political as well as a personal statement.

I use my body as a site for representation, and do 'bleeding performances' on stage in front of an audience about four times a year. At a bleed, I also work with a doctor, who inserts a needle into the veins in my arms to let the blood flow freely. One of the doctors I have worked with was on the ethical committee of the BMA.

I also give one-to-one performances [called Aktion 398] at galleries and museums around the world, where about 200 people come into the room to see me one by one. During performances I'm not aware of time. I'm naked and I paint myself white, and wear a white collar that you put on dogs so they don't lick their wounds: it is a metaphor for being vulnerable and powerful - if you use it in the right way. Stuart is like the nurse who comes to take your details and gets you from A to B. He also cuts me.

I appear with the wound and people can touch it or just look. It's like when you go into a church and see a beautiful painting and you want to touch it but you can't. When people come to watch, they bring their own baggage and make what they want of it.

Stuart Barclay I am an anarchist, which is why I started working with Franko. People should be able to do what they want as long as they're not messing anyone else around. I think if he wants to express himself in the way he does, he's got every right. I'd seen Franko before, but we met properly in 1996 at the ICA when I went to see his show there. He wanted me to hoist him up at that one, but I had a bad back.

I can see the emotion in Franko's performances, but to me it's just people reflecting on their own mortality. It only takes a few drops of someone else's blood for people to think, Shit, that could be mine. When people come into the gallery for Aktion 398, it reminds me of slowing down to see a motorway accident and catching a glimpse of the corpse; sometimes you look and see gallons of Claret and you think, Oh, maybe I shouldn't have looked.

I'm a people watcher. When I'm not with Franko I drive a lorry, delivering beer to pubs and clubs, and I do freelance scarification. I also like messing about with collages and cutting things out - photos and text. I've done a lot of door work over the years, so I can sense someone who's potentially dangerous straightaway. We only have to look at each other and we both know. Some people have a thousand-yard stare and you know they're trouble. I rarely get flustered, but if something major went wrong, like one of his arteries collapsed, I'd have a few problems. I could get his heart started again and that's probably about it.

I tell Franko how long he's got if he is doing a bleed: I have my eye on the clock. I'll quite happily cut him - it's not something you learn, you just get stuck in. I've also cut some text on his back. His hourly shock in the one-to-ones is when I come to re-do the cut - that brings him out of it a bit. I have to keep the wound fresh.

I've been to Italy, Norway and Sweden with Franko, and we've also been to Mexico together. I was shocked at the amount of cops in the streets with guns there. Anywhere that's had a bit of pain and suffering is more open to seeing his performances. I'm looking forward to going to America with him next year. It will be interesting to see what the US audience is like.

 Franko B takes part in a group show at the Wellcome Trust's gallery in London, from 5 October (020 7611 7211); the next Aktion 398 is at the National Review of Live Art in Glasgow, 1-5 November (0141 564 5552); www.ainexus.com/franko

webTitle: Six of the best... places to pick summer fruits

fields.headline: Six of the best...
fields.standfirst: ... places to pick summer fruits.
fields.trailText: Apparently, we're getting lazier as a nation. That's the sad surmise, anyway, which you might make on hearing that the pick-your-own trade has been declining for the past 10 years. Another reason may be our growing affluence. As Charles George of The Fruit Garden (Groesfaen Road, Peterston Super Ely, Cardiff; 01446 760358) puts it wryly, 'We do get what we call the BMW brigade, who come into the farm shop in white shoes and say they haven't time to pick.'
fields.body:
Apparently, we're getting lazier as a nation. That's the sad surmise, anyway, which you might make on hearing that the pick-your-own trade has been declining for the past 10 years. Another reason may be our growing affluence. As Charles George of The Fruit Garden (Groesfaen Road, Peterston Super Ely, Cardiff; 01446 760358) puts it wryly, 'We do get what we call the BMW brigade, who come into the farm shop in white shoes and say they haven't time to pick.'

At least these ladies who love fruit realise the produce at The Fruit Garden is worth travelling for. Friends who came beetling back to the capital after a brief spell in the country say it is the one thing they miss about Cardiff. George supplies the catering trade all year round; the PYO is naturally a summer thing. There are blueberries, raspberries, strawberries, tayberries, jostaberries, red-, white- and blackcurrants. It's one of very few places where you can try 'Marais des Bois', a cross of commercial and wild strawberries which have the lovely perfumed flavour of alpines. Mrs George uses equal proportions of blackcurrants, redcurrants and tayberries to make her 'summer-fruits sorbet', sold with other ice creams made on the farm under the label Ices from the Fruit Garden. Customers picking their own fruit reward themselves with ice cream by the scoop, but it is also sold by the half-litre.

At Woods Brasserie (Pilotage Building, Stuart Street, Cardiff Bay; 029 2049 2400), which is reckoned by aficionados to be the best restaurant in the area, slender, sophisticated customers are served The Fruit Garden's strawberries with black pepper and lemon juice. Greedier ones order them with Eton mess, a mixture of crushed meringue with Chantilly cream and a drizzle of puréed berries.

Most of the exotic berries - tayberries, loganberries, sunberries, et al - are hybrids involving raspberries and blackberries and have their following among jam makers, because they tend to be sharp when firm, and instantly crushable when fully ripe, so difficult to present in a fruit salad. Jostaberries are a cross between blackcurrants and gooseberries and purists think them odd.

At Priory Farm (Sandy Lane, Nutfield, Redhill, Surrey; 01737 823304), farmer Nick Shinner notices that people picking their own 'buy lots of strawberries and raspberries, then just a few blueberries to sprinkle on top because they look nice'. Most are sold in the blueberry pies marketed along with other home-baked dishes in the farm shop. But he maintains that blueberries, though thought of as American, grow slowly under our grey skies and therefore have more flavour than imports. It seems odd, therefore, that Priory Farm already has 'monster' blackberries, but these are the specially bred 'Silvan' variety, which are 'twice the size of raspberries and have a wonderful flavour'.

Strawberries remain the most popular berry of all. If you'd like some without a hint of weedkiller, try Church Farm Organics (Church Lane, Thurstaston, Wirral; 0151 648 7838), where two varieties - 'Symphony' and 'Honeyoye' - are the main crop. They taste fantastic, according to farmer Steve Ledsham, who says converting his land to Soil Association standard is the best thing he's done. Yet they cost just £3.30/kg - less than some conventionally grown PYO strawberries.

Two farms in West Sussex are worth a special trip. Churchfield Farm (West Chiltington, Pulborough, West Sussex; 01798 812353) offers all the regular fruits, plus jostaberries, tunnelberries (similar to tayberries) and golden (autumn) raspberries in an immaculate setting. With its trimmed grass paths and neatly espaliered fruit bushes, it looks like a giant kitchen garden. 'We're in the leisure business more than the food business,' explains owner James Mursell.

This social observation is taken seriously by Stewart Beare of Tulley's Farm (Turners Hill, near Crawley, West Sussex, 01342 718472). Fifty acres are devoted to PYO fruits and vegetables, including strawberries, raspberries, tayberries, loganberries, all the currants, gooseberries and plums. But as it is families whose food consumption is highest, and as children find fruit picking rather dull after the first few mouthfuls, Tulley's Farm lays on an extraordinary range of amusements. Apart from miniature tractors, trailer rides, straw tunnels and an animal enclosure, there is a goat run on which pygmy goats trot delicately above you in the trees and an eight-acre maze. It's cheaper than Legoland, and a tea of fresh berries beats burgers hands down.

 For a list of PYO farms throughout the UK, send an SAE to the Farm Retail Association, PO Box 575, Southampton, SO15 7ZB

fields.headline: Reach for the sky
fields.standfirst: Valencia could never compete with the glories of Gaudi's Barcelona, or Gehry's Bilbao. But that was before the city's favourite son, Santiago Calatrava, started building his crystal palaces
fields.trailText: Valencia could never compete with the glories of Gaudi's Barcelona, or Gehry's Bilbao. But that was before the city's favourite son, Santiago Calatrava, started building his crystal palaces.
fields.body:
Put Santiago Calatrava in front of the astonishing new science museum that he has designed for his home town of Valencia, and you would never believe that he could be responsible for it. Calatrava in person is soft spoken, a diffident, diminutive figure. His work, on the other hand, has swagger, even grandiloquence in bucketloads. And in Valencia, at least, it is on a truly gigantic scale.

Calatrava, guarded by his fiercely protective wife - an asset that is part of the essential armoury of many successful architects - is unworldy and monkish. But his work has become part of the raw material of power, an essential bargaining counter in the cut and thrust of ambitious politicians keen to make their mark. 'I don't go running after publicity,' Calatrava says.

But he doesn't need to. His work is perfectly capable of speaking for itself. And he has the drive of a child prodigy with the talent to do anything. He trained as an architect and an engineer. He designs furniture and makes sculpture.

When the BBC asked him to make a film about his favourite piece of architecture, it was no surprise to find that he chose to be filmed in the crypt of Antonio Gaudi's unfinished cathedral of Sagrada Familia in Barcelona, sketchbook in one hand and water colours in the other. Like Gaudi, Calatrava is fond of putting natural forms to work in his buildings. You can see bones and plant structures not very far from the surface. He, too, is a Catalan, and a one off. And as with Gaudi, people either regard his work as genius, or become uncomfortable with the monomania of its single mindedness. But it is clear that he identifies with Gaudi's otherworldiness as much as with his architecture. Gaudi lived like a monk, and is now being put forward as a candidate for sainthood. Calatrava is entirely uninterested in the material trappings of success, and shows a complete absence of guile. 'I just design to get things right,' he says.

It is an unlikely formula for success, but in less than 10 years, it has driven Calatrava from relative obscurity as an engineer architect specialising in spectacular bridges, and given him the chance to design cathedrals, museums and airports. Calatrava's plans for rebuilding Valencia took pride of place at an extraordinary show of his work at the RIBA eight years ago, when he was still known as just a bridge builder. To find them, you had to run the gauntlet of a room full of surprisingly bland art - still a sideline of Calatrava's, along with his furniture. Then there was a sequence of architectural schemes for sites all over the world, each more flamboyant than the last. And then, just when you felt there was nothing else left for Calatrava to throw in, you spotted the small white skeleton of a dog positioned at the door, and next to it, the Valencia project.

The dog was there to demonstrate the lessons enginers have to learn from natural structures. But it felt more like a memento mori, a skull for contemplation in the philosopher's cell. And it underscored just how much Calatrava stands out from the usual run of Miyake-clad architectural superstars.

He presented his design for a new museum quarter as a family of individual but related projects, with a series of elegant all-white models. They were arranged in sequence, starting with the smallest, a planetarium, and pulling back to reveal more of an apparently endless landscape, entirely the product of Calatrava's feverish imagination. There was a science museum, an opera house, and an arboretum.

The models looked frankly unbelievable. So much so that you began to wonder if there might not be something wrong with the scale. They showed buildings that seemed to belong in the same category as one of those Frank Lloyd Wright schemes for a skyscraper a mile high that sometimes haunt the imagination of architects of a certain age, equipped with a sufficiently robust ego. Usually, even when there is a client with just enough cash to pay for the model, they are never actually meant to be built.

Calatrava, barely 40 at the time, seemed a bit young to go in for this kind of dreaming. But he already had a whiff of the other-worldly vision that lingers around engineers who profess to find a hidden order in blades of grass, snowflakes and palm trees.

As it turns out, they were far from being the architectural fantasies that many people assumed. Ten years later, the project is even bigger than it looked in all those models and in sight of completion. It has gone through a few changes on the way. Plans to build a huge telecommunications mast were pronounced unviable and were dropped, though not before work had started on the foundations. But these were used to support the opera house instead. 'It's like constructing one cathedral on the foundations of another, as was often done in the past,' Calatrava has said of the changes. And other designers have been brought in to work on the landscaping and the adjoining sites. 'It's not all my work, you must understand,' he says, leaving you a little unsure about whether he is being modest or trying to suggest that he would have done things differently.

But there is no denying that it adds up to a remarkably powerful piece of architectural planning in the grand manner. In the midst of a scrum of apartment slabs 20 floors high that frame the site, albeit at a respectful distance, the project needed to be big. And big it certainly is. Imagine what it would be like walking through South Kensington if the Natural History Museum, the Science Museum, the Victoria and Albert, and the Crystal Palace were all being built simultaneously, and you get some idea of the pharonic scale. Valencia has caught a particularly virulent strain of the construction bug - fuelled by European Union cash - that is affecting so many contemporary Spanish cities, and not a few in Britain, too. And it has convinced itself that it can make the leap from a dusty provincial backwater on the edge of a virtual desert into the European big league by sheer effort of will and by building enough opera houses, bridges, museums, aquariums and metro stations.

A lot of the buildings are complete now. And the city is busy trying to sign up the people with the cachet to fill them, too. Zubin Mehta is being talked of as the musical director for the opera house. A conservatoire is under construction. There is a convention centre designed by Norman Foster.

What makes Valencia's complex even more extraordinary is that so much of the work has gone to just one architect. Calatrava, is, to put it mildly, something of a favourite son. He left Valencia for France in 1968 when he was just 16 years old, but came back when his attempts to study art there were thwarted by the May riots. He did his architecture degree at home, then moved to Zurich to do an engineering doctorate. He lives and works in Switzerland, but Valencia still treats Calatrava like a local football hero. It didn't just commission one of his signature bridges, the unmistakable sign of a city with an inferiority complex struggling to make its mark - even Manchester has one now - Valencia actually named its bridge after Calatrava.

In fact, Calatrava's home town was relatively slow to discover his special abilities. It was the bridges that he built in Barcelona, swooping like a fully extended long bow, and for the Seville Expo, supported by a single giant mast leaning at a dizzying angle, that really established his reputation. It was the Swiss who gave him his first big architectural commission - a railway station, Stadelhofen, in Zurich - and the French who followed it up by asking him to design the extraordinary TGV station at Lyon's Satolas airport with its roof that soars over the tracks, fanning steel blades in the air, like an eagle feathering its wings. Bilbao signed him up for yet another bridge and about to open his airport.

By the time he got to work in Valencia, Calatrava was a tried and tested crowd pleaser. He did buildings that managed to recreate the qualities of traditional architectural monuments in that they could stop the traffic without actually imitating the past directly, in the manner of that other Spanish maverick, Ricardo Bofill. Indeed, they have a way of looking aggressively modern. It was the perfect combination for politicians who wanted to be able to present themselves as being both populists and forward looking.

To a wider public to whom most architecture simply looks like a collection of boxes, one indistinguishable from the next, Calatrava's work is something special. You could say that he is like a painter retreating from abstraction, or an atonal composer rediscovering the idea of harmony.

He designs complicated show-off structures that demonstrate to even the uninitiated how much effort is going into keeping the building up, or stopping the bridge from wobbling. But unlike hi-tech architects, Calatrava pretties up his structures. He has a fondness for smooth, multiple curves, shaping his buildings like overhanging snowdrifts, or breaking surf. Each individual piece is considered a piece of sculpture, with Brancusi as an acknowledged inspiration.

It's an approach that means that he is not as popular with other architects as he is with the crowds that pour over his bridges and come flocking out of the Valencia planetarium still wearing their red-and-green 3D glasses in the sunshine. After the early and undoubtedly brilliant bridges, they find his work beginning to teeter on the edge of kitsch, now that he seems to have added a dash of early Dan Dare and a pinch of Art Deco to his enthusiasm for genetically modified Gothic architecture. In Barcelona, his design for a telecommunications mast immediately next to the city's Olympic stadium, described by its critics as resembling an overgrown radiator mascot from an ancient Buick, sparked an unsuccessful campaign to stop it being built. And in Berlin, Calatrava was embittered enough about losing the competition to rebuild the Reichstag to publically accuse Norman Foster of plagiarism when the British architect was forced by Helmut Kohl to add a glass dome to his winning design. Foster quietly pointed out that while Calatrava's design had indeed included a glass dome, the idea was hardly an original one in Berlin, a city with hundreds of domes to choose from.

The approach to Valencia from the airport is through baked-brown scrubland and bare rock, from which undistinguished concrete slabs stud the landscape at aimless intervals, interrupted by the occasional flash of brilliant green where irrigation brings the soil alive. Then as you enter the city, new apartment blocks mushroom everywhere, suddenly dropping back to reveal Calatrava's complex of buildings. His competition-winning master plan for the whole area puts the various elements of what Valencia calls a Science Park in long straight rows along the dried-up riverbed that twists and turns through Valencia, a scar left by the diversion of the Turia river back in the 60s to ensure that there would never be a repetition of the catastrophic flood that devastated the city in 1957. It's a bold formal plan, in an area that has previously lacked a sense of vision in its development. Calatrava says the design is driven by climate. 'In Britain, if you want to keep plants alive, you have to protect them from frost with a glasshouse. It's so hot and dry here, that you have to provide shade and water.'

Thus each of the buildings is positioned with its feet in one or other of a series of giant reflecting pools that run the whole length of the site. Calatrava has used them as elements in his composition, counting on night-time reflections to magnify the impact of the buildings.

The largest, and for Calatrava the most ambitious, element is the 1,800-seat opera house, due to be completed in three years' time. Not even a master of structural engineering with his track record can avoid the necessity of building a large square fly tower, which gets in the way of his swooping geometries. He has attempted to hide it under a series of flying roofs that contrive to give the building the slightly sinister look of a Samurai helmet. Functionally, they are justified by sheltering a secondary outdoor auditorium that provides an additional 2,500 seats to the main hall. Then comes one of the two bridges that sweep across the riverbed to link new Valencia with the old city. Next in the sequence is the planetarium, the first part of the complex to open for business.

Calatrava has hidden the concrete shell that accommodates laser shows and special-effect films inside a secondary shell structure, partly cut open at the edges to provide a degree of shade, connecting it with a network of walkways that reach out all over the site. There are various interpretations of the planetarium's shape. Calatrava's sketches show an eye, its lashes fluttering up. And at night, reflections in the water do indeed have the effect of making the hemispherical dome look like the ball at the centre of an oval eye. But during the day, the two concentric shells make the planetarium look more like a tortoise. Then comes the most flamboyant structure of all, a science museum due to open in September. It has glass walls on all four sides, with a spiny structure of pointed arches holding up a series of platforms inside and out and propped up by what look like twin diving boards, but which actually provide access.

The intricate structure rears up against the sky like the bleached bones of some long-dead giant sea creature, beached in the sand. It has the jagged outline not of a lobster exactly, but maybe an even more exotic crustacean, a Morton Bay bug inflated to gigantic scale, perhaps.

The fourth structure on the site, also almost complete, is the arboretum that Calatrava has designed: a ribbed set of hoops that will provided a pleasant, shaded walk.

With a reputed cost of £2bon, it is a development on an epic scale, one that few cities even twice Valencia's size could contemplate. All the city must do now is hope that the visitors come, and that they find Santiago Calatrava's architecture as fascinating as Valencia does.

And in Valencia, at least, it is on a truly gigantic scale. Calatrava, guarded by his fiercely protective wife - an asset that is part of the essential armoury of many successful architects - is unworldy and monkish. But his work has become part of the raw material of power, an essential bargaining counter in the cut and thrust of ambitious politicians keen to make their mark. 'I don't go running after publicity,' Calatrava says. But he doesn't need to. His work is perfectly capable of speaking for itself. And he has the drive of a child prodigy with the talent to do anything. He trained as an architect and an engineer. He designs furniture and makes sculpture. When the BBC asked him to make a film about his favourite piece of architecture, it was no surprise to find that he chose to be filmed in the crypt of Antonio Gaudi's unfinished cathedral of Sagrada Familia in Barcelona, sketchbook in one hand and water colours in the other. Like Gaudi, Calatrava is fond of putting natural forms to work in his buildings. You can see bones and plant structures not very far from the surface. He, too, is a Catalan, and a one off. And as with Gaudi, people either regard his work as genius, or become uncomfortable with the monomania of its single mindedness. But it is clear that he identifies with Gaudi's otherworldiness as much as with his architecture. Gaudi lived like a monk, and is now being put forward as a candidate for sainthood. Calatrava is entirely uninterested in the material trappings of success, and shows a complete absence of guile. 'I just design to get things right,' he says. It is an unlikely formula for success, but in less than 10 years, it has driven Calatrava from relative obscurity as an engineer architect specialising in spectacular bridges, and given him the chance to design cathedrals, museums and airports. Calatrava's plans for rebuilding Valencia took pride of place at an extraordinary show of his work at the RIBA eight years ago, when he was still known as just a bridge builder. To find them, you had to run the gauntlet of a room full of surprisingly bland art - still a sideline of Calatrava's, along with his furniture. Then there was a sequence of architectural schemes for sites all over the world, each more flamboyant than the last. And then, just when you felt there was nothing else left for Calatrava to throw in, you spotted the small white skeleton of a dog positioned at the door, and next to it, the Valencia project. The dog was there to demonstrate the lessons enginers have to learn from natural structures. But it felt more like a memento mori, a skull for contemplation in the philosopher's cell. And it underscored just how much Calatrava stands out from the usual run of Miyake-clad architectural superstars. He presented his design for a new museum quarter as a family of individual but related projects, with a series of elegant all-white models. They were arranged in sequence, starting with the smallest, a planetarium, and pulling back to reveal more of an apparently endless landscape, entirely the product of Calatrava's feverish imagination. There was a science museum, an opera house, and an arboretum. The models looked frankly unbelievable. So much so that you began to wonder if there might not be something wrong with the scale. They showed buildings that seemed to belong in the same category as one of those Frank Lloyd Wright schemes for a skyscraper a mile high that sometimes haunt the imagination of architects of a certain age, equipped with a sufficiently robust ego. Usually, even when there is a client with just enough cash to pay for the model, they are never actually meant to be built. Calatrava, barely 40 at the time, seemed a bit young to go in for this kind of dreaming. But he already had a whiff of the other-worldly vision that lingers around engineers who profess to find a hidden order in blades of grass, snowflakes and palm trees. As it turns out, they were far from being the architectural fantasies that many people assumed. Ten years later, the project is even bigger than it looked in all those models and in sight of completion. It has gone through a few changes on the way. Plans to build a huge telecommunications mast were pronounced unviable and were dropped, though not before work had started on the foundations. But these were used to support the opera house instead. 'It's like constructing one cathedral on the foundations of another, as was often done in the past,' Calatrava has said of the changes. And other designers have been brought in to work on the landscaping and the adjoining sites. 'It's not all my work, you must understand,' he says, leaving you a little unsure about whether he is being modest or trying to suggest that he would have done things differently. But there is no denying that it adds up to a remarkably powerful piece of architectural planning in the grand manner. In the midst of a scrum of apartment slabs 20 floors high that frame the site, albeit at a respectful distance, the project needed to be big. And big it certainly is. Imagine what it would be like walking through South Kensington if the Natural History Museum, the Science Museum, the Victoria and Albert, and the Crystal Palace were all being built simultaneously, and you get some idea of the pharonic scale. Valencia has caught a particularly virulent strain of the construction bug - fuelled by European Union cash - that is affecting so many contemporary Spanish cities, and not a few in Britain, too. And it has convinced itself that it can make the leap from a dusty provincial backwater on the edge of a virtual desert into the European big league by sheer effort of will and by building enough opera houses, bridges, museums, aquariums and metro stations. A lot of the buildings are complete now. And the city is busy trying to sign up the people with the cachet to fill them, too. Zubin Mehta is being talked of as the musical director for the opera house. A conservatoire is under construction. There is a convention centre designed by Norman Foster. What makes Valencia's complex even more extraordinary is that so much of the work has gone to just one architect. Calatrava, is, to put it mildly, something of a favourite son. He left Valencia for France in 1968 when he was just 16 years old, but came back when his attempts to study art there were thwarted by the May riots. fields.headline: Barefoot Doctor
fields.standfirst: An alternative look at health issues. This week: how to control weight, prevent morning sickness, and cope with the office bully
fields.trailText: An alternative look at health issues. This week: how to control weight, prevent morning sickness, and cope with the office bully.
fields.body:
How many times have you been to a GP with a list of seemingly unconnected debilitating symptoms to be told after perfunctory examination, 'It's probably a virus'? To be fair, it probably is.

With the proliferation of people on the planet has come a proliferation of viruses. From the Latin virus (meaning the poisonous sap in weeds), viruses are primal slime looking for a friendly host-body to colonise. Don't take it personally - it's just nature's basic urge to thrive on every level.

There's currently a particularly interesting slimeball virus circulating the length and breadth of the land. It 'invades' the liver, causing sudden extreme tiredness, headaches, bloated stomach, indigestion, mild depression or disorientation, grouchiness, fever, intestinal cramps and sometimes sore throats. Its symptoms reoccur every fortnight or so for at least a few months. They are almost indistinguishable from glandular fever or Epstein-Barr syndrome and not dissimilar to hepatitis.

The intense stress of going through your daily paces - work, travel, social networking and technology-accelerated communications - pounds the nerves, liver, kidneys, heart and digestive organs hourly. Air-, water- and food-borne pollutants are increasing exponentially, making the liver work far harder to detoxify your system. The constant self-assessment necessary to adjust to the daily marketplace, along with the insidious bombarding of the senses with product advertisement, upsets your sense of self-esteem. This expends and diverts vast amounts of energy normally used to maintain the immune system. More than ever, our defences are strained, leaving us increasingly vulnerable to virus invasion.

To build your immune system, you first need to start with the mind, which then relays the message to the body. Make a clear choice and intention to attain all the health and longevity within your power. This will mobilise the necessary energy to stabilise your system and protect you against 'invasion'.

Daily exercise is crucial in helping this regulatory energy circulate. It should be a combination of hard and soft, external and internal exercise. Running and yoga. Weight-training and t'ai chi.

Avoid rich, greasy, stodgy food and stimulants - this will help to take the strain off the liver. Relax, breathe and remember that you feel far stronger when you know you're loved, so love yourself as best as you can. Above all, factor in time for unbridled joy. Take yourself out to the nearest good party and dance. Dance till your socks fall off. For in that uninhibited, childlike state, your true strength will be revealed.

Dear Barefoot Doc, since turning 30, I've been putting on weight but haven't been eating any more than I usually do. How do I stop it?
Ros Mitchell, Taunton, Somerset

Around 28, your metabolism goes through a change. Your digestive organs no longer function quite so efficiently and need extra help. In Chinese medicine, it's thought that your spleen and pancreas are responsible for regulating your weight. Help them along by taking a fingertip lick of horseradish each morning (this stimulates the spleen). Introduce millet into your diet (considered to support the spleen). Obviously, avoid fatty food. Take a serious 30-minute walk at least three times a week and increase general exercise levels. Most importantly, spend regular time visualising your body exactly as you would have it, as this sets up an autonomic command to the body to deblob.

Dear Doc, I'm pregnant and suffering from morning sickness all day long. Someone recommended acupuncture. Is it safe to have it done when you're pregnant?
Sarah McEwen, Edinburgh

It's not only safe but often highly effective. Naturally, there are points contraindicated during pregnancy, but any trained acupuncturist will know which ones to avoid. Morning sickness, according to Oriental physiology, arises because the kidney energy which normally supports the liver energy is otherwise engaged in supporting the baby. The liver subsequently overheats and loses control of the stomach energy, which in turn rises to the throat, thus causing nausea. By the time you've unravelled that explanation, you should be well into your second trimester and the sickness should have passed naturally. Meanwhile, two or three acupuncture sessions can turn the condition round in no time.

Dear Barefoot Doc, I hate my boss and feel constantly bullied by him. This has happened in every job I have ever had. How can I change this?
Mark Brown, Leeds

Perhaps this is a childhood pattern being enacted unconsciously. Children bullied by fathers or older siblings often find themselves unwittingly inviting the same scenario in adult life. First you must build your self-esteem. Rebirthing sessions and NLP (Neuro-Linguistic Programming) are both effective and fast. Kick-boxing is a quick way of building confidence and releasing hatred. Then it's down to some respectful yet assertive communication with your boss. Finally, remember it's not your boss you hate, but what he does.

If you have any problems you'd like answers to, please write to Barefoot Doctor at Life Magazine, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC12 3ER or email him on www.barefootdoctorglobal.com

fields.headline: The perfect...
fields.standfirst: ... ballet
fields.trailText: ... ballet
fields.body:
My perfect performance would start with the bedroom scene in Manon , the pas de deux. It's very passionate but lyrical at the same time - it's about love, really. I've lost count of how many times I've danced Manon - it's a Kenneth MacMillan ballet and he's my favourite choreographer. He almost has words in his steps - you could be watching a play, and I love it. Actually, the Royal Ballet is doing Manon at the moment.

After that, as a complete contrast, I would probably go into the second act of Giselle. It's the act where she dies from love, becomes this ethereal creature, and there's this wonderful pas de deux that the corps de ballet is also involved in. It's very potent. The magic of the second act of Giselle is that it removes you, takes you to a different world.

Then I think I'd go into something completely classic, like Sleeping Beauty, which is just one of those things that a ballerina has to do, in much the same way that an actor does Shakespeare; at some stage they have to do Macbeth. I would do the rose adage, which is at the very beginning when she arrives at the party and her father wants to introduce her to the four princes and she has to choose one of them. The dancer does this very technical set of steps where she has to stand on one leg and do some very demanding balancing. Although it is very technically demanding, it's not all about technique, though - you have to be charming and soft as well as very strong on your legs.

Finally, I'd have Anastasia by MacMillan again - the last act, the third act, when she's in an asylum. It's a very powerful piece, and I was nominated for a Lawrence Olivier award for it when I did it at the Royal.
