fields.headline: Seriously, it's Richard Blackwood
fields.standfirst: Most people would be content with the stand-up comedy shows, the TV series and the hit record. But not Richard Blackwood. He is too busy planning stage four - to be Britain's answer to Will Smith
fields.trailText: Most people would be content with the stand-up comedy shows, the TV series and the hit record. But not Richard Blackwood. He is too busy planning stage four - to be Britain's answer to Will Smith.
fields.body:
I 'm standing on the crest of a hill, around 15 miles up the coast from Montego Bay. A hot and bothered video crew waits for British comedian Richard Blackwood, who is in Jamaica to film the video for his forthcoming single. '1,2,3,4 Get with the Wicked' can be heard rippling across the countryside.

Blackwood's rise to the forefront of black comedy - and now late-night light entertainment - has been little short of miraculous. His career as a stand-up began only six years ago, at the age of 22, and has seen a quick progression from the margins to the mainstream. A little over three years ago, he was still an undercard performer at the Hackney Empire. Then he was offered regular slots on MTV. Last year, The Richard Blackwood Show was unleashed on Channel 4, drawing in more than 1 million viewers a week and establishing him as a brand. And now, with a hit single, he has been called a British Will Smith.

Black British comedy has failed to define itself on national TV since The Lenny Henry Show a decade ago. And in Blackwood - young, apolitical and with a style that goes down as easily as Coke - the genre has a totem around which to gather. Even in his late-night slot, Blackwood has managed to corral together an impressive array of guests - LL Cool J, Don King, Prince Naseem and Mel B. Now, standing before me at the shoot, he nods in acknowledgement. 'We'll have a chat later,' he says. 'Gotta earn my crust first.' He returns to the video - a romantic escape scenario, in which he attempts to outrun the father of the female lead.

Throughout the afternoon, filming progresses at a painstakingly slow pace. As his friends amuse themselves, Blackwood looks on at the huddles of figures, occasionally strolling over for a chat. He is always well groomed, his little goatee seemingly drawn on to his face with a thick crayon. Those big, dark eyes blink perhaps slightly too fast - and the mouth has an uncanny knack of breaking into a happy-to-see-you grin.

Comedians are almost always too busy with self-flagellation to bother with their immediate surroundings. But Blackwood - with his über-slick presentation - has little in common with most other comics. His isn't a personality constructed out of gags and clever one-liners. In fact, throughout the two-day shoot he rarely cracks a smile from his co-workers, preferring instead to listen quietly and appreciatively to their gags.

Later that evening, Blackwood walks over to my table near the bar. He is simply dressed in casual wear - baggies cut off below the shins, a T-shirt and his trademark diamond-studded earring. Thankfully, he seems to betray none of the surly introspection that typifies most comedians. When I inform him that I had watched consecutive videos of his MTV performances, The Richard Blackwood Show ' and a guest slot on the Jo Whiley Show, he only grins politely. 'You got a triple dose, huh?' he offers. 'Must have been tough.'

Richard Blackwood grew up in Streatham, south London, in the mid-70s, the product of a stable family environment. He doesn't smoke or drink. His only moment of rebellion, he admits, was at the age of 16, when he took to selling bootleg pornographic videos.

While he was at college studying for a business degree, he was already meeting agents, and by the time he graduated he was ready to launch himself into the black comedy circuit. 'I couldn't believe people were willing to pay for this stuff,' he says. His father married model Naomi Campbell's mother, Valerie, when Blackwood was 10 and Naomi was 12. The two never shared a home - he lived nearby with his grandparents, his mother having moved to Sweden - but were close as teenagers in the years before she started her modelling career.

'We were closer when we were younger - then my dad and her mum split up. She's got her life to lead, and I have my own. Remember, we were only together for a short space of time; our parents were together for only seven years. But we speak from time to time. Naomi's good people. She was a good sister for a long time: she saw me at the clubs. We still talk.'

He has rarely spoken about his half-sister before, and now excitedly relates an anecdote. 'She told me she was seeing Mike Tyson,' he giggles. 'We were sitting in my room - and she told me she'd started going out with him. I was just too shocked - in fact, I didn't believe her.'

Throughout the interview, Blackwood speaks of business plans - for the immediate and the future. I recall a passage from American variety performer Bob Hope's 1954 memoir, Bob Hope's Own Story: Have Tux, Will Travel . Always surrounded by a production line of writers who were permanently on call, Hope took to phoning his jokesmiths day and night. 'Thrill me,' he'd simply say.

'I'm not like that at all,' breathes Blackwood, genuinely astonished. 'I guess TV makes you lazy - and I do less and less stand-up. I have other people helping me write, but TV is much more disciplined. You only have so much time, and the whole thing is rehearsed to a point beyond professionalism. Modern comedy is much more slick now, remember. Can't be cussin' and swearin' on MTV. There's always a script that goes through various sets of people. The networks don't like mavericks these days - so I have to play ball.'

Blackwood's debut album, the cautiously titled I Know You'd Love to Hate This won't give New York's underground rap scene any worrying thoughts of a rival British explosion. With its rhythmically populist, distilled ragga beats and pan-Atlantic cultural references, the album makes for entertaining, if inoffensive, listening. And Blackwood is the first to acknowledge his musical limitations.

'I grew up listening to people like Eric B & Rakim, and Run DMC. But I wouldn't even begin to compare myself to them. If you're going to take my rap thing seriously, then you're not getting it. I'm trying to make it fun: it's an extension of the comedy. I'm trying to bring that aspect of my show to the music - nothing more, nothing less.'

The defence of his music comes across as almost fidgety, agitated to a degree of calm ferocity. Earlier, his manager, Beverley Randall, had told me: 'The first time I saw him, I told him I wouldn't manage him. And he was astounded. "It's because you're too hungry," I said. He just seemed to want it all so badly. It was like watching pure ambition drip off someone.'

He was recently signed to a record label in a deal reputedly worth £1m. An 11-track collection of pleasant-enough street anthems, the album includes his debut single, the Top Ten hit 'Mama - Who Da Man?' The record has, for the most part, been produced by his uncle, Junior Giscombe, who himself had a hit single, 'Mama Used to Say', back in 1982.

Black urban polymaths are still an American phenomenon. Richard Pryor, Eddie Murphy, Martin Lawrence and Will Smith (the latter is Blackwood's blueprint for success) all personify the post-civil rights delirium of capital-led franchises supplemented by both stage and screen. The brashly political tones of black American comedy, obsessed by output, aggrandisement and celebrity, are unique to the African-American psyche.

British comedians are often characterised by their geeky behaviour. The profession attracts a certain kind of social misfit - all those hours spent holed up in bedrooms scribbling one-liners on the back of cereal packets must require a unique brand of vanity.

'You're right,' admits Blackwood, earnestly. 'Comedy is just one of those careers - it seems to attract all the odds and ends of society. The kind of people who know they're funny long before any of their friends realise it.' Between thumb and forefinger, he starts to stroke his beard. 'Me? Was I that geeky? Yeah. If I had a gig on Friday, you could probably speak to me on Monday - from then on, I was hiding somewhere, rehearsing. I already had the material, I just wanted to perfect the delivery.'

Compared to Lenny Henry - who peeled back the institutionalised racism of the 1980s while providing a dim promise of hope to the Black left - Blackwood's one-liners supply playful jokes that easily pacify an apolitical generation. Even on the rare occasions when he has dropped all cued caution, his well-oiled professionalism re-programmes his routine back on message.

'I made this joke about the Queen once,' he says. 'I said, "The bitch has her face on money, and she looks bored. If my face was on money, I'd never look bored." I never should have said it - there was no need for it. I have nothing against the Queen: it's not like I know her. I'm wary about swearing too much - but at the same time, I don't want to avoid the issues of the day. I felt guilty about that one for a while afterwards.' Yet, only minutes later, he contradicts this very assertion. 'I'll always say what I think. I'm never going to hold back. 'Cos Richard Blackwood is always raw.'

Like most comedians, Blackwood feels a need to justify his humour; this he does in almost religious detail. 'People get angry when they hear certain things - I asked Don King how he pulled off that fight in Zaire in the middle of the jungle. I mean, there were no toilets there. So how did he pull it off? A couple of days later, this woman grabs me in the street. "I'm from Zaire," she says. "Why did you portray Zaire like that on your show?" I had to explain to her I was talking about that part of Zaire. I've got the thing on tape to back me up.'

There's that seriousness again - comedians, I reckon, spend too much time making other people laugh to ever treat themselves in a self-deprecating manner. Blackwood ignores the comment - he has warmed to his theme of Black conservatism.

'People are trying too hard to emulate negativity,' he pronounces. 'Kids nowadays know that it's fashionable to be hard. They listen to rappers talking about ghetto life, and understandably the kids want some of that. They don't equate money with hard work. They just see Puff Daddy with all his diamonds. None of the kids know it took him around a decade of hard work to put that together. And, more to the point, kids just don't have those positive role models any more.'

Later on, I carry a chair over to Giscombe's table, near the edge of the video shoot. Behind us, Blackwood and his friends squeal down the hill on shop-worn mopeds - even in the heat, and with the director suffering from sunstroke, the chase sequence will require a number of takes.

Over curried saltfish, lightly fried chicken and freshly sliced pineapples, Giscombe dispenses weighty chapters from his encyclopedic knowledge of modern pop. With his wire-rimmed spectacles, knee-length blue shorts and multi-hued trainers, he's likeable company - peppering his sentences with an agreeable 'thank you'. 'You think the record industry is short of singer-songwriters? Thank you. My point exactly: all the major labels are thinking of easy money with boy bands. And just think of all these kids that'll be washed up by the age of 20. Thank you.'

He smiles, watching Blackwood career past on his moped at dangerous speeds. The comedian seems oblivious to his sex appeal on the set - and you sense that he rarely deviates from his determined business plans. Rubbing his glasses on his vest, Giscombe laughs - it's the quiet, knowing giggle of an industry veteran. In his previous incarnation as a pop star, he relished all the hospitality that followed his career - famously appearing at the Soul Train awards to promote his hit single. 'Look at him, having fun,' he says now. 'He's working hard - but these are the days for it. All the effort will pay off.'

Blackwood Inc, admits Giscombe, is a hypothetical conglomerate of his own founding. According to plan, the comedian's résumé should eventually index his credentials across all the sub-registries of the digital age - cinema, music, the internet and light entertainment. 'You buy a computer, you want it to do all kinds of things,' he says, by way of explanation. 'Entertainers are the same. Being a jack of all trades is important right now. Look at Michael Jordan: he's a one-man industry.'

Giscombe strolls over to the catering tent for a glass of water. On the surface, he seems to cloak any ambition with neighbourly humour. But stretching out an arm to shield himself from the mid-afternoon sun, he casually lets slip his hopes for his nephew. 'How far will Richard go? That's up to him - it depends on how badly he wants it. I want this boy to go all the way, and I believe he can make it.' He wheels around to face me. 'Let's face it, nothing's for ever,' he adds. Giscombe could now be talking about himself; his already hushed tones seem drowned by the memory of that hit single, now almost 20 years ago. 'Richard has to make the most of the momentum. It's all about branding him on to the international map - after that, there are no limiting factors.'

That afternoon, Blackwood had sat silently in the back of the minivan as the film crews made their way to the next location. His co-star in the video, and a guest on I Know You'd Love to Hate This, General Levy dragged on a joint behind him. A drum'n'bass producer of significant reputation, Levy enjoyed notable success in the early 90s: his maniacal features were on regular display in style bibles such as The Face ' and i-D .

'Jamaican women have strange feet,' Levy pondered, loudly, half-stoned. 'They're rough at the bottom - you could light matches from them soles. Man, them feet are rough - they could tear your flesh off. Feet like that are like weapons. I'd do anything for a Jamaican woman, except rub her feet. It's 'cos they is always walking - look at 'em.' He said, regretfully: 'Love Jamaican women - just can' take the feet, though. Dem is too rough.'

Levy's light-hearted banter had the mini-van's occupants in hysterics - vendors peered up from their stalls to gawk at the helplessly creased faces trundling past them. Blackwood, though, seemed distracted, gazing sternly out of the window.

That afternoon I'd said to him: 'The Black press has been especially cruel in its denunciation of your music.' 'Yeah,' he'd sighed. 'I don't know why - I really don't know why. Maybe it's that British thing of knocking someone down.' He looked momentarily hurt, gazing forlornly out of the window, his eyes hiding behind a thick pair of wrap-around sunglasses.

The vilification of Blackwood in the ethnic press poses an obviously interesting question about the trappings of free Black enterprise in the UK. In the US, basketball stars like Shaquille O'Neal and Denis Rodman - the most implausible of musical talents - have both released big-selling rap albums to little critical abuse. And comedian Chris Rock's 'Roll with It' and 'Bigger and Blacker' have both featured interpolated musical collaborations with rap auteur Prince Paul.

Yet Blackwood, to his considerable mystification, while previously glorified by newspapers and magazines such as New Nation , Hip-Hop Connection and Touch Magazine has, in recent months, seen his musical venture systematically scorned, then ridiculed. 'People don't have a problem with someone like Will Smith rapping: he doesn't take himself too seriously,' says Vince Jackson, editor of Touch Magazine . 'Blackwood, on the other hand, seems to act like he means it. There is another argument - and maybe this might be a little cruel. As a rapper, Richard simply isn't very good.'

'That's not the point at all,' Giscombe told me minutes before I left Jamaica. 'We're not saying he's a great rapper - we're saying he's an entertainer.' Blackwood's uncle sighed, giving me a parting hug. Then he darted back to his project - the branding of Richard Blackwood. I left, an old Bob Hope gag in my mind: in his 1996 compendium of presidential one-liners, Dear Prez, I Wanna Tell Ya , perhaps fazed by the criticism over his conservative stance over the Vietnamese war, Hope wrote: 'Laughter is non-partisan.'

Blackwood's career - ever soaring, over-achieving, easily digestible - says much about the current state of black comedy. A decade ago, The Richard Blackwood Show would have rendered him a paradox - out of touch with the common ground against Thatcherism. These days, however, an apolitical nuance is a marketable attribute. Late- night entertainment - once by definition virulently leftwing and sociopolitical - has returned to the chirpy, hippy, happy heyday of the 70s. It should help turn Blackwood into a star of these times.

 Richard Blackwood's new single, '1,2,3,4 Get with the Wicked', is released on 4 September

webTitle: Down and out in New York

fields.headline: Down and out in New York
fields.standfirst: The Hotel Providence offers shelter of a sort to the 224 men who live and die in its windowless cages. Guy Lawson spends three weeks with Sleepout Jackie, Methadone Stevie, Turk and Raul in a Bowery flophouse
fields.trailText: The Hotel Providence offers shelter of a sort to the 224 men who live and die in its windowless cages. Guy Lawson spends three weeks with Sleepout Jackie, Methadone Stevie, Turk and Raul in a Bowery flophouse.
fields.body:
The Hotel Providence stands at the intersection of Grand Street and the Bowery in lower Manhattan, a nondescript five-story brick building diagonally across from the Romanesque columns of the long-defunct Bowery Savings Bank. To the west is the bustle of Little Italy and SoHo; to the east are Latino neighbourhoods and the bars and bistros of the gentrifying Lower East Side. The façade of the Hotel Providence is chipped, the paint the colour of wan flesh, and the sign advertising its presence is small, inconspicuous in the riot of billboards and store fronts. Days on the Bowery, the streets of Chinatown surrounding the hotel are teeming with pedestrians; passers-by hurry along the pavement without a sideward glance. Nights, after the lighting-fixture and restaurant-supply stores have rolled down their metal sliding doors, the avenue is deserted, lit only by the thin yellow glow of street lights and of traffic slowly making its way downtown.

The entrance to the Providence is wedged between a Chinese restaurant and a vegetable market. Inside, beyond the two or three men always loitering in the doorway, a single, steep flight of stairs leads up to a landing, where a clerk sits at the front desk behind a thick glass cage. The new operators are Chinese and their sides of conversations about paying rent, trying to pick up mail, and complaints were shouted across the front desk in fractured English.

The marble floor was cracked and riven with grime, the air thick with the smells of men left to their own devices. The windows were stained brown by generations of cigarette smoke and soot; it was impossible to see into the hotel from the street, impossible to see out from the lobby.

At night, before the alcohol and drugs had taken hold, the talk in the lobby was muted and friendly: 'How'd you eat today?' 'Got an extra smoke?' 'Burger King has a special, a Whopper for 99 cents, a buck seven with tax.' Many had become permanent residents of the Providence, some having lived there for decades, and they had gained the legal rights of tenants under New York law: their rent raises were controlled by the city in accordance with the rate at the time the man first moved in. Some men were still paying as little as $4 or $5 a night and, in theory at least, they had recourse to the courts and police to ensure that they are not evicted. New arrivals, classified as temporary residents, faced a rule that wasn't posted but that was universal on the Bowery and strictly applied: the most time that the managers permitted a newcomer to stay was 21 nights in a row. The days each new arrival spent in the Providence were carefully marked in the ledger book, and at the end of 21 days, he was required to leave the hotel for a night or two before he was allowed to return.

The hotel lobby, the point of return at dark, filled with men as the sun set and the coming winter began to chill the nights. The men were mostly white and Hispanic. The permanent residents and regulars, like Raul, were in their late thirties and forties and older, although many looked years and even decades beyond their years. Stevie, a gaunt methadone junkie, his complexion deathly pale, sat at a table and drank a bottle of Wild Irish Rose; Turk, dressed in shorts and a canvas sun hat, shared the leftover won ton and tofu he collected from a Chinese restaurant across the street. Another man, who couldn't muster the price of a room but was allowed to spend his evenings in the lobby, tried to sell anything he had come across in his wanderings that might have value: Bic razors, a broken watch, a snowsuit. The transients were younger, in their twenties and thirties; new men turned up in the lobby on most nights.

The Providence was originally built in the 1880s as a place for sailors to sleep off their shore-leave drinks. At the time, places like the Providence were known as 'cage hotels' - then, as now, the 'rooms' weren't, in any real sense, rooms at all: most were cubicles measuring 3.5ft wide, 6ft long and 8ft high. The walls were flimsy wooden partitions; there were no windows in most rooms, and chicken wire was strung over the top in place of a ceiling. Among the varieties of shelter once available on the Bowery - 'barrel houses', which provided a place to sit out of the rain in exchange for the purchase of keg beer; 'rope houses', with ropes strung across the room for men to lean against as they tried to sleep standing up; 'flophouses', often amounting to nothing more than a roof overhead and a space on the floor of an open room - the cage hotels, with a private 'room' and chicken-wire ceilings, were relatively upmarket; they have become what are now known generically as flophouses.

The second floor of the Providence was divided between the lobby and rooms mostly occupied by permanent residents. Upstairs, each of the floors had reputations for violence and danger that varied depending on who was talking: the third floor was safe, the fourth and fifth infested with drug dealers; the fourth was all right, but the third and fifth were risky. My room was on the fourth floor, near Stevie's. Whenever I opened the door, I was met by a waft of rank, dead air. Inside, a rickety metal-frame cot with a piece of plywood under a wafer-thin mattress and covered by a single torn sheet pocked with cigarette burns; pillows and blanket weren't provided. The room was painted in two tones, dull green and dull red, and there was one exposed light bulb and one hook and Spanish graffiti scratched on the wall next to a faded poster of an Indian chief and a note taped in a corner that said, 'Just a reminder_ to keep trying.' The bathroom was at the far end of the floor, four toilet stalls for more than 60 men, the tiling cracked and filthy and marked with scrawlings saying Flush Don't Be A Pig, and threats and counter-threats, claims and counterclaims that someone was a Homo who Takes It Up The Ass. In the dead of night, the man in the next room moaned in his sleep, his low cries joining the chorus of hacking coughs and wheezes and the deep, guttural rasp of throat-cleared phlegm sounding throughout the hotel. Roaches crawled across the floor and walls, and small, airborne, biting midges lit on the sheets. Some men tried to control these plagues with sprays and chemical bombs, but most just learned to live with them. That first night I didn't sleep at all.

Mornings came early at the Providence, stirrings beginning just after dawn, voices calling out, televisions turned on, radios tuned to Howard Stern and salsa and all-news stations. Sleepout Jackie, a long-time resident, lived a few doors away on the fourth floor. Sleepout ran a kind of restaurant from his room - a 'chuck wagon', he called it - and he sold heros and meatball sandwiches for a dollar each. Sleepout said he had been attacked with a machete once, and he stayed clear of the lobby at night because there were too many fights. Stevie, the methadone junkie who lived one hallway over, had battled with Sleepout, and Sleepout had thrown buckets of cold water through the chicken wire of Stevie's room.

In the Providence, I soon discovered, there was little interaction among the men, apart from the evening gatherings in the lobby, and in a nook at the back of the second floor, where some went to smoke joints. The rooms were too small to fit a visitor. Conversations in the hallways and the stairs were brief and perfunctory; the long-time residents knew each other, and took vague notice of comings and goings, of illnesses and arrests and deaths, but there were few friendships. There were occasional low-budget visitors stopping in the hotel, like the college graduate from the Midwest who worked as a bike courier in Manhattan and who quick-stepped his way to his room each evening, or the two young French hipsters in black leather pants and silk shirts who checked in one night to cop heroin. For the residents, though, the Providence's drug dealers were a constant and watchful presence. Sleep was difficult, impossible when a drunken argument started. The stench was close and tangible, the temper lawless.

Detective Robert Sushinsky from the Fifth Precinct, who regularly checked the hotel's register for men with outstanding warrants, and who was often called to the hotel to collect the corpse of an alcoholic or junkie who had died in his sleep, told me the police wouldn't send undercover cops into the hotel because most of the men there had done time in jail and they could smell anyone who didn't belong there. It was too dangerous, he said, not worth risking an officer's life.

Sheets of drywall and planks of lumber were stacked in a corner of the second-floor lobby, their purpose unexplained. The toilets on the fifth floor were being torn out, to be replaced with two new toilets and two shower stalls; the showers were new, but now there were two fewer toilets. The management was slowly working its way down through the hotel, Stevie said, and they were going to add the caging and redo the bathrooms on all the floors. Meanwhile, for the permanent residents, there was routine - eat, sleep, try to hold down a minimum wage job maybe, wait for a welfare check to arrive at the front desk, somehow get the money to cop drugs, watch game shows and ball games in the lobby.

He had a crumpled, tattered copy of a circular entitled 'Tenants' Rights', distributed by a free legal-services office in the neighbourhood. 'The hotel is not allowed to do anything to keep you from becoming a permanent tenant with full rights,' the advice said. 'The so-called 21-day agreements are not legal or enforceable.' Raul said he was exhausted; he was sweating and he was high from the reefer he had just smoked to take the edge off the methadone. He said shoplifting was hard work - risky, tense. Raul was warm and quick to please, and he had the remnants of an easy charm. He said he had a strong leaning toward spirituality and philosophy. In college, he had written a long paper on the notion of cause and effect, and he said he thought about the question a lot. The narrator of Robert Pirsig's Zen and the Art of Motorcycle Maintenance had nearly lost his mind trying to fathom the great questions, he said, and he reminded Raul of himself. 'For everything that occurs,' he said, 'there's an antecedent cause. And I'm saying, "How can I improve my life by creating better causes day to day?" He had been a crack addict in his twenties, nearly committing suicide in the trough of one of his deep depressions, and he had turned to heroin in his thirties; he used methadone now, with the occasional joint when he could get a couple of dollars together. He said he had $10,000 worth of tools in the garage at his parents' house, along with a stash of methadone pills he was hoarding for the day he would wean himself off the drug by lessening his dose little by little.

He said he had $10,000 worth of tools in the garage at his parents' house, along with a stash of methadone pills he was hoarding for the day he would wean himself off the drug by lessening his dose little by little. Read the second part of Down and out in New York here

fields.headline: Go see...
fields.standfirst: ... Made in London
fields.trailText: ... Made in London
fields.body:
Most visitors to London collect snapshots of Big Ben and the Houses of Parliament. Effie Paleologou prefers anonymous streets and deserted stations (see picture, right). But then Paleologou is no ordinary visitor. She graduated from the Royal College of Art in 1997 after arriving in Britain from Greece just six years earlier, and her large-scale photographic images of the city by night have the suffused feel of an Edward Hopper painting.

A late-starter in the art world, Paleologou draws her influences primarily from literature. She cites Kafka and Baudelaire as points of reference in the two images of London by night that she is showing as part of the Made in London group exhibition at Zelda Cheatle Gallery. 'My work is very much based on the idea of the flneur [someone who wanders aimlessly],' she says. 'When I was making it, I didn't have a pre-planned idea of where to go: I'd start with a reference point and then lose myself. Sometimes I would find someone interesting and follow them. As a woman, it was quite scary walking the streets at night, but I tried to remain invisible and trust my instincts.'

Sue Parkhill's self-portraits have a similar sense of the unknown at their core, each depicting a different route that her life could have taken. It's all about supposition - what might have happened if... Collectively, the series of photographs offers an engaging visual record of the sort of fleeting mental images to which we can all relate.

Fresh out of the RCA, Paul Hodgson calls himself a 'reluctant creator', but his Neoclassical-style portraits are sumptuous and bold - not least because he willingly takes the risk of reinforcing the gender stereotypes of the 'old masters'. Braver still is Mark Power, whose subject is the universally derided Millennium Dome. Instead of the usual sputnik shots, Power has taken his camera literally into the bowels of the building, where the urinals in the gents' loos poke out of the blue-tiled walls like the barrels of a gun. Duchamp would have been proud.

 Made in London is at Zelda Cheatle Gallery, 99 Mount Street, London W1 (020 7408 4448) from 1 August to 15 September. Effie Paleologou's next solo show is at Hastings Museum, East Sussex (01424 781 155) from 2 September to 5 November

webTitle: Barbara Ellen: Smells like team spirit

fields.headline: Smells like team spirit
fields.trailText: You'll have to go to the cinema if you want to see the latest mutation of the male rebel fantasy. The movie in question isn't a remake of The Wild Bunch, Easy Rider, or even West Side Story. The movie is High Fidelity.
fields.body:
You'll have to go to the cinema if you want to see the latest mutation of the male rebel fantasy. The movie in question isn't a remake of The Wild Bunch, Easy Rider, or even West Side Story. The props aren't motorbikes, guns or knives. The movie is High Fidelity, directed by Stephen Frears, adapted from the Nick Hornby novel, and starring John Cusack as an emotionally stagnant music-obsessed sweetie. A case of rare vinyl at dawn, and a few pick 'n' mix muso nerds. Still, the stench of male rebellion is in the air as Cusack sits among his records and tussles with age- old quandaries: to commit or not to commit? To alphabeticise, or not to alphabeticise? Those are the questions. And while it's not exactly Peter Fonda screeching off in a blur of tyres and testosterone, something tells me that it's the best your modern rebel can do.

What is modern man rebelling against? What have we got? As women, the answer is very little. It seems to me that modern women let men do pretty much what they want - go to the football, drink themselves blind, play records until their ears bleed, forget to marry them. Yet women are still lumbered with the reputation as the gender that fun forgot. Ask any man, and their story is that we don't really like it when they go to the football, we're secretly unamused when they play their records, we covertly roll our eyes when they get drunk. This tolerance thing is all a big act, and once we get our claws into them properly, that's it - the end of the world as they know it.

Hornby's more popular novels are a case in point, working on the rather spurious premise that male maturity is all about giving up your passions (football, music) and settling down with a wonderful woman, who would then obviously do everything in her power to stop you enjoying yourself.

In all fairness, High Fidelity is great fun, and Hornby's male protagonists are always clearly defined as self-centred architects of their own misery. Still, is it any coincidence that, in wider culture, female characters routinely signify the end of pleasure rather than the beginning? Whether it be in movies, novels, soaps or sitcoms, it seems that women are cast as the killjoy sex, on a mission to part men from their small pleasures. Men, in turn, are seen to be heroically stubborn about hanging on to them.

The message rings out loud and clear: however much a man might love a woman, he owes it to his fellow urban outlaws not to let her stamp out the small fire that is him and his Gram Parsons boxed set and Arsenal football rattle. She's just going to have to accept his gigantic record collection. She's just going to have to put up with him attending away games. She's just going to have to wait until the right Bob Dylan lyric (live bootleg version, side two, track four), makes him feel he's ready to make a commitment.

Unsurprisingly, women are sick of this sulking and posturing, not to mention all the cheap denim. The truth is, we don't mind men who are into 'stuff'. If anything, we prefer them - figuring that men who have amusements and passions have a better than average chance of being amusing and passionate. Women don't even seem to want to pester men into marriage any more. The most recent NOP survey about 'Bachelor Girls' says that women are putting off commitment in favour of the single life, with twice as many women as men claiming that they don't want to get married at all. So, there we go - a whole generation of men let off the hook, with no one to yell at them, sneer at them, never mind want to marry them. Maybe that's the problem.

It seems to me that men enjoy their maverick outlaw fantasies and nothing - not your complete acceptance, your support, even your outright enjoyment of their quirks and foibles - is going to stop them living them out. It's a case of: 'I like football/records/getting drunk, and you're not going to stop me.' The point is, modern woman is no longer interested in trying to stop modern man from doing anything. She's too busy making sure he doesn't try to stop her.

So it is that in High Fidelity , Cusack's obsessive record collecting and list making is seen as a metaphor for his immaturity and perversity, but only by the man himself. Like so many of his generation, his embarrassment and sense of rebellion are all in the mind. Women are either oblivious to all these tormented wranglings, or they find them quite charming. They certainly aren't going to waste their energy trying to get some commitment-shy bozo to marry them. That's so last century, darling. And yet, crazed by arrogance, men still keep on running, and keep on writing novels and screenplays about how they keep on running. Look behind you, guys - there's nobody there.

webTitle: The loafer's guide: The big chill

fields.headline: The loafer's guide
fields.standfirst: The big chill
fields.trailText: The big chill
fields.body:
Oh no, not another summer festival...
Listen, this isn't just any old festival - The Big Chill prides itself on being a civilised if not sedate affair. Targeted at those who have grown tired of larger festivals such as Glastonbury or Reading, it appeals to a slightly older, balder raver who isn't really comfortable sitting in a mud-drenched field with a load of bug-eyed undergraduates. As the website says: 'Don't come expecting a full-on dance party, this is a daytime-based, mellow event.'

Tell me more...
Well, The Big Chill started life as a club night in Islington, north London, where its use of the latest visual and audio technology quickly caught the attention of the music press. Its annual outdoor festival, subtitled The Enchanted Garden, is now considered one of the most important music events of the year, famed for introducing new talent. Past performers include Mercury prize-winning Talvin Singh, and this year there are confirmed sets from Nitin Sawhney, Norman Jay and A Man Called Adam. The setting is the picturesque Larmer Tree Victorian Pleasure Gardens, near Salisbury in Wiltshire, complete with Roman temples, ponds and peacocks. 'The idea of trying to relax in a grotty arena surrounded by high fences and billboards is not our way,' says founder Peter Lawrence. It's not all music: you can join in debates on current issues, hear literary readings or unwind with raiki and shiatsu massages. Added extras for any comfort-seekers are a champagne and spirits bar and, shockingly, there are WARM SHOWERS ON SITE!

So how do you get tickets?
The bad news is that the event is sold out. With only 7,000 tickets on sale, it's significantly smaller than the other summer festivals and it's this intimacy that the promoters want to maintain. The good news is there are Big Chill events held throughout the year - there's even a Big Chill holiday planned to the Greek island of Naxos in October. For more information, go to The Big Chill website

fields.headline: Pulling no punches
fields.trailText: Under what circumstances would you hit a child? Obviously, I'm not talking about your own children. But other people's children, that's trickier.
fields.body:
Under what circumstances would you hit a child? Obviously, I'm not talking about your own children. You don't have to read a single page of a childcare manual to latch on to the notion that cuffing your own kith 'n' kin is very much yesterday's parenting. But other people's children, that's trickier.

There you are, faffing around with Fred, Daisy and Mo in the communal garden trying to inculcate in them an interest in football - kick ball towards child, child watches it go past and come to rest, child says, 'Why did you do that, Dad? - when the psycho kid on the block comes tearing on to the scene. Looking like a member of the French Foreign Legion on holiday - cropped hair, tight shorts, great fixity of purpose - there is no children's toy too fluffy, no piece of flora and fauna too benign, that he cannot, using some native ingenuity, transform into a weapon sufficiently lethal to put your kids in casualty.

To be fair to Foreign Legion, thanks to a mix of bad aim and luck, he has never succeeded. But there were times when it was a close call and times when Fred and Daisy lay stricken that I found myself on the verge of giving him a good kicking. Luckily, a minimal level of basic decency intervened just before the boot went in. It is neither big nor clever to beat up on a three-year-old. Although...

Happily, now all is milk and honey in the communal garden. The turning point occuring when Foreign Legion was enrolled at the local Catholic school. This institution is the Manchester United of primary schools: forever finishing top of the league table and attracting plenty of adherents whom it is a stretch to call local. Given the fact that we had attended the church religiously, in at least one sense of the word, given the fact that the mother of our children is called Grainne Maria Bernadette O'Driscoll and given the fact that we had given the Canon the winner of the 1999 Derby, coincidentally called Oath, we were pretty confident that Daisy and Fred would gain admittance to the school that had tamed the Legion.

Wrong again. A combination of the catchment area being moved 10 yards to the west, a small move but sufficient to push our flat outside of it, and the arrival of a bevy of French Catholics wearing real fur and happy to put their platinum credit cards on the collection plate scuppered their chances. If Grainne had been called Lourdes... but, hell, who said Catholicism was easy.

Anyway, I was reminded of all this when a few friends independently warned me of a nipper operating out of the Islington area who makes Legion look like a lamb. This Kid is dynamite. On the one occasion I saw him in action, a birthday party, he surprised the guests by screaming, 'I hate you' repeatedly during that one quiet moment which occurs just before the host blows out the three candles on her cake. Twenty minutes later he went one better, creating something of a side show during a game of musical statues by tripping a co-competitor and as he lay on the ground, kicking him twice, very hard, in the head. Nasty.

The father of the host, and a more peaceable man you could not hope to meet, looked ready to chin his first three-year-old while the mother, some might say feebly, tried to cajole the assailant into saying 'sorry' to his victim, who was lying in his mother's arms while his father inspected him for signs of cranial damage. The rest of us, with great rapidity, made our excuses and left.

Since then, The Kid has been busy assembling a reputation for random acts of extreme violence which make his party turn look the work of an amateur. Which is tough on all those people who are too polite not to exclude The Kid from their social whirl. Tough, too, on The Kid's parents.

Every way you cut it, their cake looks bleak. Is The Kid the way he is because of genetics, which doesn't do a whole bundle for your self-esteem; or conditioning, which in these days of full-on parenting is possibly worse? Grim as it may be for the parents whose progeny come into contact, usually violent, with The Kid, it is grimmer still for the parents of The Kid. They can't hit their own child; they can't be seen to be bribing someone else's child to hit their child; they are desperately and secretly hoping that another parent loses his cool and hits The Kid for them. And then they can get all huffy about it.

webTitle: Wenger knows he needs to spend his money wisely

fields.headline: Wenger knows he needs to spend his money wisely
fields.trailText: Where does Arsène Wenger go from here? How does he find adequate replacements for Marc Overmars and Emmanuel Petit?
fields.body:
In the end it was less prolonged, less acrimonious, less excruciating than when the Spanish acquisition dominated the close season at Highbury a year ago. Still, for the Arsenal hierarchy there are so many echoes of Real Madrid's raid for Nicolas Anelka last summer: again the timing is unfortunate, the loss of quality acute, the defeat by player power frustrating, the money enormous. Now they face the task of replacing Marc Overmars and Emmanuel Petit as ingeniously as filling Anelka's boots with Thierry Henry. Quickly.

If they do, they will be all smiles, with an estimated £30 million-plus for two players whose commitment has visibly waned over the past year or so. If not, Arsenal's aspirations are in danger of being eroded before a ball has been kicked in earnest.

It's almost as if Arsenal encouraged Barcelona to bring their Figo-enriched chequebook along to Highbury. It isn't simply a case of cashing in on the inflated Spanish market, even though the astute Arsène Wenger has made his club well over £40 million profit in 12 months on the comings and goings of Anelka, Overmars and Petit. It hadn't gone unnoticed that certain senior players were struggling for motivation and consequently dampening morale in the dressing room. Sometimes the time is right to sell a player, however talented.

Overmars, so restless he was hawking himself around Spain and Italy at the tailend of last season, had run out of inspiration in the red-and-white shirt. As for Petit, who spent much of last season moaning, going through the motions, or both, there is the feeling that the Londoners have seen his best days as he approaches his 30th birthday.

It would be churlish to abuse Barcelona's new signings for being tempted away. The Catalans can offer much heftier salaries than most in the Premiership, as well as being one of the world's most prestigious clubs. Why should men like Overmars and Petit, foreigners who won virtually all there is worth winning in England in their first season, feel loyalty is more of a motivating factor than an irresistible new challenge and a massive rise?

Where does Wenger go from here? How does he find adequate replacements? So far French international Pires will slot in on the left wing and the club have extremely high hopes of new Cameroonian signing Lauren. In addition they are confident of ironing over Edu's immigration problems and expect the Brazilian, recently sent back from Heathrow, to have a smoother welcome to north London as soon as can be arranged.

More should follow. Regardless of the midfield holes there is a more pressing situation vacant in attack. It's not too unrealistic to imagine Tony Adams as an emergency striker.

At least Arsenal have bundles to spend. Having said that, they don't intend to be held to ransom just because any potential seller knows they are suddenly flush.

That didn't stop them hiking up the fee for Overmars and Petit as a direct knock-on effect from the Figo millions sloshing around in Barcelona's bank account, but one of Wenger's key transfer principles is that he loathes to exceed what he believes to be value for money.

He is unlikely to try to resurrect a deal for summer tar get Sylvain Wiltord, while his club continue to hold out for their asking price - £15 million for the Bordeaux rebel is simply not common sense.

The one thing Arsenal realise, probably more intensely than most, is that whoever they bring in more than likely won't stay long. Remember, both Overmars and Petit had several years left on their contracts. Remember, Wenger didn't put either of them on the transfer list. Both players made it clear they wanted out, and again the ever-increasing might of players and their insatiable agents won the day.

The Catalans can offer much heftier salaries than most in the Premiership, as well as being one of the world's most prestigious clubs. Why should men like Overmars and Petit, foreigners who won virtually all there is worth winning in England in their first season, feel loyalty is more of a motivating factor than an irresistible new challenge and a massive rise? Where does Wenger go from here? How does he find adequate replacements? So far French international Pires will slot in on the left wing and the club have extremely high hopes of new Cameroonian signing Lauren. In addition they are confident of ironing over Edu's immigration problems and expect the Brazilian, recently sent back from Heathrow, to have a smoother welcome to north London as soon as can be arranged. More should follow. Regardless of the midfield holes there is a more pressing situation vacant in attack. It's not too unrealistic to imagine Tony Adams as an emergency striker. At least Arsenal have bundles to spend. Having said that, they don't intend to be held to ransom just because any potential seller knows they are suddenly flush. That didn't stop them hiking up the fee for Overmars and Petit as a direct knock-on effect from the Figo millions sloshing around in Barcelona's bank account, but one of Wenger's key transfer principles is that he loathes to exceed what he believes to be value for money. He is unlikely to try to resurrect a deal for summer tar get Sylvain Wiltord, while his club continue to hold out for their asking price - £15 million for the Bordeaux rebel is simply not common sense. The one thing Arsenal realise, probably more intensely than most, is that whoever they bring in more than likely won't stay long. Remember, both Overmars and Petit had several years left on their contracts. Remember, Wenger didn't put either of them on the transfer list. Both players made it clear they wanted out, and again the ever-increasing might of players and their insatiable agents won the day.
